PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping

PARA.TAB: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
This Petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:

There is an urgent demand from the majority of Australians for immediate Federal Government intervention, to comply with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory, and protect the remaining high conservation value forest areas which support flora and fauna unique to Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to:
immediately implement the moratorium clause in the 1992 National Forest Policy Statement, and cease all logging activities in high conservation value forests;

permanently protect in reserves, all old growth, wilderness, and other high conservation value forest areas, under the custodianship of Australian indigenous peoples, in cooperation with local communities, conservation and scientific organisations;
reap only what is sown by utilising readily available plantation timbers for industry needs;
rapidly implement timber industry transition from native forests to plantations, with provision for retraining, redeployment, and compensation if necessary for affected workers and contractors;
restructure the paper and fibre board industries to use annual fibre crops such as kenaf, hemp, cane etc.

create employment incentives to collect seeds, propagate, establish and manage sustainable permaculture-style mixed species timber plantations, on existing cleared and degraded lands, and encourage investment in the growing and marketing of indigenous forest products, such as native fruits, nuts, berries, seeds, oils, and other nutritional and medicinal resources.
develop educational environmental tourism as a sensitively managed industry, in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for Aboriginal cultural heritage and sacred sites; and
further support the above initiatives by the progressive utilisation of defence personnel, resources and funding, to assist rural communities to implement sustainable plantation forestry practices.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bell (from 80 citizens) and Senator Bourne (from 253 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we citizens of Australia support the Government's efforts to assist nations with the clearing of land mines and also support a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel mines.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate support our call for a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel land mines, give priority to expanding Australia's support for mine clearance in affected countries and use its influence to encourage other countries to give greater support to mine clearance efforts.

PETITION.PARA: Senator Harradine and Senator Margetts (from 4,342 citizens) and

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Coastline
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned, wish to lodge our protest, in the strongest possible terms, at the Federal Government's inaction to take legislative measures to protect our coast.

We the surfriders and TRACKS readers of Australia have watched our coastal treasures, the ecology, biodiversity and beauty of the Australian coast marred by urban development, poor planning and pollution, especially over the last 25 years.
The ALP has been in government for half that time and we've lost double our resources.
We (not so humbly) demand that you urge the Federal Government to act now to establish a national coastal agency with national powers to stop the destruction of our Australian coastline.
We also demand that the Federal Government recognise and include surfriders in the major decision making forums and call on you to contribute resources toward those who protect our surfing coast.
Finally, we demand that the environment be recognised in the Australian Constitution.
We are tired of waiting! You must act now. Please write to me and inform me of what you are going to do to save our surf.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

. . . their desire to respectively call upon the Federal Government to introduce legislation that will require the National Registration Authority to provide all available information on registered chemicals.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate Indonesia's continued denial of human rights to the people of East Timor.
Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. actively support the right to self-determination of the people of East Timor;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. repeal the Timor Gap Treaty; and
5. stop all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.

PETITION.TITLE: Freedom of Choice
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the Citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That we:
(1) Affirm the importance of quality education for all the children of this Commonwealth of Australia irrespective of their religion, nationality or sex;
(2) Support the rights of parents to have freedom of choice of the school for their child;
(3) Support the right of all non-government schools to maintain their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos;
(4) Support the freedom of choice in staffing of all Churches and religious organisations.
(5) Support freedom of religion and the right of all Churches and religious organisations to maintain their distinctive foundational ethos.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate oppose any attempts to introduce legislation that would jeopardise these freedoms and rights and which would force Schools, Churches and religious institutions to compromise their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray:

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Australian Senate Assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of certain residents of Perth in the State of Western Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the grave environmental and health consequences arising from the recent decision by the Government of France to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate note that those petitioners whose signatures appear below:
(a) are appalled at the political arrogance of the recent decision by the Government of France to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific;
(b) commit themselves to a voluntary boycott of the consumption of all goods made in France until such time as the French Government reverses its decision;
(c) call on the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to initiate the diplomatic action necessary to bring about a reversal of the French decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Afghanistan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and members of the Senate assembled, the petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Parliament that many members Afghan born Australians continue to suffer due to trials of separation from family members who have sought refuge in Pakistan, Iran, India and Russia.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners draw to your attention the state of unrest and political instability current in Afghanistan and the resultant trauma being suffered by people within Afghanistan, displaced Afghan people living outside the country and Australians of Afghan background.
Your petitioners respectfully draw your attention to the impossibility of displaced Afghans being repatriated in the near future and call on the Australian Government to:
work with the United Nations to achieve peace in Afghanistan;
provide support to Afghans wishing to migrate to Australia by making access to a Special Assistance Category; and Women at Risk;
work with NGO's to achieve reconstruction in Afghanistan.

Motion (by Senator Spindler) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to prohibit discrimination on the ground of sexuality or transgender identity.
Motion (by Senator Spindler) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to ensure that people receive equal treatment in areas governed by Commonwealth law and are protected against discrimination on the grounds of their sexuality or their transgender identity.
For the purpose of the bill sexuality is defined as heterosexuality, homosexuality and bisexuality.
In addition, the bill seeks to provide long overdue protection against discrimination for people going through a gender reassignment process or identifying as transsexuals.
My motivation for this bill is the firm, indeed passionate, belief that a civilised, cohesive and humane society must live by the basic tenet of justice for all.

To deny equal treatment to a human being because she or he is of a different gender, race, colour or nationality is fast becoming unacceptable in our community, and a measure of our progress in building the core values by which we want to live.
The same principle applies to sexuality.

On his recent visit to Australia, Reverend Jim Wallis said at a meeting of the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship that we should treat the issue of discrimination against gay and lesbian people as an issue of civil liberties rather than as a matter for theological debate.
In this context it is worth noting the 1986 statement "The Pastoral Care of Homosexual Persons" by the Catholic Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith:

"It is deplorable that homosexual persons have been and are the object of violent malice in speech or in action. Such treatment deserves condemnation from the church's pastors wherever it occurs. It reveals a kind of disregard for others which endangers the most fundamental principles of a healthy society. The intrinsic dignity of each person must always be respected in word, in action and in law."

The bill seeks to remove discrimination in areas of Commonwealth law including employment, education, superannuation, industrial relations, the provision of goods and services, sporting activities, clubs and associations. It also contains protection against vilification and the incitement of hatred on the basis of a person's sexuality or transgender identity.

It is recognised that any effort to bring about positive social change must take account of the need to respect deeply held religious beliefs, of the need for a person's own `private space' and, if they want to change their attitudes, the possibility to do so at their own pace in these areas.
Accordingly, the bill provides exemptions for churches, religious teaching institutions and church schools for teachers and persons seeking, and studying for, ordination.

The exemption applies if the institution is acting in good faith to avoid injury to the religious susceptibilities of adherents of that religion and if it is acting in accordance with the tenets, beliefs or teachings of the particular religion or creed.

The process of producing what turned out to be an extremely complex piece of legislation was lengthy. The decision to take on the project was announced during the debate on the Sexual Conduct Bill late in 1994. It was triggered by the narrow ambit of that legislation, limited as it was to the right to privacy under the ICCPR and the missed opportunity it represents in its failure to deal with discrimination in a comprehensive way.
In Australia anti-discrimination provisions of varying quality have been enacted in NSW, Queensland, South Australia, the ACT, the Northern Territory and particularly inadequately, in Victoria.

The concerns federal Attorney General, Mr Lavarch, is reported to have about the constitutional validity of comprehensive anti-discrimination legislation on the grounds of sexuality do not appear to be well founded.

The external affairs power in s.51 XXIX of the Constitution brings into play the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), the International Covenant on Economic Social and Cultural Rights and ILO Convention III. The ICCPR prohibits discrimination on the grounds of race, colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status.

In its `view' on the Toonen case, the UN Human Rights Committee said that "the reference to `sex' in articles 2 and 26 is to be taken as including sexual orientation". The High Court is likely to accept that interpretation, particularly since it is open to the Court to base it also on "other status".
The need to construct the bill's constitutional underpinning in this way points to the urgent need for a comprehensive constitutional Bill of Rights, but that is a topic for another day.

It is to be hoped that the ALP Government will find the courage to support this long overdue bill to deal with Commonwealth areas of responsibility and that the Coalition Parties can overcome that small but strident homophobic opposition in their midst, as they largely did in the vote for the Sexual Conduct Bill.

I believe that the apparent concern of both the Opposition and the Government that they would risk losing votes if they moved to achieve legal equality for people with a sexuality outside the mainstream is misplaced.

The social philosopher, John Rawls, suggested that the level of civilisation reached by a community can be judged best by how it treats minorities. On that basis I am confident that Australians are essentially fair-minded people and that they will agree that it is only fair and just that people of a `different' sexuality are protected against discrimination in employment, in education, in the provision of goods and services, etc.

To forestall some of the hysterical misrepresentations that will undoubtedly flood the airwaves, let me emphasise that the bill does not promote homosexuality, does not give any support to paedophiles, does not attack the institution of marriage, but simply equalises the legal position of same sex couples with defacto heterosexual couples.

It is not proposed to give homosexual, bisexual and transgender people any rights or advantages that no one else has. Rather it is proposed to ensure as far as possible to put a stop to the particular disadvantages suffered by homosexual, bisexual and transgender people. In many cases it is not an exaggeration to call it persecution—persecution of a minority which should not be tolerated in a democratic, liberal and pluralist society, a society which prides itself on the safeguards it claims to provide for individual rights and liberties, the sort of society that Eva Cox in this year's Boyer lectures calls the `civil society'.

The reality is different. In a survey undertaken in 1994 by the Melbourne group, Gay Men and Lesbians Against Discrimination (GLAD), 1000 gay and lesbian people were interviewed. In the Report `Not a Day Goes By', 45 per cent of lesbians and gay men reported some form of harassment or discrimination in employment, including loss of jobs. 41 per cent of lesbians and 25 per cent of gay men reported inadequate services or refusal of service, 22 per cent of lesbians and 33 per cent of gay men had experienced inappropriate responses from police including harassment and actual violence in some cases. 70 per cent of lesbians and 69 per cent of gay men reported being verbally abused, threatened or bashed in a public place.

Not a pretty picture and one that other reports and anecdotal evidence indicates is replicated throughout the country. It is not a situation we should continue to tolerate while we avert our eyes and shrug our shoulders.

The principle of essential equality before the law has led me to include heterosexual people in the definition of sexuality and as a result they too will be beneficiaries of the protection against discrimination the bill offers. A `special measures' provision will enable members of any particular sexuality to obtain exclusive access to services and facilities where this is needed to achieve equal opportunities.

The same sex couple provision will provide the legal basis for specific amendments to other Commonwealth legislation on Immigration, Superannuation, Social Security, Evidence, Health Insurance, Family Law, etc. to the extent that the amendments in this bill do not adequately remove the effect of discriminatory provisions contained in other Commonwealth Acts.

The prohibition of discrimination in the payment of superannuation benefits (cl.10) and the same sex couples provision will enable surviving partners to collect superannuation payouts in situations similar to the 1995 Greg Brown case where payment was refused because the partners were of the same sex.. In the establishment of superannuation and life insurance policies companies will be able to discriminate only on the basis of relevant actuarial data.

The blanket provision to equalise the legal position of heterosexual defacto and same sex couples will result in some criticism from the gay community, partly on the basis that the `defacto' legal construct does not reflect adequately the nature and quality of same sex couple relationships, notably because the notion of dependency is not as prevalent as in heterosexual relationships. However, this distinction is not as validly drawn as it once may have been in view of the growing sense of equality and desire to share between partners of opposite gender.

It must also be recognised that the provision does not attempt to define all same sex relationships but merely provides a legal basis for those same sex couples who are in a `genuine domestic relationship' and want to be treated as such.
The second point made often during the consultations was the obvious one of the reduction in Social Security and Unemployment payments as a result of a `couple' classification.

At one level the natural response is "you have to take the bad with the good". At another it should lead us to reexamine a policy which penalises Australian couples and families for coming together in one household. Although brought to light by the `same sex couples' debate, the issue is one of general interest and of considerable importance for the community as a whole.
In a country where politicians of all hues expound the value of the family as an essential building block of a stable society, we should stop penalising people when they form such family units.

It would clearly make much more sense to pay benefits to everyone at the individual rate and thus to provide an incentive for family formation. In other words, the adage "Two can live as cheaply as one" should be used to build a more cohesive society rather than serve as a means to reduce the level of Social Security payments.

The high cost (approximately $7bn) of such a change is due in part to the fact that unemployment benefits would be payable to non-working spouses of above average income earners. However, this merely accelerates the development of the policy to provide support for home carers. By removing the financial disadvantage of family formation, it is likely that more people would form caring and sharing partnerships, including those not dependent on a sexual relationship, thus providing a more supportive community and corresponding savings in remedial social services.

Recognition is long overdue that lesbians, gay men, bisexual and transgender people are sons, daughters, sisters, brothers, uncles, aunties and sometimes parents. They are members of families and deserve to be treated as such and not as outcasts.

To return to the process: following the decision late in 1994 to proceed with the bill, I visited every State capital as well as Darwin and Alice Springs for consultations with representatives of relevant groups and organisations. An Issues Paper arising out of these meetings was released in February 1995 at Melbourne's Midsumma Festival, and circulated throughout Australia, eliciting numerous responses and comments.

The first draft of the bill was completed on 6th of June to be followed by further, revised editions on 24 October, 13 November, 22 November, 24 November. I record with great appreciation the patience, understanding and high professional competence Mr Peter O'Keefe, Assistant Clerk of the Senate and Mr Geoff Harders, Consultant Parliamentary Counsel, brought to this enterprise, together with the comment and advice contributed by several people at the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission.

One of the more distasteful episodes was a series of attacks mounted by a small section of the gay press who appeared determined to put the party political objective of denigrating the Democrats above the interests of the gay community.
At the other end of the spectrum the publication of the Issues Paper sparked off a sleazy campaign and vicious dirt. Some of these have been submitted for legal advice.

Mr John McNicol, reportedly with former associations to the far right Logos Foundation and now of the so-called `Christian' Alliance, was a little more careful: he merely threatened to mount a well financed political pressure campaign similar to those used by his American sister organisation to silence or unseat politicians daring to support gay law reform. Not surprisingly I am occupying a place of honour in his list of targets, but the Attorney General, Mr Lavarch, and Mr Downer get a mention, too, mainly because of their role in getting the 1994 Sexual Conduct Bill through Parliament.

I deny Mr McNicol's claim to the term `Christian'—his views and methods bear no resemblance to the teachings of Christ, who preached tolerance, sought justice and championed the cause of the disadvantaged.
I record with some relief and gratitude the expressions of encouragement and support I have received from many leaders, office bearers and members of Australia's mainstream churches.
I commend the Sexuality Discrimination Bill to the Senate and to the Australian community as a bill which goes to the very question of who we are and what kind of a society we want to be.

A bill for an act to amend the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990, and for related purposes.
A bill for an act to amend the law relating to trade practices to promote better business conduct, and for related purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table revised explanatory memoranda relating to the bills and move:

The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 3) 1995

The purpose of this bill is to introduce amendments to the Wool International Act 1993; the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993; the Farm Household Support Act 1992; the Agriculture and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act 1992; the Agricultural and Chemicals Code Act 1994; and the Fisheries Management Act 1991.
The bill further repeals the following inoperative acts:
Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Act 1981
Beef Industry (Incentive Payments) Act 1977
Coal Production (War-Time) Act Repeal Act 1948
Dairy Industry Stabilisation Act 1977
Dairy Industry Stabilisation Levy Act 1977
Drought Assistance (Primary Producers) Act 1982
Fishing Industry Act 1956
Fishing Industry Research Act 1969
Fishing Industry Research and Development Act 1987
International Sugar Agreement Act 1978
Rural Industries Research Act 1985
Wheat Tax Act 1957
Wheat Tax Act 1979
Wheat Tax (Permit) Act 1984
Wheat Tax (Permit) Collection Act 1984

The proposed amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act 1992 will ensure that the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (NRA) is required to comply with the policy directions of the Agricultural and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand. This is in accordance with the principle of the Commonwealth, state, and territory governments being equal partners in setting the policy direction of the national registration scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals.

A number of the other proposed amendments are collectively concerned with the Department of Primary Industries and Energy's management of chemicals subject to import and export restrictions under international obligations such as the prior informed consent procedures. The obtaining of information about chemical products from the NRA is a factor in that management. The proposed amendments will not place any additional reporting burden on the chemical industry as the necessary information is already required to be provided to the NRA.

Provision is also proposed for the NRA to be able to impose a fee for the issuing of certificates of export. Those certificates relate to requests from the chemical industry or importing countries to establish the bona fides of a particular chemical product following evaluation of the product by the NRA. Appeal provisions to the administrative appeals tribunal will be available to aggrieved applicants in the event of the NRA's refusal to issue a certificate.

The proposed amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Act 1994 clarify the application of the compensation provisions under part 3 of the code. Those provisions apply when certain information is provided on request to the NRA as part of the review of existing agricultural and veterinary chemicals. The related transitional provisions have also been clarified.

It is also proposed to introduce provisions to streamline the issuing of national notices under the AGVET codes. This will enable the NRA to issue one national notice rather than separate notices for each jurisdiction, and represents improved efficiency for the NRA.

The amendment to the Fisheries Management Act 1991 will provide that where there is an acquisition of property within the meaning of paragraph 31 of section 51 of the Constitution, reasonable compensation or compensation as determined by the federal court, is payable.

The government announced in the second reading speech to the Wool International Act 1993 that the establishment of Wool International was part of the strategy to develop a much stronger and commercially driven Australian wool industry, in more direct control over its destiny.

The government continues to believe that the industry's long term future lies in it continuing to move towards a market driven approach, closely attuned to the needs of customers and end users, and free from unnecessary government involvement.
This package of amendments to the Wool International Act 1993 is part of this evolutionary process, and includes:

PARA.TAB: termination of voluntary, or additional, contributions of wool tax over and above 4.5 per cent Of the sale value of shorn wool other than carpet wool;
setting the amount payable to wool international in respect of the stockpile debt component of wool tax by regulation; and
enabling wool international to undertake a program to develop and evaluate the forward marketing of wool through its subsidiary, wool international holdings.

SPEECH.PARA: The payment by growers of the compulsory 4.5 per cent debt component of wool tax from 1 July 1993 onwards entitles them to a share in any surplus from the sale of the stockpile by wool international, to be made available once the associated government guaranteed debt has been retired, as well as to equity in any privatised Wool International.

The Wool International Act 1993 currently allows these eligible wool tax payers to gain additional entitlements by making voluntary contributions up to 5.5 per cent of the sale value of shorn wool, other than carpet wool, in addition to the 4.5 per cent stockpile debt component of wool tax.

The circumstances in the wool industry have changed markedly since the present statutory framework was put in place in 1993, and there is now anticipated to be in a significant surplus arising from stockpile sales after the government guaranteed debt has been retired. This has led the board of wool international to recommend that the surplus from the stockpile sales be made available to growers once the government guaranteed debt has been retired, and that any privatisation, if that is the wish of eligible wool tax payers, be funded from the non wool assets of wool international. The government has agreed with this recommendation.

In these circumstances, it is considered there is no justification for eligible wool tax payers retaining the right to make voluntary contributions. In particular, the retention of this right could provide the possibility for a small number of large, well-off, producers to enhance their entitlements at the expense of other eligible wool tax payers, not in a financial position to make voluntary contributions.

The government, after consultation with the industry, therefore announced in a media release dated 20 June 1995 that it proposed the legislation be amended to provide for the cessation of voluntary wool tax contributions from that date.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Setting the debt component of wool tax by regulation

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, the amount payable to wool international in respect of the tax imposed under the wool tax acts on shorn wool, other than carpet wool, is prescribed in the Wool International Act 1993 at 4.5 per cent. These payments go to service stockpile debt.

At the May 1995 annual general conference of the Wool Council of Australia, it was announced that the government had agreed to conduct a review of the 4.5 per cent component of wool tax payable to Wool International. This decision was taken in the context of the significant projected surplus of funds in Wool International once the government guaranteed debt has been retired.
The review, to be conducted in early 1996, will examine if there is scope to reduce or even eliminate this component of the tax from 1 July 1996.

The proposed legislative changes will enable speedy implementation of the outcome of the review by setting the amount payable to wool international by regulation. The changes will provide only for the amount to be maintained at the current rate of 4.5 per cent, or lowered.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Future marketing activities of Wool International

SPEECH.PARA: As part of its legislated functions, Wool International has been examining various options for further developing risk management mechanisms for the industry, and it has recommended that its subsidiary, Wool International Holdings, undertake a limited trading program to develop and evaluate forward and futures markets as a risk management tool.

Amendments to the Wool International Act 1993 will therefore be necessary to allow Wool International to hold shares in a subsidiary undertaking such a program including the use of futures and currency contracts for hedging purposes.

Under the proposed amendments, Wool International will require the prior approval of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy before it can commence the trading program using Wool International Holdings.

Strict measures to limit the financial risk of the proposal and details of operational aspects, such as reporting requirements, will be specified in the conditions encompassed in the ministerial approval. It is envisaged that the memorandum and articles of Wool International Holdings will need to change to reflect these conditions.
Other key points regarding the program are:

PARA.TAB: it will be a `stand alone' commercial operation with a two year time frame commencing in 1996
it will be funded from revenue received from the management of non-wool assets, as provided for in the existing legislation
there will be no government guarantee involved
wool international holdings will have access to the stockpile on a commercial basis only
regular reports will be provided to the wool international board, and through it to the minister
rigorous risk management arrangements will be put in place to ensure that the operation of the program is conducted within an agreed capital limit
separate and transparent accounting will be required
subjection to all the requirements of corporations law, and all forms of taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: The use of Wool International Holdings will ensure the trading activities are kept separate from those of Wool International proper, whose main legislative concern will remain the management of the stockpile.
This separation is very important in the context of maintaining market confidence in Wool International's stockpile operations.

The point is therefore emphasised that the program undertaken by Wool International Holdings will in no way impact on the disposal of the stockpile under the fixed release schedule. Wool International Holdings will only have access to the stockpile on the same commercial basis as any other industry participant.

The government believes the proposed program, which has the full support of the Wool Council of Australia, represents a natural progression in Wool International's efforts to stimulate more effective management of risk in the industry, the need for which has been clearly demonstrated by the current price volatility in the wool market. Unlike most other commodity markets, the wool industry, particularly growers, does not make adequate use of risk management options such as forward selling and futures contracts to manage risk.

However, while the forward trading proposal is ultimately directed towards risk management and strengthening the forward and futures markets for wool, it will also provide valuable information in considering the options regarding a privatisation of Wool International.

It will assist eligible wool tax payers to evaluate the commercial viability of a privatised organisation undertaking forward marketing operations and providing risk management services. In that way it will help eligible wool tax payers to make a more informed decision regarding privatisation.

The proposal does not pre-suppose the eventual privatisation of Wool International. Eligible wool tax payers, through the issue of a prospectus, will have the choice, based on their own commercial judgement, as to whether they leave their equity in a privatised Wool International.
If Wool International were ultimately to be privatised, the stockpile would nonetheless continue to be managed by a separate entity, probably a statutory authority.
The amendments to the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993 amend two provisions of the principal act.
A consequential amendment to section 51 of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Act 1993 is needed to take into account the proposed amendments to the Wool International Act 1993.

This section requires wool tax payers, in recommending the percentages of wool tax payable under the wool tax acts to the Australian wool research and promotion organisation in respect of research and development, and promotion, to have regard to the legislated percentage of wool tax payable to Wool International in respect of debt reduction. Under the proposed amendments, this amount will now be set by regulation.

The bill will also repeal the provision at section 79 for wool industry funding of the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council, and substitute this with provision for an industry contribution to the proposed Australian Animal Health Council Limited.

The Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council ceased operations on 30 June 1995, and the proposed Australian Animal Health Council limited will be established as a non-profit company, limited by guarantee, under corporations law.

The Australian Animal Health Council will be jointly owned and funded by the Commonwealth Government, state and territory governments and the peak national representative bodies of Australia's livestock based industries. Its mission will be to ensure the Australian animal health service system is capable of maintaining acceptable national animal health standards which meet consumer needs and market requirements at home and overseas.

The Wool Council of Australia has sought and supports the amendment. This is an interim measure which will cease to apply after the 1996-97 financial year. The Wool Council is considering alternatives for longer term funding and will advise its position in due course.

The Farm Household Support Act 1992 is being amended to ensure that the drought relief payment is payable to eligible farmers only within the period specified on the drought exceptional circumstances certificate. This will ensure that drought relief payments are used by eligible farmers to meet their basic living expenses only during those periods of extreme drought.
The amendments to reinsert drought relief payment to section 43(1) are to correct previous consequential amendments which erroneously omitted drought relief payment from this section.
The amendment to the Imported Food Control Act 1992 allows persons other than officers of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) to be appointed as authorised officers.
The amendment will allow quarantine officers of the various state and territory departments of agriculture to be involved in the inspection of food imported into Australia.
AQIS anticipates a more effective and efficient service to clients as a consequence of the amendment as it minimises, where possible, the duplication of inspection activities.
I commend the bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
SYDNEY 2000 GAMES (INDICIA AND IMAGES) PROTECTION BILL 1995

The purpose of this bill is to assist in preserving the financial integrity of the Sydney 2000 Olympic and Paralympic Games by facilitating the raising of licensing revenue in relation to the games through the regulation of the use for commercial purposes of the indicia and images associated with the games.

As honourable Senators would no doubt be aware, the hosting of the Olympic Games in 2000 is an event of great significance to Australia, providing a unique opportunity to demonstrate to the world this country's skills, talents, environment and achievements. This government was a strong and enthusiastic supporter of the bid for the games and its support and assistance will continue throughout the task of organising the games.

This task is very large and complex. It is also very expensive. As the host nation for the year 2000 Games, Australia will be expending considerable sums of money in the lead up to the year 2000 to arrange the construction of facilities and infrastructure, organisation and marketing required for the Sydney 2000 Olympics.

The cost of staging the Sydney 2000 Olympic and Paralympic Games is estimated to be $2 billion, and will be shared between the organising committees, the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games (SOCOG) and the Sydney Paralympic Organising Committee (SPOC), the government of NSW and the Commonwealth Government. As well as providing $150 million toward the cost of staging the Sydney Games and up to $25 million toward the cost of the Paralympics, the Commonwealth Government will provide $140 million to sports in 1995-96. This includes $46 million to Olympic sport through the "Maintain the Momentum" program and the "Olympic Athlete" program ($135 million over six years) which is designed to ensure the best possible preparation of Australia's athletes for the Atlanta and Sydney Games.

Sources of revenue to meet the costs of the Sydney Games include the sale of television rights, ticket sales and the licensing of the right to use the games indicia and images. After television rights, licensing, or sponsorship, rights are the most important source of revenue to meet the costs of organising and staging the games. It is expected that the revenue raised from official sponsorships would need to be of the order of $700 million to meet the revenue budget of the games.

The ability of SOCOG and SPOC to attract sponsors will depend to a large extent on the degree of exclusivity afforded to the licensed indicia and images. Official sponsors recognise the commercial value of associating themselves with events of the magnitude of the Olympic Games and are willing to pay considerable sums of money to use the words and symbols associated with the Olympics. In this regard, I note that SOCOG has recently announced that Telstra and IBM are to jointly contribute more than $100 million as the first members of Team Millennium, the corporate sponsorship program for the Sydney 2000 Games—the deal was negotiated in anticipation of the strengthening of the legislative protection of intellectual property rights associated with the Sydney Games.

"Ambush marketing", however, has the capacity to erode seriously the official sponsorship revenue if not stopped or minimised. Ambush marketing is the unauthorised association of businesses with the marketing of an event, such as the Sydney Games, without paying for marketing rights. Typically it is the competitors of official sponsors of major sporting events that engage in these activities. Australian and overseas experience of recent Olympic Games has highlighted the threat that uncontrolled ambush marketing activities can pose to the value of exclusive licensing rights on Olympic Games symbols and indicia. Because ambush marketing can be very effective in creating a perception that the "free-rider" is in fact an official sponsor, it can dissuade official sponsors from continuing their association with the Olympics, or substantially reduce the amount sponsors are prepared to pay for the rights.

The preservation of sponsorship revenue is fundamental to achieving a sound financial outcome for the games thereby ensuring the least call on the public purse. The Government of NSW has underwritten and bears full responsibility for any deficit between the games income and expenditure. The protection of official sponsorships against ambush marketing is therefore critical.

The Commonwealth Government has always recognised the importance of protecting the sponsorship revenue. The Prime Minister, on behalf of the commonwealth, endorsed the bid, noting the provisions of the host city contract, and undertook to make every effort to facilitate the implementation of the commitments made. The government has long been supportive of the Australian Olympic Committee in its endeavours to ensure appropriate protection for Olympic symbols such as the five rings and the designs of the Olympic flame and torch—the Olympic Insignia Protection Act 1987 was put in place expressly for that purpose. That act was amended in 1994 to extend the protection available.

This bill provides additional protection to try to ensure a good budget outcome for the Sydney Games. It will protect the use of a wide range of words and expressions against ambush marketing during the lead up to and including the Sydney Games. It will pick up most of the recommendations made in March 1995 by the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee in its report entitled Cashing in on the Sydney Olympics: Protecting the Sydney Olympic Games from Ambush Marketing. The bill will have a limited period of application and will cease to have effect after 31 December 2000.
Mr President, I would now briefly outline significant features of this legislation.

The bill seeks to provide protection to indicia encompassing words and expressions associated with the Olympic and Paralympic Games. Words and phrases such as "Olympic", "Olympiad", "Paralympic", "Paralympiad", "Sydney 2000", "Sydney Games", "Millennium Games" and "Summer Games" will be protected against unlicensed commercial use under this legislation. Particular word combinations will also be protected under this legislation. These include, for example, any combinations of the words "Olympics", "Olympian", "Paralympics" and "Paralympian" with words, numbers or phrases such as "Sydney", "2000', "Two Thousand", "Games", "Medals", "Gold", "Silver", "Bronze", "Green and Gold" and "Sponsor".

In addition to protecting particular words, numbers and expressions, the bill also seeks to provide protection to certain images that in the circumstances of their presentation suggest, or are likely to suggest, a connection with the Sydney 2000 Olympic or Paralympic Games. These images may be either visual or aural representations.

The rights in the above protected indicia and images vest with SOCOG and SPOC. These two bodies have the power to use and to license others to use the indicia and images identified in the legislation for commercial purposes.

To constitute use for commercial purposes, the Sydney Games indicia or images must be applied to a person's goods or services for advertising or promotional purposes, or for enhancing the demand for the goods or services, and in a manner which would suggest that the person is a sponsor of, or has an association with, the Sydney 2000 Olympic or Paralympic Games or both. That is, a person who sells or promotes their goods or services by using any of the protected indicia or images in a way that would be reasonably understood as suggesting that the person is claiming a connection with the games would be using them for commercial purposes.

In order to enable the public to be aware of the identity of those licensed to use the Sydney Games indicia and images, a register will be established and maintained by SOCOG and made accessible to members of the public at its office in Sydney. The register will also be accessible throughout Australia at State Offices of the Australian Industrial Property Organisation. An entry in the register will include details such as the name and principal place of business of the licensed user, the Sydney Games indicia and images that the licensed user may use and the circumstances in which the indicia and images may be used. A person whose name is entered on the register is to be taken to be a licensed user of the Sydney Games indicia or images specified in that entry. A document certified by the Chief Executive Officer of SOCOG is evidence that the particulars set out in the document are entered in the register.

This bill, however, is not about placing an absolute fetter on any use of the protected Sydney Games indicia and images. The government recognises that while the preservation of sponsorship revenue is essential to achieving a good budget outcome for the games, the fundamental rights of the community to freedom of expression must be respected, particularly in relation to words that have passed into common usage. It must therefore be emphasised that restrictions on the usage of the Sydney Games indicia and images will apply only to unlicensed commercial use of the protected indicia and images.
Moreover, it is made clear in the bill that the legislation is not intended to affect the working of many aspects of everyday business.

It is recognised that some individuals and corporations already use the indicia prescribed in the legislation in conjunction with their goods and services. There are for example goods and services which either have the trade marks "Olympic" or include the word "Olympic", such as "Olympic tyres" and "Olympic Airways". This legislation is not about stopping traders who have been using these indicia and images for years from continuing that use. The established rights of owners of registered trade marks or designs containing those indicia and images remain unaffected so long as the trade marks or designs are not used in a way so as to imply a connection to the games.

The use of the Sydney Games indicia or images solely for the purposes of providing information, or for the purposes of criticism or review, is not of itself prohibited. Examples of such provision of information include the reporting of news and presentation of current affairs, the factual description of goods or services provided by a business (such as stating that accommodation is available at a hotel that is located near the Olympic site), or the factual description by an athlete of their performance and achievements. Examples of criticism and review are those which are likely to appear in newspapers, magazines or similar periodicals, in a radio or television broadcast, or in a cinematographic film.

The government recognises that the reasonable needs of sporting bodies in relation to fundraising for and promotion of their preparation of athletes and teams for the Sydney Olympic and Paralympic Games should be allowed to continue. Those reasonable needs could involve use of the Sydney Games indicia or images for the purposes of providing factual information. As I have just explained, the bill is not intended to affect this type of use. Nevertheless, as I noted when I presented the government's response to the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee's report, the government believes that, in the interests of clarity and certainty, it would be desirable for sporting bodies to negotiate Memoranda of Understanding with SOCOG to cover their proposed use of the Sydney Games indicia and images. Such a Memorandum is currently under negotiation between the Australian Sports Commission and SOCOG.

The bill provides various remedies to SOCOG, SPOC and licensed users to enforce their rights in relation to the Sydney Games indicia and images. Thus, where an unlicensed user uses Sydney Games indicia or images in contravention of the bill, SOCOG, SPOC or a relevant licensed user may bring an action against the unlicensed user. The remedies available under the bill include injunctions, damages and corrective advertising. However, in addition to those remedies, the courts have the discretion to provide remedies under any law (whether a law of the commonwealth, a state or a territory) that confers any rights or powers on SOCOG, SPOC or a licensed user. Most notable in this regard are the remedies provided under the Trade Practices Act 1974 in relation to engaging in conduct that is misleading or deceptive.
The bill also includes appropriate customs measures to limit the possibility of the importation of goods which seek to ambush the Olympic Games marketing.

The on-going cost to the government of administering this legislation will be minimal. The Australian Customs Service will be able to carry out the measures of this legislation relating to the monitoring of imported goods at the barrier within their existing resources. It is likely that the increased security of the Olympic 2000 indicia and images will enhance SOCOG's and SPOC's capacity to ensure the financial viability of the 2000 Games through its marketing program.

I believe that the bill introduces significant protection for the Sydney Games indicia and images. The protection provided by this bill will both complement and enhance the protective measures already in place under Australia's current intellectual property laws to ensure, to the extent possible, that a good budget outcome is achieved for the Sydney 2000 Games.
I commend this bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
AUSTRALIAN SPORTS DRUG AGENCY AMENDMENT BILL 1995
Mr President, this bill amends the act that established the Australian Sports Drug Agency.
This bill will enhance the international leadership role that Australia has established in the fight against the use of prohibited drugs in sport.

The bill will allow the Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA) to work more co-operatively with International Sporting Federations to conduct an annual program of drug tests both at major sporting events and out-of-competition.

The bill will also ensure that Australia's successful anti-doping programs operate even more efficiently and effectively. Under this legislation, our drug testing programs will continue to deter athletes from using drugs while at the same time ensuring that the rights of athletes undergoing drug testing will not be compromised.
Most importantly, this bill will reduce the likelihood of successful legal challenges to positive drug tests based on minor or trivial technicalities.
ASDA was established as a statutory authority on 18 February 1991—a speedy response by the government to recommendations of the then Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts.
I am pleased to say that following the establishment of ASDA, Australia has become recognised around the world as a leader in the international fight against doping in sport.
Since its establishment ASDA has had remarkable success. I would like to share some of the highlights with you.

ASDA has arranged for more than 15,000 drug tests to be conducted and has implemented comprehensive education programs throughout schools and sporting organisations in Australia. All these drug tests are analysed by the internationally accredited Australian Sports Drug Testing laboratory in Sydney.
During the last year more than 3,000 drug tests were undertaken with more than 99% being "drug free".
ASDA has been successful in working with professional sports leagues to conduct testing programs on a fee-for-service basis.
ASDA has played an increasingly successful role in working internationally so that our athletes can compete on a more level playing field, for example,

PARA.TAB: ASDA has carried out the drug testing programs for the World Swimming Championships, the South East Asian Games, the World Weightlifting Championships and a host of other major international sporting events;
it has developed guidelines for drug education for use by the international sporting community;
testing programs have been developed co-operatively and implemented by the international controlling bodies of Athletics, Rowing, Weightlifting, Swimming and Gymnastics;

during the last 12 months the amount of out-of-competition drug tests conducted by international sporting organisations has increased by nearly 50%. ASDA can deservedly take some of the credit for this upsurge in the international response against drugs in sport; and
most significantly, following a request from the Chinese anti-doping authorities, the ASDA is assisting China to establish its own sports drug agency.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has also entered into anti-doping agreements with other countries including the United Kingdom, Canada, New Zealand and Norway. This multi-lateral agreement will include, among other things, the establishment of an international benchmark for testing programs, utilising the world wide system of accreditation and certification.
Australia was also the first non-European country to accede to the Council of Europe Anti-Doping Convention aimed at harmonising anti-doping programs among countries.

Our substantial international achievements were possible only because we have strong and successful national programs. I was pleased to report that a National Drugs in Sport Framework was endorsed earlier this month by the commonwealth, state and territory Sports Ministers.
All those ministers recognise that achieving the objectives of this anti-doping initiative will result in:
athletes around Australia being exposed to consistent drug testing programs;
opportunities for all elite athletes to receive sport drug education;
an emphasis on promoting the ethos that the use of drugs to enhance sports performance is cheating; and
improvements in the expertise of government and sport to develop effective drugs in sport policies.
These objectives will be achieved through the co-ordinated action of all governments.

Effective anti-doping programs that deter athletes and their associates from cheating need to recognise that everyone must be treated in a fair and just way. The Framework recognises the principle of natural justice and the need to respect the rights of individuals, particularly the rights of young athletes.

The development of this framework involved all key players in the sport industry in both the government and non-government sectors. It was pleasing to note that the Confederation of Australian Sport (representing more than 100 national sporting organisations) acknowledges the importance of this anti-doping initiative.
This national initiative will be critical in achieving the government's goal of a drug free Sydney 2000 Olympic Games.

Australia's strong and committed anti-doping stance was considered a significant factor in Sydney's successful bid to host the 2000 Olympic Games. This success provides Australia with a unique opportunity to further address a concern of the Australian sporting community with the lack of an international level playing field in respect to doping. With the international sporting spotlight firmly on Sydney after the Atlanta games, Australia is well placed to continue demonstrating leadership through its effective domestic anti-doping programs and to advocate to the international sporting community the need for, and benefits of, a dedicated anti-doping effort.
In July this year, the government endorsed a comprehensive package of measures aimed at pursuing a drug free 2000 Olympic Games. These measures include:
a drug testing program targeting international athletes competing and training in Australia;
advocating out-of-competition testing programs by International Sporting Federations that target their top athletes on an annual basis;
drug testing programs by the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games (SOCOG) at the 2000 Olympics and the test events leading up to the games;
the maintenance of an internationally accredited drug testing laboratory in Australia and continuing research to ensure new doping practices can be detected;
education programs throughout school and sporting communities;
anti-doping agreements between Australia and other countries; and
measures to reduce both the prescribing and illicit supply of performance enhancing drugs.

This package of measures will be implemented by key organisations from the sport, health, education and law enforcement agencies in the government and non-government sectors. The Australian Olympic Committee and SOCOG will also play a critical role in the fight against drugs in sport. It is encouraging to see that SOCOG has already established its drug testing expert committee which has a very strong ASDA involvement.

A drug free Sydney 2000 will also require the co-operation of international sporting organisations. Towards this end, the government has already signed a tri-partite anti-doping agreement with the International Olympic Committee and SOCOG.

Our anti-doping effort will not only be critical to the sporting and financial success of the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games but it also has the potential to re-establish the credibility of international sport by encouraging the international sporting community to embrace a drug-free sporting ethos and by providing a launching pad to take this ethos into the 21st century.
This bill will help achieve this goal.
This bill and our anti-doping policies are about sportsmen and sportswomen and their right to compete in drug-free sport.
For this reason the government has made a great effort to understand the concerns of our athletes and to ask them if they think our anti-doping programs are successful.
A 1994 survey of elite athletes in Australia showed that:
they believe that ASDA's drug testing program is likely to deter elite athletes from using prohibited drugs in sport;
there is a high degree of satisfaction with all aspects of the ASDA testing program, including the conduct of ASDA personnel;
73% of elite athletes rated ASDA successful at balancing an individual's right to privacy with the need to maximise the deterrent effect of the drug testing program;
the way ASDA works in the sporting community has received wide endorsement with the majority of all elite athletes suggesting ASDA consults successfully with sport;
the wide range of sources of information on drugs in sport utilised by elite athletes reflects a generally better informed and aware sporting community; and
86% of elite athletes believe that an independent national organisation, such as ASDA, should be responsible for drug testing.

The overall conclusion from this survey is that our approach to the drugs in sport issue has been successful. Information collected over the past three years suggests that in the core areas of drug testing, education and policy work, ASDA has made and sustained a positive impact within the sporting community.

These views support the results of the 1993 Mugford Report titled The Value of Sport, Ethics and the Control of Performance Enhancing Drugs: A Study in the Australian Sports Community which states that:
athletes perceive the use of drugs for performance enhancement primarily as cheating;
ASDA is succeeding in creating a climate where athletes are committed to the rules rather than simply obeying them because of the fear of detection, i.e. conformity rather than compliance;
this climate makes use of performance enhancing drugs much harder for athletes to justify; and
sports people identified a definite value to society created by sport and it is clear that drug testing and educational programs undertaken by ASDA protect that value.
While it is clear our anti-doping policy has been successful, we must not become complacent. The amendments in this bill will ensure that our anti-doping programs can operate optimally.

The bill refines the Australian Sports Drug Agency's objectives to ensure the ongoing relevance of the Agency to the continuing fight against drugs in sport. The amendments do not significantly alter these objectives but expresses them in terms of outcomes rather than outputs. As a result the revised objectives emphasise ASDA's deterrence, educational and national and international advocacy roles. ASDA's revised objectives are to:
deter the use of scheduled drugs or doping methods in sport;
encourage the development of programs to educate the sporting community about matters relating to drugs in sport;
advocate the international adoption of consistent and effective anti-doping programs; and
co-ordinate the development of a consistent and effective national response to matters relating to drugs in sport.
The bill also refines ASDA's functions to clearly identify a range of strategies to be implemented by the Agency to achieve the proposed outcome-oriented objectives. These functions are to:
develop and implement drug testing programs; and
advocate the international development and implementation of consistent and effective anti-doping programs; and
encourage Australian national sporting organisations, state and territory sporting organisations and professional sporting organisations:

TAB.TAB: (i)to develop and implement comprehensive and consistent anti-doping initiatives (including initiatives relating to testing for the use of drugs and education about matters relating to drugs in sport); and
(ii)to use the services of the agency and accredited laboratories;

SPEECH.PARA: develop and implement initiatives that increase the skills and knowledge of people involved in sporting activities about matters relating to drugs in sport;
advocate and support research in and outside Australia about drugs in sport;
implement anti-doping arrangements;
encourage the establishment of means for the carrying out by departments and authorities of the states and territories of initiatives relating to drugs in sport;and
co-operate with those departments and authorities and with non-government sporting organisations to implement those initiatives.

The bill will also enable ASDA to work more co-operatively with International Sporting Federations in conducting effective drug testing programs. The agency is increasingly being asked by these federations to undertake testing on their behalf and ASDA can expect an increase in the number of requests for testing in the lead-up to the Sydney
Olympics.

At present there is no uniform international procedure for sample collection and testing. Most International Sporting Federations have sample collection procedures that differ from each other in a number of small variations. These variations have made it difficult for ASDA to undertake testing on behalf of International Sporting Federations as the procedures do not strictly comply with the procedural requirements of the current ASDA legislation.

The bill will permit the agency to overcome this problem and undertake testing for International Sporting Federations, either at international events being held in Australia or when contracted to conduct other event and out-of-competition testing, even in those cases where International Sporting Federations' procedures are slightly different to the procedures outlined in the ASDA legislation which, of course are primarily designed for our domestic testing regime.

This in no way suggests that the existing high standards will be diminished in any way. The amendments provided by this bill simply identify the procedures which ASDA must strictly comply with to ensure the integrity and accuracy of the drug test result. They also identify those procedures which require only substantial compliance. This will enable the agency to recognise drug test results even if there are minor irregularities provided those irregularities do not cast doubt on the actual test results.

This bill has been framed following widespread consultation throughout the sporting and legal communities and other interested parties. This includes the Australian Olympic Committee, the Confederation of Australian Sport, National Sporting Organisations, Australia & New Zealand Sports Law Association and the Privacy Commissioner.

This legislation reflects the privacy and human rights principles laid down in other commonwealth legislation. In particular, only those who need to have access to information will be informed. The government has also been concerned to protect the rights of athletes and has built into the legislation certain appeal rights to ensure athletes are protected.

The administrative and operational expenses related to staff and program costs will be determined annually in the Budget. The appropriation to ASDA for 1995-96 is $3.412 million. This includes an allocation to undertake 2,500 "public interest" drug tests on Australian athletes and international athletes who train or compete in this country.
It is anticipated that ASDA will generate additional income approaching $0.5 million each year from "user pay" education and testing services.

Mr President, this legislation is even more evidence of this government's commitment to drug free sport. A commitment that is underpinned by an allocation of $20 million for anti-doping programs between now and the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games. This sends a clear message to both the Australian and international sporting communities that we intend to "beat the cheats".

It also sends an important message to our drug free athletes that this government intends to do everything possible to ensure that Australian sportsmen and sportswomen are able to compete in sport which is free from banned doping practices.

I am sure that all Senators want to ensure that our sporting tradition for fair play remains an integral part of our sporting success and that our children can inherit sport free from the use of drugs.
Mr President, I commend this bill to the Senate.
TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT (BETTER BUSINESS CONDUCT) BILL 1995

Small businesses make up 96 per cent of all firms in Australia and account for 45 percent of all employment. Increasingly, jobs growth is being fuelled by the demands of the small business sector. Many of Australia's most innovative firms are small businesses. These firms are critical to the export growth of Australia's manufacturing and service industries and are at the forefront of the push into Asia. Therefore, when small businesses complain that they are being unfairly exploited, there is good cause to listen.

Small businesses have long argued that they are not getting a fair go, and that the protections offered by the Trade Practices Act 1974 do not give relief from a range of unfair practices. Many of the concerns raised by small business are simply the result of competitive forces in the marketplace and thus do not justify a legislative response.

There remains, however, some practices of legitimate concern which are not prohibited by the Trade Practices Act 1974. Circumstances can arise where a firm cannot, due to the actions of another, protect their interests and are subject to exploitation in a manner unsustainable in a competitive and open market. The exploitation of small firms in existing commercial relationships denies many firms the capacity to develop and is an impediment to growth in this important sector of the economy. This bill seeks to remove such impediments.

However, it should not be forgotten that the market is a hard place. It is the nature of business that all firms seek to maximise their returns. The government recognises this and does not propose to prevent hard bargains being struck, provided that they are struck fairly. It is not the intention of this bill to protect firms from their own mistakes, nor is it intended to provide them with a guarantee of business success. It is about restoring choice to commercial bargains and allowing those who are denied choice the opportunity to take steps to protect their own interests.

This is not a bill to prohibit harsh or oppressive outcomes. Agreements with such outcomes, freely entered into and consequent of full disclosure, must be allowed to stand. This is, however, a bill that addresses those commercial relationships where one of the parties has no choice. Further, the bill only targets conduct that is harsh or oppressive and not in the present or future legitimate interests of the corporation.

Concern has been raised in some quarters that this bill undermines primacy of contract and threatens the fabric of Australian commercial activity. Australia's strict laws of contract are a comparative advantage in the Asia-Pacific region, and assist in attracting investment into this country. The government recognises this, and the bill preserves the advantages that certainty of contract gives to the business environment.

The bill is limited in the scope of its application to businesses in a pre-existing commercial relationship. The reason for this limitation is that, however painful the decision, businesses that have no sunk costs in a commercial relationship can walk away if the terms and conditions are not commensurate with the return.

The provisions of the bill also only apply to commercial relationships of major significance to one of the parties to the arrangement. This is not a bill to provide relief from every provision that a firm finds inconvenient or burdensome.

This bill is concerned with prohibiting the exploitation of a party denied commercial choice by virtue of the particular relationship they have with another firm. It is not about providing relief for firms from downturns in the market or industry wide practices. For example, the forced reduction in the price paid to automotive component suppliers by the major car companies would not be covered by this legislation as it arises from changes affecting the Australian car industry as a whole, namely exposure to international competition. It is legitimate for the major car companies to seek to force reductions in price on their suppliers as the level of competition in the sector increases.

It is important to note that the bill is confined to the exploitation of a particular commercial relationship. A company that chooses to engage in a common set of conduct across all commercial relationships is not exploiting any one particular arrangement. In a competitive market, a company which unfairly exploits all its commercial relationships is likely, in the long term, to do greater commercial damage to itself than to any one party with whom it deals.

Even when conduct is found to be harsh or oppressive it may be justified by specific considerations which are peculiar to the particular relationship. The bill reflects this by allowing reference to the whole of the commercial relationship and the surrounding circumstances.

In markets where competition is reduced, such as in markets where the company has a substantial degree of market power, existing provisions of the Trade Practices Act governing the misuse of market power prevent the exploitation of firms. This bill addresses discriminatory conduct, where a company exploits a particular relationship to seek extra-market rents unsustainable in the open market.

It should be recognised that a number of industry sectors have already taken steps to address the matters covered by this bill. This is to be commended. Many landlords, including the larger ones, have adopted practices that recognise the mutually dependent nature of their relationship with their tenants. The government welcomes the cooperation between the Building Owners and Managers Association and the Retailers Council of Australia on encouraging better business conduct between landlords and their tenants. This bill supports these changes in leasing practices, by capturing those firms that refuse to comply with industry developed norms of behaviour.

The government welcomes moves towards industry codes of self-regulation as they create a regulatory environment protects all participants while allowing for a flexibility for change that legislation cannot deliver. This bill, with the other provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974, provides a legislative safety net for industry codes of practice, reducing the level of regulation that would otherwise be necessary for many industry sectors. By listing adherence to self-regulatory codes as a factor which a court may have regard to in determining whether conduct is harsh or oppressive, the bill explicitly recognises the important role these codes play in establishing acceptable standards of business conduct.

The bill is seen as an important facet of the regulatory framework for the petroleum and franchising sectors. Smaller participants in these industries, concerned at their relative lack of commercial independence from larger corporations, have welcomed these measures, as they provide protection from abuse while not involving the government in the everyday operations of their businesses. These firms have stated that they do not want heavy-handed government regulation of their dynamic industry sectors. They want an environment where they are protected from exploitation but where commercial success depends on their own commitment and business acumen.

This bill has been drafted with a view to providing realistic and effective protection without imposing unacceptable compliance costs upon business. The bill provides for better business conduct whilst not having any financial implications for the government. It is consistent with the government's policy of `minimum effective regulation'.

This bill aims to improve standards of business conduct, and does not seek to rely on enforcement for its effect. Where matters still result in dispute, the bill, through its support of industry codes of behaviour, favours mediation. Court action is a costly exercise, in both time and money, that many businesses cannot afford. The government supports moves which reduce the burden on the court system such as mediation of disputes, particularly under mechanisms arising out of industry-specific codes of practice. Willingness to subject disputes to arbitration rather than pursuing the claims in courts should be encouraged and taken as a commitment by the parties to making business relationships work.

This is not a small business protection act. It is about allowing businesses to operate to the best of their abilities in an open market. Under the bill, firms still have a overriding onus to look after their own interests and to protect themselves against exploitation. Only where a corporation knowingly denies a firm this opportunity, or ought reasonably to have known that this was likely, will the bill provide relief.

This bill is about changing the way firms interact so that those with significant interdependence cannot ignore the impact of their decisions on those bound to them. It is a bill that recognises that improved standards of business conduct benefit all firms and encourage higher growth and greater economic prosperity.
I commend this bill to honourable Senators.
