SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee on the meaning and operation of section 51(xxix) of the Constitution, dealing with treaties and the external affairs power, together with submissions and transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: On 8 December 1994 the Senate asked the committee to inquire into the Commonwealth's treaty making power, which is also often referred to as the `external affairs power'. The committee consulted widely in relation to this reference. It conducted public hearings in all capital cities, except Darwin, and it received 157 written submissions. This perhaps has been the most comprehensive review devoted solely to the operation of the external affairs power.

PARA.TAB: At the outset I wish to place on record my appreciation to the committee secretariat, especially for the outstanding work by Anne Twomey, Catherine Hawkins and Peter Thomson. They have given the committee invaluable assistance during the last 12 months. I also wish to thank fellow committee members for their contributions and application to what has been, I think, one of the most important reports handed down by a Senate committee.

A number of central issues arose from the evidence which the committee received. These concerns related to the impact of international treaties on the Australian federal system and the sovereignty of the nation; the degree of consultation undertaken by the government prior to entering into and ratifying treaties; and the issue of the respective roles of the parliament, the government, and especially the executive, in treaty making.

The legislative power to implement treaties in domestic law is governed by section 51(xxix) of the Constitution and, as I have stated previously, is commonly known as the `external affairs power'. At Federation in 1901, the Commonwealth government did not possess the executive power to enter into treaties. This prerogative remained with the United Kingdom. Australia subsequently became an independent nation, capable of entering into treaties on its own behalf.

The current interpretation of the external affairs power is that it is an independent plenary head of power that supports laws with respect to matters that are physically external to Australia and laws affecting Australia's relations with other nations. The power also supports legislation that implements Australia's obligations under treaties, regardless of whether the treaties' subject matter is otherwise constitutionally within the Commonwealth's legislative power.

Recently the High Court decision of Teoh demonstrated the increasing importance of the impact of treaties on Australian law and, I would say, supports the necessity for greater parliamentary involvement in the treaty making process. It is argued that the wide interpretation of the external affairs power to cover matters that are not external to Australia may threaten the continued existence of the Australian federation; that is, a wide interpretation of the external affairs power might permit the Commonwealth to extend its legislative competence to cover areas previously considered to be within the domain of the states.

Since 1973 with the Seas and Submerged Lands decision, the High Court has been seen to broaden the application of the external affairs provision. I would suggest to the Senate that that was part of the concern put to the committee during its hearings.

There were 11 recommendations made; they were unanimous. The first dealt with the information provided to the public at large in relation to the treaties that were entered into. Although it is stated that Australia is party to approximately 920 treaties, there is still some uncertainty as to that exact number. Accordingly, the committee considers that it is necessary for the government to conduct an audit of treaties to determine the precise scope of Australia's international obligations.

The committee also recommended that the government report annually to the parliament on measures it has taken to implement treaties in the previous year. The committee also considered that a treaties database should be established by the government, and that it should be readily accessible by the public free of charge.

One of the concerns that was raised before the committee was about consultation. The committee was concerned that the public does not have access to adequate information and is not adequately consulted by the government prior to ratification of treaties. In some cases, the government may consult only the peak body in relation to a particular interest group. However, in relation to some groups a peak body may not be as representative of that interest group as the government may believe. Therefore, the committee considers the government should endeavour to consult widely with all relevant groups to overcome such problems.

The committee went on to consider the role of the states and territories and, I might add, the states and territories were united in their submission to the committee that there should be a further body, a treaties council, set up in addition to the Standing Committee on Treaties. The Standing Committee on Treaties comprises public officials and the committee thought it was desirable not to duplicate the process and form another body but simply build on the Standing Committee on Treaties and establish a treaties council. This treaties council, however, should be made up of elected representatives from the parliaments of the states and territories. That would mean that you would have representatives from both state governments and oppositions and territorial governments and oppositions. As well as that, the committee recommended that on the council there should also be representatives from the federal government, federal opposition and minor parties in the Commonwealth.

The committee also recommended that there should be a joint parliamentary treaties committee which would be able to review treaties prior to ratification. The committee recommended that the government should table treaties at least 15 sitting days prior to ratification and thereby provide an opportunity for the parliament to refer to a joint parliamentary treaty any treaty under consideration. Wide powers would then be afforded to that joint parliamentary committee to inquire into and report on the treaty concerned.

There was some mention made of amendment to the constitution. The committee was of the view that that was not an option available unless there was bipartisan support and that, accordingly, legislation to regulate the exercise of the external affairs power was a more preferable option. There was also some mention made of the fact that there should be parliamentary approval of treaties. The committee stressed that parliament should not be involved in the negotiating of treaties but that the question of any parliamentary approval should be referred to the joint parliamentary committee for its consideration. The committee was of the opinion that this was such an important matter that it required a discrete debate in relation to this issue alone.

As I said, these recommendations were unanimous. They are indeed ground breaking. They take us to an area in relation to the external affairs power where this country has never been before. I believe that if these recommendations are accepted you will have increased consultation with not only the states and territories but also the community at large. I believe these recommendations would go a long way to addressing the concerns that were put to the committee. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as a member of the committee to briefly comment on this report: Trick or treaty? Commonwealth Power to Make and Implement Treaties. It is a report that has had considerable work expended on it, and I wish to commend the Chairman, Senator Chris Ellison, for his leadership that has made this report and its weightiness, in more ways than one, possible.

PARA.TAB: I also pay tribute to members of the secretariat, in particular Ms Catherine Hawkins, Ms Jane Grace and Mr Steven Bull. All of them contributed to this report and worked extremely enthusiastically and diligently. I do not want to forget the deputy chairman of the committee, Senator Barney Cooney, who contributed untiringly to this report.

As Senator Ellison said, the area of treaties requires careful consideration. This country and this parliament have often been placed in the position where treaties which have had domestic consequences have been concluded by the executive government of Australia. Very often when we talk about that, the international treaty relating to human rights is mentioned. I believe those developments are extremely positive. The Australian Democrats have supported them.

Our opinions are coloured very often by the content of the treaties. The Democrats are not happy about some treaties, such as the treaty relating to the World Trade Organisation which committed us to certain action under GATT. That very much highlights the situation that this parliament and the community at large must be involved in the discussion of treaties and must be able to contribute views and opinions and have a substantive debate on significant treaties before they are concluded.

Despite the recent Teoh case, which has been met by the government's action with the so-called anti-Teoh bill which says that there is no such thing as any expectation that public officials will act in accordance with international conventions and treaties that Australia has ratified and signed, I still believe that obligations on the part of Australia are created and that the international community will expect Australia to act in accordance with commitments it has made in treaties and that parliament should not be in a position to be compelled to meet these international obligations that the government has created without first having had an opportunity to come to grips with the details of the commitment that we are entering into.

The committee has weighed carefully a number of avenues to achieve that. As Senator Ellison said, the committee recommended the creation of a treaties council with very wide representation. Some people might say that it is too unwieldy and too large because it is proposed that the council have representation not only from the Commonwealth government and all state governments but also representatives from oppositions and representatives of so-called minor parties. The reason—and I believe it is a sound one—is that this council is not a decision making body but is a consultative body. Its establishment is only a recommendation at this stage. I hope the recommendation is accepted by parliament. It will be established as a dragnet measure to flush out all concerns in the nation about a proposed treaty that creates obligations on behalf of Australia. If you look at it from that point of view, I believe there is a strong case for wide representation.

The committee also recommends the establishment of a joint parliamentary committee to have treaties referred to it, to examine them in detail and to report to parliament on them. I believe that is the appropriate place for treaties to be carefully considered and for the recommendation to be made to the parliament as to the value or otherwise on the treaty. It is appropriate that such a committee be established.

I make a brief comment on the bill that Democrat Senator Vicki Bourne introduced. Its provisions require that parliament approve certain important bills before they are signed. The committee has not been able to reach a decision that it wholeheartedly recommends that procedure, but it has decided that how legislative provisions, and what legislative provisions, should be made to achieve parliamentary approval of certain classes of treaty should be referred to that committee. It does require further consideration.

The final matter I would like to comment on is the provisions which ensure that widespread consultation and the provision of information throughout the community are undertaken. It is not an easy or light matter for a country to accept international obligations by way of treaty, and it is proper and fitting that, as the community becomes politically more interested and politically more expert, it should have an opportunity to comment; it should have an opportunity to express an opinion on the content of those treaties. I commend the committee's report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the remarks so far made by Senator Ellison and Senator Spindler and go on to say that this is a groundbreaking report. I think it is going to be the first of a series of reports about an issue which is of growing importance, not only to Australia but to the world as a whole.

PARA.TAB: I perhaps rather rudely left a person in my room. I said I would go around and make some comments on this. The person was Pierre-Michel Fontaine, who is the regional representative for Australia, New Zealand and the South Pacific for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. He is about to leave Australia in this area after doing what I think everybody would agree is outstanding and very effective service here. He is returning to Geneva. I think it is a great loss to Australia that he is going back to Geneva, but there you are. I would like to pay tribute to him. It is an indication of just how important international relations are, and it is important since they are of that pre-eminence in our life that they be dealt with properly. I think this is a landmark report that will begin, as I say, what I hope is a greater and deeper consideration of the area.

A remarkable feature of this report is that it is a unanimous report, and I think that is a tribute to all those on the committee, in particular Senator Ellison. This is an area where it is quite clear from debates in this chamber that there are differences of opinion about how external affairs should go. To get a unanimous report and a series of recommendations which are the basis for a very important development is I think a great tribute to the chair, Senator Ellison, in addition to the rest of the committee. So I would like to pay tribute to that.

When you get people on the committee such as Senator McKiernan and Senator Abetz, and Senator Margetts and Senator Chamarette were participating members, I think it was a task that only great leadership could bring to fruition. So I would like to pay tribute to Senator Ellison in that respect. I notice that one of the participating members is Senator Kemp, and I think that, although Senator Kemp has pursued this area of considerations to great effect, it took a person like Senator Ellison to tie it all together in the way it has been done.

Having said that, I think Senator Ellison and the rest of the committee would agree that great tribute must be paid to the committee secretary, Anne Twomey, and to Peter Thomson, who left part way through the report. He was doing outstanding work in this area, but that was ably taken over by Catherine Hawkins. I wanted to pick them out because they were the ones amongst a secretariat which I think is probably the busiest secretariat not only in the Senate but in Parliament House. Their workload is cruel, to say the least, and how they produce reports like this of such quality time and time again is beyond me.

We have not even given the staff a Christmas party. It is a dreadful business. We will have to do something. That is the only discordant note—having worked this committee into the ground for the year, we have not as yet done anything for them. We should give them perhaps a couple of packets of peanuts and at least a glass of water: we should do something. In all seriousness, I think all of us would gather together in saying we have nothing but the utmost respect, if not the utmost awe, for the way these people have gone about their business.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to make a few comments about the report by the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee entitled Trick or Treaty? Commonwealth Power to Make and Implement Treaties. It was a great honour to serve on that committee and be part of the unanimous recommendations that are now before the Senate.

PARA.TAB: This clearly is a watershed report. I want to pay a tribute to all my fellow senators who sat on that committee and also to the staff for their intellectual prowess, their sharpness and their capacity to actively engage in debate with us senators as to the consequences of certain propositions that we put up in deciding what the terms of our report ought be. I just want to place that on record.

In my first speech in this place I made reference to my concerns about the international treaty making process and the way that that was having an adverse influence on the federal-state relations within our Commonwealth structure. I note that after my first speech one Senator Rod Kemp came up to me and said it was nice to know somebody else was interested in treaties. Senator Kemp was one of the driving forces in this Senate, and indeed within the Australian public, to highlight some of the difficulties occasioned by the treaty making process.

Another point that needs to be stressed, as Senator Cooney did, is that this is a unanimous report. Once again, that shows and points out to the community at large the very good work that the Senate and its committee system undertakes. I know that there is a certain gentleman in another place who refers to us as `unrepresentative swill' but I have to say that when you have documents of this nature produced by this house on a unanimous basis the people of Australia can be absolutely satisfied that the Senate does work, that the Senate committee structure works very well for the betterment of our political processes and for the betterment of the Australian people.

One of the recommendations of the report which I am delighted with is recommendation No. 9, which does suggest that there ought be, if you like, an impact statement on the domestic law of Australia pursuant to any treaty that we might sign, because so often we have signed treaties with scant regard for the domestic consequences of signing those treaties. We then have federal governments abusing those treaties for their own domestic purposes. I remember the heartache I went through at about this time last year when I was unable to vote with my colleagues in relation to the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill because of the adverse impact that was going to have on the Commonwealth-state relations and the way that got its legal foundation through an international treaty.

We were told at the time by an Attorney-General who was beating his breast that we had an international obligation to pass this legislation; it was absolutely vital. But then, of course, when the High Court made a decision against the federal government in relation to the Teoh decision, all of a sudden all those international obligations were thrown out the window and we had a situation where the government then introduced legislation to overturn the impact of the international obligations—which, of course, shows the two-faced approach that the federal government has adopted to international treaty making.

If there is to be an impact statement or an audit of the impact of international treaties on domestic legislation, we will then find out the true consequences of signing up on treaties. Some would argue that the Convention on the Rights of the Child, for example, would not allow for corporal punishment of children. I would have thought that 80 or 90 per cent of the Australian population believe that loving discipline of children can include an aspect of corporal punishment. Of course, the federal Attorney-General quite properly has dismissed the outlawing of corporal punishment pursuant to that convention. But, quite frankly, if that is the Australian domestic line, then we should not have signed that international treaty. Recommendation 9 requiring this audit or impact statement on the domestic legislation prior to signing a treaty I think will be of great benefit for the treaties council and for the people of Australia.

I believe it has been agreed that we should all limit our comments as much as possible. May I simply make this other comment? I personally believe that, ultimately, there ought be an amendment to the constitution, but it is more important for us to get a unanimous report and that was why I was more than willing to go along with this unanimous report rather than suggest that the constitution be amended, because I am sure that we would not get bipartisan support for such a suggestion. I believe that this report is a victory for parliamentary democracy, for the people of Australia and for commonsense. I commend the report to the Senate and the people of Australia.
Debate (on motion by Senator Calvert) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Employment, Education and Training References Committee on the sale of Bond University, together with submissions received by the committee and the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I start speaking on this report, I would like to pay special tribute to the staff of the Employment, Education and Training References Committee for taking a reference at very short notice and, in a very short space of time, producing a report of such excellent quality.

PARA.TAB: The committee believes that the sale of Bond University, one of only two existing private universities in Australia, to a public university represents a threat to national interests. The committee has focused its attention on three issues: firstly, the risk to public money; secondly, the potential of the bid to change by stealth higher education policy, including no fees for undergraduate study by Australian students; and, thirdly, the impact the purchase will have on the independence of Bond and, hence, on the diversity of choice in higher education options in Australia.

In relation to the safety of public money, the committee had two main concerns. The first of these relates to the initial purchase. The university's bid is believed to be around $110 million and the University of Queensland has assured the committee that no public funding or assets will be used to purchase the land and building.

How such a risk of $110 million debt is to the public purse depends very much on the nature of the securities given. This raises the key question: in the event of the venture failing, how would the bank redeem its debt? The committee believes, on the evidence to date, that there is still a risk to public money. The committee is unconvinced that the assets which would be used as security equate to the value of the loan that they are held against. Moreover, what government is going to take the risk of damaging the reputation of one of its leading public universities by not coming to the rescue in the event of a default?

The committee acknowledges that the University of Queensland has offered to enter into a formal agreement with DEET to subject to public scrutiny all its operations with respect to Bond. The committee has been unable to obtain enough detail about the form of this agreement to assess its value or enforceability. Therefore, we are being asked at this stage to take a lot on faith.

Cross-subsidisation between a public and private university is also of considerable concern. In the long term the potential for direct cross-subsidisation is far greater, particularly in the event of the University of Queensland developing a contiguous public campus, as foreshadowed at Robina. The committee considers that there are grounds for concern here. According to some witnesses, such arrangements would almost inevitably lead to cross-subsidisation. While the safety of public money may be the most immediate of the concerns raised by the sale of Bond University campus, the sale is also seen to represent a real threat to aspects of current higher education policy.

Of particular concern to the committee is the threat to the policy of no up-front fees for undergraduate studies for Australian students. The committee acknowledges that the current government policy does, in theory, prohibit the charging of up-front fees to Australian undergraduate students. However, this official position has been undermined by a number of developments over recent years: firstly, the existence of at least a partial legitimisation of the user pay principle through the introduction of HECS; secondly, the opening up of some post-graduate courses to full fee-paying arrangements; and, thirdly, the use of commercial arms of universities to offer fee-paying courses for which credit may be subsequently given as part of an undergraduate degree. In this context, the sale of Bond University can be seen as having the potential to undermine the policy of no fees for undergraduate study by Australian students even further. It is the committee's view that such a debate is appropriate at the present stage of development of higher education systems and this is encompassed in our first recommendation.

While Australia's commitment to a high quality public system of higher education is unlikely to diminish, it is important that any developments in the private sphere with respect to higher education are guided by suitable government policy. Only then will the interests of both public and private sectors be served. To this end, the committee has recommended that the Senate and Commonwealth government encourage and facilitate a broad public debate on issues arising at the interface between the public and private activities of universities, on the role of the non-government sector in the provision of higher government, and the implications of these matters for higher education policy and funding.

One of the biggest concerns to the committee related to the implications for Bond University's independence of the University of Queensland with the University of Queensland being a landlord and member of Bond's council. The committee regards a pure landlord-tenant relationship between the University of Queensland and Bond as considerably less threatening to the public perceptions of Bond's independence than a more direct involvement of the University of Queensland in Bond's affairs. However, on balance it regards such a relationship as conducive to a public perception that Bond University might in some way be beholden to the University of Queensland. A much greater threat to Bond's independence is the proposal that the University of Queensland have members on Bond's council.

The educational program at Bond is under the council's ultimate control. The University of Queensland's influential presence on that council, therefore, could profoundly affect Bond's program over the long term. Put simply, the argument is that the loss of diversity with the University of Queensland's bid for Bond is that the purchase of the campus by the University of Queensland and the elements of University of Queensland control will mean elimination of Bond University's private and independent essence. A distinctive element and an alternative style of undergraduate study for Australian students would therefore be lost.

Something different is happening at the Bond campus and it should be allowed to thrive and prosper in the national interest. The committee has, therefore, made two other recommendations. The committee recommends that, in the national interest, the purchase of the Bond University campus by the University of Queensland should not proceed. The committee also recommends that public universities should be disqualified from participating in any re-tendering or other future selling process for the Bond University campus. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by thanking very much the staff of the secretariat for their professionalism. They have to deal with quite improper inquiries which are held in an improper and, in my view, totally inappropriate way. As a consequence, they are placed in an intolerable position of, to a large measure, becoming essentially propagandists in terms of presenting material on behalf of senators which do not reflect the evidence. This stands in sharp contrast to the previous committee report which has just been presented, where very difficult matters were dealt with in an entirely different way.

PARA.TAB: What we have here today is yet another pernicious, failed Senate inquiry which is built fundamentally upon a lie. That lie is contained on the cover of this report, which refers, in its terms of reference, to the sale of the Bond University. There is no sale of the Bond University. This was supposed to be an inquiry into the sale of the real estate at Bond University—a very important difference. There are no public funds at risk in this episode. The only waste of public funds is involved in the operation of this Senate committee itself. In that regard it is my view and the view of Labor senators that this is an abuse of the privileges of this parliament and an abuse of the committee system of the Senate.

As far as I am concerned it demonstrates yet again the complete lack of moral leadership within the Liberal Party. It was once said that it was just a question of apathy and lethargy on behalf of the Liberal leadership that various senators could behave in the way they do in the Senate. What has occurred to me on this occasion is the direct involvement of the Liberal leadership in what I believe to be a totally inappropriate strategy to undo the University of Queensland bid. It is a strategy that does the Liberal leadership and the Liberal Party no credit whatsoever.

It is quite clear that the recommendations contained in the majority report are thoroughly predictable and are totally unsupported by the evidence. They are based on prejudice, presumption and, of course, on patronage. The so-called findings of the Liberal majority on this committee fly in the face of the facts, they fly in the face of the law and they fly in the face of political morality.

This grubby little inquiry is part of a concerted campaign to undermine the University of Queensland bid for the purchase of the Bond campus and adjoining land—some 450 hectares of prime real estate. Planning developments include eight hectares of high rise, 81 hectares of townhouses, 57 hectares of houses, as well as a research park and a commercial facility. And Liberal senators come in here in this pious and pompous manner and try to tell us this is a matter of national interest. What we have seen here is a process of political interference in negotiations between commercial bidders for the assets of a company that is in receivership. It is a totally inappropriate use of the Senate to do such a thing.

The whole matter has been prejudged from the start, as was indicated when this whole inquiry was announced in the pages of the Australian by Senator Hill on 6 September. Further prejudging was quite clearly demonstrated on 15 November in the Australian by Senator Tierney, when he indicated he thought the allegations that had been made by witnesses were damning. What we have here is an example of a group of people within the university who have come together. The main players are Professor Carmichael, Professor Goldsworthy, Professor Corkery and Professor Farrar, in his role as Acting Vice-Chancellor following the resolution that was carried at Bond unanimously by the staff that Professor Messel be removed as the Vice-Chancellor. Professor Messel, of course, is now involved in his role as executive chancellor. I mention also Xavier Clarke and, of course, Terry Gygar, the chief of staff from the office of the Vice-Chancellor.

This group was brought together upon the calling of tenders by the receiver. The group's strategies were on a two-pronged basis. The first was to form a consortium with private investors, such as BHP and News Ltd, that would act to bring together a corporate base to coordinate a bid for the lands at Bond. This consortium was coordinated by Peter Laver, the Director of Corporate Relations at BHP. This group was later joined with the Council of Bond University to access some $20.2 million from accumulated funds to act as a deposit and enable them to borrow funds needed for the purchase of the university lands.

The second phase of the inquiry was to destroy other bids by Queensland University, Monash University and Griffith University. To this end they issued a writ against the receivers and creditors, KPMG and the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan, to try to gain a lease and extract damages accordingly. It was very interesting to note that only last week EIE called in the $95 million debt as a result of some of their shenanigans in regard to the Supreme Court in Queensland.

It was interesting to note that the Bond contract with EIE was predicated on the assumption that that loan would become payable once a profit was declared by Bond University. This first occurred in the 1993-94 year when Bond posted a profit of $680,000. I understand that, as a result of that, Bond University Ltd was called upon to repay the loan, but has since ignored it. It can no longer ignore that call.

Bond University Ltd has made a profit of $6.7 million in the last year. As I say, only last Friday week a writ was issued against Bond University for the immediate payment of the $95 million subordinated debt. It is the irony of this strategy that it has backfired. BUL now faces the real prospect of receivership itself as a result of these quite wicked manoeuvres through this place and through the courts.

The second part of the strategy of the group was to frustrate the other bidders through trade practices action. This action was clearly undertaken to frustrate other bidders and failed yet again because the Trade Practices Commission came down against BUL.

The third and most insidious move was political approaches through the Senate. To understand just what those links are one has to understand who forms the backbone of the consortium and their direct links to the Liberal Party. One member of staff at Bond University is Professor Ashley Goldsworthy, Dean of the School of Business. Professor Goldsworthy's role in this plan has been clearly to coordinate the political interference in the sale.

He is a former Liberal Party National President and is currently a member of the National Executive of the Liberal Party, as is Senator Robert Hill, the mover of the motion which referred the sale of Bond to the committee.I understand that Professor Goldsworthy told a meeting of deans at Bond University that he, Professor Goldsworthy, had written the terms of reference moved by Senator Hill.

It should also be noted that, despite his prominent role, Professor Goldsworthy did not himself ever give evidence to this inquiry. But his involvement had been more indirect through the coordination of all other submissions through BUL. Another active participant has been Terry Gygar, Chief of Staff in the Office of the Vice-Chancellor of Bond. Mr Gygar is the former state Liberal Party member for Strafford in the Queensland parliament.

Amongst the submissions we received was a letter to Professor Goldsworthy from a prominent business person, who was—and I quote—`writing in response to Professor Goldsworthy's letter of 30 October 1995'. There is no doubt, and Professor Goldsworthy indicates in his letter to the alumni:

SPEECH.PARA: I have been asked to coordinate the task of encouraging supportive submissions from as broad and diverse a base as possible for the Senate inquiry next week.

So there is no doubt in my mind. There has been an insidious orchestration of submissions and political interference in the sale process has occurred. I do not think it is appropriate that people should be sanctimonious about the weight of so-called findings based on these submissions.

PARA.TAB: What we have here is a clear collusion of interests in such a way as there has been interference in a commercial transaction. The evidence has been ignored by the majority report. There has been no evidence whatsoever that public funds have been involved. There has been quite clearly an inappropriate use of the Senate. In my view, it is totally and completely wrong for the Senate to be involved in a political interference of the proper and legal and prudential duties of the receivers in regard to the disposal of private assets of a company that is in receivership.

Quite clearly in terms of the Trade Practices Commission's findings, there is no direct competition between Bond University Ltd and the University of Queensland. In my judgment, this inquiry has been an inappropriate use of the Senate. It is a totally morally bankrupt approach to politics in this country for the Senate to interfere in private commercial proceedings, which of course involve matters before the Supreme Court, and impinge upon the proper legal corporate law and the proper prudential responsibilities of receivers.
Debate (on motion by Senator Calvert) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Economics References Committee entitled Connecting you now: Telecommunications developments towards the year 2000, together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Before speaking to the report, I want to particularly thank the committee secretariat—our secretary, Rob Diamond, and researchers James Satrapa and Liz Williams—whose expertise and knowledge of modern technology in communications were invaluable in the writing of this report, which required a great degree of knowledge and involved a lot of technological terms. I congratulate them for the way they have reduced these technological terms so that the report has become more readable for members of the community who are interested in this area.

PARA.TAB: I also thank my colleagues on the committee, particularly the committee's deputy chairman, Bruce Childs, for their efforts in once again enabling our committee to table a unanimous report. It is some 18 months since the committee commenced this inquiry, and at that time two other major inquiries were being untaken. In this inquiry we considered the outcomes of these reports in making our own determinations. Our committee also completed two other urgent major inquiries while the telecommunications reference was being dealt with. It is intended that this report be distributed on the Internet, which is our contribution to the technological advances in communications.

The report is intended to reflect public debate about Australia's future communications requirements and how we are best able to meet those requirements now and in the future. The committee has tried to focus, however, not so much on the technology but on the people who will use it. This is a report about people and about the impact technology is having on society. We are becoming a different society as computers and advanced technology make their way into everyday use.

The committee's wide-ranging terms of reference cover the technological developments that will allow for better opportunities for communication. The terms of reference also address the consequences for Australian consumers and industry.While the possibilities of new communications are exciting, the committee quickly became aware that they will not be shared equally by all Australians. The committee has therefore paid particular attention to the needs of rural and remote communities, low income earners and the elderly to see whether their communication needs are being met. The committee considers it very important for public sector programs to coordinate their activities if they are to properly benefit the Australian community. The committee was also interested in the possibilities for work and the potential for industry in a new communications environment.

The committee is sufficiently concerned about the privacy implications arising from the use of converged communications technology to recommend extending the Privacy Act to the private sector. The committee is also concerned that the failure to address the security of electronic transactions could adversely affect Australian business.

The committee is keen to ensure that advances in information technology and telecommunications will not widen the gap between the information rich and the information poor. It therefore emphatically recommends that our diverse communities are able to actively involve themselves in designing their own communications environments.

Like other infrastructures, our future communications networks will serve as a framework to support social interaction, education, health, government services, business activities, recreation and our communication with the rest of the world. By neutralising the tyranny of distance, our future communications networks may even be the key to reversing the long slow population decline which has been affecting so many of our rural communities. I quote only one small part of our report which reports on a recent article in the Economist. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The death of distance as a determinant of the cost of communications will probably be the single most important economic force shaping society in the first half of the next century. The cost of using services may be determined on other criteria such as the speed and capacity of the line. How those effects will translate into benefits for customers in rural and remote Australia is yet to be seen, but a commitment from government and carriers to maintain the process of reducing costs is vital.

Many in the community are looking to government and to their elected representatives to play a leadership role in the new information and technology environment. The committee sees a continuing role for government as an information provider, a builder of infrastructure and a partner in industry development. There is also a role for government in ensuring that social objectives are met, that distribution of technology is fair and equitable, that it is affordable, that it is private and secure, that it reflects community needs and that the great majority of Australians can use new technology easily.

PARA.TAB: The timing of this report is important. General policy frameworks are in place, industry is well on track to repeat and indeed improve investment returns and major telecommunication reviews are now complete. The committee's recommendations will provide the basis for some important adjustments and finetuning at an earlier rather than later stage. Once again I particularly thank the members of the secretariat, who are here in the chamber for the tabling of this report, for the work they have done over a long period, and a very intense period, too, in getting this report tabled. I once again thank them on behalf of the committee and I commend this report to all senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Calvert) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the additional submissions received by the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee for its arts education inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Neal and the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report No. 341 entitled Financial reporting for the Commonwealth: Towards greater transparency and accountability, and I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the tabling speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The tabling speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The recommendations in this report, if adopted by the Government, would result in the most significant changes to financial reporting for the Commonwealth since Federation.

In this report, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts maintains the momentum for moving the Commonwealth away from its outdated cash accounting system into the accrual accounting culture. Australian business, of course, has long operated in the accrual accounting environment.

Accrual accounting recognises revenue and expenses in the accounting period in which they are incurred, irrespective of whether cash is paid or received. Accrual accounts for government departments would include depreciation on assets, employee entitlements such as long service leave and the value of goods and services received free from the Commonwealth or other bodies. Accrual information better reflects the true cost of providing services.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics advised the Committee that, by the turn of the century, the International Monetary Fund will be requiring accrual based information from statistically advanced nations. The recommendations in Report 341, if adopted, would ensure that Australia is well placed to meet international requirements for accrual information on the financial position of the Commonwealth by the year 2000.

In 1992, the then Minister for Finance, the Hon Ralph Willis MP, announced that the financial reporting framework for Commonwealth agencies would be recast to reflect accrual accounting concepts. For the 1994-95 financial year, all government budget-sector agencies have submitted annual financial statements on an accrual basis—most for the first time.

But this is just the first step! Government agencies cannot be expected to take accrual accounting and reporting seriously if they are still required to budget on a cash basis and continue to be funded by cash appropriations.
The challenge now is to move Commonwealth financial management—including the Commonwealth Budget cycle—into the accrual environment.
The Committee takes up the challenge in this report.

Building on the recommendations contained in its Report 338, Accrual Accounting—A Cultural Change, the Committee proposes in Report 341 that the accrual reports of government agencies—including government business enterprises—should be consolidated into an accrual based whole of government report for the Commonwealth.

To comprehend the significance of whole of government reports it is important to understand what they are. Quite simply whole of government reports are the financial statements of the government as a single entity. They are derived from consolidating the accrual based financial statements of individual agencies which collectively represent the government.

Whole of government reports would show, among other things, the total revenues and expenses of government operations, the value of assets available to the government and the total obligations of the government, in a concise and easily readable format. This information is not currently prepared on an accrual basis for the government as a single entity.

Whole of government reporting for the Commonwealth will make the financial position of the Commonwealth more transparent. In particular, since whole of government reports will reveal the Commonwealth's assets and liabilities—and not just cash flows—it will be immediately apparent if the government of the day is running down the asset base of the Commonwealth to fund recurrent spending, to the cost of future generations of Australians.
In Report 341 the Committee also makes recommendations which give guidance on contentious technical issues that will need to be sorted out before whole of government reporting can be implemented.

Report 341 proposes the preparation of audited whole of government reports for the 1997-98 financial year. Leading up to this it is proposed that the key agencies, the Department of Finance and the Australian National Audit Office, develop a model and perform trials for the consolidation process. I understand that this action has already begun.

But the preparation of whole of government reports is not the final stage in the transition from a cash to an accrual culture. There is little point in preparing the latest and greatest financial reports for the Commonwealth unless there is also a mechanism for feeding this information into financial planning and, ultimately, into the Budget.
If the Commonwealth produces excellent whole of government reports that sit on the shelf, then the whole exercise will have been a horrendous waste of administrative resources.
In this report, the Committee proposes a financial reporting framework that ties the Budget process into the accrual environment.

At the moment, the form and content of the Budget Papers is at the discretion of governments and their advisers and there are no plans to move the Budget process away from cash reporting. If the Government ignores the recommendations in Report 341, the media and the community will continue to focus undue attention on the cash deficit or surplus. As one American economist has pointed out, the budget deficit is `a number in search of a concept'. Evidence to the Committee's inquiry into fiscal responsibility legislation pointed out that cash aggregates such as the budget deficit or surplus have little meaning and are not sensible fiscal policy targets.

It is just not sensible for the Commonwealth Budget cycle to continue on a cash basis once government agencies have moved to accrual reporting and once the Commonwealth itself has started to publish accrual based whole of government reports.

There has been enough confusion about the Commonwealth's financial position when all the Commonwealth's financial reports have been prepared on the same basis. The prospect of having the Department of Finance publish a set of accrual numbers for the Commonwealth and the Treasury publishing another set of cash numbers for the Commonwealth—and the public trying to understand why the numbers don't add up—is clearly one to be avoided.
In Report 341, the Committee recommends that budget appropriations, forward estimates and the Budget process itself should move into the accrual accounting environment by the year 2000.

In the Committee's view, it is important that the Parliament plays a key role in determining the form and content of financial reports tabled. After all, such reports are prepared principally for Parliament's use.

Accordingly, the Committee also recommends that the Government introduce legislation to be called the Fiscal Reporting Act in which Parliament can determine the type of financial reports to be presented by governments.

The Fiscal Reporting Act—as envisaged by the Committee in Report 341—would formalise the tabling of the Budget Papers, the Treasurer's Mid-year Review and the Actual Budget Outcome. The Committee recommends the preparation of two additional Budget cycle reports:
a pre-budget fiscal strategy statement (to be tabled three months prior to the Budget); and
a `user-friendly' condensed version of the Budget Papers that would be easily understood by the general public.
But more importantly, the Fiscal Reporting Act would be the vehicle by which the Parliament could require the Budget cycle reports to be prepared as accrual based whole of government reports.

The Committee has also examined the possibility of enhanced Parliamentary scrutiny of the Commonwealth's financial reports. At the moment, Parliamentary committees examine the financial performance of government departments and agencies—but not the Commonwealth as a whole.

The Committee recommends that whole of government reports produced by the Department of Finance should stand referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. The Committee also recommends that the Budget Papers should stand referred to a parliamentary committee to be established for this purpose under the proposed Fiscal Reporting Act.

Mr President, by heeding the recommendations in this report, the Government has an opportunity to ensure that Australia is at the forefront of the international trend to accrual reporting for governments.

Mr President, in relation to international financial reporting practice, the Committee was fortunate to be briefed at length by experts from Canada, New Zealand and the United States of America. I would like to place on the record the Committee's appreciation of the special assistance we received from officers of these jurisdictions.

Also on behalf of the Committee, I would like to thank all those who contributed to the financial reporting inquiries by making written submissions or giving evidence at public hearings. I would especially like to thank the observers for these inquiries—George Carter from the Department of Finance and Lynne O'Brien from the Australian National Audit Office, and, as always, the Secretariat.
I commend the report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Calvert) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report No. 342 entitled The administration of specific purpose payments: A focus on outcomes, and I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the tabling speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The tabling speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Report 342 is the result of the Committee's inquiry into the administration of Commonwealth-state agreements for Specific Purpose Payments held between 1994 and 1995.

A central feature of Australia's federal fiscal arrangements is the flow of Commonwealth financial assistance to state and local governments. As you will know, Commonwealth financial assistance to the states is divided into two categories: Specific Purpose Payments, or SPPs, and General Purpose Payments. In 1995-96, the Commonwealth paid out approximately $18.3 billion in accordance with the 90 odd SPP agreements between the Commonwealth and the state governments, local governments, universities and non-government schools.

One of the striking features about these SPPs is their diversity. They range in value from programs with a Commonwealth contribution of less than half a million dollars per annum to those with Commonwealth contributions of over $3 billion per annum; and from one off grants to 10 year programs. Administrative structures and arrangements also vary greatly, depending on the size and complexity of the program and the degree of involvement by the Commonwealth government, other levels of government and non-government agencies.

In the last decade, reviews at the Commonwealth and state level have highlighted considerable potential for improvements in the administration and structure of SPPs and in the effectiveness and efficiency with which SPP funded services are delivered to the public. The weight of evidence prompted the JCPA to establish its own inquiry, which has culminated in this report.

The JCPA made an early decision to confine its inquiry to the administration of SPPs and avoid entering debate on the appropriate balance of SPP and GPP payments to the states or the merits of individual SPP objectives. These issues are matters of policy and are well canvassed at the regular Council of Australian Governments (COAG) and Commonwealth-state ministerial meetings.

Despite arguments to the contrary from some state governments, the Committee believes that SPPs are a legitimate vehicle for ensuring that Commonwealth policies and priorities are implemented, even if this is done by complementing or `topping up' existing state government services. As such, the Commonwealth should have the primary responsibility for setting the broad policy and national objectives for SPPs.

The Committee believes, however, that the Commonwealth should shift its focus from the micro-management of SPPs and leave state governments with greater responsibility for service delivery planning. The trade off for granting the states greater autonomy in service delivery planning is that the Commonwealth will place a correspondingly greater emphasis on measuring service delivery performance.

The Committee became concerned that too few SPP agreements clearly articulate what the SPPs are designed to achieve, in terms of impact on the community. The result is often a continuing preoccupation with the activity associated with SPPs, rather than with the results of the activity. The Committee has recommended that all SPPs should have concise statements of what the SPP is trying to achieve, expressed in terms of measurable outcomes. Associated performance indicators should also be specified in SPP agreements.

Correspondingly, and importantly, state governments and other parties receiving SPP funds should be held accountable for their performance towards meeting program objectives, or what they achieve, rather than so much on how they achieve the objectives. However, the Committee believes that input controls such as maintenance of effort clauses, matched funding agreements and caps on the proportion of funds that can be spent on administration should not be phased out of SPP agreements before performance agreements are phased in.

Furthermore, most SPP agreements will need a more sophisticated framework of sanctions in place for non-compliance with the terms of SPP agreements before the Commonwealth can give full responsibility for service delivery planning to states. Such sanctions might include a temporary return to a greater Commonwealth involvement in service delivery planning and oversight.

While the continuous collection and assessment of performance data should be the main way of measuring SPP performance, the Committee believes it important for SPP administrators to be subject to external scrutiny by independent evaluators. The Auditor-General is the Commonwealth's major external reviewer and has a mandate to conduct performance audits of public sector entities and programs. However, the mandate does not extend to allowing the Auditor-General to evaluate the performance of the state agencies also involved in administering SPPs.
The former Commonwealth Auditor-General has argued that Commonwealth Auditors-General should be able to conduct holistic performance audits that `follow the Commonwealth dollar through'.

Such audits would best be performed by Commonwealth and state Auditors-General conducting the audits with joint teams. There is the practical difficulty, however, that not all state Auditors-General have the same performance audit mandates. The Committee believes that the ultimate goal should be uniform audit legislation in all Australian jurisdictions. A less ambitious, but more achievable goal, which the Committee has recommended, is that all audit legislation be harmonised to allow Auditors-General to conduct joint performance audits of SPPs.

In the short term, the Committee sees greater potential for coordinated audits between the Commonwealth Auditor-General and those state Auditors-General who have a mandate to conduct performance audits. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended that the Auditor-General investigate the possibility of conducting coordinated performance audits of SPPs with state Auditors-General.

Mr President, the Committee has recommended major changes in the way that the Commonwealth acquits the many hundreds of millions of dollars that it provides to the state governments, universities and non-government schools each year as part of SPP agreements.

Let me state at the outset, the Committee believes that it is fundamental for the Commonwealth to be assured that SPP funds are spent on the basis on which they were allocated. However, the Committee believes that it is possible to streamline SPP financial accountability mechanisms and still allow a full acquittal of SPP funds. In essence, the Committee believes that the Commonwealth should be satisfied with the audited and appropriately annotated annual financial statements of SPP fund recipients for SPP acquittal processes.

The advantages of this model are numerous. The agency receiving SPP funding does not have to prepare separate accounts for the Commonwealth, the audit task is not duplicated and the Commonwealth can be assured that the statements will be prepared promptly. There will thus be a savings in time, effort and costs and one set of documents that satisfy the financial accountability requirements of all parties.

On a related matter, the Committee has recommended that Commonwealth departments administering SPPs should liaise with the Department of Finance to determine whether SPP payments are being made on an optimal schedule and dates to minimise the Commonwealth's recourse to short term borrowing. Such a recommendation has the potential to save the Commonwealth considerable sums of money, as badly timed transfers can place pressure on the Commonwealth's cash holdings and contribute to the need for short term borrowings to cover any cash shortfalls. This recommendation compliments recommendations made in an earlier report by the Committee—Report 340, concerning cash management in the Commonwealth.

Mr President, the Committee believes that it is important that both the public and service deliverers are aware of the Commonwealth's financial contribution to the delivery of SPP funded services. In the Committee's experience it is all too easy for the Commonwealth's contribution to joint Commonwealth-state programs to be ignored. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended that all SPP agreements should include arrangements to ensure that the Commonwealth's contribution is recognised in application documentation, approval announcements, media releases, official openings and other program publicity.

The Committee acknowledges that implementation of some of its recommendations will not be easy, particularly for the large, ongoing SPPs in the health, education and community services areas. Reforms will be gradual, not just because of the difficulties in measuring outcomes and performance, but also because of the impossibility of quickly reorganising complex systems without service delivery suffering.

Despite the practical difficulties, it is important that the momentum for reform continues, particularly as the political will to do so exists. The Committee believes that its recommendations, if adopted, will ensure that the momentum is not lost and that SPP administration and accountability, as a whole is improved. Most importantly, those individuals or groups in the community who receive SPP funded services, of what ever form, should receive more efficient and effective service, delivered in the most economical way possible.

Mr President, in conclusion, I would like to express the Committee's thanks to those people who contributed to the review by preparing submissions and giving evidence at the public hearing. I would also like to thank the staff of the Secretariat for assisting the Committee in preparing the Report. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report No. 343, titled Tax law improvement: A watching brief, and I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the tabling speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The tabling speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: In February this year it was announced that the JCPA would be keeping a watching brief on the work of the Tax Law Improvement Project—this report is the first tabled as a result of that brief.
The Tax Law Improvement Project is engaged in the task of completely rewriting Australia's income tax legislation.

It is a task of national significance and one which the Joint Committee of Public Accounts supports. Indeed the Improvement Project was established in response to one of the recommendations in the Committee's Report 326, An Assessment of Tax, which was tabled in Parliament in November 1993.

Report 343, contains the Committee's comments on evidence taken at a public hearing held in October this year. At this hearing 17 witnesses from government, from tax and accounting bodies, and from academia were invited to give their views on a range of issues relating to tax law improvement.

Our intention in presenting this report is not to call into question the work of the Improvement Project, much of which has been strongly supported in the Parliament and the wider community. Rather, our interest is to ensure that the opportunities we now have to reform our tax law come to fruition.
There are three main themes which emerged at our hearing and which are reflected in the report. These are:
the scope of the terms of reference for the Improvement Project;
the way in which the rewritten law should be delivered to Parliament and implemented; and
the need for a separate forum to examine matters of tax policy.
I would like to touch briefly on each of these matters.

It has been said that the capacity of the Improvement Project to produce simplified tax law is limited by its inability to examine and propose changes to tax policy. Since the beginning its mandate has been to re-express, in simpler language, the law as it currently stands—not to review current tax policy.

After weighing the evidence, the Committee believes that the mandate of the Improvement Project is appropriate. To encumber the Project with a broader responsibility at this stage would jeopardise the chances of producing better tax law within the sort of timeframe set for the Project.
The second main theme discussed at the hearing was the delivery schedule for the rewritten legislation.

The Project Team is proposing to deliver the new law to Parliament progressively, as it is drafted, and to seek progressive implementation, with each instalment of the rewritten law commencing for the income year beginning after Royal Assent.

An alternative view, which has some currency within the tax industry, is that a deferred commencement date should be set for the rewritten law at the completion of the Project—the so called `big bang' approach.

There are valid arguments in favour of both approaches, but on balance the Committee considers that progressive implementation of the rewritten legislation is a better option than deferring commencement of the legislation until the conclusion of the project.
The final and most contentious issue emerging from the hearing was in relation to the need for a separate forum to consider tax policy issues.

The evidence we received indicated widespread frustration in the tax and business communities about the way in which tax policy has evolved and is debated in Australia. This frustration generated a number or views about the need for an alternative tax policy forum, about how such a forum might be constituted and about what such a forum might consider.
Although the Committee is sympathetic to the concerns underpinning these views, in the end, the Committee does not support the calls for a new external forum for the development of tax policy.
The development of tax policy is, and will always remain, a government's prerogative. The Treasury is rightly the focus of tax policy development in Australia.
This is not to say that Treasury always gets it right, nor that tax policy should be determined in a vacuum.

We received evidence which was strongly critical of the way in which Treasury deals with stakeholders in the tax system. It seems to the Committee that Treasury could improve its performance in this area by adopting the sort of open and inclusive consultative processes used by the Improvement Project in its work.

Even though we believe Treasury is the appropriate body to convene and direct any consideration of the strategic direction of tax policy, there is a legitimate role for Parliament to play in ensuring that issues emerging from the work of the Improvement Project are given close consideration.

To this end the Committee intends to continue its watching brief in the area of tax law improvement. While I expect that most tax policy matters emerging from the Improvement Project would, in the normal course of events, be taken up by Treasury and the ATO, the Committee will follow up any significant matters which appear not to be receiving appropriate attention.
Mr President, opportunities for reform are rare and it is important that the momentum for change initiated by the establishment of the Improvement Project is not only maintained, but built upon.

The Improvement Project shows every sign of achieving the objectives set for it. This is to the credit of all involved in the Project. I would like to particularly acknowledge the efforts of the Project Director, Brian Nolan, who is performing a difficult job with distinction.
Nevertheless, the Committee agrees with those who have argued that the Improvement Project should be seen as the first step in a more ambitious reform of the tax law.

Ultimately a tax simplification program must focus on more than rewriting the Tax Act, it must seek to review tax policy and simplify both the full body of tax law, and the administrative systems underpinning the law.
This broader goal is the challenge which will confront governments over the next decade.
I commend the report to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Senator Troeth had moved by way of amendment:

PARA.TAB: At end of motion, add:

PROCTEXT.PARA: ", but the Senate condemns the failure of the Government's measures to assist young unemployed people".

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was adjourned last evening, I was talking about the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill (No. 2) 1995 and what we feel is the ham-fisted attempt to target money to `those who need it most'—in the government's words—which is the government's usual justification. I had mentioned that the amendment the government is suggesting will not result in any increased fairness. It will only make people find more expensive rental accommodation so as to be able to access rental assistance and have slightly more money to meet their needs. Therefore, I had foreshadowed that we would be opposing schedule 7 of the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill (No. 2) 1995 in the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: Another concern with this bill is the amendment under schedule 2. That amendment takes 15-year-olds on special benefits allowance and moves them on to the youth training allowance. I would like to know what the difference is in the amount of each of these benefits. If the minister is not able to provide me with that, perhaps we can ask that further in the committee stage.

We have concerns with schedules 1, 2 and 4 of the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill (No. 3) 1995. Schedule 1 is about extended deeming. It seems to be a fairly neutral change in itself. But there seems to be the incongruous situation where valuation of investments for the purpose of taking the interest as income can be different for two people with exactly the same investments; this can occur because they can be valued at different moments in time. Therefore, there is no certainty for people to know how much of their income will be lost in amounts of deemed income. Approximately 200,000 pensioners will have their rates reduced because of deemed income from their investments. I would like to know how many students and youth will be affected in this same way.

I would also question the amendment in schedule 2, which is to keep recipients of the youth training allowance who get sick for more than 13 weeks on that allowance, instead of transferring them to the sickness allowance. I would like to know what the difference in rates is between the two—if not at this stage, perhaps in the committee stage.

I have mentioned my concerns at the amalgamation of jobsearch and newstart into one, under schedule 4. I believe that it is important for the government to keep a rigorous collection of statistics of the success of case management based on the length of the person's unemployment. I do not believe that it should be easier for the government to lump all unemployed people together, as it may blur long-term unemployment issues and special management of long-term unemployed people in the future.

The definitions of paid work, the type of training that long-term unemployed people can receive, the different styles of paid work they can access from self-employment, collective, cooperative or community based work and voluntary work need to be reassessed by the government for long-term unemployed people. Much effort is expended trying to get long-term unemployed people back into the full-time work force, instead of dealing also with their changing needs and new ways of looking at the concepts of `leisure' and `work'.

At another level, I am concerned that this amalgamation will lead to a further fudging of the statistics, blurring any true analysis of the success of case management. People working in this area would know of the number of questions I have asked as to how much the government can tell us about the success of case management; and the answer is that they can tell us very little.

Putting people into training for 13 to 16 weeks is sometimes of more benefit to a government who can claim that moving people from newstart to jobsearch allowance is solving the unemployment problem, rather than benefiting the people concerned. We need to deal with the unemployment problem by creating alternative definitions of work, looking at the needs of the whole person instead of seeing a person who is not in full-time work as idle, and targeting services with a flexibility that the current structure of case management does not permit but has the potential to provide.

I would like to emphasise here that this does not mean that we are saying case management is wrong. We are saying that the government needs to know what they are trying to achieve with case management and should actually be working on outcomes and putting their resources into outcomes rather than putting resources into the squeaky wheel. I urge the government to take this to task. I also foreshadow that we will be opposing schedule 4 of the youth training allowance bill No. 3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing this debate I would like to thank the senators from all sides of the parliament who have contributed to it. The bills that are before the parliament and are to be addressed today are the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bills Nos 2 and 3 for 1995. As has already been discussed, these are mainly mechanical bills to reflect changes that have been considered and approved by the Senate over the last few days to the Social Security Act. This will ensure that the youth training allowance is similar in nature to other Commonwealth income support.

PARA.TAB: Before I address the bills, I would like to make some response to some of the comments that have been made here in the chamber. I would like to state that during the time of this government the number of unemployed 15- to 19-year-olds has fallen substantially. It has fallen from a level of 150,000 when the government came to office in 1983 to now around 90,00, a drop of 40 per cent in teenage unemployment. Of course a lot of other things have happened over those 12 1/2 years as well. These days 15- to 19-year-olds are by and large not in the work force. They are at school or in TAFE training or higher education. Secondary participation has increased from around one in three going on to year 12 when the government came to office to three out of every four going on to year 12 now.

Commonwealth growth funding for the TAFE and training sector has also seen participation increase in that sector and the higher education undergraduate population has increased by over 50 per cent. These are indeed quite significant changes. This has happened because young people these days need additional skills to be able to enter the work force. The kinds of unskilled jobs that were available to 15- to 19-year-olds in the past, particularly the 15-year-old school leavers, have simply disappeared. To enter the work force in the 1990s young people require more than just a basic year 10 level.

I would also like to refer to my government's achievements with apprenticeships and traineeships. The federal Labor government has been very successful during its period in office in seeing the labour force grow. The labour force has increased by around 25 per cent from some 6 1/2 million to around eight million. At the same time, the number of apprentices and trainees commencing has also increased.

I note particularly that the opposition should be aware that when they left office apprenticeship and traineeship commencements were of the order of 35,000. In the last year they numbered some 70,000, so we have doubled the performance of the opposition, whereas the teenage population has increased by only a little over 20 per cent.

The government has introduced a range of other measures, including Austudy, Working Nation's youth training initiative and the recently announced jobs pathway guarantee program. These initiatives are delivering more opportunities than ever before for young people to participate in education and training which will lead to full-time employment. The youth training initiative is particularly important for those young people who leave school, possibly before they complete their studies, and experience difficulty in finding work. The YTI, as it is called, provides individual assistance through case management to encourage young people in this situation to undertake full-time study or to participate in approved training and jobsearch activities.

However, the number of young people unemployed is still too many and is concentrated particularly in some regions. That is why the government has adopted a structure of area consultative committees, along with the case managers regime, to ensure that the attack on unemployment, particularly on youth unemployment, is concentrated on those regions where greatest assistance is needed. In addition, 52 specialist youth liaison positions have been established and placed in the Department of Employment, Education and Training regions with the highest youth need.

I note that there is an amendment to the motion. The government opposes that amendment, on the grounds contained in the remarks I have just delivered. I commend these bills to the Senate and thank the senators who participated in the debate for their contribution.
