TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the government's motion and we continue to support the position that we advocated in the chamber here a few days ago which was designed to benefit Australian students.

PARA.TAB: There are two principal matters involved in this debate. The first is the government's attempt to force an accelerated repayment of HECS upon existing and past students. We estimate—in fact, we have had the advantage of the government figures in this regard, so I can say that they estimate—that potentially some 800,000 Australian students are affected by the government's proposed change. It seeks to change the rules on students in relation to repayment of a HECS debt without the approval of those students. We argued in this place that that was unfair and, therefore, that it should be resisted.

Unfortunately, the history of this government has been that it seeks to change the rules on students in relation to HECS, it seeks to lower the threshold and it seeks to force earlier repayment. It is not surprising that Australian students have become disillusioned about these continual breaches of promise.

We see no reason why we should back down on this. It is really just akin to another tax. Students entered into a compact with government whereby, in undertaking higher education, they agreed to accept the burden of part of the cost of that higher education, which becomes a debt—the higher contribution debt—and they agreed to repay that debt on certain terms and conditions. The government should not then subsequently seek through legislation to change the rules to unilaterally and retrospectively change the student obligations. We have stood by Australian students, both existing and past students, in this debate and against the government's attempt to disadvantage them in this way, and we continue to stand on that position.

The second issue related to the government's attempt to change the eligibility rule for HECS from permanent residence to citizenship. Again, we said this was unfair as it applied to those current permanent residents in Australia. It is much the same principle, but in this case when you enter Australia on certain terms and conditions we could not see why those terms and conditions, as they applied to the benefit of a HECS funded education, should not be changed unilaterally. We see no reason to depart from that position either.

With regard to future students, we think a different situation applies. We can argue about what is the appropriate level of HECS repayment of HECS debt or the terms of repayment for future students. Although we may in this instance have different views from that of the government, nevertheless, we think there is a different principle when future students decide to accept the offer of substantial publicly funded higher education on different terms and conditions from the past. Students either accept the offer of support from government or they do not. That is why we think that is fundamentally different from seeking to change the rules on students who have already been educated or are being educated on certain terms and conditions.

Similarly, we think the same principle applies in relation to those entering this country. If they enter this country knowing that HECS eligibility is based on citizenship rather than permanent residency, that is the basis upon which they take the HECS opportunity. It is fundamentally different from those who have entered on different terms and conditions.

We are not talking about very large sums of money in this instance. I understand that in relation to the accelerated repayment of HECS for next year we are talking of a figure just over $8 million. That is $8 million when we look at the public contribution to higher education of around $5 billion.

One would not have thought the Senate's decision to stand by students in this instance could therefore logically have any effect upon the government's capacity to fund higher education overall. It obviously has no relevance at all. Unfortunately, Minister Crean has entered upon a path of political blackmail in that he has said unless the Senate passes this bill and inflicts this extra burden on existing and past students, he will refuse to fund additional places that are necessary in higher education. The interesting thing is that this government had already made the promise of those additional places.

TALK.START.PARA: —Took the kudos.
—It took the kudos. It made promises in the lead-up to the May budget and in the course of the May budget.
—Conditional upon—

—There were no conditions attached to it. If you read the minister's press release of 17 May when he details the additional places for Queensland and sets out which university receives which places, you will see there was no condition attached to it whatsoever. The minister might like to table Minister Crean's press release of 17 May and he will see that that is the case.

PARA.TAB: The government took the kudos and finally acknowledged it was undersupplying places to areas of population growth in Australia—in particular, Queensland, Western Australia and a small number of places in northern Tasmania. These were areas that had been disadvantaged relative to the rest of Australia. I remind you, Madam Temporary Chairman, that we have been calling for the provision of those places for a long time. Finally, the government determined it would meet that public obligation and announced those places. It attached no conditions to that whatsoever.

As I said, we have this exercise of political blackmail whereby the minister now finds it politically convenient to argue that unless the Senate in effect charges existing students more, that allows the government to legitimately break its promise to future students to provide them with the places that are necessary.

That is an appalling argument. To try to, in effect, set existing and past students against future students and to seek to tell future students they are going to be penalised unless present and past students accelerate the repayment of their HECS debt is an appalling abuse of Australian students. The minister should be ashamed of the grubby political tactic that he has engaged in in this instance.

The figure for next year, as I said, is just over $8 million. The government will gross it up over a period of years, but we are talking about places that are to be provided next year. In the case of Queensland, it is an extra 2,000 places. An amount of $8 million will come in from the HECS contribution if this bill were passed in the form that the government wishes. Really, it is not a large sum of money in relation to the provision of extra places.

Because the government has realised all of a sudden that Queensland is too politically sensitive, it has now changed its position from that which it was threatening in the lead-up to last weekend and during last weekend, which is that it would cut Queensland places. It has now, as I understand it—and Senator Cook will no doubt confirm this—decided it will not cut Queensland places. The latest threat from Minister Crean which he put out to the press yesterday was to provide the places in Queensland and instead to cut them from South Australia and Victoria. That is equally appalling.

The reason it is appalling is not only that it breaks another promise to South Australia and Victoria, but also there is a significant unmet demand in the southern states. In fact, Victoria has the highest unmet demand in Australia. There has been an historically high participation rate but there is still a very high unmet demand. So not only is this government not going to meet an obligation in relation to that unmet demand, but also it is going to worsen the situation by reducing the number of places.

Madam Deputy President, you will remember that, when the government made its promise in the budget to Queensland, it said that future expected places, the so-called pipeline places, in Victoria would be abandoned. That was bad enough in itself, but it is now going further and threatening to withdraw a further 4,000 university places from Victoria—another exercise in political blackmail. Queensland is too difficult because the government has a whole series of seats that are threatened at the next election in Queensland. So let us quarantine Queensland and take the pain out on the southern states of Victoria and South Australia.

This government may not understand that, due to the incompetence of previous state Labor governments in particular, both South Australia and Victoria were practically bankrupted. We now have Liberal and coalition governments in those states trying to rebuild the economies in ways that produce more high value added jobs. The success of that economic strategy initiative is very dependent upon the higher education sector in South Australia and Victoria educating enough graduates to contribute to the economic restructuring and, therefore, the rebuilding of wealth in both South Australia and Victoria.

So not only is it a breach of promise to South Australians and Victorians but it would significantly undermine the capacity of those states to reinvigorate and rebuild their economies. It is hard to imagine anything this government could do that would be more counterproductive to the interests of the populations of South Australia and Victoria than what it is threatening to do in this instance.

I suspect what will happen—and we got a hint of this from Minister Crean last week as well—is that the minister will decide it is too politically difficult to cut places from South Australia and Victoria, so he will move to his third phase of the political blackmail strategy and that will be to threaten to withdraw research funding from the universities. In an interview on Brisbane radio last Friday he said that was another option that was open to him. The minister has been, I understand, communicating with the universities now threatening to do this in order that they might apply greater pressure on us to change our position and to endorse his requirement for earlier repayment of HECS by existing and past Australian students.

It has been an appalling bit of politics all round. I reiterate that there is no relationship between the government's obligation to provide adequate university places in this country and to pay for them in the same way that it pays for all undergraduate university places. This bill does not refer to that at all. This bill is about other matters, such as the earlier repayment of HECS and changing the test from permanent residency to citizenship. There is nothing in this bill that links those two matters together.

The government must stand firm on its promise on places. If it does not, the coalition certainly will and will fund them in the way that we fund all other places in Australia. At this last minute the government ought to recognise that it has no right to seek to change the rules on students in the way that it is seeking to do within this bill and withdraw its proposal which is so unfair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This chamber should insist on the opposition's amendments to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) which would grandfather the increases to HECS repayments, the lowering of HECS repayment thresholds and the reclassification in relation to Australian residents so that current students will not be affected. An incredible amount of codswallop has been talked about in the other place in relation to the changes that were made in this place. There was also the most appalling examples of divide and rule in an attempt to set one part of the university system against the other by saying that one group must be responsible for accepting cuts so that another group can get the funding that they need. I think that is atrocious.

PARA.TAB: In the last couple of years we have noticed levels of underspending in a number of government areas, and the disguised cuts would indicate that the government is clearly responsible for any decisions it made in spending or not spending. It is not this chamber's decision not to support funding for higher education places. There is clearly a need in terms of research. It is felt, as indicated, that at least a couple of hundred million dollars is needed to just keep up with what has happened in the depreciation in research. There is an implied threat that research might be the next to go, and that is appalling. That would not be a clever thing to do. Allowing that kind of education capital to go down will not save money in the long run.

An example of the level of debate in the other place in relation to these measures is what happened when a letter was read out by the member for Adelaide, Ms Worth, from the Students Association of the University of Adelaide which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Crean
I present these petitions and form letters to you which express the anger and dissatisfaction of the students of the University of Adelaide with the Federal government's Higher Education policies.
Students are fundamentally opposed to the introduction of up front fees in any form and deplore ALP attacks on permanent residents as continued student activism has clearly demonstrated.
The member for Forde (Ms Crawford) then interjected:
The up-front fees are against non-Australian students.

We have heard a lot in the press about recent statements made by the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) regarding political correctness in relation to multiculturalism, accepting people from other countries and so on. I am just wondering about the level this debate went to in the other place.

PARA.TAB: As I say, the whole approach of setting one group of students against another and making them responsible for the government's proposals to cut funding in any way in higher education is disgraceful. It is time that senators stood up and said that it is not right. If the government is deciding to cut funding for extra places, that is their decision. The fact that there is not even more demand for places is largely due to the government making it a Hobson's choice for many students in relation to surviving through university. The fact that the government are even talking about decreasing in some areas the standards for acceptance in universities indicates that they may have gone too far.

Basically, I think it is disgraceful. Senators are doing the right thing in relation to these amendments. We obviously agree these amendments were not the strongest position this chamber could take, but they were reached by a consensus amongst all except the government. Therefore, we believe they are worthwhile pursuing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is looking pretty lonely and desperate in this battle. As Senator Margetts has pointed out, the rest of this chamber is insistent upon this legislation, which has passed this place in this form. Senator Hill pointed out in his contribution the extent to which the government has moved about, how the minister has made threats and how various lackeys of the minister have come up with a description of what is going to happen, what threats will be taken out, how students will be hounded from one part of the country to another—these threats are not being suggested metaphorically but actually—how places will be denied to some students and granted to others, and how there is great potential for the minister to finally back down and to recognise the political expediency of not denying promised places to any students but rather cutting research funding in a way which is perhaps not quite so public but still just as effective in denying this government's obligation to meet and properly fund educational needs in

SPEECH.PARA: Australia.

PARA.TAB: We have had a number of figures bandied about in relation to this. Minister Schacht was in the chamber the other day attempting to blind us with science and to convince us with some statistics. The statistics were never based on any contribution from the government which enabled us to recognise fact and reality; they seemed more to be statistics which were convenient and numbers which were becoming bigger as the minister's eyes grew wider. An attempt was made to find a number which would impress us.

I rely on the number which is directly related to how many students there are in this category and the percentage of increase that the government would propose to accelerate their debt repayment. The number mentioned by Senator Hill was probably closer to reality—and, in this first instance, that means around about $8 million to the government.

We are told that this is of great desperate need and that it is a number so important that students may be denied their opportunity to engage in tertiary education. I am impressed by the coincidence—it seems a strange coincidence to me, but it is a useful one to think about—that this number is very close to another number: $7 million. That number was used in quite a cavalier fashion without a lot of responsibility and thought attached to it. The government seemed to be quite ready to depart with $7 million to assist one of the world's richest men to engage in a speculative project and to help him spend some money on some sort of Disneyland project in Sydney.

If the government can quite easily fund $7 million to help Rupert Murdoch in his latest project in Sydney, why is the government spending so much time and effort blustering and flustering about $8 million which may be denied them on behalf of an investment on Australia's future through Australia's tertiary education system? How can one number be of such huge consequence and another one get almost irrelevant attention?

Of course, we have heard and seen in recent days in this place such a fuss made about the government's funding of legal challenges of one of its colleagues. The government is quite prepared to depart with taxpayers' money on the one hand, but it is being so mingy about directing money towards the recognised need to fund university places for Australia's students on the other hand.

So I think these coincidences should be noted. I think the government should be condemned for trying to tag the rightful provision of student places for the benefit of the whole of Australia—because, after all, it is the whole of Australia which benefits greatly from any investment in our education system. It should be condemned for being so parsimonious in relation to recognising its rightful obligation to properly provide for Australia's education, yet being so cavalier with handing out money for other propositions which have a political expediency attached to them.

The Senate finds itself in a situation where it has to be impressed by the threats of the minister, it has to suddenly change its mind and depart from the principles which the Senate has upheld or it has to insist on the amendments which were passed in the Senate. The government has not given in the chamber today any reason for the Senate to change its motion. It has offered no explanation for retracting its position. All we have seen over the past few days, before the government returned with the rejection we have before us, has only confirmed our position because no real reason has been attached to this change.

The reasons put forward in the media and in the other place have had no principle attached to them. The expediency is a purely political one. There is no rationale attached to the reasons put forward. We have had a desperate plea to adopt this measure for the reason that the budget is limited. The coincidence that I mentioned questions that. We also heard the excuse that because places have been promised to Queensland university students they should be funded by other students.

I remind the Senate that this was a budget measure, announced at budget time. I remind the Senate that the Democrats stated their opposition at that time and issued press statements soon after. We had no reaction from the minister for some months. I think it was 21 September before I saw mention in the press of the minister being concerned about how this measure would affect plans to provide extra places. But since that time there has not been the degree of panic and threat that we have seen in the past few days.

There has been plenty of time to recognise the effect of what the Senate was proposing to do. I must acknowledge that, around the same time we did, the coalition made its position clear, as did Senator Margetts. The rest of the Senate was quite clear about the reaction to this measure. The government has only itself to blame for the degree of desperation we have seen today. There has been plenty of time to recognise the effect of our opposition to this proposal. There has been plenty of time to find other ways to meet the funding of those places. The government has come in here, flailed about, compiled figures and made excuses why this action should be taken retrospectively to the real action. And, for all that, it has not given any reason for changing our position, so we won't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has moved this amendment to support the position in the House of Representatives, and it will insist on this amendment. None of the speakers in the debate so far has advanced anything new at all. The people of Australia who have heard this debate have just witnessed an unholy marriage between electoral populism and expediency by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: The logical foundation of what everybody in this chamber has said is that you can spend money without raising it; that if you create new places you can fund them from some vague part of the budget. I am not particularly surprised by the Greens and the Australian Democrats because it is not entirely inconsistent for them to assume that, in economic management, you can spend without raising taxes and have outlays without getting income and without going into deficit. There has been a consistent threat in a number of their policies, put forward on a populist front appealing to sectional interests, to agree to every spending operation that comes along without having to fund them. Therefore, I am not surprised by their reaction.

But what is absolutely shocking is an opposition, pretending to be a government and wanting to contest the polls while presenting its credentials to the people of Australia as being strong on economic management, which believes that we can spend money without raising it. What it is doing is simply caving in to what it regards as a sectional interest that will support it in this but ignoring and not consulting the authoritative bodies that exist to give voice to the higher education area.

For example, the package that the government has put forward is one which raises $50 million in the higher education budget in the 1996-98 triennium, which translates into 5,000 new student places. The opposition wants the places, but it will not raise the money. It somehow says, `Well, you go off and find the money.' And, after having punched several holes in our budget since May of this year, opposition members at macro-economic level then attack the government on the basis of: is the budget in surplus or deficit? At sectional interest level, they go around punching holes daily and without any fiscal rectitude or responsibility, appealing to populist sentiment that you can give places without funding them. Then we hear Mr Howard and Mr Costello saying, `Well, since we have knocked back these measures and those measures, the government can't bring down a balanced budget.'

This chamber has been used as a manipulation by parties rather than as a chamber of review. It has been used by the coalition, in consort with the minor parties, to prevent budget measures—not to review budget measures, but to prevent them—and then attack the government over its management of the budget. The people of Australia see through that. It is, therefore, no surprise at all that the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, the National Tertiary Education Union and the National Union of Students all endorse the government's package. The government has consulted with those groups. But the opposition has not consulted with those groups.

The first mistruth that was presented in this chamber as justification for going down this course was that, when the Minister for Education, Employment and Training, the Hon. Simon Crean, announced these changes, he did not say—and this is, broadly put, the allegation made by Senator Hill a moment ago in debate—that the places were dependent on the funding. I have in front of me Mr Crean's press release of 9 May 1995, in which he announces the new places. Let me go to what he said. We have had an allegation, unsupported by quoting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, what did he say?
—from any authoritative text, about what he said. I have the authoritative text here; let us see what he said. Mr Crean said:

SPEECH.PARA: The government's integrated package provided for growth in student places, funds for research and research infrastructure which will be funded by the reallocation of existing resources and improvements to the operation of HECS.

TALK.START.PARA: —Improvements to the operation of HECS!

—Improvements to the operation of HECS. What we are here to do is to improve the efficiency and operation of HECS. It is because you choose not to like those changes, which are improvements, that you want to therefore prevent 5,000 people, who could be university students, from finding places. You say, `Well, just go off and find the money.'

PARA.TAB: A government allocates funds in its budget to programs and running costs. And once allocated, those funds remain fixed. The government does not have the discretion to start switching things around. This is an integrated package, as Mr Crean said back on 9 May. That is the basis of why the first contention of the opposition and the minor parties should be rejected.

The second basis for rejection is, of course, what the organisations in higher education say. I have here letters from the Council of Australian Postgraduate Association of Students, a press release from the National Tertiary Education Industry Union and a media release from the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee, all of which endorse this package. But this chamber decides that the authoritative agencies representing proper views in this field should be overridden because this chamber knows better.

The government insists on its amendments. I recognise that the review nature of this chamber is to review decisions made in the people's house, the popularly elected house and the chamber in which government is formed in this country. Those decisions, having been subject to review, have been reviewed, returned to the House and, rejected by the House, have come back here. The review nature of this chamber seems to have been disintegrating in favour of it becoming a party political arm of the coalition seeking support from the minor parties in order to obstruct government programs.

At the end of the day the parents and the students, or those would-be students—the 5,000 who would have got places—will not thank the Greens, will not thank the Democrats and will not thank the coalition.
Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill, as the shadow spokesman on education, will not be thanked either. Those who miss out if you insist on this measure and we cannot proceed will know who is to blame here.

PARA.TAB: I think the sorrier part is that this chamber is moving from being a chamber of review to a chamber of obstruction, and obstruction against the wishes of the broad community. That is reason for pause and consideration by other senators. I ask you in the time between now and when this motion is put to consider it and vote against what you said earlier.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly I want to respond to a few things that the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) said. Firstly, I regret that he is continuing this approach of the government to threaten students and future students and to set existing students against future students. It is depressing to hear a government advocating such an approach to politics in this country.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I regret that he did not tell the whole truth in relation to the letters of representation. I think if he is prepared to face up to that truth he will come back and tell you that NUS has been against, and continues to be against, the change from permanent residency to citizenship, and that is contained in the letters that he was referring to just a few moments ago. But he did not tell you that at all. He said that they were totally locked in to the government's package, and that is simply not the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —He missed out the first paragraph.

—Yes, as Senator Bell said, he missed out the first paragraph. Thirdly, I want to table the minister's press release of 15 May. I said 17 May; I am sorry my memory was two days out. This is a press release in which Minister Crean and Queensland education minister Hamill boast of the government's achievements in being able to provide these new places in Queensland and detail the particular universities, even down to the particular campuses, that will benefit from this. Senators who wish to refer to this document will find there is not a word in there about this being conditional upon existing and past students having to pay for it. There is not a word on that at all. I also want to table the press release to which the—

—On a point of order, Madam Temporary Chair: it is always a matter of how you judge the debate in this place, but Senator Hill is ignoring a press release by the minister of 9 May which makes the position explicitly clear by saying that any attempt to unravel it in the Senate will put the growth places in jeopardy. Senator, you cannot go on with your misrepresentation that there was no warning by Minister Crean. You are skewering the truth. The 9 May press release makes this point absolutely clear.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Reynolds)—There is no point of order. It is a debating point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will help the minister by seeking leave to table the press release of 9 May 1995 so that those who are interested in this issue of who is telling the truth can read the press releases and make the determination for themselves.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook quoted from it. I do not dispute what he quoted. He boasted about an extra 11,000 places that would be provided and an extra sum of money for research which would be funded by the reallocation of existing resources and improvements to the operation of the higher education contribution scheme. They are coming in here today and saying that to force by legislation early repayments by students—to rip that money back from students without their agreement and contrary to the agreement that they had reached with students—
—Not students, Senator; they are past students.
—You are seeking to apply this to existing students, future students and past students.
—Repayment is not when they are students, Senator.
—The repayment is after they cease to be students.
—You just said `repayment by students'.

—It will be repayment by existing, future and past students. The government is coming in here today and saying that students should have appreciated that, when the minister said he was going to improve the operation of the scheme, he meant that he was going to legislatively require them to repay the debt earlier. If you, Senator Crowley, say that was a fair representation to students, then you are kidding yourself. When Minister Crean in effect said on Brisbane radio last Friday that students knew the obligation they had because he came clean with them in his press release of 9 May 1995, he was being totally misleading.

PARA.TAB: The real issue is a question of priority of expenditure, when it comes down to the crunch. Honourable senators will remember that Prime Minister Keating was prepared to apply $150 million of taxpayers' money as a contribution to the demolition of the Cahill Expressway in Sydney because he regarded it as an eyesore. Yet he is not prepared to allocate public money to provide these extra places in higher education.

He was prepared to apply—and did apply—some $12 million to promote the government's superannuation scheme, for purely political benefit for the government. That was his priority, but it was not his priority to properly support these further places in higher education. One could go on.

In the end, it is a question of priority of expenditure and the government makes its choice. In this instance the government has chosen to fund other issues and other interests rather than higher education. We say that is an error in judgment which is compounded by the fact that it has sought to rip this money off present, future and past students to pay for this promise.

The Senate should stand where it was when this bill last left the Senate. As has been said by other senators, the government has produced no further argument today to convince us to take a step otherwise.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the chamber and the minister that accelerating payments by students only leaves a revenue hole in future years. It is not a revenue raising measure; it is a revenue accelerating measure. This means that there is nobody left in the Senate to blame for the revenue hole later for the same funded places. It is a total nonsense to say that accelerating payments now will create a revenue hole. It only means that you have to fudge figures later or find someone else to blame. It is a total nonsense, and the government should own up to that.

—The minister spent some time trying to assert blame. It looked very much like somebody pointing with both hands in different directions, claiming, `It wasn't me, Your Honour. It wasn't me, Sir.' I think the electorate will recognise that this government has a responsibility which it is trying to avoid. It has a responsibility which it recognised by declaring that new university places would be made available, but to tie it to a particular group of people and say, `You students will pay for it' is to confuse an obligation.

PARA.TAB: To suggest that we in this place want that to be done without any further revenue raising from any source at all is to entirely misrepresent our position. We are quite happy to consider a more appropriate tax regime. We are quite happy to recognise that it is the entire community which benefits from an investment in education and that, therefore, it is the entire community which should recognise its responsibility to fund it. But to assert that we come in here and do not want to consider those is based on no foundation whatsoever. The minister, in pointing his hands in all directions but at himself and saying, `You're to blame, not me,' is really conducting an exercise which will be recognised by the electorate for what it is: a desperate way of trying to fund it without being brave enough as a government to say, `Well, the community should pay for these extra places'—the entire community, not the student community.

That has been our position all along. Our position has been that there should be no discrimination, that the ends do not justify the means in this case. The government has described the ends as being a wonderful situation where new university places can be funded and has said that that, therefore, justifies discrimination and justifies changing the rules, as Senator Hill said, without the approval of students—a unilateral movement by the government from a compact, bargain or agreement, whatever it might have been, that was made with students at the time as to how much contribution they would make, how they would make it and when they would make it. The government has made a unilateral alteration to that without the agreement of the other party to the compact, agreement or deal. That is not fair. It is not fair in our society. That is not how we do things in other areas. That is not how people understand agreements to be made.

If the government chooses to do that and say that because the ends are desirable, because it is desirable that we have extra places, that justifies this unfair strategy, then let the government be judged on that, because I contend that the ends do not justify the means. It is almost as good as saying, `We are going to put a GST on food for blue-eyed children only and all the others will be free from it. We will discriminate in certain areas because we are going to do something good with the money that we get from it.' I just cannot understand how a government from this perspective can propose such unfair and discriminatory practices as this accelerated HECS repayment and this discriminatory residents versus citizens debate. It would be a different matter if we had a society which was based on such a foundation, but we do not. It does not apply to the other activities of government, to the other obligations of government, so why should it apply here?

We have, of course, contended in the past that the whole HECS scheme itself is in contravention of our international obligations to not charge fees for education. I have in the past indicated that I would seek avenues to challenge the whole basis of HECS. I am indebted to Mr Dudley Kavanagh, a law graduate in Tasmania, who has done a considerable amount of research in this matter. I know that this is neither the time nor the place to pursue it, but when I am able to devote some more time and attention to this, I intend to do so.

That has been our position all along. We challenge the fundamental idea that university places should rely upon this scheme. That does not alter our capacity to recognise that it exists at the moment and at the moment what exists should be pursued and should continue to apply in the fairest possible way. Whenever we are confronted with an unfair change proposed by the government, we reserve the right to challenge that, notwithstanding that we disagree with the whole deal anyway.

There is no way that the government can justify what it is proposing here. Neither the minister seeking to assert blame in a misguided attempt to escape blame himself nor the government as a whole attempting to threaten either students or this parliament will change our position.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not take long because these issues have now been extensively canvassed. Everyone has had a second go in response to what the minister said, clearly putting words into the minister's mouth that were not said or deliberately intending to misrepresent him.

PARA.TAB: In response to Senator Bell, this is not about discussing tax regimes or anything else. That is another debate for another time. HECS is with us and what the minister is doing is introducing some improvements as well as a slightly increased rate of return of HECS but not with any jeopardy of the basic level of AWE.

It is interesting to know that both NUS and CAPA have found, in consultation, that those increased rates are acceptable because they are very progressive. It is hitting people at the top end who are much better able to return those HECS charges than the people who come in on AWE. That is very important. The minister made that clear in his press release—the one so conveniently tabled by Senator Hill—that retaining the first compulsory repayment threshold at average weekly earnings persists. The government is determined to make that the case.

A lot of the arguments that have been used in here have been trawled across by Senator Cook, and I will not put them again. But there is clearly a misrepresentation of what the minister's position was. He has made it clear all along that if the dollars are not there it does put in jeopardy the possibility of expanding those places. That is quite clear. To say that was not made clear is to very much misrepresent what the minister had to say.

Senator Hill wanted to say that the word `improvement' is hardly fair to describe the changes in HECS. The students see it as certainly an improvement. There is a possibility of earlier repayments and voluntary repayments. These are changes in flexibility of the repayment of HECS that are, at least according to the people having to repay it, beneficial.

I think it is very important to recognise, Senator Bell, that not everybody goes to university. If you have a look at who still gets access to university, it is very much a section of the community which in the past we would have called privileged. Although we have expanded very much the number of people who do have access to our universities through our special programs and targeted ways of assisting people not usually expecting to go to university to have access, still and all you would have to say the majority of people who go to our universities are people who will then have the benefits of that education and very often access to assistance through their primary and secondary schooling that is not available to all families.

According to the schedule of fees—I can read them out but I am sure you know it better than or at least as well as me—those people do not have any liability to return anything if they never earn an income or if they never earn above AWE. There are some people who are assisted in this way.

It is not reasonable to talk about students repaying either because it does carry the implication that students while they are being students have the obligation to pay. Once students are finished their courses and are then working as professionals, as people employed in all sorts of areas, they then get to pay back the HECS. They are not paying it back as students. Again, I would say that is open to misinterpretation. The government is not persuaded by any of the arguments put by the opposition to change its mind. It looks as though, from what you have said, that none of you are prepared to change your mind, so I think we would all be assisted if we proceeded to the vote.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Cook's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1995INCOME TAX (FRANKING DEFICIT) AMENDMENT BILL 1995INCOME TAX (DEFICIT DEFERRAL) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 29 June and 13 November, on motions by Senator Sherry and Senator Bolkus:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), and the two bills relating to the franking deficit and deficit deferral constitute a huge package of tax changes. Many of them are incredibly complex. They add hundreds more pages to the taxation laws. It is, quite frankly, disgraceful that the Senate is debating these bills only now, in the dying days of the spring sittings, and possibly the last three days of this parliament.

PARA.TAB: The government has had months to get these bills into order. These are taxation bills which flow from the budget or, indeed, from some earlier decisions prior to the budget. It is an indictment of the government's inability to manage its legislative program and a clear indicator of the disregard and contempt shown by this government towards the parliament that we are now, in such a compressed period of time and at such a late part of the session, debating the bills at all.

The fact that we are required to debate the whole package cognately, which greatly truncates the time available for debate, simply compounds the disgrace. How on earth can complex legislation of this nature that touches every Australian in one way or another be given adequate consideration in this time frame? It is blindingly obvious that the answer is that it cannot. Let me put down at the outset the coalition's attitude towards the two major bills: the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995.

In respect of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995—and I will try to talk about some of the details later—the coalition is totally opposed to the government's attempt to destroy employee share acquisition schemes. We will, accordingly, be voting against that part of the bill. We will also move amendments to those parts dealing with the capital gains tax, rollover relief for merging superannuation funds, the proposals relating to local government councillors and the proposals relating to late lodgment penalties. We believe that in some of those the drafting is very faulty and inequitable. We will be seeking to improve those.

The coalition is extremely concerned about the drafting of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995. We have taken very careful note of the wide range of representations that we have received on this matter so far as it relates to trusts. On behalf of the coalition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:

", but the Senate, concerned at the nature, scope, impact and implications of the proposed amendments set out in Schedule 7 of the bill, resolves that the proposed amendments in Schedule 7 be referred to the Economics Legislation Committee, for inquiry and report on or before 13 February 1996".

It would be the coalition's intention that, when schedule 7 is eventually approved, maybe amended, as a result of the Senate committee's examination, the provisions of the bill should date from 9 May 1995, the date of the last budget, as the government has proposed in the bill.

PARA.TAB: The coalition will also be moving consequential amendments in the committee stage of the bill to remove the government's schedule 7 amendments from the bill so as to allow the passage this week of the other parts of the bill. The coalition will also be moving other amendments during the committee stage of this bill in respect of the retrospective elements of the proposals relating to capital gains tax on the tax paid by non-residents on Australian assets, in respect of retrospectivity in the government's proposals on dividend imputation and in respect of the R&D tax concession proposals.

Let me now turn to some of the details of the two major bills; namely, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995. Time will prevent me from commenting at all during this speech on the second reading debate on the other two bills; namely, the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Amendment Bill 1995 and the Income Tax (Deficit Deferral) Amendment Bill 1995. I hope to comment on those bills in the committee stage.

I will turn first to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. This is an omnibus bill dealing with tax exemptions for state and territory bodies, employee share acquisition schemes, refunds of tax file number amounts deducted in error, pensions, allowances and benefits, superannuation measures, late lodgment penalties and sales tax. The most substantive changes in this bill are contained in schedule 2, which deals with the tax treatment of employee share acquisition schemes. It is on that aspect that I would like to focus my comments.

Schedule 2 replaces section 26AAC of the Income Tax Assessment Act with a new division 13A, which provides for the taxation of shares or rights provided to employees under an employee share acquisition scheme, commonly known as ESAS. This is the third occasion that this Labor government has attempted to legislate workable tax rules for employee share acquisition schemes, and it is the third occasion on which it has, sadly, failed. The reasons for that are complex, but basically the heart of it lies in the concern that the union movement and members of the rank and file of the Labor Party have in terms of employees having a stake in the businesses they work for.

The government claims that these changes are necessary to reduce the exploitation of the existing legislation and to ensure that the tax concessions available under the new arrangements are directed at share schemes which encourage employees to own shares in the company in which they are employed or a holding company of the employer. The government claims that the measures will increase the taxation benefits available to employees under these schemes.

The government's claims are clearly one thing; the consequences of the legislation are quite another. When the current Treasurer (Mr Willis) decided to bring employee share acquisition schemes within the net of the fringe benefits tax, the consequences of his actions were made clear. The government was warned, but they refused to take advice from anyone involved in the schemes. They refused to listen to the concerns of industry. They even refused to listen to warnings from within Treasury. As is typical of this government, the Treasurer attacked the messenger, by claiming that anyone who disagreed with the government was a supporter of tax avoidance. That was a cowardly response and unbecoming of the Treasurer of this nation.

Let me be absolutely and unreservedly clear on this issue of tax avoidance here and now: I and the coalition have always been and will always be committed to stamping out any action whatsoever that is designed for the purposes of avoiding the will of this parliament as expressed in its legislation, including its taxation legislation. That is absolute. It is a commitment set in stone.

Let me make it equally clear that the coalition does not believe that our tax laws can be treated as if they are an end in themselves. They are not something which can be brazenly separated from the operation of the Australian economy and Australian society. Our tax laws must be drafted to take account of commercial, social and political reality. Sadly, it is apparent that our tax laws in respect of share acquisition schemes have been drafted only to achieve a fiscal outcome and to satisfy a political goal. The commercial reality and the social desirability of these schemes have been ignored.

The coalition was not surprised when the Treasurer was finally forced to concede, at the end of March this year, that his plan to impose fringe benefits tax on employee share acquisition schemes was ill-conceived and ill-considered. The proposed changes contained in this bill are the result of the Treasurer's earlier intransigence to reason. They are the result of the government's isolation from reality and its shelter in economic theory.

What is even more critical, though, is that these changes—the latest changes in this bill—are also wrong. The government could have acted to amend section 26AAC to take out its flaws, which are recognised. Instead, the government proposes to introduce a new taxation regime which is only designed to make share acquisition schemes less attractive and less available to ordinary Australian workers. The proposals threaten the viability of current schemes and they restrict the potential for further expansion of employee share ownership.

The notion that employees should share in the wealth of the enterprise that they work in must surely be supported by every member of this chamber. Does any senator seriously argue that employees should not be able to enjoy the benefit of holding a stake in the future success of their employer, or that they should not have the opportunity to tie their own financial advancement to that of the company they work with and for? Certainly the coalition has no doubt on that score. We are totally supportive of employee share schemes that achieve that end.

I cannot believe that the government does not appreciate the benefit of these schemes. The benefit of employees having a capital share of their employer and the productivity and industrial relations benefits of these schemes should be unquestionable. Recent studies have indicated that the top 350 companies with a share plan outperform on every measure those without one.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' AFFAIRS (1995-96 BUDGET MEASURES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 22 November, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to speak on behalf of the coalition in support of the Veterans' Affairs (1995-96 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), which contains a number of amendments to various acts and is designed to implement the changes which were announced by the government in the budget. This is the second and final bill covering budget measures for veterans. Many of these amendments, as we see each year, mirror the changes that have been included in social security legislation and they are designed to bring veterans into line with the provisions which are operating under the Department of Social Security. The opposition does accept that the majority of the provisions in the legislation are designed to benefit veterans.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) in his second reading speech in the other place specifically mentioned the needs of older veterans, most of whom are now in their 70s and who served in World War II. I agree with the minister that, while this has been an important year in which we have commemorated the achievements and the sacrifices of our veterans from that conflict, it is important that we also look ahead in seeking to improve the way in which we respond to the needs of veterans. Of particular importance at the moment is the needs of aging veterans. The focus on an elderly constituency has to be that much greater.

I am pleased that there is now an initiative in developing a program for discharge planning. It is a matter which I raised at a meeting in Launceston only a few months ago. There has been much community concern there at the failure of hospitals and the department to work effectively together to put in place measures to support veterans and war widows when they are being discharged from hospital.

All around Australia these days people are being discharged earlier and earlier. Many go home to an empty home or to a very frail spouse. These things have to be taken into account and planned for in advance so that we do not send veterans and war widows home to a crisis situation which so often leads to readmission to hospital and sometimes even worse. So I am very glad to see that initiative and the development of that program. I look forward to it being well introduced all around Australia with not much delay.

I also have a particular affection for the program which enables carers in the Department of Veterans' Affairs to have respite care provided in the home. So many elderly people, especially if they become frail and confused, become even more frail and confused if respite care is provided in an institution with which they are not familiar. I would like to see the department focus more on the resources going into respite care in the home, wherever appropriate, of course, rather than in an institution. It is certainly much more cost-effective to provide it in the home and I think it is better for the veterans and the elderly war widows.

So those are my personal prejudices, if you like, put on the record. We need to be focusing—and I recognise that the department is focusing—more and more on our veterans and war widows as people who are now quite elderly, in the majority of cases. I was also delighted to hear last night that a veteran has been successful before the High Court in not having to provide his tax file number. This is something that some of us have been concerned about for a very long time. I am glad to hear that, on the grounds of privacy, apparently, he won. I have no more information than that at this stage. Good for him.

Before I sit down I would like to mention another matter relating to another group of veterans whose sacrifice has not always been recognised as it should have been in this country. I am referring to the Vietnam veterans. Next year, between 12 and 18 August, there is to be a massive convention and reunion in Launceston. They will be celebrating and remembering 30 years since the Vietnam War and the event will coincide with the anniversary of the battle of Long Tan.

The organisers in Launceston have undertaken a massive effort to notify veterans all around Australia, in New Zealand, Canada, the United States and the United Kingdom about this convention. Of course, it is very hard to contact all those people who served together so long ago. I have offered to help in a small way by announcing this occasion in the Senate so that it will be recorded in the Hansard. I also hope that some people are listening as we broadcast today.

I ask Vietnam veterans who would like to receive information about the convention to contact me at Parliament House. I will pass the information on to the organisers of the convention. They are very keen to have these people come back after 30 years to rightfully celebrate being Vietnam veterans, which is a matter of honour. We should all honour the service they gave in a difficult campaign.

The organisers do not have contact addresses for all units. If we could get information on those contact addresses, I will pass that on as well. Anybody who is listening today or who will read the Hansard I urge to make contact so that we can make this the best possible reunion. The chairman of the advisory board is Brian Harper, and the secretary is Malcolm Merrick.

Not only is this a great occasion for Vietnam veterans and their families to have a reunion, as a senator for Tasmania I can say proudly that it is also an opportunity for people to come and see our beautiful state, enjoy its heritage, perhaps some fishing, perhaps some snow, or whatever it is they would like to do in Tasmania. We are very proud of our state and it would be very worthwhile for people to combine the convention with a holiday. It is also an important convention for Tasmania from a financial point of view. Obviously, it is in the interests of everybody in Tasmania to encourage Vietnam veterans to come down and see us in August next year.

The other matter relating to this conference that I would like to raise is financial assistance. The Tasmanian Vietnam veterans have made a huge undertaking but the resources they have are not all that great. I am very glad that the Liberal state government has made a financial contribution, undertaking to help with the costs. But, to date, there has been no such commitment from the Commonwealth—which, after all, is the level of government which sent these men away to fight on Australia's behalf. Surely, it is not too much to ask that the Commonwealth Department of Veterans' Affairs make a contribution to support this important reunion and convention.

I take this opportunity to call on the federal government to match the state contribution dollar for dollar, and to make it clear soon that they will do it. After all, when planning a convention you need to know well ahead what resources you can call on if you are going to be as effective as you can be. I find it very strange that the Commonwealth, which has been approached on this matter, has not been prepared to make that commitment. I urge the government to think about this very carefully.

This will be no ordinary conference because the organising committee hopes to provide a forum for veterans to continue to strive for reconciliation and to fight for recognition from mainstream Australia. The convention will also provide an opportunity to air grievances, discuss needs, and meet with the government and its representatives. They will also be having workshops, which will be joint efforts between the veterans, the association and the government to discuss current and new issues.

I think the convention will also provide an opportunity for discussions on the future involvement of the Vietnam veteran as a representative Australian veteran. As our World War II veterans age, the leadership of the veterans' community will start to pass, as it already has, to the Vietnam veterans. It is very important to these veterans themselves and to our country that they be included as an honoured part of our veterans' community—and that means that at the government level, the RSL level, with other veterans' organisations and in the wider community Vietnam veterans of Australia feel that they are honoured, as their fathers and grandfathers have been.

So I call on the federal government to demonstrate that that is also their view. They can achieve this by making sure that the resources necessary for this important convention to go ahead are provided not only by the state government but also, equally, by the Commonwealth government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —(12.55 p.m.)—The measures in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (1995-96 Budget Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1995 before us are largely beneficial to veterans and are to be welcomed. As we have such a short time today and, indeed, wanted to see this legislation passed before the end of the session, we have agreed to have it during the non-controversial business time.

PARA.TAB: However, the Democrats do have one or two areas of concern. In view of the shortness of time, I would just mention those particular concerns. We have been contacted by Aged Care Australia, who are worried about the administration of the residential care allowance. They foresee nursing homes and hostels being involved in considerable changes to the fee charging arrangements when the administration of this allowance reverts to the Department of Human Services and Health in one or two years time. They have written to the department expressing their concerns and are awaiting a reply. The Australian Democrats will be carefully monitoring the implementation of this new scheme.

Our second area of concern is the change in the threshold for rent assistance. My colleague Senator Woodley has already addressed this at considerable length yesterday when we discussed the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill 1995. Whilst we welcome the increase in rent assistance payable to single or illness-separated pensioners, or to pensioner couples with dependent children, by $5 a fortnight, we are disappointed to see that this will be paid for by an increase in the rent threshold for all pensioners.

The increase in rent assistance will cost the government $0.23 million in the four years to 1998-99, yet the increase in the rent threshold of the same time frame will save $4.05 million. In other words, the winners in this policy change, those who gain, will do so at the expense of other veteran pensioners—and there is still, for the government, a substantial net gain.

The Australian Democrats are not supporting this increase. We will not put it to the vote, as we are in the noncontroversial bills session, but we do wish to register our very strong opposition to this change.

I would like to take the opportunity to mention very briefly that we have been receiving frequent and very serious complaints about HACC services for veterans. These appear to relate to a couple of states in particular, but they are certainly Australia-wide. In this regard it seems that a number of states are not carrying out their obligations. Certainly, as veterans age, they are going to require additional home based services.

We have yet to be convinced that the Commonwealth is fulfilling its undertakings to veterans in this area. Indeed, as we move into the new session of parliament next year, the Democrats will be monitoring the situation very carefully and have already been considering a reference to one of the Senate standing committees on this issue, requesting that it look at the whole issue of home care services and support services for veterans.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (1995-96 Budget Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1995 which is now before the chamber. It contains a range of measures which were announced at the time of the budget in May this year. The majority of these changes are most welcome. It is not my intention to take up the Senate's time with a detailed analysis of the bill, but there are two matters with which the Greens have problems.

PARA.TAB: The first problem is the increase in the rent threshold for those receiving rent assistance. I thought that the Democrats would be putting an amendment to overturn this measure, and such an amendment would have had support. However, on listening to Senator Lees I realise that, because of Senator Woodley's failure to convince the chamber of support for similar amendments in yesterday's debate on the social security bills, the Democrats will not be proceeding with that intention. Therefore, I want to express the concern of the Greens on this issue. We would certainly vote against this part of the bill if it were going to the vote.

The other measure is the increase in the guardian's allowance. As with the Social Security bill dealing with this matter, the increase is to take effect in September next year. This is a budget measure announced in May this year, and the government is getting the kudos for having announced it in May this year, but is not intending to deliver on that promise until September of next year. We believe that that is an outrageous and unacceptable delay for those awaiting this much needed increase. We will put an amendment which brings forward the increase to December of this year and I trust that the amendment will gain the necessary support. It is not a fair commitment by the government in the budget to then defer it to such a degree that it disappoints the people who had assumed that they were going to receive some consideration under this measure.

Because this bill has been classified as non-controversial, and has been placed in the lunchtime on the basis that divisions will not be called, it is necessary to just seek the support of my colleagues for my amendment and to have that amendment rise or fall on their voices. At this point, I state a personal protest at the way in which the government has organised the program so that bills that are clearly worthy of some debate of the decisions being made are being crammed into the lunchtime. It is a failure in democracy that divisions cannot be called. In that respect, this bill should not be appearing at this time. It does not have the consensus of the chamber and it should not be here.

I will probably reiterate that remark from time to time over the next two days because I believe that the government, instead of prioritising its bills, and limiting it to those that are absolutely essential, has used what I could only class as emotional blackmail on those people who feel that they want to support the good measures in this bill by forcing them to limit the debate on measures within it that are not desirable. Because the Greens are supporting the bill, I am simply making that personal protest. I would urge the government and the opposition to give consideration to my amendment and support it when it comes to the committee stage.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing for the government, I do not want to take the time of the Senate unduly. I do, however, reject the concept of blackmail. I do not believe that that would be an appropriate description of the government or the opposition's approach on this legislation. Certainly, it is a significant piece of legislation with extensive and very different aspects to it. I respect the fact that Senator Chamarette disagrees on one particular matter and, to that extent, I suppose it is unfortunate that from her perspective she sees the legislation as controversial. I respect her position but I do not agree with it.

PARA.TAB: It is unfortunate, I suppose, that we are left with restricted time at this time of year to deal with legislation in this manner. I know the government would prefer that not to be the case but we are not sitting longer hours except on two occasions. I know others might disagree on the hours issue but I have some pretty firm memories of the sorts of hours we used to sit. We know the constraints that we are under in terms of time and we know why we have to deal with legislation in this way. I note the opposition is not opposing the bill and I do not think there are any more useful comments I can make at this stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule 9, page 99, item 2, proposed point 42-C8, omit "be increased by $104 on 19 September 1996", substitute "be increased by $104 on 7 December 1995".
2.Schedule 9, page 99, item 5, proposed point 45Y-G10, omit "be increased by $104 on 19 September 1996", substitute "be increased by $104 on 7 December 1995".

This amendment brings the guardian allowance forward from 19 September 1996 to 7 December 1995, and I have indicated why that should be the case. It is a government promise. If it were simply I who disagreed with the failure of the government to institute this promise, that would be a legitimate matter to marginalise. However, in speaking on this, I am speaking for all the people who are recipients of the guardian allowance and I do not think in that way it should be marginalised. I would seek the minister's advice as to whether I have any support for this amendment and also that of the opposition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can indicate that the government cannot support the amendment. We were not aware that Senator Chamarette was going to proceed with the amendment today at lunchtime. We take note of her comments and her criticism but we cannot support the amendment.

Bill agreed to.
