DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 October, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995 replaces the original bill, the Human Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1). This was the bill that the Labor government completely botched when it went through the parliamentary process last time, a mistake which only highlighted its ignorance of procedures in the House and here in the Senate itself. After a charade like this, Labor has absolutely no right to complain about delays of legislation in either house of parliament.

PARA.TAB: The coalition basically has no real problems with the legislation and we will not be opposing its passage. However, we do wish to highlight and strongly oppose the incompetence that the government has shown in its dealing with this bill. You will recall that that incompetence saw the original bill divided on the floor of the Senate and thus rendered inoperable. That incompetence arose from Labor's arrogance and lack of respect for the institution of parliament. I can go further along those lines but I think the government might have received the message.

Since we are in effect revisiting the Human Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1)—again, thanks to Labor—a lot of the issues in this bill have been gone over and now we have a chance to do it all again. For this reason, I will mention the major issues that have already been raised and then focus on health care and aged care, both of which were raised in these bills and both of which are issues which are, and should be, of increasing importance and interest in Australia today.

The amendment bill repeals the Handicapped Person's Assistance Act 1974. Schedule 1 proposes amendments to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993, the Health Insurance Act 1973, the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, the National Health Act 1953 and the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992. Schedule 2 proposes technical amendments to a number of acts.

The child-care rebate is aimed at strengthening the act and clarifying and helping to facilitate certain procedural aspects of the Commonwealth child-care cash rebate scheme. Several of these amendments provide hardship provisions to help those people who are currently excluded from the rebate scheme but who should be able to get it: for example, children over the age of 13 who have a disability or other special needs requiring ongoing child care; carers under the age of 18 who have certain child-care qualifications; and parents who are currently unable to have work related commitments because of extenuating circumstances.

Due to administrative issues and technical errors, amendments are needed to make consequential changes to the act to bring it in line with changes to other Commonwealth legislation. These other administrative arrangements allow the delegation of powers by the managing director of the commission, allow the minister some discretion over receipting requirements, strengthen powers to overcome overpayments of the rebate, allow the Health Insurance Commission to backdate carer registrations to the date at which they were first eligible to register, also cancel family or carer registrations and recover payments when an administrative error has been made. They also ensure that the rebate is not paid for child-care costs which have been, or will be, reimbursed by another agent such as an employer. They clarify that the rebate is payable for child-care costs incurred for certain specified absences from care and also clarify the backdating of family registrations, as well as the eligibility of overseas students to claim the rebate, by amending the courses of study that are described and correct technical defects in the act.

In regard to the Health Insurance Act 1973, the amendments are needed to correct drafting errors in the Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Amendment Act 1994 which established the services review scheme, and allow for the appointment as presidents of the professional services review tribunals persons who hold, or who have held, judicial office in state and territory jurisdictions.

You will recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the report of the professional services review board was to be debated and it somehow dropped off the list. But I thought it was interesting in that report that $1.3 million has been spent in over the 12 months since that tribunal was established. From memory, 27 deputy commissioners have been appointed on a part-time basis and something like 132 reviewers. After the expenditure of that sum, that extent of money, not one health professional has been reviewed in the 12 months. It reminded me very much of the Yes, Minister program about the hospital that had been functioning very successfully without any patients. This is another example of that construction.

The amendment to the Health Insurance Act 1973 in relation to the Health Insurance Commission is an amendment to expressly give the Health Insurance Commission the function of providing consultancy and management services to the Commonwealth and other Commonwealth bodies. The amendment also enables the Health Insurance Commission to retain evidential material seized pursuant to the execution of a search warrant until the reason for its seizure no longer exists or a decision is made not to use it in evidence. The National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992 has amendments to specify that, before appointing the chairperson of the council, the chairperson of the Australian Health Ethics Committee or a member of the Australian Health Ethics Committee classified as a person with knowledge of the ethics of medical research, the minister will consult with each state and territory health minister.

In regard to the amendments relating to nursing homes and their regulation, these amendments remove several provisions relating to review of decisions and adding merit review rights for decisions on the amount of Commonwealth benefit that may be advanced to nursing home proprietors. These proprietors should be able to see how the level of Commonwealth benefit has been calculated.

There is also an amendment relating to exempt bed status by giving the minister the power to revoke or suspend this status if the nursing home fails to satisfy nursing home care standards. This is because a criterion for granting an exempt bed status is that the home provides a higher standard of accommodation and services than normal. This amendment will ensure that standards are maintained and make sure that the extra charges for these nursing homes are justified. This is something that is very important and is an issue which Senator Patterson has pursued in estimates, particularly before the Community Affairs Legislation Committee.

An example she raised during the February estimates earlier this year highlighted this fact. Without mentioning names, there was a nursing home in Victoria which was charging excessively high fees and not providing adequate services accordingly. In fact, in a standard monitoring visiting report done by the federal Department of Human Services and Health, of 31 standards only eight were met. Yet, because it was an exempt bed status nursing home, it was charging $915 a week. Of course, the department had received complaints from relatives and patients, and from the time she raised it, it had been six months without any action. Hopefully, this amendment will prevent this situation occurring again.

While the coalition supports this amendment, it is merely a small step in the direction of things that need to be done. Australia's ageing population is increasing in numbers and is obviously going to continue to do so. This is something that the government continues to ignore. Over and over again, we see cases of Labor discriminating against and neglecting our older Australians. Over and over again, we point out these policies and actions hurting the aged and over and over again, the government turns a blind eye, ignoring these problems and failing to take adequate action.

The poor treatment of the aged includes things such as the funding crisis in nursing homes. Professor Gregory's report stated that over $100 million per year was needed to upgrade and maintain basic standards for nursing homes. What do we see—the government allocating only $36.4 million over four years.

Nursing home subsidies and domiciliary care subsidies were cut by $11.2 million in the budget. Obviously what is needed is a more flexible system which will ensure that there is adequate funding available to run nursing homes and hostels but also to enable them to be properly maintained and upgraded. It is crucial that there are adequate infrastructure and appropriate funding systems in place in the aged care sector as we move into the next century.

The aged care sector is facing pressure from changing community expectations. Aged people and their families have increasing expectations of the physical and quality of life standards in aged care. So there is an ongoing need to upgrade facilities and the quality of care.

I turn now to the treatment of dementia. The government has failed to recognise the needs of people with dementia. Ambulant dementia sufferers who have severe behavioural problems often have been inappropriately `integrated' with other hostel and nursing home residents. In many cases, the dementia sufferer is disruptive and can negatively affect the quality of life of other residents in the integrated facility. Where dementia-specific hostels have been established, the inadequate level of government funding has rendered the facilities unviable unless they are cross-subsidised from other sections of the aged care facility. Despite desperate pleas from the aged care sector, the government has refused to consider a more appropriate level of funding for these residents.

The self-funded retirees are affected. Having been denied the l-a-w law tax cuts promised by Mr Keating, they will not benefit from the government's proposed superannuation contribution in lieu of these tax cuts because retirees do not pay into superannuation funds. Carers are also affected. Only $10 million has been allocated over three years in the budget, that is, only $3 million per year which would go nowhere to meet the needs of carers for income support. Carers such as residential aged carers have been discouraged by the lack of trust and respect the Labor government is giving them.

As I have mentioned, the need for aged care and aged care places is on the rise. There will need to be incentives for private enterprise as well as the government and the not-for-profit sector to enter the field. It is also essential that government, aged care providers, consumers and carers work together as a team to develop an aged care system that meets the ever changing needs of the aged. As I mentioned earlier, the coalition does not oppose the passage of the bill. However, these are amendments which should have been passed much earlier and should have resulted in a lot less wasted time, time which was lost due to Labor's incompetence.

While amendments to areas such as health and child care and in to relation nursing homes are a step in the right direction, there is still a long way to go. This is something the coalition and the community recognises and in government we will address these issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Public Service Legislation Amendment Bill 1995, which was first introduced into the House of Representatives on 28 June despite the fact that it is, in the main, a non-controversial bill, was not debated in the House of Representatives until 28 September. It has now been with us for some time but has not managed to struggle its way up the list. It is an important bill, despite the fact that it is non-controversial in the sense that the opposition does not oppose the bill. It is an indictment, again, of the government's conduct of business in this place that it leaves a bill of this nature to be debated on what is the second or third last sitting day of this session—and possibly the second or third last sitting day of the parliament. The bill gives effect to the government's decision announced in the 1995-96 budget to amalgamate the Merit Protection Review Agency, the MPRA, and the Public Service Commission, PSC, to form the Public Service and Merit Protection Commission.

PARA.TAB: By way of background to this move, following the abolition of the Public Service Board as part of the extensive machinery of government changes which were made back in 1987, three central agencies were given defined roles in relation to personnel management and industrial relations in the Australian Public Service. These agencies are: the Department of Industrial Relations; the Department of Finance; and the Public Service Commission. The Public Service Commission has approximately 150 staff and a running cost budget of around $17 million, although its net outlays in 1995-96 will be only $13.25, according to pages 64 and 65 of the portfolio budget statements for the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet.

The Public Service Commission is responsible for all appointments, promotions and terminations within the Senior Executive Service, which is the top management group within the Australian Public Service. The Public Service Commissioner also has a range of responsibilities in relation to non-SES staff employed under the Public Service Act 1922. Non-SES staff comprise a very large number of staff—about 140,000. The responsibilities of the Public Service Commissioner include establishing employment and staffing policies and guidelines covering recruitment, promotion, mobility, discipline, equal opportunity in employment, redeployment and retirement.

The commissioner is also involved in some case work, principally in the area of redeployment and placement of excess staff. The commissioner has responsibility for entry level training policy and for developing core competency standards for all staff. Individual departments, however, have responsibility for the implementation of core competency standards as well as the development of agency specific competences.

The Public Service Commission does not have the same powers and responsibilities as did the old Public Service Board that it replaced. It is not easy to draw a concise yet entirely accurate distinction between the old board and the Public Service Commission. But, in broad terms, the Public Service Commission provides advice and promulgates guidelines, whereas the board used to set rules and frequently was itself a prime decision maker in relation to individual staffing matters.

The other agency—the one it is proposed be merged with the Public Service Commission—is the Merit Protection and Review Agency. It is a statutory body that was established under the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees Act) 1984 to provide independent review of decisions and actions affecting Commonwealth employees in relation to their employment. It has been argued that the agency has a key role in human resource management in the Australian Public Service because of the major impact that many of its decisions have on staff management practices, including time management and agency performance.

The MPRA has the equivalent of 56 full-time staff positions. It has a running cost budget for 1995-96 of approximately $6.56 million, although this amount is reduced by receipts to give a figure of about $4.58 million for total outlays in the present financial year, according to the portfolio budget statements for 1995-96 for the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. This information is shown on pages 73 to 75 of the portfolio budget statement.

This bill looks at the amalgamation of two important agencies. As I said, it is a pity that there has been such a delay in the bill being debated. It is worth pointing out that the decision to amalgamate is contrary to the recommendation in the report of the Public Service Act Review Group, commonly called the McLeod report. That report was released in January of this year. That group was set up under the chairmanship of Mr McLeod to review the Public Service Act, and it did not, in its report, recommend the merger of the Public Service Commission with the Merit Protection and Review Agency. Indeed, it recommended that the Merit Protection and Review Agency remain separate. The agency, by its nature, is a joint union and management body whereas the Public Service Commission is all about management structures. Whilst the two are somewhat complementary, they are of themselves very different.

The coalition will not be opposing the legislation. Indeed, we support the legislation but there are a couple of points that need to be made about the Public Service. I make these points bearing in mind the fact that the savings to be achieved as a result of the amalgamation are said to be modest. So it is not going to achieve a big deal with respect to savings and government finances. One of the things that concerns the coalition is that it appears that Ms Forward, the Director of the Merit Protection and Review Agency—and this emerged from evidence that she gave at the Senate estimates hearings earlier this year—was not consulted in any significant way, if at all, about the amalgamation before the announcement of the amalgamation. It was during those hearings that my colleague Senator Minchin asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Were you given the opportunity for consultations about the advantages or disadvantages of this prior to a decision being made or was it something that you read about in the newspaper?
Ms Forward responded:
Neither of these reflects the facts of the matter.

So, quite clearly, she did not have much of an input into what was going to happen. It is equally clear, I think, that the agency or its principal officers feel that a greater degree of consultation would have been desirable before the decision was taken on the agency's future. That this consultation did not occur is a reflection, I think, of this government's lack of commitment to both the principles and practices of open government. If the government is unwilling to enter into consultations with its own employees, it is little wonder that the general public is cynical, and increasingly so, of the government's advocacy of open government.

PARA.TAB: There are several other issues that the coalition wishes to raise about this proposal. The effect of the proposal will be that members of the agency, including the director, will retain their officers after the merger whilst the Public Service Commissioner will have the powers of a secretary in relation to the staff of the new commission. It is expected that the Merit Protection Commissioner will exercise personnel and financial management powers in relation to officers required for the purposes of the Merit Protection Act.

Three issues have been raised regarding this bill. Firstly, is the amalgamated agency guaranteed continued resourcing and independence? Secondly, will the proposals of the McLeod report be implemented in full and, if so, will the agency's workload decline as a result? Thirdly, is it appropriate to create one body which both makes personnel management rules and adjudicates on grievances arising from the administration of those rules?

They are important questions and I think that people can have genuinely held, differing views on those, on all of them really, but particularly on the question of whether one organisation should be able to make both personnel management rules and adjudicate on grievances arising from the administration of those rules. We may have had some similar experience of this in the past but, for most of the period of the Commonwealth Public Service, there has been a separation, as I recall it, of the agencies that look at the promotion and appeals system compared with those that are formulating the personnel management rules.

That is not to say that putting the two together will necessarily cause problems of a great magnitude, but it is something that will need to be handled very carefully. I hope that the parliament will have an opportunity to monitor the progress of the amalgamated body to ensure that the concerns that have been raised by some people in relation to the amalgamation so far as that aspect is concerned are not actually fulfilled.

An additional issue concerns the functioning of the MPRA itself and the manner in which it conducts its investigations. That is evidenced by the controversy surrounding the investigations into the management of the Australian War Memorial which have been—and I think still are—the subject of legal action. They have caused considerable community concern and they have raised serious questions about the agency's procedures. That is a separate issue to some extent from the question of the future of the agency itself, but they are matters of concern. In the amalgamated organisation it will be important that those matters are reviewed so that the concerns that have been expressed, and the questions that have been raised, about the quality and nature of the Merit Protection Review Agency's procedures are fully examined and that, where change is necessary, the changes be made.

As I said, the financial impact of the proposals is small—indeed, somewhat surprisingly small, in my view. The combined budget of the two agencies is something of the order of $20 million per annum. According to the explanatory memorandum, the amalgamation will reduce outlays only by approximately $200,000 in 1996-97 and in subsequent years. Any saving is a worthwhile saving, but it does surprise me that the saving is as small as that. It is a very small proportion of the combined budget.

Having said those things, the coalition supports the amalgamation. It is an important developmental step in Public Service procedures. I do not know whether the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) is able to comment on this, but I have just received today in the rounds the statement by Gary Johns, the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters. It is a document headed A New Public Service Act: a progress report to the House of Representatives which is dated November 1995. I just picked it up as I came into the chamber so I have not had the opportunity to look at it.

The document presents an outline of a Public Service Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 which proposes a major rewrite of the Public Service Act. Amongst other things, it says that in May of this year the government accepted Mr Johns's recommendation that the 1922 act should be repealed and replaced with a new Public Service Act. He said that there were three major reasons why we need a new act: firstly, that the current act is too complex and hard to read; secondly, that it is out of date; and, thirdly, that it is inconsistent with the current management philosophy and the prevailing community-wide industrial relations system. He goes on to say that the new act will embody a series of principles governing the employer-employee relationship within the Australian Public Service to ensure that employees are aware of their rights as well as their responsibilities.

The question I put to Senator Sherry, through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, is: what is the relationship between the document now released by the minister for a new Public Service Act and the proposals contained therein and the bill we are now debating?

The bill we are now debating has been around, as I said, for several months. Indeed, it was introduced at the end of June. Events have overtaken it to some extent; on the other hand, they may not. There may be no relationship between the two. In your summing up, I wonder whether you could let the Senate know what the implications for the bill before the Senate now are of Minister Johns's recently circulated document.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect to the savings to be achieved, Senator Short has said they are modest: approximately $200,000, from a joint agencies budget of $2 million. Certainly, $200,000 is modest in that context, but a saving is a saving. In government it is important to continually be looking at more efficient ways in which the Public Service can be structured and, particularly, in government, if we are seeking to finance expenditure from savings, every dollars counts.

PARA.TAB: Concerning the comments about Ms Ann Forward expressing her concerns, it has been reported to me that relationships between the two organisations to be amalgamated are very productive and cooperative and any difficulties that may have been expressed are largely put to rest. The statement that the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, Mr Gary Johns, has released really is unconnected with the legislation in the sense that it is a progress report on the review of the Public Service Act. I understand there will be an act introduced in the new year. While I am on this issue, I would point out that the McLeod report did not make a recommendation on the amalgamation of the two organisations that we are dealing with in the legislation. It did not make a comment either for or against. It did review the agencies but it did not say, `Don't amalgamate them,' or `Do amalgamate them,' so the report was neutral in that sense. I thank Senator Short for his contribution.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 22 November, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industry Commission Amendment Bill 1995 amends the Industry Commission Act of 1989 to allow greater flexibility in the operation of the Industry Commission. The bill contains four main amendments. The first amendment is to allow the appointment of commissioners, other than the chairperson, on a part-time basis in addition to the current full-time basis. The second amendment is to allow a consequential increase in the maximum number of commissioners, other than the chairperson, from eight to 11. The third amendment is to allow a single commissioner to act on behalf of all other commissioners on an inquiry in the absence of other commissioners, but limits inquiries to public hearings and then only in emergency situations.

PARA.TAB: The final amendment is to require full-time commissioners to obtain the consent of the minister to engage in paid employment outside the duties of his or her office. The amendment also is to restrict part-time commissioners from engaging in paid employment that, in the minister's opinion, conflicts with the proper performance of the commissioner's duties. The amendments are, overall, sensible proposals for amendment, and the coalition does not oppose these changes.

There are some points to be made in relation to at least two of the amendments. The first amendment to allow the appointment of commissioners, other than the chairperson, on a part-time basis in addition to the current full-time basis is aimed at increasing the commission's chances of attracting a more diverse range of suitably qualified people. The commission will be able to recruit people holding other positions who are unwilling to become full-time commissioners. This a very sensible proposal because there is a wealth of talent out there in the general community, particularly in the business world.

There are people who have business experience and who would be eminently qualified and suitable for working with the commission, but whom you will not get unless you are able to offer work to them on a part-time basis, rather than a full-time basis. This amendment should, in itself, widen the potential pool of suitable people considerably. The members of the coalition think that this is a good idea and we certainly support it. However, it does mean, as the second amendment makes clear, that there would be a consequential increase in the maximum number of commissioners. The proposal in the bill is that this consequential increase be an increase of three, which means that the number increases from eight to 11.

The other amendment that requires a brief comment is the third of the four amendments, the one allowing a single commissioner to act on behalf of all other commissioners on an inquiry in the absence of other commissioners, but limited to public hearings and only in emergency situations. That amendment will apply where unforeseen circumstances such as accident, illness or injury prevent one or other commissioners on an inquiry from participating in the public hearing. In such circumstances the remaining commissioners will be able to preside at the public hearing or part of a public hearing.

The financial impact of the proposals is said to be nil; it does not have any financial implications. I am pleased to note that the government has said that, should the number and mix of full-time and part-time commissioners increase beyond the present funding levels, an increase in funding would be sought through the normal budgetary processes. On that basis and given the fact that the proposals look sensible and will add to the flexibility and the operations of the commission, and will enable the government to attract a wider range of qualified and experienced and relevant people to serve on a part-time basis as commissioners, the coalition supports the bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

The amendments are non-controversial. It has been a productive 55 minutes. Thank you.
