TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, Senator Cook. I remind the minister that last month he told the Senate that the government's `tax policies are in the budget'. Four days later he said, `To the best of my knowledge, we have not formulated our tax policy for the next election.' A week ago he said, `We do not intend to introduce new taxes in the forthcoming election and in winning government, subsequent to that.' And yesterday he indicated that the extent of the government's commitment was only to keep general taxation revenue as a proportion of GDP at around their current levels. The minister has enunciated four different positions in the space of just over one month. In those circumstances, minister, I ask what is your current position? Will you rule out new taxes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of the quotations that have just been retailed to me have a familiar ring, but they do lack the context in which they were made. There has been a thread of consistency through the position that I have put all along. I have no doubt that the opposition will want to play on the meaning of words and check how many angels can dance on the head of a pin in order to pretend that there is some inconsistency. The line of consistency is there and it is strong.

PARA.TAB: When we came to power in 1982-83, the tax revenue to GDP ratio in Australia was 24 per cent. In the year 1995-96 we expect the level of tax as a percentage of GDP to be 24.2 per cent. In other words, what I am saying here is that we came to power in a recessionary climate in which the level of growth in the economy was low and when you would expect, because there were fewer people employed, there was less business activity and lower profits, the returns to the Commonwealth in the form of taxation to also be low. But what I am pointing to now, in an economy which today's national accounts underline more pointedly than any other question that I have got from Senator Hill in the last two years, in an economy which is a strong and growing economy, is that the burden of taxation on Australia for the 1995-96 year is expected to come in at 24.2 per cent.

So in a strong economy when there are more people employed you would expect to obtain more taxes. When the profit share is higher, you would expect the income to the Commonwealth from corporate tax to be higher. When the activity in the business sector is greater, you would expect that to be also.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order on relevance: this is all very interesting, but the question was designed to allow the minister to work his way through four conflicting statements on what the government's tax policies are, an opportunity to clear the inconsistencies. It has nothing to do with history. What I have done is put to him four inconsistent statements on tax policy and asked him to tell the Senate and the Australian people what are the government's intentions.
—The question was on tax policy. The answer is on tax policy. I am not in a position to dictate to the minister how he should answer it.

—That is right, Mr President. I wonder what the next attempt will be to try to interfere with this answer. The point is that we inherited a sluggish economy with low receipts. We now have a strong economy with high receipts. The level of taxation is the same.

PARA.TAB: That is the commitment we have given to Australia. That is the commitment I reminded the Senate about yesterday. That is the commitment the government stands by. That is the commitment the Treasurer has most recently given. That is the position of the government.

There is no secret agenda. What we have from Senator Hill is an attempt to pretend, in the absence of any fleshed out policy from the opposition whatsoever and in the absence of any policy detail on the economy from the opposition whatsoever, that there is some secret agenda by the government.

The figures I have given show a consistency by the government over the 12 1/2 years of our office in terms of the level of taxation in Australia. That is the undertaking we have given, and that is the undertaking we will stick by.
I noticed in the Australian Financial Review today the editorial headed `Howard ducks hard decisions'. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: Once again the Leader of the Opposition—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President. It is the same point of order. That has nothing to do with this question. The minister says the government has no secret agenda. Yet he has put down four inconsistent statements on the government's tax policy. What we are asking him to do is clarify the government's position and his position. That was what the question was all about. It had nothing to do with what is in the Financial Review, nothing whatsoever.
—I have already ruled on that.

—Thank you, Mr President. This is getting tiresome. The heading of the editorial writers, that is, the editors of the Australian Financial Review, is `Howard ducks hard decisions'. It goes on to say that he is unwilling to face up to the hard policy choices. All I can say is: gutless in opposition, gutless in government. What Australian voters realise is that if you are unprepared in opposition, without the responsibilities of office, to face the hard questions, if you ever had the responsibilities of office you would run scared.
—As the minister did not even attempt to answer the question, I ask it again. In view of your four inconsistent statements, what are the government's tax policies? Do you rule out new taxes?

—I have answered this question. You just cannot spot through Hansard, pick up four quotes and pretend they are all different, without seeing them in context. There is a thread of consistency between the lot. I just said—I will repeat it since although you are only about 12 feet from me you apparently did not hear—that the government is committed to maintaining the level of taxes in the broad Australian community. That is what the Treasurer said yesterday. That is what I said yesterday. That is what I say again today is the position of the government.

PARA.TAB: If you go back over our entire period of office, the level in 1982-83 was 24 per cent of GDP and for the year 1995-96 is expected to be 24.2 per cent of GDP. That is a record of consistency. The nature of the economy at the two nodal points is very interesting. That is the point I made. In a depressed economy you would expect the receipts to be low. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner. In April this year you asked Hayden Opie to carry out an independent inquiry into allegations made concerning the women's artistic gymnastics program at the Australian Institute of Sport. Have you received that report? If so, can you inform the Senate of Mr Opie's findings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am able to inform the Senate that I have received Mr Opie's report about allegations that were made earlier this year concerning the women's artistic gymnastics program at the Australian Institute of Sport. I am able to table a copy of the full report and the summary, for the information of senators. Copies of the summary are available immediately, but printing requirements have meant the full report will only be available tomorrow.

PARA.TAB: On 18 April this year I asked Mr Opie, who is the president of the Australian and New Zealand Sports Law Association and a respected Melbourne University legal academic, to carry out the independent inquiry. Mr Opie received more than 150 written submissions, and over 160 witnesses from across Australia were interviewed, some of them more than once. Evidence was taken from a broad range of people, including current and former gymnasts and their families, officials in the sport, AIS and external administrative, medical, scientific and coaching personnel and various other people who have an interest in the program.
The key findings of Mr Opie's inquiry were:

ANSWER.PARA: Almost all allegations of abuse by the Inquiry pursuant to its terms of reference have not been proven and the media reports of April and May 1995 must be regarded as greatly misleading. No systematic or widespread abuse of AIS female gymnasts has been found to occur at any time. The Inquiry did not find any credible evidence of inappropriate treatment of gymnasts currently in the program.

The Inquiry did find a handful of complaints of past inappropriate treatment to be proven which in the overall circumstances of the Inquiry are relatively minor. These related to the inappropriate use of the sauna in the first half of 1986 and to one incident of hitting and two incidents of rough handling of the one gymnast in late 1992 or early 1993 by a coach who was employed by the Australian Gymnastics Federation at the time. He was based in the AIS gymnasium but is no longer associated with the AIS. No physical injury was caused by that inappropriate treatment.

I believe that these allegations of abuse within the women's artistic gymnastics program at the AIS have been thoroughly investigated by Mr Opie. I am satisfied that there are no inappropriate training methods or abuse occurring within the program.

PARA.TAB: The inquiry has recommended counselling for the coach involved in the 1992-93 incident, and that particular coach's conduct will be referred to the Australian Coaching Council and the Australian Gymnastic Federation. It is important to point out that this coach is no longer associated with the AIS and was not an AIS employee at the time of the incident. The inquiry has not recommended that any action be taken against the coach involved in the 1986 incident.

The inquiry made further recommendations regarding the designation of a confidential counsellor for the gymnastics program and the existence of rules about gymnasts having boyfriends. I have asked the chairman of the Australian Sports Commission for advice as to the appropriate means of implementing the five recommendations of the inquiry.

The allegations raised earlier this year were very serious allegations. They did deserve to be properly investigated. I do thank Mr Opie for the thoroughness of his investigation, and I commend his report to senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, can you tell the Senate what the federal government is doing to ensure that Australian coaching standards and methods are of an acceptable level?

—The Australian Sports Commission has and will continue to keep a close watch over coaching standards and methods. Coaches in all sports have an important responsibility to nurture the talents of their athletes and, of course, to treat young athletes with care.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Sports Commission recently revised the code of conduct for coaches in order to more closely define the standards expected of AIS coaches. The Australian Coaching Council has developed a generic code of conduct for all coaches. National sporting organisations are being encouraged to adopt this code. The ASC has recently negotiated an industrial award for coaches through the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, which stipulates that coaches formally negotiate their responsibilities, standards and goals with the director of the AIS. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of former distinguished Senator John Coulter, who has just left us. I welcome you back on behalf of senators.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In March this year, when asked by John Laws to rule out the introduction of wealth or inheritance taxes, the Prime Minister said, `I am not in the business of ruling in and ruling out taxes on the radio.' Two days later he pointedly refused to rule out the introduction of a services tax, saying, `I am not ruling things in and out because there is no point.' The Prime Minister has now had eight months to throw these dead cats out of the ring. Will you categorically rule out the introduction of wealth or inheritance taxes and the introduction of a services tax, or are you simply going to the electorate asking for a blank cheque so that if re-elected you would be free to kick long-suffering taxpayers to death with these sorts of draconian tax measures?

—We are not going to the electorate asking for a blank cheque. That is what the opposition is up to. That is not what we are up to. We are saying that when we came to power in 1982-83 the level of taxation as a percentage of GDP was 24 per cent. This budgetary year the level of taxation as a percentage of GDP is expected to be 24.2 per cent. That is a record of consistency that we expect and intend to maintain. That is our position.

PARA.TAB: I am not going to get into a position here—I said this yesterday and I will say it again today—in which someone comes up with a favourite tax that they have on their mind and asks for things to be ruled in and ruled out. What we as a government have always said is that it is the total level of taxation in the community that is the reference point. We have been consistent on that point.

We have been able to successfully reduce levels of taxation overall during the course of our government. According to the OECD statistics, we are the second most lightly taxed country in the OECD. If we were taxed at the level of the OECD average, then Australians would pay $50 billion extra in additional tax. That is how we compare in the club of developed countries in the world of which Australia is a member—the second most lightly taxed and on average taxed $50 billion a year less than what the other countries in that category of developed countries are taxed.

That is our record. If we want to go to the level of taxes under the opposition compared with us, people in Australia know the answer to that question. Under you, they were higher; under us, they are lower.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—That is true.
—That is not true.
—It is true and you continue to carry on that it is not true.
—It is simply not true.
—You know what you're saying is false. If you want to pause on that point, let me get the—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Before Senator Cook realises that the answer he has just given was the one he should have given to Senator Hill, can I simply say that any attempt to frantically turn up some material that might start to address ancient history lectures about the levels of taxation in the early 1980s is clearly utterly irrelevant. You are capable of understanding that this question has nothing to do with coalition tax policy more than a decade ago, and you ought to rule at least that part of it out.

—On a further point of order, not on that point of order: yesterday, Mr President, you made much of the fact that you weren't going to tolerate people suggesting that other people were liars and imputing improper motives to them, for example, by saying, `That is a Carmen.' Yet you have allowed the minister to say, `You know what you're saying is false.' That is a clear imputation against all of this side. Mr President, you would not allow it last week from our side. It is a clear inference from that side that people on this side are liars, that they know what they are saying is false. If you want to follow what you have told this chamber before, you have to ask him to withdraw that matter.

—On Senator Vanstone's point, that is not what I said at all. I suggest you read what I did say in Hansard. On Senator Alston's point, I think Senator Cook has already answered your question and he is at liberty to expand on the points that he is making if he wants to.
—Mr President, I rise on a further point of order. What do you say, Mr President, if I say to you: you know what you're saying is false?
—I am suggesting that you read the statement that I made the other day.
—Yes, but that is not what I'm asking. I'm not asking what you just said. I am saying: what do you say if I put it to you now that you know what you're saying is false?
—I would treat it with disdain. Please take your seat. You have made your point.
—Ignore it, would you?
—I would treat it with the disdain that it deserves.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Can you rule whether or not those comments are unparliamentary? That is what you are being invited to do, because they impute an improper motive and suggest that somebody has been telling an untruth knowingly therefore having the requisite intent to, in other words, make it into a lie. Mr President, consistent with your previous rulings, you must rule that the comments of the minister are unparliamentary and they should therefore be withdrawn. Mr President, if you want to carry the respect of this side of the house, you do have to be consistent in the way that you rule.
—I have made it quite clear that it had nothing whatever to do with the statement I made the other day. I suggest that you read the statement. It is clearly not out of order.

—On a point of order, Mr President, are you ruling that a statement that `you know what you are saying is false' is in fact quite in order and that it does not impute anything to any other honourable senator?
—I'm saying that, in longstanding practice of this chamber, that has been regarded as being in order, while calling somebody a liar has not.

—I want to go on and prove my assertion, that is, if you go to the record, government revenue as a percentage of GDP under the Howard administration averaged 26 per cent and under Labor averages 24.1 per cent. If you go to the levels of personal income tax, the top marginal rate of personal income tax when John Howard was Treasurer was 60 per cent; under Labor it is 47 per cent. The bottom marginal rate when John Howard was Treasurer was 30 per cent; under Labor it is 20 per cent. As a consequence, I stand by my claim.

PARA.TAB: One of the reasons I couched my phrases in the way in which I did is that I know that Senator Short is a professional economist; he used to work for the Department of Finance before he was elected to the Senate. I had a choice: to say that he knew that what he was saying was wrong, or impute his professional status as an economist. I don't mind which choice the Senate takes. But he is wrong, whether he knew it or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we be quite clear about this. You do have the ability to rule out certain things, don't you? You understand that. You also know that your Prime Minister has specifically left open the option of wealth and inheritance taxes, on the one hand, and services taxes, on the other. Is your position now, shortly before the federal election, that you want to keep the option open to go down those paths? Is that your position? At the very least then, can I ask you: do you stand by your statement of last week that `we do not intend to introduce new taxes in the forthcoming election'? At least the people are entitled to know what you stand for and what your intentions are. Can't you at least address that part of the question?

—I have addressed that part of the question several times. What I am refusing to do, and what I will continue to refuse to do, is to accept the words you want to put in my mouth, Senator, because I won't accept from you what Labor policy is. You don't even know what Liberal policy is, let alone what our policy is. And you don't know what Liberal policy is because you haven't got one. We know, according to the Australian Financial Review, that in any case your leader has not the courage of his own convictions. I have made it plain three or four times and it would be a matter of tedium for me to make it plain five or six times—
—Never stopped you before.

—It has never stopped me in the past, says my colleague Senator Collins. I stand by the remarks I have made, the remarks the Treasurer has made and the remarks the Prime Minister has made. We will keep the level of taxation at about the same level of GDP as we have done all the way through. We are a tax-reforming government. We have reduced the level of taxation overall. We are the second most-lightly taxed economy in the OECD, and it would cost Australians $50 billion more if we were simply an average economy. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Cook, the Minister representing the Treasurer. The minister would be aware that today's national accounts show that seasonally adjusted GDP increased by 1.6 per cent in the September quarter and by 3.3 per cent through the year, exceeding the median market expectation of around 1.3 per cent. A stable economic environment with appropriate fiscal responsibility contributes to this continued growth. Can the minister explain the benefits of this continued growth for the Australian economy? Can he also indicate how this would be affected if the government happened to be one which was unable or unwilling to show strong leadership and fiscal responsibility in order to maintain a stable environment for industry?

—Today the Australian Bureau of Statistics reported the national accounts for the September quarter 1995. To the last of those questions that have been put to me, I would say that it would create a framework for the national economy in which you could not expect the same levels of jobs growth, profit or overall economic growth or investment.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the other parts of the question. For most of this year Mr Howard has been saying that the economy is highly vulnerable and that we have only had five minutes of economic sunshine. So much for Mr Howard and so much for those senators opposite who have been enthusiastically endorsing his rhetoric. Today's national accounts showed that the economy is in very sound shape indeed. We have recorded the longest period of continuous growth since records commenced in 1959. All the indications are that the economy is set to continue growing not just for several more quarters but for several more years.

We should never forget just how dismal a failure Mr Howard was when he was Treasurer. We have just recorded 17 consecutive quarters of economic growth. That is four years and three months of growth. The best Mr Howard could manage when he was Treasurer was five consecutive quarters of economic growth. That is a measly one year and three months of growth. If 17 quarters equals five minutes of sunshine, the best John Howard can manage as Treasurer is one minute and 28 seconds. At once, the stark comparison reveals John Howard's past failure and exposes the opposition's claims about five minutes of economic sunshine as distortions and as nothing more than hollow rhetoric.

The fact that we have smashed the economic growth record is, of course, tremendous news for Australians. But what makes this recovery particularly special is that for the first time in a generation we have been able to combine strong growth with low inflation. When John Howard left office in 1983 we had a recession, double digit unemployment and double digit inflation. In contrast, today's national accounts show an economy that grew by 1.6 per cent in the September quarter in seasonally adjusted terms and by 3.3 per cent through the year to the September quarter 1995. The national accounts also indicate that inflation continues to remain moderate. Over the last year the private consumption and non-farm GDP deflators, which are broader measures of inflation than the CPI, both increased by less than three per cent.

In addition to strong growth and low inflation, the highlights of the recovery so far include real wages up by six per cent, real household disposable income per capital up by 12 per cent, productivity up by 13 per cent, total private new capital expenditure up by 31 per cent and company profits before income tax up by 150 per cent.

Looking at the remainder of 1995-96, continuing high levels of employment vacancies, strong international competitiveness and high levels of activity in the September quarter all point to continued economic and employment growth and further falls in the levels of unemployment. That is good news for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Labour productivity change is running at an annual rate of less than three per cent, according to the latest national accounts, yet wages, salaries and supplements are increasing at an annual rate of more than seven per cent. Isn't the discrepancy a cause for concern? Doesn't it imply further increases in the rate of inflation? Isn't it the reason why the Governor of the Reserve Bank and the markets believe there is little likelihood of a reduction in interest rates?

—Here we go again. This is another invitation—I think the second one this week—to invite me to speculate on movements in interest rates and to express a view about what the Governor of the Reserve Bank may or may not have said about interest rates. The opposition knows—maybe it has forgotten because it has not been in power for so long—that ministers in governments do not speculate on two things: they do not speculate on movements in the exchange rate and they do not speculate on movements in interest rates, and nor should they. So I will decline the invitation to speculate on interest rates inherent in this question.

PARA.TAB: The question goes more broadly to measures in the national accounts about the performance of the economy. I have just answered a question from my colleague on the back bench about the performance of the economy. In summary, we have strong, steady growth. We are past the boom-bust cycle. We are into a steady but strong, nonetheless upward trend line for economic growth for Australia. The important characteristic of the quarterly accounts that came out at 11.30 this morning is that this strong growth is married to historically low inflation. For the first time in a generation Australians are looking at a growth economy with low inflation. That is good news for the economy.

Part of the question also related to productivity, and productivity measures in the national accounts. If one turns to productivity measures for Australia, one would have to say, looking at the history of the Australian economy, that we are witnessing now historically high levels of productivity, particularly labour productivity, in the economy. If we compare levels of productivity now with the time when the coalition was on the treasury bench, we see they are higher now. One of the reasons why they are is that we have introduced other measures which have encouraged investment in capital equipment, thus improving the stock and efficiency of plant and equipment in Australia, which means that the input of labour creates a vastly greater output in productivity terms. We have also decentralised the wage fixing system and enabled collective bargaining to ensue in the workplace and traded productivity gains for wage increases, which has also underpinned productivity growth. We are looking at strong, historically high productivity.

Another part of the question goes to the earnings part of the national accounts brought down today. The earnings measure shows higher earnings by ordinary Australians. That is not a bad thing—ordinary Australians having an extra few dollars in their pockets. That is attributed to an increase in farm earnings because of the end of the drought—and farmers having more income as a consequence—and the propensity for more overtime to be worked in the economy, and to productivity changes as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer the minister to the recent elections held to determine the board membership of Coles Myer where, despite a very wide spread of shareholdings, the ultimate composition of the board was determined by holders of large voting blocks. I ask the minister: will the government in its current review of the corporations law examine the introduction by law of voting systems designed to achieve more democratic board representation—that is, representation in proportion to shares held by all shareholders, including small shareholders? In particular, will the government consider the so-called cumulative voting system commonly used in the United States and producing results similar to the quota preferential system used to elect senators?

—Senator Spindler, you have just sent a message of shock and horror through the corporate sector with a suggestion that we have the same sort of voting system for them as we have for this place. The composition of a company's board is a matter to be determined in accordance with a company's articles of association. It is not a matter in which the government can intervene.In terms of voting systems, maybe I will pass on your suggestion to the Attorney-General and he can reflect on it over the break.

PARA.TAB: What we deem as essential for the effective representation of shareholders is that companies engage in best practice corporate governance. Obviously, the quality of corporate governance is quite fundamental. We have been keen to ensure we can enhance the levels of corporate governance in Australia. We have taken measures—I think you have been aware of them—including the improvement and streamlining of provisions of the Corporations Law relating to meetings, the adoption of a new ASX listing rule requiring listed companies to report on the corporate governance practices they have in place, as well as proposed reforms to the corporations law to provide for a statutory derivative action. As you would appreciate, this will be a particularly important weapon for minority shareholders and will provide much needed discipline for corporations. We have moved down those avenues to raise the quality of corporate governance, recognising that government cannot be involved in who is selected for a company's board.
Your question goes to the system of voting. As I said, we do not have any plans to change that. But I am sure that, if I do not pass on your ideas to the Attorney-General, you will. So I will do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the minister was so kind to offer to pursue the issue with the Attorney-General, could he make sure that the main principle of what the Democrats are proposing gets across? We are simply saying that the voting power to elect directors should be related to the shareholding spread and that small shareholders, therefore, should have an opportunity to represent their interests.

—I essentially said three things. Firstly, there are no plans to change. Secondly, a voting system like the Senate's is something that we would bestow on only our worst enemies. Thirdly, in terms of passing on the information, that is all I will do.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, Senator Cook. I refer to reports last week that Professor Fels intends to apply the new competition legislation to anti-dumping, commenting that `most of the successful anti-dumping actions in Australia would not pass the competition policy test'. Does the government support Professor Fels in these endeavours to bring anti-dumping within the purview of his new commission?

—I am aware of what Professor Fels has said. I must say I think he was stating the obvious in that there are close links between competition policy and trade policy. That is essentially what he was saying. There is an obvious interaction between competition amongst domestic producers and competition with overseas producers through imports.

PARA.TAB: This link is important to Australian producers not only as they compete at home but as they seek to compete in foreign markets as well. The linkages between trade and competition policies are receiving attention in international fora—as Senator Boswell knows and, I think, as he has referred to in his question—like the OECD. The Australian government does support those discussions and does support a continuance of those discussions.

I can assure Senator Boswell that nothing in the recent amendments to the Trade Practices Act or in the government's national competition policy increases the scope of the ACCC to involve itself in anti-dumping matters. For the information of the Senate, the only part of the Trade Practices Act which deals with anti-dumping is section 46A. This section applies only to dumping disputes between Australia and New Zealand. That change was made to the Trade Practices Act in 1990 with the agreement of the New Zealand government.

Neither the OECD nor the ACCC sets the competition or trade policy framework which we have in Australia. That is set by this government and by the parliament where it involves legislative change. Current anti-dumping activity involving Australia compares well with overseas countries. Our policies protect the interests of Australian industry, both as producers and as consumers of imports. We would not be willing to change those policies without much widespread consultation with Australian industry, I might say.

As I said, the interaction between competition and trade policies is attracting discussion in international fora like the OECD. The government thinks there is a lot more work to be done in this area. We will participate in the international discussion with interest. But I can say that we have no plans to extend the operation of the Trade Practices Act to cover anti-dumping matters beyond its current specific application to New Zealand.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very detailed answer. It is gratifying to know that that is the government's position. But my next question is: would you tell Professor Fels in no uncertain terms to keep his hands off the anti-dumping legislation that has nothing to do with him whatsoever?

—I am sure Professor Fels will have noted your comments. I do not need to pass them on to him. Without going to a defence of Professor Fels, which I would normally make and happily do so, he of course will defend himself. But I just make the observation that, when it comes to legislation, this parliament decides.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. What involvement has the Office of Indigenous Affairs in the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet had in formulating the recommendations of the ATSIC review committee on native title representative bodies? Is it true that this review committee has recommended that there should be only one representative body for each region? Has this been accepted as government policy? Why is it being proposed to reduce the options of Aboriginal communities in choosing a body to assist them in native title claims, especially when the Native Title Act explicitly allows for more than one body to exist?
—I am sorry; I do not have a brief on that matter. I will need to take the question on notice, but I will give you an answer as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I ask: what is the objective of the government's policy in relation to nuclear disarmament and the Canberra commission? Is it, as Senator Gareth Evans seemed to imply two days ago in question time, the absolute and total elimination of nuclear weapons, or is it deep and significant reductions to absolute minimal levels? If it is the former, what effect does that have on our allies? Particularly, what do the Americans think about it? What is the effect of it on the joint defence facilities and the ANZUS alliance? Were the implications of this policy thought through in detail by Defence before the policy was made public?
—Part of Senator MacGibbon's question asks me what is in Senator Gareth Evans's mind.
—No.
—Yes, it does. I will let Senator Evans speak for himself. But, yes, there was consultation between departments on the evolution of this policy.
—Rubbish.

—Senator Alston gives a self description by way of interjection. We were consulted, both at a departmental and ministerial level, on this particular policy. As Senator Evans I think has said, there is a fine line eventually to be drawn by the total abolition or some retention for deterrence reasons. That is one of the reasons I think the Canberra commission exists. We still face one ultimate conundrum in terms of total nuclear disarmament of how we deal with a rogue state not signed up that develops such a capacity. I am sure the Canberra commission, in all of its wisdom, will develop some views on that to the assistance of this government and a whole range of leaders right around the globe.
—Since I have been invited by Senator Robert Ray to add a few words of my own, I make clear, as Senator MacGibbon ought to be well aware, that under article 6 of the—
—Pass the parcel, is it?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just like tag wrestling.
—Tag wrestling, it is.
—That is right. Give me a tag. Okay!
—This is an unusual practice, but I will allow it seeing as it is a broad question.

—The point of the matter is of course that the nuclear powers are committed to absolute elimination of nuclear weapons by virtue of signing up to article 6 of the non-proliferation treaty. That is the goal to which they have committed themselves already. The question is about the practical attainability of that goal. Those of us who argue for absolute zero as being not only desirable but achievable do so in the context of making the point that, if you are serious about non-proliferation, the existing nuclear weapons powers are going to have to get serious for the first time about elimination.

PARA.TAB: But there is a big problem about working out how to achieve stable deterrence all the way down to zero. There is a big problem about getting acceptance in practice of that obligation so far as the existing declared nuclear weapons states are concerned. As Senator Ray said, that is what this commission is all about: to try to map a realistic plan for actually getting to zero which will demonstrate that it is in fact possible to meet the obligations and that the world will be a safer and saner place as a result.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that Senator Gareth Evans has come into the question, maybe he can resolve the ambiguity because he has only compounded it by coming into the question today. Are you going to push for absolute zero nuclear weapons, or are you going to push for deep and meaningful reductions? Why don't you be honest and forthright so that we can get behind you? If we do not know where you are going, we cannot help you.

—Of course we are going to push for absolute zero. That has always been our commitment; that is always our understanding of what the actual commitment under article 6 of the NPT is; that is our belief as to what is desirable; and that is now our belief as to what is achievable.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the minister advise the Senate of the level of importance that the government places on addressing the problem of land degradation in framing its policy responses to the issues confronting rural Australia? Will the government support a policy providing for fodder subsidies when it is clearly understood that this practice contributes to land degradation?

—You can take this one if you like, Gareth. It is now estimated that the annual loss of agricultural production in Australia due to land degradation is around $1.4 billion. Given this cost, it is imperative that this issue be tackled on all policy fronts by both federal and state governments. In an all-out effort to halt and reverse the degradation of our land and water resources, this remains one of the key tenets of this government's rural and environmental policy strategies. Of course the two have to go hand in hand. To use just one example: the government's overall landcare funding for this year from my portfolio is in excess of $110 million.

PARA.TAB: It was in this context that I was heartened to read the following paragraph in the primary industries section of the confidential speakers notes that were issued by the Liberal Party to its sitting members and candidates. If you want to have a look at two pages of absolutely vacuous rubbish, you want to have a look at the regional affairs page of this document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is responsible for it?

—Ian Macdonald, presumably. The paragraph reads, `Recognise land degradation as Australia's most pressing environmental problem and provide incentives to repair past damage and encourage sustainable farming practices.'
—It sounds pretty good to me.

—It is; I said that I was heartened to read it. It says that the coalition will regard this as being the most pressing problem. It is a laudable sentiment. The problem is that I would strongly urge Australia's farmers, and particularly members of the conservation movement, to ask the Leader of the Opposition how that sits with the opposition's 10-point policy for drought. This drought policy, as I have pointed out before—
—What about your policy?

—It is in fact the only detailed opposition policy document that has been released since the last election; the only one. It completely contradicts the paragraph that I have just quoted. The drought policy advocates the reintroduction of fodder subsidies that clearly encourage overstocking during drought. That is one of the known features of drought subsidies and that is why drought subsidies were rejected comprehensively by all ministers—Labor and non-Labor—as far back as 1992. Such subsidies remove the encouragement for livestock producers to reduce stocking levels and to conserve pastures at a time when they are most vulnerable, and that is during a drought.

PARA.TAB: The result is further land degradation through overgrazing—overgrazing that then increases the severity of the next drought. It is a vicious circle; one that all ministers—Labor and non-Labor, as I said—broke in 1992, and it should remain so. All of those ministers since—Labor and non-Labor—have consistently rejected at every meeting of ARMCANZ where this has come up the reintroduction of these fodder subsidies.

The reason I mention that is that the opposition's commitment to fodder subsidies was explicitly reaffirmed by Mr Howard only a week or two ago in a tour of New South Wales drought areas. He pledged that the opposition would reintroduce an ancient policy that has been comprehensively rejected by every primary industry minister in Australia irrespective of their political affiliations. As long as that remains the official policy position of the opposition, it cannot claim to be really serious about land degradation being the most pressing environmental problem—which it is—that this country has.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Crowley, the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Minister, at present, if a patient pays with a valueless cheque and then claims a cash refund from Medicare, the government takes no action. How will this change with yesterday's announcement?

—Senator Herron, I do not understand what you mean by that comment. I am very prepared to tell you about the changes proposed. If you would like to give me further detail about what you want addressed, I will certainly address it.

PARA.TAB: The changes are really very interesting. Patients who turn up at a Medicare office will no longer have to fill in the forms. A patient will be able to pass the doctor's bill and their Medicare card across the counter and the account will be settled immediately, either with a cheque to the patient or a cheque sent off to the doctor. It will make a very considerable difference to the ease of the process. It will make the turnaround time for patients quicker and it will certainly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections on both sides. Senator Crowley has the floor.

—Thank you, Mr President. It will reduce the paper flow in Medicare offices, and that will be of great benefit to the Health Insurance Commission. Also, it will be very much easier for patients because filling out all those forms is a step that will not be necessary.
—There is no check on it. That is the point.

—Senator, if you would just stop shouting for a minute and listen it might be a bit of a help. It is also proposed to allow people to make claims per the telephone, particularly if they are remote from a Medicare office. These programs are designed to assist patients in their reimbursement through Medicare. There is no doubt that it will do that. Not having to fill in forms unnecessarily will be of great benefit to patients, and it will certainly be of benefit to the Health Insurance Commission. It should reduce the time and, therefore, the cost of claims against Medicare.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. My question had 30 words in it. I thought it would be clear. My point of order is in relation to relevance. I have waited three minutes for an answer to my question.
—You should have stopped shouting.
—Would you like to have a go at it? Senator Evans had a go with Senator Ray. Would you like to have a go, Senator Bolkus?
—Get to your point of order, Senator Herron.
—The minister has not approached my question. I am just asking if anybody over there can answer my question, Mr President.
—Order! The minister said right at the outset that she was not clear on what you were asking. She was answering the question as she saw fit and she is relevant to the general thrust of the question.

—Senator, I made it quite clear that the changes announced will be of great benefit only and I cannot see how you would want to object to them. The assistance will be of economic benefit to the Health Insurance Commission, therefore to the taxpayer in terms of the cost, and also, of course, of great assistance to people making claims. The convenience for them will be very significant indeed, both in time and in ease of getting those—
—What about the fraud aspect?

—Are you concerned that if a cheque is paid to a person who makes a false claim under Medicare there will be a difficulty with this? If that is the question you are raising it is a question I have already asked.
—No.

—Then, Senator, I have to say that I am not clear on the point of the question you raise. It seems to me to go to the changes proposed to make Medicare payments easier. As I say, if there is something further you want me to understand, please ask and I will deal with it.
—Perhaps I could clarify for the minister—
—In how many words?
—In six words: will it make fraud easier?
—That's five words.
—You are right.

—I am advised that no, it will not; that the Health Insurance Commission is very concerned to address those questions in anticipation of moving to these changes. It is a matter of balance. The question of fraud is very high on the list of concerns for the Health Insurance Commission. I have asked that question. I have been advised that it is a major concern and that, no, the prospects for fraud should be no more this way than they ever are and that, as much as possible, the Health Insurance Commission will be particularly keeping an eye on that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Minister, I refer you to the significant decision that the government is about to make, in which your department is very much involved, on our remaining native forests which are outside the existing reserve system and which obviously are of considerable significance to our plantation timber industry. I ask: is it correct that the Commonwealth government has hired the services of a public relations consultant in order to convince the Australian people that this decision is indeed a good decision? As I have now heard from many sources that indeed you have, I go on and ask a second question. If the government has prepared a reasonable forest package—that is, one based on scientific evidence and which acknowledges the potential of our plantation timber industry—why does the government need assistance in selling it?

—I am not aware whether there has been any consultant engaged, as Senator Lees has alleged in her question. I can only seek advice from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet that is coordinating this particular matter. I am happy to do that, Senator, and come back to you when I get a response.

PARA.TAB: Senator, I can say that I do not believe there will be the need for a lot of effort to go in, from the point of view of any public relations consultancy, to sell what comprises the decision on forests that the government will be announcing later in the week. I might say to you, Senator, as I outlined to the Senate at some length yesterday, that it is the government's intention, and mine as the environment minister, to ensure that the conservation elements of the national forest policy statement—our commitment to a comprehensive, adequate and representative forest conservation reserve system—are enhanced through this process.

We are very serious about the biodiversity benchmark that we have set in relation to our forest policy. We are serious about protecting 15 per cent of the 17:50 distribution of forest types in Australia. We are serious about protecting at least 60 per cent ranging through to 100 per cent of poorly reserved old growth. We are very serious, Senator, about protecting at least 90 per cent of wilderness ranging through, again, to 100 per cent of poorly reserved high quality wilderness.

We are also very serious, Senator, about ensuring that areas are set aside in advance of making determinations about the final composition of a forest conservation reserve system. We are also very serious, Senator, about ensuring in our forests that we see, in production forest, ecologically sustainable practices taking place in relation to the timber industry. We are also very serious, Senator, about ensuring that for the first time we not only advance those conservation elements of our forest package but do so with a wood and paper industry strategy in place.

We are also very serious, Senator, about addressing the issues of structural adjustment, of course, that are raised because not only are there environmental issues that we have responsibilities for addressing as a government but there are serious social and economic consequences of any decisions we make in relation to setting aside areas of high conservation value native forests. We are also serious, Senator, about ensuring that our plantation resources in this country are enhanced and that existing resources are appropriately utilised.

Of course, that means, I think, Senator, that you can be confident, when the government announces the detail of its package in relation to the forest issues, that it will be the most significant step forward that we have seen in the forest industry debate for decades. I am confident that we will see a very significant step forward in relation to the conservation of our high conservation value native forests. I believe that the government will honour its commitment of ensuring that our approach is balanced. It is based on a very good process—the best process we have ever seen in place—and also done on the basis of scientific criteria that has been accepted from all sides of the debate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, I ask you to reconsider the ruling you gave during question time in response to a number of points of order from this side about the statement, `You know "what you are saying is untrue" is not unparliamentary.' During question time I had the opportunity of reading through a booklet entitled `Rulings of the President of the Senate from 1953 to 1971', volume XI, which details a few rulings. For example, ruling 229 is:

PARA.TAB: It is not in order for a Senator to refer to the answer given to his Question as being "false and misleading".

SPEECH.PARA: There are a lot of other examples. For example, you are not allowed to say that something is a `distortion of the truth'—that is ruling 107. Ruling 132 says it is a `disorderly expression' to refer to somebody making an `untruthful statement'. `The senator forgot to be a little bit honest' is also a disorderly expression.

PARA.TAB: With due respect, there are numerous rulings from former presidents indicating that a reflection on somebody's integrity in relation to knowingly not telling the truth is imputing improper motives, is a disorderly expression, is disorderly conduct and should therefore be withdrawn. You, Mr President, in fact, are charged with making that decision as to whether or not a comment should be withdrawn. In fact, ruling 134 says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the responsibility of the Chair to decide whether or not a remark is offensive and should be withdrawn.

With due respect, for a fellow senator to be told, `You know that what you are telling is untrue,' can have no other implication than, `You are telling a Carmen Lawrence; you are telling a lie.' Mr President, with due respect, if—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. One thing you have explicitly ruled about is that the reference to `telling a Carmen Lawrence' in the context in which Senator Abetz was just offering that observation is obviously not helpful to the maintenance of decorum and dignity in this place.
—Thank you for making my point. Come in, spinner!
—I ask you to withdraw that reference.
—Mr President, with due respect, I was canvassing a ruling in which you yourself said that to say `Carmen Lawrence' refers to—
—You were not quoting me directly, though, as I understood it. You were actually using it in—
—That is a ruling. Is it not a ruling any more?
—No. I did not think he was quoting me.
—Mr President, if I could, with due respect, remind you of what I said, I read out ruling 134:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the responsibility of the Chair to decide whether or not a remark is offensive and should be withdrawn.

I then reminded you, Mr President, of your ruling that to say `Carmen Lawrence' was, in your view, `a lie' and, therefore, offensive and ought be withdrawn. Similarly, I am suggesting to you in exactly the same vein the comment, `You know what you are saying is untrue,' has to be seen in the same category as a `Carmen Lawrence' or `a lie'. On that basis, I would ask you, with respect, to reconsider your ruling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on the point of order: as I understand your ruling, it was not simply in response to a suggestion that `What you are saying is false' may or may not be, depending on your judgment, out of order. On the basis of previous decisions by the chair quoted by Senator Abetz, it may well be that a senator who says, `What you are saying is false,' could be held to be in breach of the standing orders. However, today's question time problem emerged not out of that statement but out of a statement that said, `You know what you are saying is false.' It is the `you know' element that provides the imputation.

PARA.TAB: The reason I support Senator Abetz's request to you to reconsider is that it may well be that you did not focus—and there was plenty going on at the time—on those first few words which changed the nature of the remark by Senator Cook to make it a far more serious and offensive remark than the suggestion which is often made that `What you are saying is false or untrue'. To say, `You know what you are saying is false,' cannot be anything else than an imputation that you are doing something deliberately that is wrong and improper. Surely that is an imputation, and I ask you to reconsider your decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can cut this short. I am happy to comply with the request and look at it again.

—On that matter, I actually heard the original remark across the chamber in the way that I suspect you actually heard the remark as a straightforward assertion that what someone was saying was false. If, indeed, Hansard should indicate that the expression actually used was as it has been described by Senator Abetz with unnecessary flourishes and Senator Baume with equally unnecessary flourishes—
—I was very restrained.

—You were actually. That is probably fair comment at this stage. I withdraw that relation to you but I put it back with nobs on in relation to him. If the remark as it turns up in Hansard actually is, `You know what you said is false,' I think we have to acknowledge that does convey an imputation and accordingly it probably is properly to be regarded as unparliamentary. Everything depends on context and the spirit in which it is said as well as the actual words. I suspect that might have been part of your ruling, too. I would suggest that there is no need to further pursue this matter because the point that is being made is probably a fair one.
—As I have said, I am happy to have a look at it. I certainly concede the point that you raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Alston this day relating to taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: This is in relation to the secret tax agenda of the Keating-Willis Labor government. I think this minister when he answers economic questions is given a brief at the beginning of the week. I think they sit him down on Monday morning and say, `Senator Cook, no matter what they ask you about the economy this is the answer.' He is very sure of himself when he is on this brief. They probably sit him down there for a couple of hours and train him away after he has had his morning cup of tea and his sleep in.

PARA.TAB: This week it was: `Minister Cook, you have had your cup of tea. The line this week is that the general level of taxation as a percentage of GDP was worse under John Howard than it is under our government. Whatever they ask you, whether it is to do with your tax agenda or any other economic question, just keep saying that. Here's a little speech that will last exactly four minutes. If they ask you a supplementary, just do the best you can, but this is the speech and stick to the line. It doesn't matter what they ask you. Whether it is Senator Hill or Senator Alston or anyone else, just stick to this line.'

Senator Cook gets himself in all sorts of trouble when he goes off the line. The briefings on Monday morning when he gets on the plane coming back from Perth are getting longer and longer. Senator Cook is getting better at sticking to the line. Earlier in question time—and it is a little bit off the subject—he was asked a question by Senator Hill in relation to four different statements he had made about tax policy. He has made a couple more today and that is clearly where he wandered off the line.

The point I want to make in taking note of his answer is that tax is something you can quote in terms of the statistics. If you want to look at the statistics as far as tax as a percentage of GDP is concerned, all you need to look at is the statistics that applied in Australia under the Whitlam government. Most people have a clear recollection of tax policy under the Whitlam government and some of the geniuses they had as Treasurers of Australia during that short period in our history.

The tax rate at that stage was much lower as a percentage of GDP than it is now under this Labor government. One of the great achievements of Mr Keating, regarded in the early 1980s by the people who gave him the award as `the world's best finance minister' or Treasurer, as we call it in Australia, is that he, who has been a great critic of fiscal discipline under the Whitlam era in his unguarded moments, has achieved a higher tax rate as a percentage of GDP than was achieved under the average years in the Whitlam regime.

I checked with the library during question time and the average rate during 1972 to 1975 that people like Senator Herron will remember as times of economic chaos in Australia was 22.6 per cent. Of course the average rate under the Keating government and as his time as Treasurer is significantly higher than that. Well done, Mr Keating. Well done, Mr Willis. You have outdone Jim Cairns and Gough Whitlam. You have actually achieved much higher rates of taxation as a percentage of GDP.

What is more important to families, however, because the rate of tax as a percentage of GDP would be almost an irrelevant consideration to them when they sit down to do their budgets at the end of the week and their tax returns at the end of the year is how the tax system in Australia and how Mr Keating's taxes affect them as a family. When this government wants to look at international comparisons, it should turn to a very important study done by the OECD as late as only a couple of years ago—in fact, 1992; not that long ago—which compared the impact of income tax as a percentage of gross earnings with the average wages of a family with two children.

Let us contemplate what that study does. It looks at the impact of taxes in Australia on the average family, with a couple of kids and probably living in the metropolitan area of one of Australia's great cities. What is the answer? It shows that Australia has higher tax as a percentage of gross earnings on families than Luxembourg, France, Portugal, Japan, Spain, Austria, Switzerland, Germany, Holland, the United States, Belgium, Canada, Great Britain, Italy, Ireland—and even higher than Norway. In fact, there are only four countries in the OECD that have higher taxes on average families than Australia. They are Denmark, Sweden, Finland and New Zealand. That study was done in 1992. I suspect the OECD are updating that. It will be interesting to look at what has happened since the 1993 election because we all know that, despite the promises of the Keating government, taxes like sales taxes and petrol taxes have increased since then. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) to a question without notice asked by Senator Minchin this day, relating to the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook did his best to dress up what really were a very disturbing set of national accounts released today. The most disturbing thing about them was the revelation that economic growth has slowed right down to an annual rate of 3.3 per cent, which is way down on what it previously was and what the government boasted about. The really disturbing thing about that level of growth is what it means for the three-quarters of a million Australians who cannot get a job under this government. These figures are very bad news for jobless Australians and mean that they will have great difficulty getting a job, and that in fact unemployment will continue to increase with a level of growth of that low order.

PARA.TAB: What the national accounts figures do is reinforce something that the National Institute of Labour Studies said in its September 1995 issue of the Australian Bulletin of Labour:

SPEECH.PARA: Medium term forecasts suggest that achieving an unemployment rate much below 7 per cent by the start of the 21st century will be difficult unless labour force growth slows and productivity growth remains flat. The government's Working Nation target of a 5 per cent unemployment rate by the year 2000 will not be achieved.

That is an authoritative statement from the well-respected and independent National Institute of Labour Studies, pointing out that the five per cent target has no hope of being achieved. That conclusion is reinforced by the figures released today showing growth slowing to 3.3 per cent.

PARA.TAB: I make two other points there. They say that even achieving the seven per cent will be difficult unless labour force growth slows and productivity growth remains flat. Of course, the government is increasing the growth of the labour force by its own policies, contradicting this, and the government has today boasted, through the form of Senator Cook, about the growth in productivity. So those two prerequisites themselves set by the National Institute of Labour Studies are being breached by the current situation.

The institute itself thinks that the best we can possibly achieve is an unemployment rate by the year 2000, which I point out is only four years away, of 7.3 per cent; and even that figure would require an annual economic growth of 3.7 per cent over the next four years, which of course is higher than the growth we have seen today. The economy is clearly slowing; the growth is likely to decline.

The institute said in this report which has just been released that if average economic growth falls below 3 1/2 per cent, unemployment will actually begin to rise. Of course, today's figure is 3.3 per cent. I heard a bank economist today commenting on these figures say that he expects that unemployment will be back over nine per cent very soon, based on these figures. So this five per cent target, which the government still proclaims to support, has been blown apart by this report and by today's figures.

The report shows that economic growth would need to average 4.2 per cent to achieve this five per cent target, which of course is out of the question. We have only achieved a rate near 4.2 per cent in one out of every three years over the last 15, so that figure cannot be achieved. The institute notes that the growth rate required to achieve a five per cent target of unemployment is simply not sustainable under current economic policy. That is why this government has to be defeated. That is why, for the sake of the unemployed, we need a change of government and a change to the economic settings so that we can achieve the five per cent target which under current settings we simply cannot do.

Under current settings, if we are to have the current rate of growth required to achieve the five per cent target, we will obviously have increases in the rate of inflation and a worsening of the current account deficit, which is already in a disastrous situation. That was the import of my question today about inflation. These national account figures show that we are about to face a very significant inflationary problem. We have wages and salaries growth hitting 7.4 per cent, way ahead of productivity growth and clearly putting a lot of pressure on inflation.

The bottom line in all this is clearly, based on the national accounts and on the report of the Institute of Labour Studies, that the government's economic policies have failed Australians, particularly the three-quarters of a million Australians who cannot get a job under this government. They have failed young Australians, a whole host of whom are about to come onto the job market in January. The government has failed them miserably and must be defeated.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Chamarette this day, relating to ATSIC funding for representative bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans's answer reveals the priority given by him to this topic in that he was not able to respond, even in a small way, to my question. I know that he has many matters on his mind. In recognition of that, his office was informed three-quarters of an hour before question time that he would be receiving a question on that topic. However, as I told him in a note, it is `questions without notice' and his failure to answer not only wasted my last question for the session but prevented me from asking a supplementary. I said to Senator Evans that I was sure he would be extremely distressed on my behalf. He owned up to his truthfulness in his response when he said, `I cannot tell a lie; I am not deeply distressed'.

PARA.TAB: I raised the question because it is a very important matter. The reason I asked Senator Evans a question in relation to this area is that I wanted to draw attention to a very negative state of affairs in regard to the funding for representative bodies. It appears that while the Native Title Act explicitly allowed for more than one body to exist in each region to allow Aboriginal communities to make a choice where there was a possible disagreement with a particular representative body or where there were two communities with competing claims over the same area—a very sensible provision—it appears that there is a proposition to reduce the options of Aboriginal communities to only have one representative body for each region. I very much wanted the minister to comment on this and to give us some kind of answer as to whether this has already been accepted as government policy and certainly to challenge that.

The other matter that I believed needed to be drawn attention to, which I would have raised if I had the opportunity, was that over 40 per cent of ATSIC funding for these representative bodies is allocated to two land councils—the Kimberley Land Council and the Cape York Land Council. I believe that there are some serious questions that need to be addressed, which the minister clearly does not have under his purview regarding the equitable access for Aboriginal communities to assist them in native title claims. I believe that the government needs to commit itself to reviewing the nature of the distribution of funding to representative bodies and address the questions of equity that are plainly disclosed.

I will later seek leave to incorporate two incredible graphs that illustrate this vividly. The first one simply shows the range of funding available to the different representative bodies. It demonstrates visually the malapportionment of funding to the two land councils that I have already mentioned. That is further exacerbated if we look at the second graph, which lays alongside that same graph and shows the percentage of population that is being served by these representative bodies. It is an absolute outrage. It extends the whole inequitability of funding that has been exposed in this government's response to native title, land funds and, presumably in the future, to the social justice package.

It seems extremely inequitable to excessively favour, in this case, certain northern land councils as opposed to those in the southern part of Australia. It is actually penalising those Aboriginal people who have experienced more dispossession, more extinguishment of native title. So, of the 250,000 Aboriginal people, we have three groups—one which may have some chance of receiving native title, and they may be five per cent of that number; one group which may have access to a land fund, which is approximately 15 per cent; and the rest, 80 per cent, being totally ignored and increasingly dispossessed with every moment that passes. They are the same names—all in the north—that appear on all the funding bodies, on all the funding that is given for native title, for the land fund and, presumably, it will be the case with the social justice package.

In closing, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the graphs I referred to earlier. I do so having taken note of Senator Evans' most inadequate response to my question. I hope he will give a better one at some point. If he is willing to do so today, I would be more than delighted to hear any response he might make.
Leave granted.
