SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Herron this day, relating to proposed changes to Medicare.

SPEECH.PARA: The question I asked was a genuine one. I have raised this matter of fraud over the last five years. It may be recalled that some years ago the Auditor-General produced a report saying that massive fraud was occurring in relation to Medicare. The community affairs committee was given a briefing to consider the Auditor-General's report. The government came out backing the Auditor-General's report and said that fraud to the extent of $400 million a year was occurring.

PARA.TAB: I questioned the basis for that figure and it was found that the basis was an estimate made on figures given in the United States as a percentage of the total amount spent on Medicare there. So, in fact, there was no basis for the figure. I pursued Minister Richardson over the matter. The figure shrank from $400 million to $80 million. I questioned it at estimates committee hearings. The figure now, with regard to money that is refunded to Medicare, is in the vicinity of $1 1/2 million. So it is a rapidly vanishing figure.

The Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) announced yesterday that from 1 December a person can go to a Medicare office with a receipt form and a Medicare card and get an immediate cash refund without having to fill out a form. This opens up the potential for fraud of a major nature.I will give three instances. It may be that the government is not concerned if a patient gives a valueless cheque to a doctor. This has occurred, particularly in relation to radiology services. A patient can write a valueless cheque, get a receipt from the doctor, and now they will be able to go along to Medicare, produce a receipt, get a cash refund and they are on their way. The government does nothing about pursuing that. I know this has occurred in a number of instances. They say to the doctor, `That's your problem. If you accept a valueless cheque, that's too bad.'

There is another aspect to it in addition to the valueless cheque situation. The government does not pursue that, even though it might occur on a number of occasions, because they consider it is not their problem. However, I know of another situation. I know this debate is being broadcast and I do not want a sudden rush of events to occur around Australia, but I think I should bring it to the minister's notice because it has occurred and it can occur under this system. A patient goes to the doctor complaining of a major headache. Eventually, upon the diagnosis determined by the general practitioner, the patient is sent for a CAT scan of the brain. That costs in the vicinity of $400. The patient pays with a valueless cheque, goes to the Medicare office, gets a refund of $400, and the cheque bounces. The next day the patient goes to another GP, complains of a headache, goes through the same process, pays with a valueless cheque, goes to the Medicare office and, as of Friday, collects another $400. That is a fraud on Medicare.

The question was genuine. With these new changes, because there is no form to be filled in now as a result of these changes, what are they going to do to stop patients committing this type of fraud? We know from the prosecutions that have occurred that more fraud, numerically speaking, is committed by patients than by anybody else under Medicare. Twice as much fraud is committed by patients over and above the next step of fraud, which is done by secretaries producing a false receipt book. This lays it right open for anybody with a receipt book or a stolen receipt book, as has occurred in the past, to go along with a receipt and a Medicare card and get a cash refund.

The third event, as I said, is intentional deliberate fraud. That has been done by a number of doctors. In the last 12 months, the average number of doctors who have committed fraud is about 53—it has been 52 and 45; it varies. Of the 47,000 doctors in Australia, 52 or 53 have committed fraud. We get this continual doctor bashing about doctors rorting the system, whereas the majority of rorting is done by patients by intentional fraud; secondly, by secretaries by theft; and, finally, by doctors.

It is a very genuine question. The minister said that it has been addressed. I am sure she did not understand the question—that should have been fairly obvious to anybody who was listening. It may be that she washes her hands and the government washes its hands of it in relation to doctors, but my concern, particularly as a taxpayer and as a representative, is Medicare itself. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Tierney this day, relating to road funding.

SPEECH.PARA: You can always tell when you have got Senator Bob Collins on the backfoot, because he assiduously avoids the key point in question. He does not even address it at all.

PARA.TAB: The reason why he refused to address the key point of the question on black spots is that, in the first year of this government's black spot program, which started after the horrific bus smashes near Kempsey in 1989, the government did spend money on back spots; in the second year they reduced the funding significantly; in the third year, after the accident, they reduced it even more; and then the year after they cut it out and it has not come back since. Yet up the entire length of the north coast on the Pacific Highway, the worst interstate connection in Australia, there are still hundreds of black spots.

We have had the disgraceful situation where the former Liberal government's plans for Motorway Pacific were totally scrubbed by this Labor government. They have no plans to do anything about a road which is 700 kilometres long and yet has 64 kilometres of divided road. The rest of that road is just 1950s-style goat track.

When I went north on the youth bus tour—and it is the first time in 15 years I have been on that road on a bus—I could see as we went around those corners and across those bridges how dangerous it was and why we have such horrific bus smashes on that road. I remind the Senate and the people of Australia that, in the last 10 years, 766 people have lost their lives on that road. How many accidents? Ten thousand accidents. Yet the way in which governments, state and federal, are now approaching this matter, it will be 20 to 30 years before the road will be corrected to what is needed now in 1995, let alone what is going to be needed in the year 2015.

The road connects two of the largest cities in Australia, Sydney and Brisbane—and by the year 2030 Brisbane will be the second largest city in Australia. What you have between them is a goat track and there is no plan to correct that.

The only bit of substance in the minister's answer to my question was, `We're spending the money around your area, Senator,' referring to the Hunter Valley. Oh, is he? Let me read from an article in today's paper entitled `Council roadwork funding cut $2.5m'. It was $3 1/2 million last year and it is $1million this year. The new Carr Labor government has chopped it to one-third of what it was. The article states:
Director of Transport and Works Mr Phil McLeod said the RTA had made little room for special projects . . .
"There is no doubt Maitland is experiencing a downward trend in regard to roads funding.

SPEECH.PARA: Notorious accident black spots, such as Raymond Terrace Road, Woodberry Road, Scotch Creek Road and Martins Wharf Road, are now going to be abandoned. What this state Labor government is doing in the Maitland area, which the minister was holding up as the shining light, is following his example: keep reducing black spot funding till it totally cuts out. How many more accidents do there have to be on that road? How many more deaths do there have to be on that road? How much more trauma will the families of New South Wales have to suffer before this government acts and treats the Pacific Highway as a road of national priority and funds it properly?

PARA.TAB: The whole problem underlying what is happening is that Labor governments significantly and increasingly continue to reduce the money they spend on infrastructure, particularly roads. The last time the Liberal Party was in power federally, in 1982-83, we were spending 62.4 per cent of the fuel excise on road funding. When those horrific bus accidents occurred on the north coast, that amount had dropped from 62 per cent to 20.8 per cent. Since that time, it has dropped to 8.4 per cent. The government rips off 92c of fuel excise dollars and does not put it back into roads. That is why we have these accidents; that is why we have these deaths. It is about time the Labor government woke up to this and started spending proper funding on the roads of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Tierney with regard to the current situation of Australian roads due to funding from the Commonwealth.
—You want to cut government expenditure.

—You will weasel your way out of anything. We know all about you. It is worth looking at particular aspects of road funding. In looking at what has happened over the last three years, we see that in 1992-93 there was an increase of $1.1 billion in the take from fuel excise, in 1993-94 it went up a further $1.3 billion and in 1994-95 another $1.3 billion.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Tierney has said, we see a gradual decrease in the percentage of what goes back into road funding. It is estimated that, in the year 1994-95, the government put $820 million into road funding, which is even less than what was put back into road funding in 1982-83. There has been a gradual decline in percentage terms of what is being put back. The actual amount that went back into road funding in 1994-95 was $817 million. The forward estimates for 1995-96 is $840, which is an increase of $20 million on the previous year's estimates, yet there is a further take on petrol and diesel excise in the order of $1.3 billion.

That is the fundamental reason why we have enormous deterioration of infrastructure and the road systems throughout this country. It underlines the points Senator Tierney made in his question today to Senator Bob Collins and is the very reason that Senator Collins cannot give a satisfactory answer in terms of the situation that exists.

When the Labor government came to office in 1983, the excise was 7c a litre. Today it stands at 33.5c a litre. I also note that the $9.7 billion taken from motorists today represents $570 for every man, woman and child in Australia. Commonwealth government fuel taxes make up 50 per cent of the retail price of each litre of petrol—that is, at a price of around 67c to 68c per litre. By contrast, oil company revenues make up 32 per cent of the price of fuel and the dealer margin is only 2.9 per cent to 3 per cent.

So the fuel excise has become a milking cow for general revenue for this government. They need to recognise, firstly, the importance of bringing a halt to the massive increases in fuel excise and the damage that is doing to living standards and businesses throughout Australia, particularly those involved in farming and mining; and, secondly, the costs which exist with regard to that. The excise on light crude in Western Australia puts up the cost of carting a tonne of grain to port by an average of between $2 and $2.50 per tonne—an enormous additional direct cost that that industry has to bear.

So I just want to put on the record that, in terms of the government's performance since coming to office, as far as fuel excise is concerned, the increase has been absolutely massive. It has been very close to 500 per cent; I think the exact figure is 498 per cent. Yet, at the same time, alongside that, we have seen a gradual reduction in the amount of money going back into our roads. We have seen a significant deterioration of our roads right across Australia, particularly in the northern parts of Australia, the western parts of Queensland, the western parts of New South Wales, the northern parts of South Australia and through the hinterland of Victoria.

People living in the metropolitan areas, for example, do not recognise this. They see their highways, the fast-lane traffic and the various things that go there. But when you go out into the rural areas, the regional areas and the mining areas you find that in some instances bitumen roads are being pulled up because they cannot be maintained because the Commonwealth government has reduced so significantly the level of funding in real terms for the task that is required to keep those roads in reasonable order. The government needs to reassess the situation of fuel excise. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: THE FAMILY LAW REFORM BILL 1994 AND THE FAMILY LAW REFORM BILL (No. 2) 1994
FINAL GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT BY THE SENATE LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL LEGISLATION COMMITTEE
(AUGUST 1995)
FAMILY LAW REFORM BILL (No. 2) 1994

The Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee Report on the above mentioned Bill was tabled on 6 March 1995. The Committee's Report was in 2 parts, the first dealing with the Family Law Reform Bill 1994, and the second dealing with the exposure draft Family Law Reform Bill (No 2) 1994. An interim response to the Committee's report, responding to the recommendations about the Family Law Reform Bill 1994, was tabled in the Senate on 29 March 1995. This final response is in relation to the second part of the Committee's Report, and deals with the exposure draft Family Law Reform Bill (No 2) 1994.
Recommendation 1
A majority of the Committee commends the exposure draft of the Family Law Reform Bill (No 2) 1994

Response: The Government welcomes this support for the enactment of the reforms to the Family Law Act to better facilitate parties agreeing solutions on their property distribution rather than the necessity for judicial decisions.
Recommendation 2
The Committee commends for the consideration of Government the matters raised before the Committee.
Response: The matters raised before the Committee included
an alleged lack of adequate consultation
a questioning of the need to change the matrimonial property regime at all
pre-nuptial agreements (including the need for them at all) and financial agreements, and particularly the formalities (such as prior independent legal advice and witnessing)
the bases for entering into, varying and setting aside both kinds of agreement
the failure to deal adequately with financial resources, particularly superannuation
the perceived presumption of equal sharing of property, and
the perceived need for Court approval of financial agreements and consent property orders

These matters have also been raised in submissions to the Attorney-General and his Department. The consultation process has been most helpful, and has given rise to a number of proposed amendments to the Bill.
Recommendation 3

The Committee, by a majority, recommends that the Court when considering how matrimonial property is to be distributed starts from the presumption that each of the parties have contributed 50% of the resources used to obtain it.

Response: The draft provisions of the Bill are consistent with this recommendation. It is clear from the text of the Committee's Report that the majority supported the provisions of the draft, accepting that they would avoid futile arguments relating to financial and non-financial contributions, largely reflect the existing law, and provide a more `structured' approach to the issue of property settlements (paragraph 2.28). The Bill goes further than the recommendation, and sets up a rebuttable presumption that the parties have made an equal contribution to the marriage as a whole, including the acquisition of property.
Recommendation 4

The Committee recommends that subsection 86C(2) be amended to add an additional factor which recognises the limitations upon the capacity to earn income (and by extension to accumulate assets) created by parenting responsibilities.

Response: The thrust of this recommendation is accepted. Subsection 86C(1) is the provision of the Bill which provides initially that the contributions of the parties to the marriage as a whole are assumed to be equal, unless the Court finds that they were not in fact equal. Subsection 86C(2) sets out the historical matters that a Court may have regard to in determining the contribution that each party made to the marriage in fact. It would not be appropriate to insert into this section a provision that would explain why a party made a greater non-financial contribution than a financial one, which is what the Government understands the thrust of this recommendation to be. Subsection 86C(3) provides that financial and non-financial provisions are intrinsically equally significant. A provision along the lines recommended would not affect the finding of relative contributions. However, a provision should be added to clause 86D to specifically recognise the lack of income due to parenting responsibilities.
Recommendation 5
The Committee recommends that the expression `history of the marriage' in proposed section 86C(2) be clarified.

Response: Accepted. This expression will be deleted. The reference to the history of the marriage has been the subject of much criticism, especially along the lines that it might reintroduce an element of fault into property proceedings and invite consideration of domestic violence in this context.
Recommendation 6
The Committee recommends that pre-nuptial agreements be non-enforceable but be available for use as evidentiary material in relevant proceedings.

Response: This recommendation is not accepted. Binding pre-nuptial agreements are a cornerstone of the revised property regime. The Committee was concerned that such agreements could be oppressive, particularly of women. They also reflected a view that there should be mandatory prior independent legal advice. The Bill did not contain provision for prior independent mandatory legal advice because it was not considered desirable to compel parties to resort to this expense before entering into an agreement. There are adequate protections in the Bill in the provisions relating to varying and setting aside. After all, parties do not have to have independent legal advice before buying property jointly, making gifts to one another, or making wills in favour of one another.

A dissenting report by Coalition Senators urged the Government to again address the issue of assumed equal contribution to the marriage as a whole, and in particular the meaning of `the history of the marriage' in proposed section 86C(2)(a).

Response: The Government accepts the thrust of this recommendation. The Government views seriously concerns that the new regime will disadvantage women and that the starting point of assumed equal contribution to the marriage as a whole will become a de facto finishing point of assumed equal entitlement of distribution. The Government will do a number of things to meet these concerns. The provisions of the Bill will be redrafted so that it is absolutely clear that the 50/50 starting point is a starting point only, and that it relates to contribution only. It will be made clear that property will only be divided in proportion to contribution to the marriage as a whole where there are no other factors, such as future needs, that would make a distribution of property on another basis more just and equitable. Amendments will be made to the Bill to ensure that financial resources will be properly taken into account. There will be an intensive education program by the Government, in conjunction with the Family Court and the legal profession, to explain the amendments and their operation, and to dispel any misunderstandings that have arisen. The expression `the history of the marriage' will be removed from proposed paragraph 86C(2)(a).
RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON
MIGRATION REGULATIONS
CONDITIONAL MIGRANT ENTRY: THE HEALTH RULES

The terms of reference for the Inquiry into Conditional Migrant Entry undertaken by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations (JSC) focused on the feasibility of allowing migrant entry to Australia, on a conditional basis for those applicants who do not meet the health requirement on the grounds of undue cost or prejudice to the access to health care of Australian permanent residents or citizens. The conditional entry was not to be available for those persons who pose a threat to public health or a danger to members of the Australian community. The terms of reference required the committee to give particular attention to the operation of the Migration Regulations in cases of disability.

In its report Conditional Migrant Entry: The Health Rules, the JSC recognised the extreme complexity and sensitivity of the issues involved in the health requirement for entry to or stay in Australia and that only a small number of cases are affected by the lack of conditional entry provisions. The JSC confirmed that the primary obligation of the health requirement is the protection of public health and safety, community resources and access by Australian citizens and permanent residents to expensive and scarce medical and welfare services.

The JSC made twenty-one recommendations which cover a number of distinct areas in addition to conditional migrant entry (Rec. 15-17), that is technical recommendations relating to the health assessment process (Rec. 1-3, 5, 9, 10, 14), assessment of applicants with disabilities (Rec. 4, 7, 8, 11, 18), health standards (Rec. 6), protection of public health (Rec. 12, 13) and access to Medicare and related fraud (Rec. 19-21).
Although the JSC's recommendations are wide ranging and complex they deal with only select aspects of the health requirement and health screening process for entry to or stay in Australia.

In response to the conditional migrant entry (CME) recommendations, the government has decided not to proceed with a CME scheme at this time due to the significant practical and conceptual difficulties in developing a scheme that could be integrated and operate effectively with the current health requirement. The detailed reasons for this are outlined in response to Recommendation 15.

In examining the CME and other JSC recommendations, the government has concluded that priority should be given to a more fundamental examination of the current health requirement with a view to rationalising the existing health regulations to make them clearer and more transparent, to develop and enhance existing guidelines and standards, and make the health requirement more sensitive and responsive to current community views and practices. While the JSC did not canvass the question of medical review, the feasibility of establishing an appropriate formal medical review mechanism is being considered in the examination of the current health requirement.

Accordingly, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Minister for Human Services and Health are undertaking a joint review of the health requirement and associated procedures for entry to Australia. Individual recommendations of the JSC, where agreed to by the government, will be implemented in the context of the review. This review builds on review activity to date such as the provision of greater flexibility in the use of the health waiver in response to JSC Recommendation 3. In many respects this and other fine-tuning of existing policy (in the context of the review) will provide the flexibility in the operation of the existing health rules which the JSC was looking for in recommending a CME scheme.

The health regulations set down in the Migration Regulations, Items 9 and 10 of Schedule 1 and regulation 144 be redrafted so that the commonwealth medical officer is responsible for decisions on the medical matters, while the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is responsible for decisions concerning the costs of treatment and availability of medical resources.
Response

It is accepted the Migration Regulations will be redrafted to clarify decision making responsibilities as part of the review of the health requirement and associated procedures. As indicated in the response to Recommendation 3, the government has, in the context of the review of the health requirement and associated procedures, amended the health waiver so that DIEA officers are responsible for decisions on the question of prejudicing access to scarce medical resources.

The demarcation of responsibility in health decision making be set out clearly, and the allocation of responsibility be consistent between the substantive health criteria (Schedule 1, Items 9 and 10) and the waiver provision (Regulation 144).
Response
Accepted. To be pursued in the context of the response to Recommendation 1.

Regulation 144(2)(d) be amended to remove the term `any' from the text of the provision, so that, as one of the conditions for the grant of a visa or entry permit for classes to which the waiver applies, an applicant must be unlikely, as a result of a disease or condition, to prejudice the access to health care of Australian citizens or Australian permanent residents. Due to concerns, though, that this recommendation may liberalise inappropriately the waiver provision, recommendation 3 should be implemented only if it is possible to make the minister's decision concerning waiver non-compellable and non-reviewable.
Response

Accepted in part. The government has, in the context of the review of the health requirement and associated procedures, amended the Migration Regulations to provide greater flexibility in the exercise of the waiver. The waiver was not previously available for exercise in those cases where the Commonwealth Medical Officer was of the opinion that the applicant was likely to prejudice the access of any Australian citizen or permanent resident to health care. The amended waiver provides for DIEA officers to make the final decision on the question of prejudicing access.

Any move to make consideration of the waiver non-compellable and non-reviewable would be inconsistent with the current decision making structure. The current structure requires decision makers to consider whether or not to exercise the health waiver (where it is available) and such decisions involving the waiver are in many classes reviewable. The increased flexibility in the exercise of the waiver does not inappropriately liberalise the waiver provision, it simply allows DIEA decision makers to consider the question of prejudicing access in the same way as the question of whether an applicant is likely to represent an undue cost is currently considered. Such decisions are made on a case-by-case basis in the light of individual circumstances.

The existing provisions dealing with the health requirement, namely the Migration Regulations Schedule 1, Items 9 and 10, regulation 144, section 20 of the Migration Act 1958 and regulation 176, be amended to provide separate categories for assessment of:
(a)diseases and medical conditions; and
(b)disabilities.
Response

Not accepted. In making this recommendation, the JSC acknowledged that there would be conceptual and drafting difficulties in separating disease and disability in the Migration Regulations. Furthermore, it noted that neither the Disability Services Act 1986 nor the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 would provide the basis for such a classification.

Apart from the considerable difficulty of distinguishing disability from disease and medical conditions there would also be significant practical problems in obtaining complete and reliable assessments overseas. A further consideration is that, other than public health, the current health requirement essentially relates to cost and access to community resources, and these are equally relevant to both disability and medical conditions. While the recommendation is not supported, briefing papers and guidelines for medical officers will address the particular factors that need to be considered when assessing people with disabilities.

The regulations set to accompany the Migration Bill 1992 should provide that non-citizens who are permanent residents should not be vulnerable to cancellation of their visa when they are outside Australia because of a prescribed disease, medical condition or disability, providing that their prescribed disease, medical condition or disability was acquired subsequent to the person's first arrival in Australia.
Response

Accepted. The Migration Reform Act 1992, implemented on 1 September 1994, replaced the previous automatic cancellation powers of section 20 of the Migration Act 1958 (for visas and entry permits under prescribed circumstances) with a discretionary provision for the cancellation of visas for prescribed reasons. In any event, and irrespective of any prescribed health criterion, returning residents are not subject to the cancellation of their visas as a result of a disease, condition or disability acquired subsequent to their first arrival in Australia as a permanent resident. Official DIEA instructions to Migration Officers state that visas held by permanent residents returning to Australia must not be cancelled on health grounds.

Priority be given to the production of the background briefing papers for commonwealth medical officers on the assessment of medical and disability conditions. These papers should provide up to date and realistic assistance to the commonwealth medical officers in forming opinions on whether or not applicants meet the health requirement for entry or stay.
Response
Accepted. The government strongly endorses the need for relevant, comprehensive and current medical information to be available to support the medical assessment process.

Four background briefing papers are currently used by medical officers. The papers cover Psychiatric Disorders, Frail Aged, Chronic Kidney Disease and HIV Infection and AIDS. In addition, work is progressing with papers on Vision Impairment/Blindness, Intellectual Disabilities and Accommodation for People with Disabilities. The development of these papers involves broad consultation with medical specialists, colleges and organisations who provide services, and advocacy groups.

The scope and relative priority for extending the current background briefing papers is being established as part of the review of the health requirement and associated procedures. This also includes examination of an appropriate mechanism for developing and maintaining background briefing papers and the related resourcing implications.

The guideline briefing papers issued by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs for use by commonwealth medical officers in assessing people with disabilities against the health requirement be based on accepted principles for the assessment of disabilities and be regularly updated in accordance with the latest research data on the various forms of disability.
Response
Accepted.

In assessing a person with a disability, sufficient emphasis be given to the likely contribution to the Australian community of the disabled person's family as a unit and to the capabilities of the individual. To this effect, the commonwealth medical officer or, where appropriate, the processing immigration officer should gather data relevant to the Minister's decision whether or not to grant a visa or entry permit or, where relevant, to exercise the health waiver, including data on:
(a)the nature of the disability;
(b)the age of the person;
(c)the opportunities for employment and likely benefits to the community of the disabled person and other members of the family unit;
(d)the capacity of the family unit to provide adequate lifetime care and support to the disabled person, without undue cost to the community; and
(e)the extent to which entitlement to government-funded support can be claimed, regardless of a person's means.
Response

Accepted in principle. This recommendation is being further examined in the context of the review of the health requirement and associated procedures. Many of the factors recommended to be taken into account when assessing applicants with disabilities are already included in the assessment of the health waiver in those classes where it is available. One difficulty is that of objectively assessing the likely contribution which the applicant or the applicant's family may be able to make to Australia.

As indicated in the response to Recommendation 3, the review of the health requirement and associated procedures to date has resulted in the health waiver being amended to provide greater flexibility in its use.

Unless there are sound reasons to the contrary, the Regional Medical Director Bangkok report to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, as is the case for all commonwealth medical officers and the Regional Medical Director Paris.
Response

Not accepted. The Regional Medical Directors (RMD) are located in Bangkok and Manchester and are employees of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (DIEA). Although the RMDs undertake the tasks of Commonwealth Medical Officers, their major functions are more closely aligned with DIEA processing functions including the monitoring of the panel doctor system used in most countries to conduct medical examinations.

Consequent upon recommendations 1 and 2, the arrangements for demarcation of responsibility between the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and the commonwealth medical officer, as enunciated in the Policy Control Instructions, the Procedures Advice Manual and the background briefing papers be brought into line with the Migration Regulation.
Response
Accepted. To be pursued in the context of the response to Recommendation 1.

The health screening standards and procedures used in assessing people with disabilities for migration purposes be aligned as closely as possible with the tests applied by the Department of Social Security in determining eligibility for the Disability Support Pension.
Response

Accepted in principle. The assessment of migration applicants with disabilities already incorporates, to the extent practicable, the same considerations relating to assessments for the Disability Support Pension (DSP). Any further alignment of assessment processes is not considered feasible because of the different purposes of the assessments. The DSP assessment is fundamentally directed towards ascertaining the extent of impairments and work ability while the migration health assessment focuses on public health, cost and use of community resources.

In the interests of protecting public health, testing for hepatitis B in particular be wider than is presently undertaken for migration purposes (pregnant women, children for adoption and unaccompanied refugee children) and be introduced for groups which, in relevant medical literature, are recognised as being at high risk. On entry, persons from those groups or countries of origin should be required to produce a certificate of immunisation or accept vaccination by state health authorities as a condition of entry.
Response

Not accepted at this time. Consultation to date between DHSH and members of the Communicable Diseases Standing Committee (CDSC) of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) and the Australian Gastroenterology Institute (AGI) indicates that there is no consensus on the public health benefit of implementing this recommendation. Matters relating to hepatitis B immunisation and screening are currently being examined by the NHMRC's Panel on Hepatitis B. This Panel is expected to report within the next 12 months. It is proposed that this recommendation not be implemented at this time and that it be reviewed in the light of the NHMRC report.

An effective and timely reporting system be introduced whereby the results of medical examinations for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and hepatitis B are passed to state and territory health authorities by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, to enable appropriate public health standards to be implemented by those authorities.
Response

Accepted. A system is already in place whereby the medical documents of applicants who may require monitoring of their tuberculosis or hepatitis B status, are passed to the health authority in the state or territory of the applicant's intended residence in Australia. The review of the health requirement and associated procedures to date has resulted in amendment of the Migration Regulations to require such applicants to provide a written undertaking to put themselves under the supervision of these authorities where this has been requested by a commonwealth Medical Officer. Options for strengthening the post-arrival compliance with these undertakings are being considered by DHSH and DIEA.

In the regulations drafted to accompany the Migration Reform Bill 1992, the special category New Zealand visa class be included with those for which the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs can waive the health criteria, provided that the minister also would exercise such a waiver under similar circumstances for citizens of other countries.
Response

Accepted. The Special Category Visa class has been developed under the Migration Reform Act 1992 for New Zealand citizens seeking entry to Australia and was implemented on 1 September 1994. Consistent with the policy of free movement of people between New Zealand and Australia and advice from DHSH on the standards of health in New Zealand, the health requirement for this class prescribes tuberculosis as the major disease of public health concern.

As a general rule, in cases where an applicant does not meet the prescribed health criteria and does not satisfy the health waiver provisions, before entry or stay may be approved, the applicant or a sponsor pay to the commonwealth an up-front fee. The amount of the fee should equal the costs, as determined by the Commonwealth Compensation Commissioner, of ongoing treatment, care and assistance, over the lifetime of the applicant, which are likely to arise as a result of the medical condition or disability identified by the commonwealth medical officer as the reason for the applicant's failure to meet the health requirement.
Response

Not accepted. A thorough examination of the feasibility of the introduction of an up-front fee as recommended by the JSC revealed significant practical and conceptual difficulties in developing a scheme that could be integrated and operate effectively with the current health requirement. It is considered that a conditional migrant entry (CME) scheme is largely incompatible with, and would have the effect of undermining, existing health policy arrangements for different visa categories. A range of specific concerns were identified in relation to factors considered as either being essential in supporting a CME mechanism or being significant obstacles to the introduction of such a mechanism. These related to:

There is a need to develop more sophisticated medical and related costing standards particularly to support a system of actuarial assessment and medical review. In this context there is also a need to further develop existing medical background briefing papers [response to Recommendation 6 refers].
a.Access

A CME scheme would create policy tensions irrespective of whether selective or open access is provided. Limiting access to the CME scheme would be inconsistent with the apparent intent of the recommendation and would be interpreted as discriminatory in application. On the other hand, provision of open access would result in considerable tension between the CME mechanism and current policy for many visa classes.

For example, spouse visa applicants currently have access to the health waiver, full merits review and Ministerial discretion while the humanitarian classes have access to the waiver. This reflects the relative policy priority attaching to these visa classes. To subsequently provide access to a CME mechanism (for the relatively small number of unsuccessful humanitarian and spouse cases) would either:

undermine the current policy intent in that these applicants would be highly unlikely to afford a CME fee with the result that yet further consideration would be given to the compelling nature of these cases (despite the exhaustive consideration preceding CME consideration); or
be considered sufficiently at variance with the policy objectives of these classes to be considered inappropriate to even contemplate the payment of a fee.

Similarly, it would be inappropriate to provide access for applicants failing to meet the entry requirement for visa categories (such as for concessional family) where the government had already decided not to provide a waiver. To provide such access would also undermine the current policy intent in that it would invariably result in consideration of compelling circumstances, where the government has not provided for such consideration.
b.Waiver

The existing medical waiver/review/Ministerial discretion mechanisms would conflict with a CME scheme and accompanying Ministerial discretion [response to Recommendation 17 refers] in a way which would make it difficult to preserve the integrity of the existing discretions.

There are considerable reservations regarding the equity of a CME scheme. The availability of a CME scheme would either be discriminatory in terms of those likely to be in a position to afford what is expected to be a very substantial average fee (estimated by the JSC to be in the order of $200,000) or otherwise incompatible with the objectives of visa classes such as those with humanitarian or close family objectives.

A CME scheme would be complex and cumbersome to operate. The extreme complexity and sensitivity of the issues involved was acknowledged by the JSC as was the fact that only a small number of cases are affected by the lack of conditional entry provisions.
a.Potential Demand

Based on information from the newly installed computer system (MIDAS), operating since mid December 1993, it is estimated that there would be in the order of 200 applicants failing the health requirement each year who may be eligible for a CME scheme. However, this number could be heavily discounted for those who are subsequently approved through exercise of the health waiver, the review process or Ministerial intervention as well as those who would not be in a position to pay the fee.
b.Administration

There would also be significant co-ordination and logistical difficulties in implementing and operating a CME mechanism. Establishing even a reasonable estimate of lifetime medical costs would be an imprecise and resource intensive process. If this is extended to include lifetime non-medical costs (such as special education requirements, welfare entitlements and supported employment) and an assessment of the likely contribution which the applicant or applicant's family may be able to make to Australia (pursuant to Recommendation 17) then the level of complexity, subjectivity and precision required would increase dramatically.
c.Impact on health budget

A likely perverse outcome of introducing a CME scheme for all applicants for permanent residence in Australia is that rather than recouping the potential health costs to the community it is likely to result in a net additional cost, thus frustrating the existing health requirement. It is probable that the combination of having open access to a CME scheme and a Ministerial waiver mechanism would have a negative impact on the health budget due to the anticipated requests and compulsion for Ministerial waiver. The administrative implications of such a situation would be difficult to contemplate.
There is currently no formal medical review mechanism to support the introduction of a CME scheme.

As indicated in the introductory response to the JSC recommendations, the recommendation for a CME scheme was in large part predicated on a perceived need to provide greater flexibility in the operation of the existing health rules. It is considered that the existing health rules already provide considerable flexibility where that is the policy objective (through use of the health waiver, access to merits review and Ministerial discretion) and that further flexibility could be achieved by simply fine-tuning the policy. The recent change to provide greater flexibility in the operation of the health waiver (response to Recommendation 3 refers) is considered to have largely addressed the JSC's concern for greater flexibility.

As a supplement to the up-front fee proposed in recommendation 15, the government investigate the feasibility of implementing an insurance bond system and/or a loan arrangement for applicants who do not meet the prescribed health criteria or the waiver provisions and who are unable to pay an up front fee to the commonwealth. In any such arrangements, the need to protect the revenue over the lifetime of the applicant should be a relevant consideration.
Response

Not accepted. Establishing alternatives to an up-front fee, such as bonds or insurance, is not feasible. Consultations held by the JSC with a number of financial and insurance institutions revealed no interest in offering such services. This reflects the fact that the risk of insuring persons with known diseases/conditions of sufficient severity to result in a failure to meet the health requirement is likely to be too great to be an attractive commercial proposition.

Consequent upon recommendations 15 and 16, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs be provided with a discretion to consider the circumstances of the applicant, particularly the likely contribution which the applicant or the applicant's family may be able to make to Australia, and either:
(a)waive any part of the up-front fee payable by the applicant or a sponsor, or up-front payment to be covered by a bond or a loan; or
(b)in compelling cases, waive in total the up-front fee payable by the applicant or a sponsor, or the up-front payment to be covered by a bond or a loan.
Response
Not accepted. Linked to any further consideration of Recommendation 15.

Introduction of a Ministerial waiver to accompany a CME scheme would result in considerable conflict with the existing medical waiver. In particular, consideration of "compelling cases" in the exercise of the CME waiver would conflict with the operation of existing waiver/review/Ministerial discretion mechanisms where the consideration also relates to compassionate and compelling circumstances. As indicated in the response to Recommendation 15 it would result in a policy tension by creating a discretion in those classes where the government had already decided not to provide a waiver. It is also indicated in the response to Recommendation 15 that an open access CME scheme in conjunction with a waiver will likely result in a net additional cost for the health budget. An additional significant difficulty is that of objectively assessing the likely contribution which the applicant or the applicant's family may be able to make to Australia.

In determining whether to grant an adoption visa or entry permit to a disabled adoptive child who cannot satisfy the health criteria, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs consider the financial and other family support able to be provided by the adoptive family and the circumstances of the adoptive child, particularly whether these factors could outweigh any likely costs to the community or access to community resources in short supply. In such cases, the entry or stay should be approved only where appropriate guarantees of support can be provided and where the relevant state welfare authorities have approved the intending adoptive parents as capable of parenting the child.
Response

Accepted in principle. The health waiver is available to the children for adoption class and already allows for consideration of the particular circumstances of the child against the likely cost to the Australian community that the child represents. The review of the health requirement and associated procedures to date has resulted in amendment of the Migration Regulations to allow for these circumstances to be balanced against the use of community resources in short supply where the applicant is likely to prejudice the access of Australian residents to the resources.
In light of the potential for fraud in the existing procedures for enrolment in Medicare and the use of Medicare cards, the following changes to the Medicare system be implemented:
(a)the Medicare enrolment procedures for non-citizens be amended to require two original documents as proof of identity, with one of those documents including a photograph; and

(b)the signature of each nominated Medicare card holder be required to be included on the Medicare card, so that every transaction can be verified as a service to the card holder or another authorised family member.
Response

(a)Accepted. Medicare policy has been amended to require non-Australian citizens to produce two original documents to establish identity one of which must be a document which includes a photograph. This policy has been included in the current policy manual.

(b)Not accepted. The Medicare card has no status in law and was never intended to be an identification card but merely an administrative mechanism to facilitate payment of benefit. Further, Medicare benefits are payable to the person who incurs the expense and not the card holder who has no particular status over other persons on the card apart from being the person to whom any general Medicare correspondence is directed. The signature of the card holder on the card would not assist identification when other family members claim.

The definition of `Australian resident' in subsection 3(1) of the Health Insurance Act 1973 be amended to prevent persons with temporary entry permits from gaining access to Medicare, but the government introduce specific legislative provisions to cover specific groups of temporary residents which the government considers should have access to Medicare, for example those granted Extended Eligibility (Spouse) Temporary Entry Permits and asylum seekers granted Domestic Protection Temporary Entry Permits.
Response

Accepted in principle. The intent of the recommendation to limit access to Medicare by certain classes of temporary residents can be achieved with minimal delay by varying the orders made under section 6 of the Health Insurance Act 1973. The orders have accordingly been varied recently to remove Medicare eligibility for skilled temporary residents. The legislation will be kept under review with a view to reinforcing these variations.

Appropriate legislative amendments be made to ensure that the Health Insurance Commissioner and other appropriate persons be empowered to provide the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs with information regarding instances of unlawful access to Medicare by temporary entrants and illegal entrants, and information regarding the extent of indebtedness of temporary residents and/or illegal entrants who have accessed Australia's health system.
Response

Amendment of section 130 of the Health Insurance Act 1973 to allow exchange of data between DIEA and the Health Insurance Commission for the purposes of detecting unlawful access to Medicare by temporary residents necessarily involves issues relating to data exchange for the purposes of the locating of illegal immigrants. These wider issues are to be the subject of separate consideration by the government and the committee's recommendation will be taken up in that context.

GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO REPORT BY JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON NATIONAL CAPITAL AND EXTERNAL TERRITORIES ON ITS INQUIRY INTO DRAFT AMENDMENT No. 12 OF THE NATIONAL CAPITAL PLAN (RUSSELL MASTER PLAN)
Mr R. L. Chynoweth MP
Chairman
Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mr Chynoweth
I write to advise you of the government's Response to the Committee Report on the Inquiry into Draft Amendment 12 (Russell) of the National Capital Plan which was tabled in Parliament on 5 June 1995.

The committee's eighteen recommendations and the government responses are attached. The government Response includes agreement to 10 of the recommendations, agreement in principle to five of the recommendations, and agreement in part to three of the recommendations.

In that it seeks to complete the National Triangle which forms the basis of Griffin's plan for the National Capital, this Amendment of the National Capital Plan is perhaps the most important amendment since the Plan's completion in 1990. I thank the committee for its work on the Russell Master Plan.
Yours sincerely
BRIAN HOWE

PARA.EMPHASIS: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO REPORT BY JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CAPITAL AND EXTERNAL TERRITORIES ON ITS INQUIRY INTO

SPEECH.PARA: DRAFT AMENDMENT NO 12 OF THE NATIONAL CAPITAL PLAN (RUSSELL MASTER PLAN)
Background

Draft Amendment 12 (Russell) was referred to the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories on 16 August 1994. The Committee's Report was tabled in Parliament on 5 June 1995. This Draft Amendment of the National Capital Plan proposes a Master Plan for Russell which, among other things, creates a framework for the Department of Defence Russell Redevelopment Project.

The Draft Amendment provides: a revision of figure 12 of the National Capital Plan showing the permitted land uses in Russell; a new statement of Land Use Policy for Russell; and, a new appendix that includes the Russell Master Plan as detailed conditions of planning, design and development.

The committee recommends that the line of the National Triangle be completed and that the extension of Kings Avenue from Russell Drive through Sir Thomas Blamey Square to the roundabout at the apex of the National Triangle proceed. However, the area from the southern end of Sir Thomas Blamey Square to the roundabout at the apex of the National Triangle must be closed to motorised traffic and constructed as a people's gathering place and pedestrian thoroughfare. In order to facilitate the movement of pedestrians between the apex and Sir Thomas Blamey Square, the proposed local road between buildings RN1 and RN2 crossing the northern end of Sir Thomas Blamey Square should not proceed beyond the eastern side of building G and western side of building F.

The layout proposed through Sir Thomas Blamey Square will be amended so that the area from the southern end of the Square to the roundabout at the apex of the triangle shows a landscaped and paved area instead of vehicular carriageways. Detailed design for the area immediately north of Sir Thomas Blamey Square to and including the apex will be prepared in 1995/1996 for construction in line with Department of Defence requirements for occupation of buildings RN1 and RN2. Design work associated with the Square will be undertaken to coincide with Department of Defence's staging of refurbishment works to buildings F and G, and in line with the need to ensure that the work does ". . . not preclude a wide range of development options should a new northern gateway to Canberra be considered at a future date." (Refer Recommendation 3).

The committee recommends that the National Capital Planning Authority in consultation with the ACT government design and implement measures to reduce traffic problems at the intersection of Parkes Way, Kings Avenue and Morshead Drive as part of the redevelopment of Russell.
The Defence Russell Redevelopment Project will result in only a small increase in employment at Russell, as the majority of the project involves replacing and refurbishing existing office space.

The Draft Amendment provides that commonwealth offices, other than for occupation by the Department of Defence, will not be approved until a review of the Employment Location Policies of the National Capital Plan has been completed.

The Draft Amendment for Russell does not depend at this time on the implementation of any traffic improvements at the intersection of Parkes Way, Kings Avenue and Morshead Drive. The longer term development of Russell should not, however, proceed until traffic problems at the junction of Parkes Way, Kings Avenue and Morshead Drive have been reduced. It is noted that the intersection is on territory Land rather than National Land and implementation of any improvements would be the responsibility of the ACT government. Accordingly, the NCPA will consult with the territory.

The committee recommends that the detailed design, planning and construction for the proposed redevelopment of Russell not preclude a wide range of development options should a new northern gateway to Canberra be considered at a future time.

The committee recommends that the excavation of the cutting into Mount Pleasant as proposed in the Russell Offices Redevelopment Project proceed, providing this cutting is limited to a maximum of eight metres.

Since the committee held its hearing the cutting has been the subject of more detailed design and discussion between the NCPA, Defence and the ACT Department of Urban Services. As a result the cutting has been reshaped to produce a benched effect. At its maximum depth the cutting will be 11 metres, with the maximum depth of the exposed cut face being 8 metres. The remaining three metres will be grassed and the reshaping will blend the cutting into the existing topography.
The committee recommends that planning for future roads should not be predicated on the demolition of existing buildings.

The Draft Amendment represents a long-term concept as well as comprising a statement of current planning intent. It is important that the Draft Amendment does not preclude the future extension of Constitution Avenue at its full width, nor the desirability of the proposed road connecting at the apex of the National Triangle to Morshead Drive.

The only new road reservations proposed to be specified on the Amendment are those which can be achieved within the proposed Defence Redevelopment program, with the exception of the proposed extension of Constitution Avenue which crosses the edge of Building A. However, even this building can be accommodated for the foreseeable future with a staged construction of the road. The other roads are proposed to be shown on the plan as indicative only.

The Russell Master Plan is intended to be implemented in stages. It allows the buildings to remain for the term of their economic life and for decisions about their refurbishment or demolition to be made in the future.

The committee recommends that the National Capital Planning Authority accepts responsibility for setting out the detailed conditions of planning, design and development for public transport routes and infrastructure on national roads, and where appropriate, consult with the ACT Authority responsible for the ACT Territory Plan.

The committee recommends that the proposed detailed amendment to the Indicative Layout diagram showing pedestrian and cycle routes be completed by the end of 1995. Further, the committee recommends that the revised Indicative Layout diagram be advertised in the Commonwealth Gazette and in the principal daily newspaper published and circulated in the territory as stated in the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988, for public comment before finalisation of the plan and design of pedestrian and cycle routes.

It is agreed that the Indicative Layout Diagram should show proposed pedestrian and cycle routes, but only the major routes and these not in any detailed sense. The Indicative Layout Diagram essentially presents only the design concept underlying the possible long-term layout and development of Russell and any changes to the Diagram should remain consistent with that intent.
The Draft Amendment will be altered as follows:

The Principles for Roads and Parking set out in the Draft Amendment at page 9 of the Master Plan, will be renamed "Traffic and Parking" and be augmented to indicate that cycleways and pedestrian paths, where separate from the local road systems, will provide safe and convenient movement generally within open space and connect with major peripheral paths.
The Development Conditions for Traffic and Parking at page 10 of the Master Plan will refer specifically to pedestrians and cyclists and set out conditions requiring:

PARA.TAB: the local road network to provide for the safe passage of pedestrians and cyclists and allow for connection to cycleways and other pedestrian paths;
cycleways and pedestrian paths, other than those within the local road network, to be provided within open space and connect with major path systems around Lake Burley Griffin, Duntroon and Campbell;
grade separation or signalised intersections where cycleways and pedestrian paths cross the arterial road system.

SPEECH.PARA: The location and design of cycleways and pedestrian paths, where these are not incorporated in the local road network, will be the subject of public consultation by the National Capital Planning Authority at a detailed design stage and before the works are commissioned.

The committee recommends that the detailed design and planning stage for pedestrian and cycle access to, and within, Russell include pedestrian and cycle routes linking the Russell precinct with the Lake Burly Griffin foreshore.
The committee recommends that buildings RN1 and RN2 be located as proposed in the Draft Amendment No. 12, with the following restrictions:
the height of buildings RN1 and RN2, including all roof structures and communications equipment must be limited to a maximum of RL617, and
no roof structure or communications equipment are to be located beyond the eastern edge of building G for RN1 and the western edge of building F for RN2.
Recommendation 10

The committee recommends that, in preparing the detailed design and plan of any car parking structures, consideration be given to constructing some of the planned levels of car parking below ground level so that such structures are not built to, or near, maximum height, thereby dominating much of the precinct's environment.5

Consideration will be given to minimising the height and visual impact of car parking structures. However, the extra cost of basement level parking may discourage the building of parking structures and act against the primary objective of progressively removing surface parking. The height of parking structures should be determined by the contribution each structure makes to the urban design principle of emphasising the natural terrain.

The committee recommends that a sufficient number of parking structures be appropriately planned, designed and constructed to meet the demands of the growing workforce at Russell and within the principle of replacing surface car parking facilities for long stay parking. Further, that such structures are not built to such a height above ground that they dominate much of the built form in Russell, in keeping with Recommendation 10.

The committee recommends that appropriate arrangements are made in the short to medium term to ensure that surface parking areas are located to cause the least possible visual impact and degradation of the environment.

In the short term there is a need for an additional temporary car park between Russell Drive and Parkes Way. The car park will be screened by earth mounding to ensure that it causes minimal visual impact. The car park will be required until the land currently occupied by Buildings B, C, D, and E is available for use as a car park in about three years time.
The committee recommends that surface parking, including short-stay parking, be prohibited in Blamey Square and the area between buildings RN1 and RN2, in keeping with Recommendation 1.
The committee recommends that details of proposed short-stay surface parking be included in the revised Indicative Layout diagram for public comment.

The Draft Amendment provides that short-stay parking will be available on-street. This will meet the needs of official Defence visitors and tourists who may wish to stop briefly to view the axis of the National Triangle and Blamey Square. It is beyond the scope of the Indicative Layout Diagram, which is essentially conceptual in nature, to show short-stay surface parking in detail.

The committee recommends that the National Capital Planning Authority and the ACT government develop a transport management strategy in conjunction with Draft Amendment No. 12, with a view to reducing private traffic and demand for parking in Russell.

It is not practicable to complete the Transport Management Strategy concurrently with Draft Amendment No 12, nor is it desirable that such a strategy be developed in isolation. The Transport Management Strategy should be undertaken after Draft Amendment No 12 has been approved, in conjunction with the relevant territory authorities and within a metropolitan context.
The committee recommends that the impact of traffic and parking on heritage sites be considered if a major new road is planned for, or near, the Russell precinct.

The committee recommends that the National Capital Planning Authority implement formal consultation processes with the Australian Heritage Commission to upgrade consideration of heritage issues in future planning and design proposals.
The committee recommends that Draft Amendment No. 12 of the National Capital Plan be approved, subject to the committee's recommendations numbered 1 to 17 in this Report.
Agreement is subject to the above responses.
THE INVESTIGATORY POWERS OF THE AUSTRALIAN SECURITIES COMMISSION
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT BY THE SENATE LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL REFERENCES COMMITTEE ON THE INVESTIGATORY POWERS OF THE AUSTRALIAN SECURITIES COMMISSION

1.On 27 May 1993 the Senate resolved to refer the issue of the exercise of the investigatory powers of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for report. During the course of the Standing Committee's inquiry, the Standing Committee was dissolved and was replaced, in part, by the Legal and Constitutional References Committee which completed the inquiry.

2.The Committee received 147 written submissions and conducted public hearings in Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne. Submissions were received from the ASC and the Attorney-General's Department in addition to a broad range of interested parties including law societies and legal firms, accountants, academics, consumer organisations, shareholders representatives and participants in ASC investigations.
3.The work of the Committee and the participation of these individuals and groups is acknowledged by the Government.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Establishment of the Australian Securities Commission

SPEECH.PARA: 4.The national companies and securities scheme laws were introduced by the Government in 1989 to enable the Commonwealth to assume national responsibility for the regulation of companies and the securities markets, and implement a regime that would meet the needs of the Australian economy into the 1990's and beyond. The Government recognised that our economy is national, with companies operating across the country and often in the international sphere. To divide the regulation of companies on the lines of State and Territory boundaries, as existed under the former co-operative companies and securities scheme, meant that there was no Parliament, no Government and no Minister with overall responsibility and accountability for the operation of the scheme. The co-operative scheme had, by that time, outlived its usefulness.

5.Chief among the new administrative organs established by the national scheme laws was the ASC, which replaced the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) and assumed responsibility for the administration of the scheme. The ASC commenced operation on 1 January 1991.

6.The powers given to the ASC by the legislature were designed to ensure that it was able to be a strong and effective regulatory body, yet one which was flexible and responsive to developments in the market place.

7.The NCSC had operated under a regime of ordinary and special investigations. The power of the NCSC to conduct compulsory oral examinations was reserved for special investigations only. Special investigations required the consent of either an individual State or Northern Territory Minister, or of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. For the most part, consent was to be granted only if the Minister or the Ministerial Council considered it to be in the public or national interest. In relation to ordinary investigations, the NCSC had to rely on the more cumbersome power to conduct public hearings to gather information.

8.This distinction between ordinary and special investigations was removed by the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989 (ASC Law) and the ASC has been given powers to conduct compulsory oral examinations in relation to all investigations.

9.The new national regulatory framework, combined with the fact that the ASC has been provided with significant resources as well as enhanced investigatory powers, has meant that the ASC has a profile and capacity to pursue its investigatory objectives that exceed that of its predecessors.

10.Like its predecessors, however, the breaches of corporate law that the ASC is called on to investigate are often extremely complex. Commercial arrangements frequently have an appearance of legitimacy. They are commonly highly structured and involve hundreds of individual transactions and thousands of documents. Professional advisers including lawyers, accountants, tax advisers and merchant bankers are used at all stages of the arrangements. Transactions often involve interstate and international activities and may be effected through the use of electronic technology. The arrangements often involve complex corporate structures or groups with interlinked shareholdings or debts, some of which may be incorporated or have assets outside Australia, often in jurisdictions which do not have cooperative arrangements with Australia for sharing information.

11.Nevertheless, the timely and thorough examination of such transactions is essential to the effective enforcement of Australia's corporate laws and, ultimately, the maintenance of investor confidence in Australia's securities markets. To this end the legislature considered it necessary to equip the corporate regulator with effective investigatory powers. It is the exercise of those powers by the ASC that is the subject of review by the Committee.

12.The Committee's inquiry commenced at a time when the ASC had only been operating some 3 years. Since it commenced operation on 1 January 1991, the ASC has grown from a skeleton staff to over 1600 employees. It has regional offices in each State and Territory as well as 12 business centres, an information processing centre in Traralgon and policy and administrative offices in Melbourne and Sydney. It has successfully, in that time, achieved a significant presence as a truly national regulator.

13.Nevertheless such significant growth can, not unexpectedly, reveal some deficiencies in the administrative practices of a large decentralised organisation. The Committee has recommended that the ASC adopt a number of administrative and funding measures to improve its investigatory practices. The Government supports each of those recommendations. The Government also notes that, in so far as these recommendations relate to internal ASC procedures, they either reflected the ASC's current practice at the time of the Report or have since been adopted by the ASC. Recommendations in this category are recommendations 2, 3, 6, 9 and 13.

14.The Committee has also made a number of recommendations for minor changes to the national companies and securities scheme laws under which the ASC operates. Recommendations in this category are recommendations 1, 5, 7, 8 and 11. The Government also supports each of these recommendations.
15.The remaining five recommendations made by the Committee address a number of fundamental issues going to the heart of the powers the ASC can exercise to facilitate an investigation.

16.The Committee specifically recognises that any examination of the investigative powers of the ASC needs to address the balance which should be struck between two competing interests: the need for effective corporate regulation and the need to protect individuals from an excess of administrative power. The Government is concerned to ensure that in re-examining that balance, the investigatory powers of the ASC are not so diminished as to render the Commission completely ineffective as a corporate regulator.

17.In general, the Government is not convinced that significant changes to the ASC's powers are warranted at this time, particularly given the comparatively short time the ASC has had to establish itself in the complex arena of corporate regulation. Much of the anecdotal evidence presented to the Committee related to one or two investigations undertaken by the Commission shortly after its establishment. The administrative changes recommended by the Committee, many of which, as already noted, have been implemented by the ASC, should overcome many of the problems identified with the handling of those particular investigations.

18.The Committee's report does not, in the Government's view, reveal any fundamental deficiencies in the ASC's exercise of its investigatory powers. In all the circumstances the Government does not consider that a case has yet been made for a significant reduction in the ASC's powers.
19.Of the five recommendations in this category, the Government supports recommendation 10 (in part), but does not support recommendations 4, 12, 14 and 15.
20.Each of the Committee's recommendations will be considered in turn.
The Committee recommends that the ASC Law be amended to provide protection, along the lines of section 92 of the ASC Law, to those persons voluntarily providing information at the request of the ASC.

21.Section 92 of the ASC Law protects informants from civil liability for defamation and breach of confidentiality, but only where the ASC has exercised its statutory powers under Part 3 of the ASC Law. Thus persons served with a notice under section 19 of the ASC Law, compulsorily requiring their appearance for examination, receive the statutory protection afforded by section 92. While the statutory powers of the ASC under Part 3 of the ASC Law may be exercised once a formal investigation has commenced under section 13 of the ASC law, a formal investigation cannot commence until the ASC has "reason to suspect" that a contravention had taken place. Those persons who volunteer information of possible misfeasance, for example in circumstances where a formal investigation has not commenced, will not receive the statutory protection of section 92.

22.This is particularly relevant to professional advisers who may, by volunteering that information, be in breach of confidentiality obligations imposed upon them. In the absence of the statutory protection afforded by section 92, informants must rely on common law principles to protect them from civil liability for their disclosures.

23.The Government notes that the benefit of such a statutory protection for informants, on this occasion directors and others involved in the compliance activities of collective investment schemes, was also identified by the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee Report "Collective Investments: Other People's Money" (Report No 65) (1993) Volume 1 at page 156.

24.The Government sees a benefit in encouraging persons to volunteer information to the ASC and agrees with the Committee that it would be desirable to extend the statutory protection presently afforded by section 92 to those persons voluntarily and in good faith providing information to or at the request of the ASC.

The Committee is pleased to observe that, in part due to the work of this Committee, a national complaints procedure has been adopted by the ASC. The ASC should include an account of the operation of the complaints procedure in its Annual Report and, at least annually, should report on complaints and their handling to the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities. The complaint procedures presently in place should be the subject of a review, after three years, by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities.

25.The Government supports the first part of the Committee's recommendation, namely that the ASC include in its Annual Report an account of the operation of the national complaints procedure that it has adopted. The ASC's national complaint handling procedure guidelines have been published in the ASC Digest.

26.The ASC has already implemented this aspect of the Committee's recommendation by the inclusion of information about complaints made against ASC staff by members of the public at page 68 of its 1994/95 Annual Report.

27.As to the recommendation that the complaint procedure presently in place should be the subject of a review, after three years, by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, the Government notes that the Parliamentary Committee's duties under paragraph 243(a) of the ASC Act include to inquire into and report to both Houses on activities of the ASC, or matters connected with such activities, to which, in the Parliamentary Committee's opinion, the Parliament's attention should be directed. The Government notes that the recommended review of the complaint procedure is thus within the anticipated duties of the Parliamentary Committee and it will bring this aspect of the recommendation to the attention of that Committee.
The Committee recommends that:

PARA.TAB: the ASC make a major effort to achieve its performance indicator of finalising investigations within 12 months of the resourcing of the investigation;
the ASC ensure that, when an investigation concludes and no further action is contemplated, notice is given to the parties involved in the investigation; and
the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities monitor compliance with this recommendation.

SPEECH.PARA: 28.The Government supports the first two parts of this recommendation and notes that they have already been implemented by the ASC.

29.The ASC has advised that its performance in meeting its indicator of completing investigations within 12 months of the resourcing of the investigation continues to improve. For the year ended 30 June 1995, the performance indicator was met in 77% of investigations.

30.The Committee's recommendation that relevant parties be informed of the conclusion of an investigation is set out in the ASC's Enforcement Manual.
