The procedure outlined in the Manual requires the ASC to inform the persons targeted by its investigation, witnesses, the complainant and any other interested parties of its decision to take no further action in respect of a matter.

31.As to the third part of the recommendation, namely that the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities monitor compliance with this recommendation, the Government notes that the Parliamentary Committee's duties under paragraph 243(a) of the ASC Act include to inquire into and report to both Houses on activities of the ASC, or matters connected with such activities, to which, in the Parliamentary Committee's opinion, the Parliament's attention should be directed. The Government notes that the recommended monitoring of the ASC's compliance with this recommendation is thus within the anticipated duties of the Parliamentary Committee and it will bring this aspect of the recommendation to the attention of that Committee.
The Committee recommends that the Corporations Law be amended so that in situations where the ASC:

PARA.TAB: obtains ex parte an order freezing personal assets under section 1323 of the Corporations Law;
the order is subsequently lifted;
no determinative order is made against the property the subject of the order; and

no successful criminal or civil prosecution results against the respondent, the respondent should be given a statutory right to recover from the ASC damages for any loss incurred as a result of the original order.

SPEECH.PARA: 32.The Government notes the Committee's recommendation for a statutory right to recover damages from the ASC in circumstances where an ex parte order freezing assets under section 1323 of the Corporations Law obtained by the ASC is subsequently lifted without a determinative order being made against the subject property and no successful criminal or civil prosecution has resulted against the respondent.

33.The ASC's power to apply to the Court for an order freezing assets, to prevent the possible or further misappropriation of assets, is an important means of ensuring that assets are available to satisfy subsequent civil recovery proceedings or to avoid the need for such proceedings at all. The ASC may apply for an order under section 1323 where:

PARA.TAB: an investigation is being carried out under the Corporations Law or the ASC Law (paragraph 1323(1)(a));
a prosecution has begun for contravention of the Corporations Law (paragraph 1323(1)(b)); or

SPEECH.PARA: a civil proceeding has begun under the Corporations Law (paragraph 1323(1)(c)).

34.The powers of the Court under section 1323 include the freezing of payments and the taking or sending of money, securities, futures contracts or other property out of the jurisdiction; the appointment of a receiver or trustee to the property of a natural person; the appointment of a receiver or a receiver and manager over corporate property; requiring that a person surrender his or her passport and prohibiting a person leaving Australia without the consent of the Court. The capacity to appoint a receiver is arguably the most valuable and versatile of the court's powers under section 1323. It is unlikely, however, that a final order, freezing the assets of the defendant, would be made on the basis of an ex parte hearing.

35.More commonly, the ASC may apply for the grant of an interim order and, in an exceptional case, that application for an interim order could proceed ex parte. Such a case would be one where the practical utility of the orders being sought may be prejudiced by advance notice of the ASC's intentions allowing, for example, concealment of those assets.

36.Subsection 1323(4) relieves the ASC from the usual requirement to give an undertaking as to damages, but it does so only in respect of applications for interim orders. The exemption for such orders encourages urgent applications by the ASC in circumstances where, for example, an investigation has only just commenced, but where urgent action is necessary to preserve assets that may be in danger of being dissipated once the investigation becomes known. Were the ASC to be required to give an undertaking as to damages it would detract from the ASC's ability to take speedy action and thus restrict what has otherwise become a critical part of the ASC's enforcement strategy.

37.In cases where regulatory action has not been possible before perpetrators have transferred assets offshore, the prospects of subsequently securing those asserts have been, generally speaking, low. Notwithstanding significant advances in the level of co-operation between regulatory authorities, co-operation that is advanced by such legislative developments as the Mutual Assistance in Business Regulation Act 1992, it is still the case that in certain overseas jurisdictions it is virtually impossible to trace assets and secure orders requiring the return of that property. By contrast, the ASC has had considerable success in a number of cases where it was able to move early to secure assets pursuant to section 1323. Such assets have subsequently been made available to pay creditors or, in some cases, investors.

38.The ASC, as the corporate regulator, will not be motivated by the same factors as a private litigant in seeking such orders. The ASC is bound to consider, in addition to the prospects of success in preserving assets, the likely effect of the action on compliance with the law generally. The ASC is not motivated by the desire to preserve those assets for its own benefit, as is a private litigant, but for the benefit of shareholders and creditors.

39.The Government notes the Committee concedes at paragraphs 0.20 and 5.20 that ex parte applications under section 1323 are sometimes necessary due to the reality of swift movements of money in the corporate world, but that it is of the view the law, as it presently stands, does not provide any incentives for caution in the use of the ex parte procedure and that there is a capacity for innocent persons to suffer loss and damage without any right to compensation for the loss suffered. In reaching this view the Committee appears to have assumed that the ASC has a policy of proceeding ex parte, or at least needs some special incentive to exercise caution in using that procedure. However, in fact the ASC uses the ex parte procedure sparingly, and in practice the circumstances in which it has proceeded ex parte have been, and should be, exceptional.

40.The Government acknowledges that the current provisions of the Corporations Law providing for interim freezing orders are widely drafted, but notes that there are other incentives for caution on the part of the ASC. These include the availability of the sanction of costs orders to be made against the ASC where the ASC is unable to sustain its claim. The courts have a discretion to award costs against the ASC if it is satisfied that the ASC has in some way acted unreasonably or not prosecuted its claim with due diligence. The costs of the interim receiver may also be borne by the ASC: ASC v Aust-Home Investments Limited (1993) 11 ACSR 137.

41.Additionally, the absence of an undertaking as to damages is a matter that a court could take into account when weighing the balance of convenience in making the interim order sought by the ASC, particularly where the application proceeds ex parte. Further, where an order is obtained by the ASC as the result of an ex parte hearing it is the common practice of the court to allow the order to run for a very limited period only. During that period the court requires that the defendant be served and afforded the opportunity to be represented at a further hearing, held at the earliest possible date, to determine whether the order should be varied, discharged or continued.

42.The Government also notes that the provisions of subsection 1323(4) are not unique. Subsection 80(6) of the Trade Practices Act 1974 exempts the Trade Practices Commission from being required to give an undertaking as to damages where the Commission applies for an injunction to restrain breaches or attempted breaches of the restrictive trade practices and consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act.

43.In all the circumstances, the Government is not satisfied that the existing fetters on the grant of interim orders under subsection 1323(4) to the ASC are inadequate and, in view of its concern to ensure that the ASC is encouraged to act without delay to secure assets in the interests of investors and creditors, does not agree with the Committee's recommendation. Nevertheless, the Government does see some merit in ensuring that the procedures governing the grant of interim orders under section 1323, where those orders are obtained following an ex parte hearing, operate uniformly across all jurisdictions. Thus the Government proposes to amend section 1323 to provide that where an interim order is obtained as a result of an ex parte hearing, that order is returnable on a day within 21 days of the making of the order or, in exceptional circumstances, such further date as is determined by the Court. Within that period the ASC will be required to effect service on the defendant and the defendant will be entitled to appear on the return date and make application for the order to be discharged or varied.

The Committee recommends that the ASC Law be amended to provide that the ASC must ensure that a witness examined under section 19 of the Law is provided with a transcript, as of right, as soon as practicable, without the necessity for a request (whether oral or written) from the witness. If the ASC decides that it is inadvisable to supply the transcript, because to do so would prejudice the investigation or endanger the privacy of the examination, then the witness should be given advice in writing to this effect.

44.Currently, under subsection 24(1) of the ASC Law, the ASC may cause a record to be made of statements made at an examination, and is required to do so if the examinee so requests. The ASC is also required, if requested in writing by an examinee, to provide to the examinee, without cost, a written copy of the record of his or her examination where such a record has been made: paragraph 24(2)(b). The ASC is also entitled to require the examinee to read the record, or have it read to him or her, and to require the examinee to sign it: paragraph 24(2)(a).

45.The Government accepts that the requirement for a request from the witness for a copy of the record is unnecessary. The Government agrees with the Committee's recommendation that, where a record of an examination is made by the ASC under subsection 24(1) of the ASC Law, the ASC should provide as soon as practicable a copy of the record to the examinee as of right, ie without the need for an oral or written request from the examinee. The Government is also concerned to retain the existing right of the ASC in paragraph 24(2)(a) to require an examinee to read and sign the transcript.

46.The Government also agrees with the Committee's recommendation that if the ASC decides that it is inadvisable to supply the transcript, because to do so would prejudice the investigation or endanger the privacy of the examination, then the witness should be given advice in writing to this effect.

47. Additionally, the Government proposes to amend section 24 to allow the ASC to release a copy of a record of examination to the examinee's lawyer. Such an amendment will give better recognition to the right of the examinee to be legally represented. Section 24 will also be amended to allow the release of a tape of the examination, in appropriate circumstances and subject to conditions as to its use determined by the ASC, to the examinee or his or her lawyer.
The Committee recommends that the ASC review its consultative arrangements, particularly with the business community, with a view to ensuring that the arrangements are comprehensive.

48.The Government supports the Committee's recommendation that the ASC review its consultative arrangements, particularly with the business community, with a view to ensuring that the arrangements are comprehensive.
49.The ASC advises that such a review has already commenced.

50.The Committee made particular reference (at paragraph 5.43 of the Report) to the omission of the Business Council of Australia, the Australian Bankers Association and the Australian Merchant Banks Association from the list of organisations with which the office of the Chair of the ASC holds periodic liaison meetings. Immediately after this criticism was raised at the public hearings held by the Committee, the ASC formally invited the Business Council of Australia to nominate a representative to attend liaison committee meetings in the Victorian and New South Wales Regional Offices.

51.As to liaison with banking representatives, the ASC advises that the Australian Merchant Bankers Association has been renamed the International Banks and Securities Association of Australia, and is one of the organisations referred to in the list of private sector bodies with which the ASC regularly holds liaison meetings at a national level. The ASC also has a network within its Regional Offices for "specialist" nominated officers to liaise with each of the four major banks in each region. The function of those liaison arrangements is to give advance warning of ASC requirements and where possible to assist banks to meet those requirements. The ASC has also advised that should the Australian Bankers' Association wish to raise any matters of general concern, at the national level, the ASC would be happy to discuss them.

The Committee recommends that regulations be promulgated requiring ASC investigation officers to undertake that the ASC will provide to the person from whom business or financial records are seized a copy of all those records which are necessary to enable the person or company to carry on the ordinary business activities of the person or company.

52.The Government welcomes the Committee's recognition of the clear need in an investigation of a suspected breach of the law that the ASC must move to seize and secure the original documents which may be needed in a later prosecution. The Government also notes the Committee's view that a change to the legislation is unnecessary at this stage.

53.The Government agrees that the existing practice of the ASC to provide to the person from whom business or financial records are seized a copy of those records which are necessary to enable the person or company to carry on their ordinary business activities, be set out in the regulations.

The regulations should further state that the requirement on the part of the ASC to ensure that such undertakings are noted on the form of Notice to Produce Documents which is served on the company or person concerned.

54.The Government agrees that the form of the Notice to Produce Documents, prescribed by the regulations, include a statement as to the obligation on the part of the ASC to provide copies of documents necessary to the continuation of ordinary business activities.

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that:

the ASC note on its relevant forms, particularly the Notice to Produce Documents and the Notice to Attend for Compulsory Oral Examination, the existence of a right to apply for reimbursement of costs and expenses under section 89;
the ASC develop guidelines for its officers to guide the exercise of its discretion under section 89;
the ASC report in its Annual Report to Parliament on the number and amount of claims made under the section, and the number and amount of claims approved for reimbursement; and
the Government ensure that an appropriate level of resourcing is available to the ASC to meet claims under section 89.

SPEECH.PARA: 55.The Government agrees that the prescribed form of the Notice Requiring Appearance at an Examination or Reasonable Assistance in Connection with an Investigation (Form 1), the Notice Requiring the Production of Books (Form 2) and the Summons to Witness (Form 3), prescribed by the Australian Securities Commission Regulations, be amended to include a note of the existence of a right to apply for reimbursement of costs and expenses under section 89 of the ASC Law.

56.The Government supports the Committee's recommendation that the ASC develop guidelines for its officers to guide the exercise of its discretion under section 89 and notes that the ASC has already developed such guidelines. Those guidelines are set out in the ASC's Enforcement Manual.

57.The Government also supports the Committee's recommendation that the ASC report in its Annual Report to Parliament on the number and amount of claims made under section 89, and the number and amount of claims approved for reimbursement. The Government notes that the ASC has already implemented this aspect of the Committee's recommendation by the inclusion of information about allowances and expenses paid to people under section 89 of the ASC Law at page 68 of its 1994/95 Annual Report.

58.The Government notes the Committee's recommendation that the Government ensure that an appropriate level of resourcing is available to the ASC to meet claims under section 89. The Government is, however, concerned to ensure that the implementation of the recommendations of the Committee that are agreed to by the Government can be resourced by the ASC within its existing funding. The Government anticipates that the number of claims under section 89 will increase significantly upon implementation of the recommendation noting the existence of the right to reimbursement on the relevant forms. This may therefore have some effect on ASC resources for investigations.

The Committee recommends that the ASC Law be amended so that the power of the ASC to exclude a particular lawyer from a compulsory examination under section 19 be only exercisable on application by the ASC to a court of superior jurisdiction. The onus should be on the ASC to prove that the exclusion of a particular lawyer is necessary so as to avoid prejudice to an investigation. The examination should furthermore be stayed during the duration of any such application.

59.The Government agrees that the ASC Law be amended so that the ASC only be entitled to exclude a particular lawyer from a compulsory examination under section 19 on application by the ASC to a court of superior jurisdiction. The Government also agrees that the examination should be stayed during the duration of any such application.

60.However, the Government is concerned that the onus that the Committee recommends be placed on the ASC, namely to prove that the exclusion of a particular lawyer is necessary so as to avoid prejudice to an investigation, is too high.

61. There is a growing body of case law concerning the circumstances in which the ASC and like investigative bodies may take the unusual step of excluding a person's chosen legal representative from an examination. The line of case law includes Wood v NCSC (1990) 1 ACSR 779, National Crime Authority v A,B & D (1988) 18 FCR 439, ASC V Bell (1991) 6 ACSR 281 and Stockbridge v Ogilvie (1993) 10 ACSR 688. Those cases indicate a consistent development of the case law confirming that investigative agencies such as the ASC and the National Crime Authority (NCA) have power to exclude a lawyer if there are "reasonable grounds for a bona fide belief on [the inspector's] part that to allow the representation will or is likely to prejudice the investigation": ASC v Bell per Lockhart J at page 286.
62.The Government considers that the statutory onus to be placed on the ASC should reflect that

developed by the case law, namely that the ASC be required to establish to the court's satisfaction that there are reasonable grounds for a bona fide belief on the inspector's part that to allow the representation will, or is likely to, prejudice the investigation. The case law has not attempted to limit the circumstances which may give rise to such a reasonable belief and the Government believes it would be counterproductive to attempt to define legislatively the particular circumstances in which an inspector may form such a reasonable belief, because of the wide variety of circumstances that arise in the course of an investigation.

63.The Committee states at paragraph 7.34 of its report its view that the only real grounds for exclusion are that the lawyer's involvement amounts to a conflict of interest in relation to his or her previous representation of other examinees, or due to prior professional involvement in the corporate structures under investigation. While the Government agrees that these circumstances are those that most commonly would give rise to a concern or belief in the mind of an ASC inspector that the presence of the particular lawyer may prejudice the investigation, the Government does not agree that it would be appropriate to state those circumstances in the legislation and thereby restrict the inspector's ability to exclude a particular lawyer if other circumstances justified that course.
The Committee recommends that the transcript of an examinee's compulsory oral examination be provided promptly and as of right as proposed in recommendation 5 above.

64.The Government agrees with the recommendation of the Committee that the transcript of an examinee's compulsory oral examination be provided promptly and as of right, subject to the qualifications detailed in relation to recommendation 5 above that the ASC retain its existing right in paragraph 24(2)(a) to require an examinee to read and sign the transcript and if the ASC decides that it is inadvisable to supply the transcript, because to do so would prejudice the investigation or endanger the privacy of the examination, then the witness should be given advice in writing to this effect.

The Committee recommends that the ASC Law be amended so that summonses for the section 19 examination should be issued by the District Registrar of the Federal Court on the application of the ASC. The summons should issue where the District Registrar is satisfied that the examinee can give information relevant to a matter that the ASC is investigating, or is to investigate, under Division 1 of the ASC Act. The issue and application in this instance should be able to be done electronically if there is a need.

65.The Government notes the Committee's comparison of the ASC's examination power under section 19 of the ASC Law with the examination procedure under section 81 of the Bankruptcy Act 1966. However, with respect, the Government submits that the comparison of these 2 procedures is inappropriate.

66.The examination procedure under section 81 of the Bankruptcy Act provides for the public examination of a bankrupt or persons associated with the bankrupt, before the Registrar or the Court, by a creditor, the trustee of the bankrupt's estate or the Official Receiver (when he or she is not the trustee of the estate). An application to summons a person for examination under section 81 must be made to the Registrar or the Court, and the Registrar or the Court has a discretion whether or not to issue the summons. Registrars usually handle the applications for examinations and they also preside at the examination.

67.As such, the examination procedure under section 81 of the Bankruptcy Act is comparable with the examination procedure under section 597 of the Corporations Law. Under section 597 of the Corporations Law, persons who may be able to provide information or assistance in an insolvency administration can be the subject of an examination before the Court. An application for the issue of a summons to a person to appear for examination may be made by a liquidator, provisional liquidator or administrator of a company; an administrator of a deed of company arrangement; the ASC or a person authorised by the ASC. The summonsing of company officers by the Court for examination is mandatory under section 596A. However, the Court has a discretion under section 596B whether or not to summons persons other than officers of the company for examination. Such an application is to be supported by affidavit evidence (subsection 596C(1))but that affidavit is not available for inspection unless the Court orders otherwise (subsection 596C(2)).

68.These amendments to the section 597 examination procedure were made by the Corporate Law Reform Act 1992. That Act implemented a number of the recommendations made by the Australian Law Reform Commission in the report on its `General Insolvency Inquiry' (known as `the Harmer Report'). In the opinion of the Harmer Report, "[t]he chief purposes of such examinations [in both bankruptcy and company insolvency law] are to facilitate the recovery of property, to discover whether conduct of the insolvent led to the insolvency and to investigate possible causes of action against third parties"(1) The Harmer Report continued: ". . . it should be acknowledged that the principal purpose of the examination provisions [namely the section 81 and section 597 examination procedures] should be the discovery of information which will assist in the administration of the estate. The interests of `public policy' in prosecuting criminal offences, though important, are in this context secondary"(2).

69.In contrast, the chief purpose of examinations under section 19 of the ASC Law is to facilitate the investigation by the ASC of suspected contraventions of a national scheme law; contraventions of any other State or Territory law concerning the management or affairs of a body corporate; or any fraud or dishonesty relating to a body corporate, securities or futures contract(3). To commence an investigation under subsection 13(1) of the ASC Law the ASC or its delegate must have "reason to suspect" that one or more contraventions of a national scheme law or a relevant State or Territory law may have been committed.

70.In addition, the circumstances surrounding examinations under section 81 of the Bankruptcy Act and section 597 of the Corporations Law are quite different to those surrounding examinations under section 19 of the ASC Law. By the time a section 81 or section 597 examination is contemplated, the fact of the individual's bankruptcy or corporate insolvency is already in the public arena. In contrast, the existence of an investigation under subsection 13(1) of the ASC Law may not be public knowledge at the time of an examination under section 19 of the ASC Law. The Courts have acknowledged that the premature disclosure of information while investigations were still on foot or the hearing of criminal charges still pending would enable persons to conceal or destroy relevant evidence and otherwise hinder or obstruct any investigation into, or proceedings with respect to, their activities."(4)

71. The Government also notes the Committee's belief that the ASC should be required to file an affidavit in support of its application which would then be available, as a public document, for perusal by any interested party. The premature disclosure of information sufficient to ground the issue of a summons, including the premature disclosure of the lines of inquiry to be followed by the ASC but are which necessarily untested at that time, carries the unavoidable consequence that the identity of persons being examined and the reasons why they are being examined will become public at an early stage of an investigation. This could result in considerable unfairness and prejudice to the individuals concerned as well as having a devastating effect upon the viability of the company. Section 19 examinations commonly involve the affairs and reputation of individuals still active in business. On the other hand, section 81 and section 597 examinations concern the affairs of individuals or companies whose affairs are already under administration.
72.The proposal would also be contrary to the policy reflected in section 127 of the ASC Law that the ASC take all reasonable measures to protect the confidentiality of information given to it.

73.One means by which the concerns of the Committee for the greater protection of examinees can be met, however, is by improving the skills of the ASC officers conducting section 19 examinations. As noted in the paragraphs following relating to Recommendation 13 of the Committee's Report, the Government supports the Committee's recommendation that funds be made available for training so that the ASC officers conducting examinations are equipped with a clear understanding of their legislation, the role of natural justice and effective communication skills. The Government notes that the ASC has already made significant efforts to provide appropriate training for its officers in examination skills. While section 19 examinations are only undertaken now by ASC officers with appropriate expertise and training, the Government sees the further enhancement of the skills of those officers as another means of enhancing the protection of examinees.

74.The Government will formally review the standards of conduct of section 19 examinations in 3 years time to determine whether the anticipated improvement in the protection of examinees has resulted, or whether additional measures to achieve this outcome are warranted.

75.In all the circumstances, the Government is not persuaded that the procedure recommended by the Committee, for the issue of summonses for section 19 examinations by the District Registrar of the Federal Court, on application of the ASC, would be appropriate.

The Committee recommends that funds be made available for training so that the ASC officers conducting examinations are equipped with a clear understanding of their legislation, the role of natural justice and effective communication skills.

76.The Government supports the Committee's recommendation that funds be made available for training so that the ASC officers conducting examinations are equipped with a clear understanding of their legislation, the role of natural justice and effective communication skills.

77.The ASC has advised that it has already made significant efforts to provide appropriate training for officers in examination skills. In April 1995 the ASC ran a 3 day intensive course for 24 senior investigators and lawyers in examination skills training. Other ASC staff undertook the same course in July 1995. The training was conducted in conjunction with the Leo Cussen Institute, a Victorian body which provides professional training to lawyers and is particularly experienced in providing advocacy training. The courses included mock section 19 examinations to generate discussion about common challenges and issues arising out of procedural aspects of section 19 examinations. The mock examinations were video-taped so as to provide an opportunity for peer review of the performance of each participant on such indicators as the structure and content of questions, the relevance of the questions to the fact situation and the examiner's style and demeanour in asking questions. Both courses were conducted on a national basis so that staff from different regional offices of the ASC were able to discuss and compare approaches in their respective offices. The ASC anticipates that the course will be made generally available to regional offices for those officers who have not had the opportunity to attend the national course.

PARA.TAB: The Committee recommends that:
the ASC Law be amended in order that an examinee appearing at a compulsory hearing under section 19 shall be entitled to the protection of the privilege against self-incrimination;
the privilege should not be available in relation to documents discovered pursuant to a notice to produce documents or the examination; and
the privilege should not be available in relation to corporations.

SPEECH.PARA: 78.The Government notes the Committee's recommendation that the ASC Law be amended to entitle a section 19 examinee to the protection of the privilege against self-incrimination.

79.The privilege against self-incrimination is an established rule of common law that no person can be compelled to incriminate himself or herself, and may refuse to answer any question, or produce any document or thing which may put that person at risk of criminal conviction or expose the person to a civil penalty.

80.The legislature may abrogate the common law privilege and has done so on occasions in the public interest. Examples of legislative abrogation of the privilege include section 155 of the Trade Practices Act, section 68 of the ASC Law and section 597 of the Corporations Law. Section 264 of the Income Tax Assessment Act also abrogates the privilege against self-incrimination by necessary implication: Stergis v Boucher (1989) 86 ALR 174.

81.The UK courts have also confirmed that their corporate investigators (the Department of Trade and Industry) may compel the provision of self-incriminating information: R v Selig [1992] 1 WLR 148. Section 2 of the Criminal Justice Act 1987 (UK) also provides that the investigative powers given to the UK Serious Fraud Office override the common law privilege against self-incrimination.

82.However, the abrogation of the privilege in the commercial regulation context is not a recent development. For example, section 17 of the Bankruptcy Act 1883 (Imp) removed the privilege over a century ago. This provision is today reflected in subsection 81(11AA) of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 (Cth). Then, as today, the rationale was that because of the especial public interest in the proceeding in which the disclosure was made, the privilege from answering was a grave obstacle to full disclosure(5).

83.The abrogation of the privilege by subsection 68(1) of the ASC Law for the purposes of examinations by the ASC under section 19 of the ASC Law is, nevertheless, balanced by a use immunity in subsection 68(3) of the ASC Law. The use immunity prevents a person's incriminating oral statement or signed record or incriminating documents produced under compulsion, from being used in evidence against that person in criminal proceedings or proceedings for the imposition of a penalty, other than proceedings for the falsity of the statement.

84.The Government believes that it has the balance in section 68 as it presently stands, between the public interest in effective corporate regulation and the more general civil liberties considerations, correct.

85.Corporate crime is unlike conventional crime in a number of respects. The privilege against self-incrimination has operated as a safeguard to protect the poor, the ignorant and the legally unsophisticated. Those against whom corporate investigations are directed are generally well-resourced, well-informed and represented by counsel expert in the field.

86.A company officer setting up a criminal scheme is able to plan it so as to use a series of apparently unrelated transactions, to act through agents and intermediaries who may be unavailable to investigators or prosecutors, and to build in as many blinds and screens as desired through foreign jurisdictions. If necessary, the scheme can leave the perpetrator as the only person with knowledge of facts that, if able to be proved, show the criminal nature of the scheme.
87.In practice, this is quite a different kind of offence from the more usual form of theft.

88.In addition, the company suffering the loss is an inanimate legal fiction often controlled by the perpetrator, unlike the human victim of theft. There is therefore typically no human victim with direct familiarity with the circumstances—so that the prosecution is forced to rely on the perpetrator for evidence. For this reason and because of the complexity of many criminal schemes, documentary evidence is also particularly useful. But it is only useful if it can be identified and explained by the perpetrator.
89.Further, unlike ordinary theft, the perpetrator has generally exploited the privilege of carrying on business using a limited liability corporate structure and using moneys invested by the public.

90.In view of these differences the Government considers it inappropriate that an examinee appearing at a compulsory examination before an ASC investigator under section 19 of the ASC Law be entitled to the protection of the common law privilege against self-incrimination that has developed in very different circumstances.

91.The Government notes that section 10 of the Corporations Legislation (Evidence) Amendment Act 1992 requires that by mid 1997 a review is undertaken of the amendments made by that Act abolishing the derivative use immunity previously available under subsection 68(3) of the ASC Law. The derivative use immunity prevented any incriminating information, document or other thing obtained as a consequence of an incriminating oral statement or signed record, being admitted in evidence against the person.

92.The impetus for the amendments in 1992 were the difficulties being faced by the ASC and the DPP in bringing effective prosecutions. The difficulties threatened to defeat the purpose of significant portions of the corporations legislation. It was clear that in strongly contested cases the onus would rest on the prosecution to establish that every item of evidence, or every document which it sought to tender, was not obtained as a direct or indirect consequence of any compulsory process utilised pursuant to the ASC Law or the Corporations Law.

93.The 1992 amendments also largely restored the law relating to the privilege against self incrimination to the position that obtained under the former Companies Code, namely that examinees were entitled to the protection of use immunity but not derivative use immunity.

94.Subject to the comments that follow, the Government considers that the review of the 1992 amendments, required to be undertaken by mid 1997, will be the appropriate forum for a re-examination of the issues in this area.

95.The Government notes the criticisms made to the Committee of the requirement that the privilege be asserted before each answer in question. The law as it presently stands requires an examinee to give serious consideration to whether it is appropriate to claim the privilege in relation to each question and the answer to that question that the examinee is about to give. In practice, however, many examinees will claim the privilege almost as a matter of form before answering each and every question. The Government also recognises that examinees are often placed in a difficult position in trying to assess whether the answer they are about to give may incriminate them.

96.In all the circumstances the Government proposes that section 68 of the ASC Law and section 597 of the Corporations Law be amended to enable a person to make a blanket claim for privilege at the outset or at any stage during the examination.

97.The Government notes the Committee's recommendation that the privilege against self-incrimination should not be available in relation to documents discovered pursuant to a notice to produce documents or a section 19 examination. The Committee's recommendation reflects the current law (namely subsection 68(1) of the ASC Law) and the Government agrees with it.

98.The Government also notes the Committee's recommendation that the privilege against self incrimination should not be available in relation to corporations. The Committee's recommendation reflects the current law (namely paragraph 68(2)(a) of the ASC Law) and the Government agrees with it.
The majority of the Committee recommends that the ASC Law be amended with a view to ensuring the availability of legal professional privilege to all parties in investigations under the ASC Law.
99.At common law, legal professional privilege protects from disclosure the contents of all oral and written communications passing between a lawyer and his or her client which are:

PARA.TAB: referrable to the lawyer/client relationship;
confidential in character; and
brought into existence for the necessary sole purpose of:
—enabling the client to obtain, or the lawyer to give, legal advice or assistance; or
—use in litigation that is current, pending or within the reasonable contemplation or apprehension of the client: Grant v Downs (1976) 11 ALR 577; Baker v Campbell (1983) 153 CLR 52.

SPEECH.PARA: 100.At common law, both the client and the lawyer may rely on the privilege to resist the disclosure of such communications. The confidentiality of such communications is protected from compulsory disclosure except where there is clear statutory provision abrogating the privilege.

101.Section 69 of the ASC Law expressly preserves a lawyer's right to claim legal professional privilege unless his or her client consents to the lawyer disclosing the privileged communication. The ASC Law, however, makes no reference to the right of the client or third parties to claim legal professional privilege in the face of a requirement by the ASC to give information or produce books. A majority of the High Court in CAC (NSW) v Yuill (1991) 4 ACSR 624 found a statutory intention to abrogate the entitlement of a client to claim legal professional privilege and held that a client could not claim the privilege to refuse to produce books or answer questions at a special examination under section 295 of the Companies Code. The High Court decision in Yuill's Case has been applied to investigations initiated by the ASC under Part 3 of the ASC Law: ASC v Dalleagles (1992) 8 ACSR 109.

102.The Government notes the Committee's review of the arguments (by the ASC and the DPP) in favour of the abrogation of the client's privilege and the arguments (by, among others, the Law Council of Australia) against the abrogation of that privilege. The Committee concludes that, on balance, it believes that the inroads on the availability of legal professional privilege by the decision in Yuill's Case have had a negative effect upon corporate regulation in Australia.
103.The Committee expressed the view that the limitation upon the privilege:

PARA.TAB: has been inimical to a constructive relationship between the ASC and the business community;
is not conducive to the building of a climate of voluntary compliance with the law;
may prompt some company officers to act without legal advice, or on the basis of imperfectly understood oral advice.

SPEECH.PARA: 104.The Government is not, however, satisfied that there is objective evidence to support that view. No evidence to suggest that the decision in Yuill is, in fact, having that impact appears to have been submitted to the Committee or has otherwise been furnished to the Government.

105.What the Committee's review does clearly demonstrate, however, is the clash of competing policies in relation to this issue. On one side is the public interest in ensuring the honest conduct of the affairs of companies by compelling those involved in a company's affairs to disclose all relevant materials. On the other is the public interest in ensuring that full and frank legal advice is sought and given by protecting the confidentiality of lawyer/client communications. There are clear and persuasive arguments for each of these competing view points. Ultimately, it is a policy decision for the legislature as to which policy consideration is to be favoured.

106.On balance, the Government remains of the view that the public interest in ensuring the honest conduct of the affairs of companies should override the public interest in ensuring that full and frank legal advice is sought and given.

107.The Government is persuaded that the continued abrogation of legal professional privilege in corporate investigations is required to enable the efficient and cost effective completion of investigations and timely enforcement action. Given the complexity of much of the conduct which constitutes breaches of corporate law, access to legal communications is essential to obtain a proper understanding of the complex legal and accounting webs that serve to mask ostensibly legitimate and complex commercial arrangements that are in breach of the law.

108.Claims for legal professional privilege can result in major delays to an investigation and prosecution process for corporate offences and, in particular, delay investigations of major cases for considerable periods of time. Such delays enable potential defendants time to leave the jurisdiction or to destroy relevant documents yet to be produced to the ASC. The adverse impact on the course of an investigation by claims of legal professional privilege is often exacerbated by unsubstantiated ambit claims of privilege which becomes the subject of lengthy litigation. In practice, legal professional privilege claimed over a very large number of documents will be found, after lengthy court proceedings, not to be available in respect of a large proportion of those documents at all.

109.It is also the case that the privilege is not totally abrogated in that oral evidence which would otherwise have been privileged and is provided by way of examination is inadmissible in both civil and criminal proceedings under paragraph 76(1)(d) of the ASC Law.
110.On balance, the Government does not agree with the Committee's recommendation.
(1) The Australian Law Reform Commission Report No 45 General Insolvency Inquiry (`the Harmer Report') Australian Government Publishing Service, Canberra 1988 Volume 1 page 249 paragraph 584.
(2) The Harmer Report Volume 1 page 255 paragraph 605.
(3) Section 13 of the ASC Law provides that the ASC may make such investigation as it thinks expedient ..where it has reason to suspect that one of these contraventions may have been committed.
(4) National Australia Bank v Saunders (1988) 13 ACLR 299 at 301 per Rogers CJ.
(5) Stone, Julius, Evidence: Its History and Policies, Butterworths, Sydney, 1991 at p44.
Senator The Honourable Gareth Evans QC
The Honourable Roger Price MP
Chairperson
Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mr Price

In the attachment to this letter I set out the Government's Response to your Committee's Report entitled "A Review of Australia's Efforts to Promote and protect Human Rights", which was tabled in Parliament on 5 December 1994.
I thank you and the members of your Committee for this Report.
Yours sincerely
GARETH EVANS

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government Response to The Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Report

SPEECH.PARA: A Review of Australia's Efforts to Promote and Protect Human Rights
Introduction

The Government wishes to express its appreciation to the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for their work on the review of Australia's efforts to promote and protect human rights internationally. The Government accords a high priority to the promotion and protection of human rights internationally because we believe that the universal observance of the rights and principles contained in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and other major international human rights instruments would result in a more just international order, from which security and prosperity of all nations and individuals would benefit.

The Committee's report deals with a wide range of issues and is an important document which focuses public attention on what are at times very complex human rights issues. As can be seen from the Government's response to the Committee's recommendations, these issues are continually under review as we consider ways of improving our performance in promoting and protecting human rights observance internationally.
Recommendation 1

PARA.EMPHASIS: As an initiative to develop regional understanding on human rights matters, the Committee recommends that the Government explore with regional countries the possibility of establishing a regional dialogue on human rights through regular ministerial meetings of the foreign ministers as appropriate, of the APEC countries and through regular contacts between the Human Rights Commissions of regional countries.

SPEECH.PARA: Agree to explore further dialogue option.

The Government seeks to establish international mechanisms for contact and dialogue wherever possible. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and other ministers regularly discuss human rights in bilateral meetings in the region. As well, the two delegations to China and the Australian Parliamentary Consultative Delegation's visit this year to Vietnam have succeeded in establishing dialogue on a number of issues of mutual concern, including that of human rights.

The Government also gives a high priority to encouraging the establishment and strengthening of national human rights institutions in countries in the region. Through the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, Australia has provided a substantial degree of cooperation and technical assistance on national human rights institutions to a number of countries including the Philippines, Indonesia, Thailand and Papua New Guinea. As well, the Government has contributed $300,000 to the UN Voluntary Fund for Technical Cooperation for the purpose of strengthening the domestic infrastructures which support human rights and, in particular, national human rights machinery in the Asia-Pacific region.

The Government has long supported the development of Asia-Pacific human rights arrangements which would complement the UN human rights machinery and national institutions established in a number of countries in the region for the promotion and protection of human rights. In this context, the Government has been, over recent years, in consultation with other governments on the prospects for a structured dialogue, which might eventually extend to regular meetings at a ministerial level. The Asia-Pacific is the only region of the world which is still without such an arrangement. The Government believes a regional arrangement would foster greater understanding, cooperation and maintenance of universal human rights principles amongst the diverse and varied social systems and cultures in the Asia-Pacific. The Government's experience on this subject suggests that although there is interest by many countries of the region in closer cooperation on human rights some of them are not ready to formalise this and that further work will be required before such an arrangement could be set in place.

To advance work on a regional arrangement, three UN-sponsored meetings have been held, in Manila in 1990, Jakarta in 1993 and Seoul in 1994. At the meeting in Seoul, while there was no consensus on the establishment—of a formal regional mechanicism there was a general desire that discussions should continue. A resolution supporting regional activity was introduced by the Republic of Korea and supported by Australia at the 1995 session of the UN Commission on Human Rights and was adopted by consensus. At a meeting of national human rights institutions held in Manila in April this year, participants, who represented national institutions not governments, affirmed their support for regional cooperation in the promotion and protection of human rights. The Government considers the strengthening of the networks that are developing between national commissions in the region will assist in the establishment of a regional human rights body.
The Government will continue to look for opportunities to extend dialogue on human rights within the limitations of available resources.
Recommendation 2

PARA.EMPHASIS: In the current debate on UN reform, the Committee recommends that the Australian Government take all appropriate measures to urge the United States administration and Congress to fulfil the United States' financial obligations to the UN promptly.

SPEECH.PARA: Accept

The Government is concerned that the US budgetary process will have a dramatic impact on funding to UN specialised agencies, the UN regular budget and its peace keeping operations. The Government is also concerned that current US domestic fiscal pressures will mean that the US will not address its significant arrears. Appropriate opportunities have been taken over the last year to register these concerns with the Administration and the US Congress. Mr. Bilney, as acting Foreign Minister, wrote to key US Congressmen noting Australia's concerns relating to declining aid volumes. In our representations we have emphasised that our concern is not the United States' internal budgetary processes but the global impact of significant reductions in foreign relations expenditure, and the need to ensure a strong US presence across the multilateral system.

The prospect of significant US funding shortfalls is focusing agencies on reform measures and presents a possible opportunity to pursue with increased determination the reform of the UN and its specialised agencies. US funding shortfalls may convince secretariats and member States of the need for closer adherence to mandates and prioritisation of work programs.

As of 31 May 1995, member States owed the UN an overall total of USD2.8 billion (US arrears were USD1.2 million). Of this amount, USD1.1 billion is for the regular budget and USD1.7 billion is for peace keeping operations. The UN Secretary-General noted in his statement to last year's session of the UN's General Assembly (UNGA49), and repeated subsequently on 22 June this year, that the financial crisis of the UN was threatening its ability to carry out its major functions, including peace keeping and other programs and activities funded from the regular budget. Australia continues to urge all UN members, including the US, to pay their assessed contributions to the UN's regular budget, to the peace keeping scale and to the specialised agencies on time and in full, as is our own practice.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that, in the current reforms of the UN, the financing and structure of the human rights regime be addressed and urges the Australian Government to continue its support for greater funding and coordination in the system.

SPEECH.PARA: Accept

The Government is committed to ensuring that adequate resources from within the UN system are made available for strengthening the operation of the UN human rights system including the Centre for Human Rights. At the 1993 World Conference on Human Rights in Vienna, Australia argued strongly for the United Nations to devote the financial resources necessary for strengthening human rights activities. Since then, Australia has continued to argue in the UN Commission on Human Rights and at the UN General Assembly, for a greater proportion of the UN budget to be devoted to human rights.

In addition to increased financial resources for UN human rights machinery, the Government has strongly encouraged the UN to provide the administrative, managerial and staff resources required by the UN Centre for Human Rights to carry out its core functions as the focal point for the human rights activities of the UN, and has supported reform efforts currently underway in the Centre. Australia has urged the Centre for Human Rights to strengthen its management so that it can operate more efficiently and effectively.

The position of UN High Commissioner for Human Rights was set up in 1994 to develop coordination between the various UN agencies on human rights as well as to integrate human rights activities in peace keeping and humanitarian assistance operations. Australia fought hard for the appointment of a High Commissioner for Human Rights and has consistently supported the development of his role as the head of the UN human rights system and in coordinating human rights activities in the UN. The first incumbent, Mr. Jose Ayala Lasso, visited Australia in April 1995 as a guest of the Government.

In keeping with the high priority the Government places on the need to ensure that adequate resources are made available for strengthening the operation of the UN human rights system and the importance of effective national human rights institutions, the Government has provided financial support to the UN for the creation of the position of Special Adviser to the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights on National Human Rights Institutions. Mr. Brian Burdekin, former Australian Federal Human Rights Commissioner and an internationally regarded expert on national human rights institutions, has been appointed to the position for a two-year period. Mr. Burdekin commenced duty in Geneva on 26 July 1995.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Australian Parliament promote the possibility of the funding of a position or positions at the Human Rights Centre of Geneva by the International Parliamentary Union.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an issue for the Australian Parliament to determine.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee urges the Government to promote, during debates on the reform of the UN, discussion of the creation of a UN Parliamentary Assembly to monitor, among its responsibilities, human rights practices on a regular basis.

SPEECH.PARA: Do not agree that this would add value to human rights monitoring.

The UN body and States already have a number of bodies for monitoring human rights. The Government is not persuaded that there would be real benefits in having a UN Parliamentary Assembly monitoring human rights, or that there would be sufficiently broad support for the proposal to make a representative, properly-resourced group possible.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that, in the process of UN reform, the Australian Government should press for a review of the committee structure to address questions of the independence of members of UN committees. In particular, the Government might urge the UN to confine the eligibility for membership of the Human Rights Committee to nationals of those countries, which have ratified the First (Optional) Protocol

SPEECH.PARA: Agree on the importance of the independence of members of UN Committees but do not accept that the present structure should be changed.

Criteria for membership of UN human rights committees established pursuant to the key UN human rights instruments are contained within each instrument. In summary, the instruments stipulate that committees should be made up of experts of high moral standing and competence in fields covered by the Conventions and elected by States parties from amongst their nationals. Experts are to serve in their personal capacity but consideration should also be given to equitable geographic distribution and principal legal systems. Alteration of this committee structure would require amendment of individual instruments. Opening for negotiation previously agreed language is an uncertain process and could result in amendments that would limit rather than enhance committee independence. In addition, amendment of UN conventions is time-consuming and expensive due to the requirement to consult widely and thoroughly amongst member States of the United Nations.

It is the view of the Australian Government that efforts should be focused on ensuring that membership criteria are adhered to rather than revising the present committee structure. To this end, Australia carefully scrutinises each application for membership to UN human rights committees to ensure that high quality candidates are selected for vacant positions. In addition, Australia advocates and promotes the continual strengthening of the international human rights system of which the human rights treaty committees are an integral element. The Government does not agree that membership of the Human Rights Committee should be confined to experts elected by States parties which have signed the First (Optional) Protocol. This would require amendment of the International Covenant on Cultural and Political Rights (ICCPR), raising the problems set out above. It is the view of the Australian Government that the existing guidelines for membership of the Human Rights Committee are appropriate and that efforts should be concentrated on ensuring the guidelines are adhered to in electing committee members.

Limiting membership of the Human Rights Committee by the method suggested would elevate the complaints mechanism above other key functions of the Committee, including the consideration of reports on measures adopted and progress made by States in achieving observance of the rights enshrined in the Covenant. Moreover, States which have not ratified the First (Optional) Protocol may be reluctant to participate in the reporting process if they were not able to nominate their nationals for election to the Committee. Membership of other human rights committees is not limited to those which have agreed to be bound by the complaints mechanism contained within the instrument.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee draws the attention of the Government to those areas not yet subject to legislation under Article 4(a) of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination.

SPEECH.PARA: Agree that further legislation appropriate here.

The Government took action to meet its obligations under Article 4(a) of the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination (CERD) by introducing legislation addressing the incitement of racial hatred. Article 4(a) states:

Shall declare an offence punishable by law all dissemination of ideas based on racial superiority or hatred, incitement to racial discrimination, as well as all acts of violence or incitement to such acts against any race or group of persons of another colour or ethnic origin, and also the provision of any assistance to racist activities, including the financing thereof.

Work on redrafting racial vilification legislation was completed in 1994 following community), consultations held in 1993 to gauge public reaction to the Racial Vilification Bill 1992, which lapsed following the proroguing of Parliament on the calling of the March 1993 Federal Election.

The redrafted legislation—the Racial Hatred Bill 1994—originated in three major inquiries which found gaps in the protection provided by the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. The National Inquiry into Racist Violence, The Australian Law Reform Commission Report into Multiculturalism and the Law, and The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody all favoured an extension of Australia's human rights regime to explicitly protect the victims of extreme racism.

The Racial Hatred Bill was intended to close a gap in the legal protection available to the victims of extreme racist behaviour, and to provide a safety net for racial harmony in Australia as both a warning to those who might attack the principle of tolerance and an assurance to their potential victims.

The Racial Hatred Bill was passed by the House of Representatives on 16 November 1994. It was introduced to the Senate on 28 November 1994 and referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee for report by 7 March 1995. In the Committees's report, the majority recommended that the Bill be enacted as introduced.

The Bill as introduced to the Parliament sought to amend the Crimes Act 1914 to provide for three criminal offences. However, the criminal offence provisions were deleted by the Senate during the Committee stages of debate on 24 August 1995.

The remaining provisions of the Bill were passed without amendment by the Senate. They created a civil prohibition against racial hatred by inserting new sections 18B to 18E into the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 to make it unlawful for a person to do an act, otherwise than in private, if:
the act is reasonably likely in all the circumstances to offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate another person or group of people; and
the act is done because of the race, colour or national or ethnic origin of the other person or of some or all of the people in the group.

On 31 August 1995 , the Government agreed to accept the Senate's amendments so that Australians gained the benefit of the remaining provisions of the Bill. Importantly this—provides an avenue of complaint to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. It is a vast improvement for people in States or Territories that currently have no such avenues of redress.
The Racial Hatred Act (No 101 of 1995) came into effect on 13 October 1995.

However, the Government remains convinced of the need for appropriate remedies in the criminal law to deal with extreme racist behaviour. It therefore, will go to the next election firmly committed to the introduction of another Bill to include such protection in the Crimes Act 1914 in the next Parliament.
Enactment of the criminal sanctions would enable Australia to withdraw its current reservation to Article 4(a) of CERD. The reservation is as follows:

The Government of Australia declares that Australia is not at present in a position specifically to treat as offences all the matters covered by Article 4(a) of the Convention. Acts of the kind there mentioned are punishable only to the extent provided by the existing criminal law dealing with such matters as the maintenance of public order, public mischief, assault, riot, criminal libel, conspiracy and attempts. It is the intention of the Australian Government, at the first suitable moment, to seek from Parliament legislation specifically implementing the terms of Article 4(a).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee draws the attention of the Government to the lack of legislation for implementation of the Genocide Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: Do not agree that legislation is necessary.

The Government does not accept the assumption implicit in the recommendation that specific legislation is necessary in order to fulfil Australia's obligations under the Convention. The approach until now has been that common law and criminal code of States and Territories provide adequate punishment for acts prohibited by the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide.
This approach accords with the practice of most other State parties to the Genocide Convention, and has not put us in breach of our obligations under the Convention.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee draws the attention of the Government to ILO Convention 169 which it has not yet ratified

SPEECH.PARA: Accept in principle
The Government is taking the necessary steps towards ratification of Convention 169, the Indigenous and Tribal Peoples Convention, 1989.

It is the normal practice for Australia not to ratify an ILO Convention until the law and practice in all relevant jurisdictions (Commonwealth, State and Territory) comply with its provisions and all State and Territory governments that have an interest in the Convention have formally agreed to ratification.

The upholding of the validity of the Commonwealth's Native Title Act 1993 by the High Court has enabled the Government to proceed with finalisation of the Commonwealth law and practice report on the Convention. Once this report is available, it will be forwarded to the States and Territories to assist them in preparing their law and practice reports. This course has been agreed with State and Territory governments.

Full consultation with indigenous communities is also necessary. In December 1993, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) Board of Commissioners agreed to support ratification following consultation with indigenous communities. However, it has become apparent that further consultation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community is desirable and the Government is currently determining how this can best be achieved.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Government table in the Parliament the reports (detailed at Table 2.2 of this report) prepared by the various Commonwealth agencies in response to our obligations under UN human rights treaties.

SPEECH.PARA: Response
Accept

The Government in future will table in Parliament copies of the final reports prepared under the major UN human rights instruments (International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, International Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination, Convention on the Rights of the Child, Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women and Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment) when they are submitted to the respective Committees.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government reinstate the regular human rights reports from all Australian diplomatic posts and urges the Government to make provision in resources and training for officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to carry out the task.

SPEECH.PARA: Agree on the importance of regular reporting but do not accept that it necessarily should be in the form of annual reports.

Regular reporting on human rights is an important requirement of Australian missions overseas. This requirement is set out in the directives provided to newly appointed Heads of Mission and evaluated in the Evaluation Review of each post conducted annually by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Human rights objectives figure prominently in the planning programs of many posts. Posts are tasked with specific reporting on human rights matters as required and many posts in countries with serious human rights problems provide human rights reporting on a regular basis. All posts are encouraged to incorporate human rights issues into their regular political and economic reporting. It remains the Government's view that because of this on-going human rights reporting, which is targeted at meeting specific needs, reporting on an annual basis irrespective of the particular circumstances prevailing in the country would be an unnecessary diversion of resources.
The Government has access to a range of authoritative annual and other reports on country human rights situations, including those of Amnesty International and the United States' State Department.

The objective of the DFAT/AusAID Human Rights Training Course, introduced in March 1994, is to educate participants in international and domestic human rights theory and practice and provide a grounding in Australian government policy with respect to human rights. An element of this is to provide practical guidance on human rights reporting and representational skills for officers including those proceeding on overseas postings. The course structure is currently being refined to ensure greater emphasis on practical exercises aimed at the development of reporting and representational skills.
Recommendation 12

[i]the further streamlining of the processes of the Commonwealth State Standing Committee on Treaties to improve the collection and dissemination of information between line departments and the coordinating agency at both the State and Commonwealth levels; and
[ii]the establishment of an educative program on the treaty process for officials at all levels of government.
Accept

Since July 1993, there have been five meetings of the Standing Committees on Treaties-July and October 1993, May and November 1994 and May 1995. The next meeting is scheduled for December 1995. Prior to these meetings, State and Territory representatives are provided with a list of current and forthcoming negotiations which show the name of the treaty and the administering Commonwealth agency, with new entries shown in bold. A brief description is provided to enable the States and Territories to determine the entries in which they are likely to have an interest. The States and Territories are also given detailed information about any matter in which they express an interest.

Improvements have been made to the processes over successive meetings, and efforts are continuing to improve further both the quality and timeliness of the material provided to the States and Territories. The coordination arrangements in place within the States and Territories is a matter for those Governments.

The Council of Australian Governments meeting on 11 April 1995 considered a position paper on reform of treaty processes presented to the Commonwealth by the States and Territories. The proposals dealt with Parliamentary involvement, the provision of information and Commonwealth/State consultation processes. The Council of Australian Governments decided that the Commonwealth/State Standing Committee on Treaties should consider the proposals for reform and report back to the next meeting of the Council.
Accept

In 1994 the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade published a revised edition of the Negotiation, Conclusion and Implementation of International Treaties and Arrangements, a handbook for the information of officials at all levels of government. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, in consultation with the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, also prepared an information kit on treaties, setting out a full description of the consultation process with States and Territories and other interested groups. In addition, the Government regularly conducts seminars for officials on international law and the treaty process.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee strongly endorses the move to inform the Parliament at an early stage in the treaty making process by tabling treaties in the Parliament before signature and recommends that the Minister for Foreign Affairs should use the forum of the Parliament to raise international human rights issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Accept

The Government welcomes the Committee's endorsement of the Government's recent policy decision to supplement information to Parliament on treaty action. This policy was outlined in the Joint Statement of 21 October 1994 by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, and the Attorney General, Michael Lavarch.

In accordance with this statement, the Government now tables the texts of multilateral treaties before action is taken to adhere to them. Explanatory notes are also provided setting out the main features of each treaty, for the assistance of Members and Senators. In addition to treaty texts, a list of multilateral treaties under negotiation, or to which the Government is considering adhering is also tabled.

Bilateral treaties are tabled shortly after signature. It is not possible to table the texts of bilateral treaties before signature, as most countries regard the texts of such treaties as confidential until signature.

These processes are designed to reaffirm the Government's commitment to responsible and transparent treaty making and to supplement the other channels for disseminating treaty action information to Parliament and the public, for example, through the Standing Committee on Treaties and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade publication, Insight.

The Government does and certainly will continue to use the forum of the Parliament to raise international human rights issues and acknowledges that to do so will often help achieve the advancement of human rights objectives.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that in order to fulfil the task of monitoring human rights policies and developments, the Human Rights Sub-Committee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade be made separate joint committee of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an issue for the Australian Parliament to determine.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the terms of reference of both the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee and the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee include a requirement to examine the compliance of legislation with the specific terms of the ICCPR and the ICESCR.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an issue for the Australian Parliament to determine.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau [AusAID] undertake a feasibility study, including a full evaluation of funding options, of the proposal by ACFOA to establish a human rights centre for dialogue and cooperation in Australia as part publicly funded and part privately funded non-governments institute.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees that such a centre would be useful but is not able to agree to any commitment of funds at this stage.

The Government agrees on the importance of regional mechanisms which promote dialogue and cooperation on human rights issues. There are a number of valuable activities in the human rights area that an independent human rights centre might be able to undertake, for example, in applied research or providing a specialist human rights information service. A human rights centre could also play a role in national and regional training and education activities, network building and institutional support. There are already a number of organisations in Australia and elsewhere involved in such activities and the Government is supporting the strengthening of infrastructures directly and, indirectly through a range of initiatives, both in Australia and in other countries in the region.

In the current fiscal climate the Government is unable to commit itself to a significant, long-term budget commitment to develop a human rights centre. Moreover, as many of the activities proposed are domestic in focus, the Government believes that were funding available to establish a human rights centre, it should be from sources other than Official Development Assistance (ODA). Alternative funding arrangements could allow also for greater operational autonomy.

An initiative of the Government's announced earlier this year in the Government's Justice Statement is the establishment of a National Human Rights and Discrimination Law Centre. The Centre will specialise in discrimination and human rights issues and aims to increase access to legal advice, advocacy, representation and support for a wide range of clients. The Centre's clients will include children, women, older people, clients from racial, ethnic, or religious minorities, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander clients, lesbians and gay men, people with disabilities, prisoners and people with mental illness. Tenders have been called for the establishment of the Centre and applications closed mid-November 1995.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the human rights fund of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade should be boosted in order to allow Australia to have greater influence in the human rights field by assisting NGOs and individuals in other countries directly.

SPEECH.PARA: Accept in principle

The Government sees the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade Human Rights Fund as important in promoting the observance of human rights overseas. The objective of the Human Rights Fund is to provide assistance directly to organisations, preferably Non-Governmental Organisations in other countries, involved in the promotion and protection of human rights. Unfortunately, in an environment of across-the-board restraint in expenditure, we have not been able to increase the size of the Fund this financial year and for 1995/96 it will remain at $ 1 00,000. The Government will review the situation for the next financial year.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Government establish an inquiry into:

PARA.TAB: the desirability of developing a Bill of Rights for Australia
the means by which such a Bill should be introduced-by statute or by referendum and change of the Constitution; and
the nature of the rights which should be encompassed by an Australian Bill of Rights. A minority of the Committee dissented from this recommendation.

SPEECH.PARA: Agree that the question of an Australian Bill of Rights should be kept under review.
