SPEECH.PARA: A number of services have also been developed specifically for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people living in rural and remote areas. Examples of these services are:

PARA.TAB: Multi-functional Aboriginal Children's Services (MACS) established in recognition of the need for specialised and culturally appropriate services for indigenous children. MACS provide a range of child care services for children, such as long day care, playgroups, outside school hours care and cultural enrichment programs. Other services, such as homework assistance, may also be provided as part of an integrated development program for indigenous children. Of the 37 MACS, 28 are located in rural and remote areas.

Outside school hours care, enrichment programs and playgroups, cater for the development needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children in culturally appropriate ways. Assistance also may be provided in the areas of homework, nutrition and health education programs and special activities.

Aboriginal and Islander Child Care Agencies (AICCAs) which are involved with the placement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children and related family welfare matters. The agencies are located in both urban and rural and remote areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the National Child Care Strategy 1992-96 for Innovative Service Delivery there is a commitment to use a percentage of places in each State for innovative services which best meet the needs of clients. These would include services in country areas which might not be large enough to support single-purpose services.
Under the cost sharing arrangements the Commonwealth and State Government are developing a range of proposals to meet these needs.

To improve further the supply of flexible child care, the 1995 Budget announced that 500 centre-based places from the New Growth Strategy have been converted to innovative community-managed places for remote areas. These services will be in addition to a number of innovative services which currently exist and will be located in areas of greatest need. The Government will work with local communities to develop the most flexible and appropriate services for their needs.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government monitor closely reports of torture and summary or arbitrary execution of children and subsequently make strong representations to those governments who are breaching international standards on the rights of children.

SPEECH.PARA: Accept

The Government will monitor closely reports of torture and summary or arbitrary execution of children and, in keeping with its overall human rights policy, make representations to governments in breach of their international obligations.
It is Government policy to follow up all allegations of human rights violations against children and, where these are substantiated, to make representations to the responsible authorities.

Violations of children's human rights are of serious concern to the Government which is active in monitoring the situation of children in vulnerable situations, including those caught up in armed conflict, those affected by exploitative labour or slavery-like practices and street children. Australia is also particularly active in monitoring the use of the death penalty, making representations on all individual cases brought to our attention and in urging States to abolish the death penalty, especially in those States where it is applied to minors.

Australian officials are participating in the work of two open-ended UN working groups elaborating possible optional protocols to the Convention on the Rights of the Child, one relating to the sexual exploitation of children and the other to children in armed conflict. These additional instruments will strengthen the international legal regime for the protection of children. Australia supports the work of the United Nations, its subsidiary bodies and specialised agencies in their efforts to protect children and improve implementation of the legal safeguards for the children's rights.

Australia also takes an active role in the drafting of the Optional Protocol to the Convention against Torture and other Forms of Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment. The Optional Protocol would provide for visits by a United Nations Sub-Committee of the Committee against Torture to places of detention within the jurisdiction of a State party.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government propose an initiative at the UN to ensure the development of an international treaty to address the question of child exploitation.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation is under consideration.

The Government set up the Tripartite Working Party on Labour Standards. Its recommendations will be considered carefully as a contribution to the development of Government policy in this area. The possibility of such an international instrument is part of current thinking on possible additional responses to the problem of exploitative child labour.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in its submission to the Working Party outlined as an option the development of an Optional Protocol to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child dealing specifically with trade in the products of exploitative child labour. The development of an Optional Protocol would greatly raise the profile of the problem of exploitative child labour and, if adopted, would strengthen existing international standards. Such an initiative would, however, be a long-term undertaking involving an extensive diplomatic campaign.
A number of international instruments addressing the question of child exploitation are already in existence.
The United Nations adopted the Convention on the Rights of the Child on 20 November 1989. This Convention has been ratified by 175 countries, including Australia (on 17 December 1990).

States that ratify this Convention must, inter alia, protect the child from economic exploitation and from performing any work that is likely to interfere with his or her education or be harmful to his or her health or well-being. Article 32 of the Convention deals with the economic exploitation of children, including child labour. Measures taken by States to implement Article 32, however, are to have regard to the relevant provisions of other international instruments.

The ILO has been concerned with the issue of child labour since its inception in 1919. In 1973 the ILO consolidated previous conventions on the subject into a revised convention, Convention 138, the Minimum Age Convention, 1973. Only 46 of the ILO's 175 member States have ratified the Convention.

Australia has not ratified Convention 138. The Inter-governmental Task Force established in 1991 to review unratified ILO Conventions and an independent expert have examined in detail the ratification prospects for the Convention. Both enquiries identified significant compliance problems for Australia concerning the Convention.

Australia's non-ratification of Convention 138 has been due to the different approaches adopted to prohibiting work for children below 15 years of age by the Convention, which is highly prescriptive, and by Australian legislation, which provides for compulsory school attendance and child welfare protection. Convention 138 requires legislation fixing the minimum age of not less than 15 years for entry into employment or work. While the Convention allows some exclusions on matters such as artistic performances or light work, the conditions under which these are permissible are quite strict. The Convention deals only with minimum age, and does not recognise that child labour encompasses a wide range of activities, not all of which are considered harmful or exploitative. By contrast, UNICEF has developed a set of criteria to assist in determining when work done by children becomes exploitative.

The Government is concerned that a Convention on such an important issue has only been ratified by some 46 countries. The ILO, however, is actively promoting observance of the Convention as part of its wider promotion of human rights labour standards in line with the outcomes of the World Summit for Social Development held in Copenhagen in March 1995 to promote respect for basic human rights as embodied in relevant ILO Conventions (including Convention 138).

As part of its follow-up action to the World Summit, the ILO is currently seeking information on the difficulties and obstacles to ratification from those countries which have not ratified Convention 138 and other core human rights conventions. This information will be consolidated into a report for consideration by the ILO Governing Body in November 1995. The ILO Governing Body will also be holding a discussion in its employment committee on a report on child labour prepared by the International Labour Office.

These ILO activities will provide an opportunity to consider what further action might be possible in terms of either ensuring greater observance or ratification of Convention 138 or whether other options should be pursued. One possible option would be to revise Convention 138. A revised Convention which establishes effective and workable standards and which can be widely ratified would underline the ILO's authority in this field and provide direction for its technical assistance activities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the rights of children be placed prominently on the agenda of the Foreign Minister during his overseas visits.

SPEECH.PARA: Accept
Wherever possible and whenever appropriate, violations of children's rights will be put on the agenda of the Foreign Minister and other Ministers or officials during their overseas visits.

Both the Foreign Minister and the Trade Minister have been briefed on children's rights matters for their overseas visits and this will continue. Exploitative child labour, in particular, is one matter which has been covered in visits and meetings by Ministers, both overseas and in Australia. This is a matter which will continue to demand attention.
Recommendation 46

PARA.EMPHASIS: [i]appropriate legislation be enacted to ensure that goods made in prison under conditions of forced labour are prohibited entry into Australia;

SPEECH.PARA: [ii]Australia initiate, through the UN and as necessary and appropriate in the future, the World Trade Organisation (WTO) a campaign to introduce international standards of minimum age and minimum conditions of work for the employed.
This recommendation is under consideration.

Australia considers forced prison labour to be a serious abuse of human rights. Forced prison labour is also a violation of a core ILO labour standard-freedom from forced or compulsory labour. It is important to distinguish between forced prison labour and work done by prisoners under conditions which comply with the relevant international standards.

The Tripartite Working Party on Labour Standards which the Government established to explore ways in which Australia could better promote core labour standards in the region, is currently considering the possible use of legislation aimed at addressing trade in the products of forced prison labour.

The Working Party will look at several legislative options, including an import ban and a point-of-sale ban. In order to ensure that any proposed measure is effective and workable, previous Australian legislation addressing prison labour goods as well as legislation in place in countries such as the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand will be assessed.

The Working Party will take into account a wide range of factors that could impinge on the effectiveness of legislative measures, including identification and verification mechanisms, enforcement mechanisms and GATT obligations. The Working Party is also exploring approaches such as bilateral agreements with specific countries, cooperation between Australian and other Customs services and consumer/industry-driven practices such as product labelling and information campaigns. These could be used to complement, or as alternatives to, legislation.
The Working Party will report to Government later this year.
Accept in part

Australia has already begun to raise the profile of labour standards issues within the UN system, is an active member of the ILO, and is engaged in regional and bilateral dialogue and projects aimed at protecting and promoting core labour standards. Australia's efforts in this area involve the Government, unions and industry reflecting our belief that a tripartite approach to the problem is the most effective way of achieving concrete results.

The promotion and protection of core labour standards is an integral part of Australia's human rights diplomacy. Within the UN system, the ILO is the key organisation responsible for protecting and promoting core labour standards. The Australian Government strongly supports its role in elaborating, promoting and monitoring international standards as well as its educational, information and technical assistance activities designed to enable countries to implement those standards. The Government considers that the ILO's capacity to monitor standards, identify abuses and ensure better compliance needs to be strengthened and will continue to work towards this end.

Elsewhere in the UN system, the Government will continue to support, and where appropriate promote, action on labour standards within the human rights machinery (eg, the Commission on Human Rights and its subsidiary bodies), working groups and special rapporteurs (eg, those working on contemporary forms of slavery) and the UN specialised agencies and funds (eg, UNICEF).

As well as working to introduce international standards, the Government is concerned that they are effectively implemented. The realisation of core labour standards is an important development goal and the aid program will seek further appropriate opportunities to protect and promote those standards through bilateral, regional and international programs eg, the Australian Support for ILO Objectives in Asia Project (ASILO), the Project to Support the Development of Departments of Labour in the Pacific (PACLAB) and the ILO's International Program on the Elimination of Child Labour (IPEC).

As outlined in the response to Recommendation 19 above, the Government has reservations about labour standards being raised in the WTO. The issue of whether there are enough trade related interests to warrant further discussion of trade and labour standards in the WTO has been raised by the United States and some European countries. The Government stands ready to contribute to such discussion in the WTO, but remains concerned that any links between labour standards and trade rules and obligations are not used for protectionist purposes, and do not create a North-South divide in the international trading system.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chapter Eleven-The Rights of Asylum Seekers

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 47

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Government review its current policy for the detention of refugees and asylum seekers.

SPEECH.PARA: Do not accept

The wording of this recommendation raises an issue of definition which needs to be clarified before the substance of the recommendation is addressed. The matter that needs clarification is the use of the word "refugee". The Government does not detain refugees, ie, those who have sought Australia's protection and have been granted a protection visa. It is assumed that the Committee's reference to "refugees" is a reference to unauthorised boat people or asylum claimants in general. The use of the term "refugee" in this context is misleading as it assumes that all boat arrivals/asylum claimants are in fact refugees in terms of the 1951 Convention and the 1967 Protocol relating to the status of refugees. Australia does not recognise its asylum claimants, whether or not they arrive by boat, as refugees until their claims under the Convention have been heard and accepted. Once a person's claims are accepted he or she is granted a protection visa and is no longer detained.

In general, asylum seekers who have entered Australia with a visa and are immigration cleared on arrival are not detained. The bridging visa mechanism allows claimants who become unlawful non-citizens to remain at liberty while their claims are assessed. There will be exceptions where an assessment is made that the claimant will not abide by conditions imposed on their bridging visa (such as regular reporting to the department) or where a claimant has already breached conditions of the bridging visa granted. Decisions to refuse a bridging visa are merits reviewable by the Immigration Review Tribunal.

It has been a long-standing policy of the Government, that unauthorised arrivals usually be detained, irrespective of whether they are asylum claimants. That current policy has been reviewed recently and the Government does not consider that a further specific review is called for. On 27 May 1993, the Senate passed a resolution requesting that the Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Migration (the Committee) conduct an inquiry into immigration detention practices in Australia. The inquiry occurred over a 9 month period and included consultations with community and government representatives. It visited various immigration detention, and reception and processing centres around Australia and held discussions with staff and detainees at those centres.

The Committee's report, Asylum, Border Control and Detention, was tabled in Parliament on 2 March 1994. In this report the Committee supported the broad thrust of Australia's existing immigration detention policy, but recommended that modifications be introduced to guard against prolonged detention of asylum seekers.

The Committee emphasised that Australia must retain its sovereign right to determine who may enter, the conditions under which a non-citizen's entry may be permitted, and the circumstances under which a non-citizen may be permitted to stay or may be removed from Australia. The Committee determined that Australia's system of immigration control, which supports Australia's important migration program, must be upheld.
During the inquiry the Committee considered a number of options presented to it for the release into the community of asylum seekers. In reaching their recommendations the Committee took account of:

PARA.TAB: the evidence that among those persons who reside in the community while their refugee claims are determined, a significant percentage disappear into the community when they are refused permission to remain in Australia;
the reluctance of community groups to become involved in any policing arrangements for ensuring that persons released into the community would not abscond; and
the difficulties associated with providing adequate support arrangements if unauthorised border arrivals were released into the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee also listened to various complaints and criticisms about the immigration detention centres and sought responses from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Australian Protective Service (APS) in relation to those complaints. The Committee found that the Department and APS were sensitive to the criticisms and were able to point to a range of improvements which had been made. In March 1992, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) prepared a draft report detailing the findings of visits made to the Darwin Detention Centre and the Port Hedland Immigration Reception and Processing Centre by the Acting Secretary of HREOC in August and December 1991, following representations which had been made to HREOC. This report, considered by the Committee, confirmed that most issues relating to conditions within detention centres are readily addressed and the most serious problem faced by detainees was the length of time they were likely to be held in detention awaiting determination of their refugee status.

While the Committee considered that the Government cannot be held responsible for prolonged detention where people pursue the administrative and legal options available to them, it was also concerned that there be a capacity to consider release. In this regard provisions are now in place for release on compassionate grounds, including age (both for children where it is in the child's best interests and for the elderly), ill health and previous experience of torture and trauma. The Government's response to the Committee's Report also stated that it will implement the recommendation to give the Minister for Immigration the discretionary power to enable the release of those who claim refugee status where they have been detained for more than six months from receipt of their application without a primary decision. Migration Legislation Bill No. 5 contained an amendment to effect this purpose and was passed by the Parliament on 31 August 1995.

A detailed response to the Committee's report was tabled in Parliament on 22 September 1994. The evidence in the Committee's Report and the Government's response, which provides agreement to implement the majority of the proposals advanced by the Committee, demonstrates not only that the Government has acted with probity in dealing with unauthorised arrivals, but that it continues to explore means by which such people can be dealt with in a more humane way.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee urges the Australian Government to recommend that the UNHCR conduct an investigation into the allegations of organised international traffic in illegal departures with a view to getting international agreement on the means to prohibit or limit such practices.

SPEECH.PARA: Accept in part.

The Government accepts that the organised international traffic in illegal departures is an increasing problem worldwide. Australia currently participates in a variety of international fora dealing with migrant trafficking with a view to developing strategies for overcoming this problem. These have included:

PARA.TAB: The Regional Consultations on Illegal Migration which were held in Canberra on 11 and 12 April 1994. These were an Australian initiative aimed at encouraging better cooperation and coordination in the dissemination of information on illegal migration (including migrant trafficking) throughout the Asia Pacific region. Australia is encouraging the continuation of the consultations in the belief that such a forum would provide the vehicle for dealing with migrant trafficking in the region.

The International Organisation for Migration (IOM) eleventh seminar on migration, held in October 1994, was on the issue of the International Response to Trafficking in Migrants and the Safeguarding of Migrant Rights and was chaired by the Deputy Secretary DIEA. The three day meeting enabled representatives from countries of origin, transit and destination to meet and discuss the problem and appropriate responses. The seminar participants called on IOM to act as a catalyst to advance international and policy dialogue on migrant trafficking by helping to forge and consolidate the necessary alliances between countries, intergovernmental and non governmental organisations and other key actors. To this end a Working Group on Migrant Trafficking was established.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has also been active in support of measures aimed at combating migrant trafficking in various United Nations organs and agencies, including the General Assembly, the Commission on Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice and the International Maritime Organisation (IMO), by co-sponsoring and supporting the following resolutions:

PARA.TAB: the IMO resolution "Enhancement of Safety of Life at Sea by the Prevention and Suppression of Unsafe Practices Associated with Migrant Trafficking by Ships". This resolution which was adopted on 4 November 1993, addressed both safety and humanitarian issues;

the UN Commission on Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice's third session in May 1994 adopted a resolution on "Criminal Justice Action to Combat the Organised Smuggling of Illegal Migrants Across National Boundaries". The resolution draws out the links between organised crime and migrant trafficking, condemns the practice and urges states to cooperate in undertaking effective and expeditious measures to prevent and punish this activity;

the UN General Assembly adopted a resolution on "Prevention of Migrant Trafficking" on 19 November 1993, which is largely concerned with the criminal aspects of migrant trafficking. The resolution condemned the practice of migrant trafficking as a violation of international and national law and as an activity conducted without regard for the safety, well being and human rights of the migrants concerned. States were urged to cooperate and take steps to frustrate this activity, including reporting to the General Assembly on measures taken to combat migrant trafficking.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government accepts the Committee's recommendation that an investigation into the allegations of organised international traffic in illegal departures should be conducted with a view to getting international agreement on the means to prohibit or limit such practices. However, the Government does not accept that the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) is the appropriate body to carry out this investigation.

UNHCR's mandate is to protect refugees and seek durable solutions to their problems. The UNHCR's main concern is that government's actions to manage irregular migratory flows do not jeopardise the institution of asylum and the principle of non-refoulement for refugees. The Government considers that the focus of the UNHCR on these vital issues should not be jeopardised by other programs such as that proposed, given that there are other organisations to address these issues.

The IOM has undertaken research on migrant trafficking and provided a forum for international and regional discussions on the issue. IOM would be a more appropriate body to undertake the proposed investigation and has advanced itself as a catalyst in this area.

TAB.EMPHASIS: [i] in the eventuality of the Tibetan Women's Association being denied accreditation to the World Conference on Women in Beijing in 1995, the Australian delegation to that conference be briefed fully on issues of specific concern to Tibetan women, with a view to ensuring that those issues are raised at the conference: and

PARA.TAB: [ii] the Australian Government keep Mr James Peng's case under close review and keep making representations to Chinese authorities until such time as Mr Peng is given a fair trial and legal representation of his own choice.

SPEECH.PARA: Accept in part

The Australian Government consistently supported the right of all women, including Tibetan women, to participate in the UN Fourth World Conference on Women and the associated Non-Governmental Forum `95. In the preparatory process leading to the Beijing Conference, Australia strongly supported accreditation procedures that were transparent and fair.

Prior to the Beijing Conference on Women, Australia made enquiries to the United Nations seeking clarification of the Tibetan Women's Association's accreditation (TWA) to the Conference on behalf of the TWA. However, the Secretary General of the Fourth World Conference on Women, Mrs Gertrude Mongella advised that the TWA did not meet UN accreditation guidelines and thus would not be able to participate at the intergovernmental level. Mrs Mongella advised, however, that it would be acceptable for the TWA to attend the NGO Forum.

As soon as the Government was alerted that the President of the TWA and eleven other Tibetan women in India registered to attend the NGO Forum had been refused visas to enter China, we made representations to the Chinese authorities in Beijing and Canberra to request them to issue visas for all NGOs registered to attend the Conference, including those from the TWA. As well, Australia made representations to the United Nations to emphasise the importance we placed on the resolution of this problem. Unfortunately, despite our best efforts, China did not issue visas to members of the TWA in India and the NGO Forum had to proceed without their valuable input.

A number of Australian NGO representatives, including two Tibetan Australians, also encountered difficulties in obtaining visas to attend the NGO Forum. In addition to official representations to the Chinese authorities, Senator Gareth Evans wrote directly to the Chinese Ambassador in Canberra seeking his urgent assistance in issuing the required visas. As a result of these interventions, all outstanding visas for Australian delegates to the NGO For-um in Beijing were issued, enabling full Australian representation at the meeting. The Tibetan women at the NGO Forum did raise issues of concern to Tibetan women.
Accept

The Australian Government has, from the outset, carefully monitored the case of Mr James Peng and has taken every appropriate opportunity to make known to the Chinese authorities its concerns regarding aspects of the handling of Mr Peng's case.

Mr Peng's trial opened in the Shenzhen Intermediate People's Court on 16 November 1994. The Court rose after seven hours of hearings without delivering a verdict. Mr Peng saw his lawyers on a number of occasions before they defended him in court on 16 November. The Australian Government made representations (see below) to the Chinese authorities that Mr Peng be allowed unimpeded access to legal counsel and that his case be handled in accordance with due process under Chinese law and that Mr Peng not be denied rights to which he was entitled under that law.

Mr Peng's lawyers represented him on 28 September 1995 during the announcement of the verdict by the Shenzhen Intermediate People's Court. The Court found Mr Peng guilty on charges of embezzlement, sentencing him to a total of 18 years of imprisonment, sixteen of which would be enforced imprisonment, with supplementary deportation. The Australian Ambassador and our Consul in Guangzhou attended the trial as observers, in line with the Government's consular obligations and concerns for an Australian citizen. Mr Peng has the right to lodge an appeal on this verdict with the Guangzhou Higher People's Court.

The Australian Government has made over a hundred individual representations to the Chinese Government to date, of which some thirty have been ministerial-level representations at senior levels of the Chinese Government, including the Prime Minister, Deputy Prime Minister Howe, Senator Evans, Senator McMullan, Senator Bolkus, Senator Cook, Mr Lee, Mr Martin, Mr Bilney, Mr Crean, the Secretary and other senior officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

Representations by Senator Evans have included a number of senior Chinese officials, National People's Congress Chairman Qiao Shi, Vice-Premier Zou Jiahua, State Councillor Li Tieying and Vice-Foreign Minister Liu Huaqiu. He has also raised Mr Peng's case on a number of occasions with Foreign Minister Qian Qichen. In a meeting with Vice-Premier and Foreign Minister Qian Qichen in New York on 28 September, Senator Evans appealed for clemency in Mr Peng's case. Senator Evans emphasised Mr Peng's detention of nearly two years, the state of his health, and the fact that he had a young family and urged that Mr Peng be released as soon as possible. Senator Evans again raised this case with Minister Qian at the APEC Ministerial Meeting in Osaka on 16 November 1995.
The Prime Minister raised Australia's concerns about the case with Chinese President Jiang Zemin in the margins of the APEC Leaders' Meeting in Osaka on 18 November 1995.

An officer from the Australian Consulate-General in Guangzhou also has made regular consular visits to Mr Peng and has actively pursued health, Welfare and access matters with the relevant authorities in Guangzhou and Shenzhen. The twenty second consular visit took place on 6 October 1995.
The Australian Government will continue to monitor closely the handling of Mr Peng's case and, as appropriate, make representations to the Chinese Government on his behalf.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government
continue to make representations to the Vietnam Government asking it to allow an
early visit by an Australian Parliamentary delegation to foster a dialogue between the
two Governments on a range of issues, including human rights; and
closely monitor allegations of religious discrimination in Vietnam and bring all
necessary pressure to bear on the Vietnamese Government to allow complete freedom of

SPEECH.PARA: Agree: implemented

The Australian Parliamentary Consultative Delegation visited Vietnam 5-12 April 1995. The delegation had good access to a wide range of senior officials, usually at the Vice Minister level, and was successful in opening effective dialogue on wide-ranging issues, including human rights. Beyond official contact, the delegation was also able to discuss matters of interest with religious leaders, the diplomatic, legal and business communities, representatives of international agencies, intellectuals and ordinary Vietnamese. The delegation also raised cases of individuals in detention and made representations for their release and well-being.

The report of the Australian Parliamentary Consultative Delegation, Australia-Vietnam Dialogue: the Currents of Change, was tabled on 11 May this year in both Houses of Parliament. In its report the delegation deals with such issues as the Vietnamese legal system; freedom of expression; freedom of religion; the circumstances of dissidents; capital punishment; rights of women; rights of the child; economic, social and cultural rights, including labour rights; minority rights; prison conditions; disabled soldiers; and the situation of returned asylum seekers.
Accept

The Australian Government continues to monitor the human rights situation in Vietnam and allegations of religious discrimination. It also encourages the Vietnamese Government, whenever the opportunity arises, to allow its citizens the right to freedom of expression, peaceful assembly, association and religion. It also raises specific human rights cases of concern such as the detention of Professor Doan Viet Hoat, Dr Nguyen Dan Que and the Secretary-General of the Unified Vietnam Buddhist Church (UVBC), the Venerable Thich Quang Do.

The Government made representations to the Vietnamese Government about the sentencing of The Venerable Thich Quang Do and five other members of the UVBC on 15 September for incidents relating to their attempts in November 1994 to distribute flood relief to the Mekong Delta outside official channels.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, expressed the Government's concerns about the sentences in a statement issued on 22 August 1995. The Prime Minister raised the issue of religious freedom with the General Secretary of the Vietnamese Communist Party, Mr Do Muoi, on 31 July 1995.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government seek the release of the Kuwaiti
prisoners held in Iraq and the identification of those deceased through every avenue

SPEECH.PARA: Accept

The present whereabouts and release of Kuwaiti and other nationals still detained in Iraq are the subject of two UN Security Council Resolutions: 686 (paras. 2(c) and 3(c)) adopted 2 March 1991, which governed the cessation of hostilities; and 687 (paras. 30 and 3 1), the so-called "Ceasefire Resolution", adopted on 3 April 1991, and which outlined the framework for future international relations with Iraq.

Both resolutions commit Iraq to releasing unconditionally all such detainees and calls on Iraq to cooperate with the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) to facilitate the compilation of lists of such detainees, access to detainees and assistance in locating nationals still unaccounted for. The resolutions specifically include the location and identification of human remains.

Australia's commitment to the comprehensive application of the UN Security Council Resolutions on Iraq remains undiminished. Australia believes there can be no loosening of the sanctions regime until Iraq complies with all relevant UN Security Council Resolutions, including the above-mentioned provisions in UN Security Council Resolutions 686 and 687 mentioned above. Australia continues to press the Iraqi Government, both multilaterally and bilaterally, to abide by all Security Council Resolutions and has, on numerous occasions, called publicly for the repatriation of Kuwaiti and other persons still detained in Iraq.
The Committee recommends that.-

PARA.EMPHASIS: the Australian Government use the forums of the General Assembly of the UN to
publicise the human rights abuses in the Sudan, specifically highlighting the revival of
[ii]the relevant Australian diplomatic post be asked to report, as a matter of urgency, on
the human rights situation in the Sudan, particularly regarding the allegations about the
revival of slavery in that country; and
[iii]independent organisations, such as Amnesty International, be encouraged to continue to scrutinise and report on the human rights situation in the Sudan.

SPEECH.PARA: Accept
The Government, in its statement to the Third Committee of the UN General Assembly on 25 November 1994, expressed its concern about human rights abuses in the Sudan in the following terms:

"Australia believes that the seriousness of the human rights violations in the Sudan demands intensive monitoring. We regret that the government of Sudan has not permitted the Commission's Special Rapporteur on the human rights situation to visit the country in order to carry out his mandate.

We are particularly concerned at continuing reports of harassment, intimidation, detention and torture of the Government's opponents and of forced displacement and relocation of people in various parts of the country.
Despite severe criticism levelled at the government of Sudan—by the international community about its human rights record, it continues to evade its human rights

responsibilities. Australia calls on the Government of Sudan to abide by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights to which it is a party, to observe and protect the human rights and fundamental freedoms of all Sudanese people, and to negotiate a solution to the civil conflict."

Australia does not have resident diplomatic representation in the Sudan. Accreditation is from the Australian Embassy in Cairo, from where the Australian Ambassador and other staff make periodic visits to the Sudan. After each such visit a report is provided to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Canberra. Human rights issues usually figure prominently in these reports.
This is an issue for Non-Governmental Organisations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government make representations to the Kenyan Government asking it to:

SPEECH.PARA: bring an end to human rights abuses in Kenya, including physical and psychological torture, detention without trial and state-sanctioned tribal fighting;
restore the rights of assembly and freedom of expression under Kenyan law;
treat all Kenyans equally before the law, regardless of ethnic background, and outlaw discrimination by any individual or body against any Kenyan on the basis of ethnic background; and
improve physical standards inside Kenyan prisons, including medical care facilities, so that they accord with international standards and Kenyan law.
Accept

Incidents of human rights abuses in Kenya continue to be of concern to the Government. The Government continues to monitor the human rights situation in Kenya and to make representations to the Government of Kenya, through its High Commission in Nairobi, on incidents of human rights abuses which come to its attention.

[i]the Australian Government make representations to the Indonesian Government seeking to have the implementation of the Anti Subversion Law reviewed by an independent body such as Indonesia's Human Rights Commission or the International Commission of Jurists (ICJ); and

[ii]the Australian Government continue to monitor the situation of Xanana Gusmao closely and to urge Indonesian authorities to release him from custody to enable effective dialogue and negotiation on achieving a peaceful settlement to all those issues which relate to the East Timorese.
Accept

The Government has made representations about the use of the Anti Subversion Law to the Indonesian Government over many years. The Government notes that this law has been used less frequently in the last few years and hopes that this trend will continue and that the law may be repealed at an early opportunity. The Government would welcome a review of the implementation of the Anti Subversion Law by the Indonesian Government or, for instance, by a body such as Indonesia's Human Rights Commission. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, has made this point in meetings with relevant Indonesian Ministers such as Attorney General Singgih.

The Government agrees with the recommendation on Xanana Gusmao. It continues to closely monitor Xanana Gusmao's situation through the Australian Embassy in Jakarta. The Government welcomed the reduction in Xanana's sentence from life to 20 years and has said that his early release would be a positive step towards reconciliation in East Timor.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee supports the Executive Council of Australian Jewry's (ECAJ) call and urges the Australian Government to continue its condemnation of "Holocaust denial", which the European Parliament has identified as a feature of contemporary European racism.

SPEECH.PARA: Accept

The Australian Government continues to condemn the thesis which denies the existence or extent of the Holocaust committed by the Nazis during World War Two. The Government will continue to guard against this aspect of contemporary European racism gaining adherence in Australia.
[i]the Australian Government use diplomatic channels to check with Russian authorities on the situation of Mr Semyon Livshits, currently in detention in Vladivostok

[ii]the Australian Government use diplomatic channels to get an up to date assessment of the human rights situation of Syrian Jews and, if necessary, make representations to the Syrian Government on their behalf; and

[iii]the UN Human Rights Commissioner monitor the human rights situation inside Iran, with particular reference to any restrictions on religious freedom in that country, especially regarding the Baha'is.
Accept

The Australian Government has formally raised the case of Mr Livshits on several occasions (the most recent being 6 October 1995) since his imprisonment and has regularly expressed its concern to the relevant Russian authorities in the context of discussions on human rights matters. In addition, the Australian Embassy in Moscow has provided advice and assistance to Australian individuals and organisations making private representations. Mr Livshits' sentence was reduced following an appeal hearing in late August 1995, and he is now due to be released in July 1996.
The reduction in his sentence appears to have been due, in part, to representations by Australia and other countries. The Australian Government will continue to follow Mr Livshits' case closely.
Accept

The vast bulk of Syrian Jews have been permitted to leave the country over the last few years. We understand that at present there are only about 230 Jews left in Syria. While we maintain an interest in their situation, representations to the Syrian Government concerning Syrian Jews are no longer considered necessary.
Accept
The Iranian authorities have, since 1991, refused to cooperate with the UN Commission on Human Rights (CHR) Special Representative, Mr Galindo Pohl.

The Australian Government fully supports the Commission on Human Rights in its activities in relation to Iran. Australia continues to press, at ministerial and other levels, for the Iranian authorities to adopt a non-confrontational approach in discussing human rights and to renew its dialogue and cooperation with the UN CHR.

In his scrutiny of the human rights situation in Iran, the UN CHR Special Representative continues to monitor and highlight the difficulties faced by religious minorities, with special attention in recent years to Baha'is and Christians.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee suggests that the Australian Government make representations to the Governments of Greece, Macedonia, Bulgaria and Albania concerning the rights of minorities within their states, to freedom of speech and association, rights to use their own language, practice their own religion, preserve their culture and rights to full participation in educational and employment opportunities within the state.

SPEECH.PARA: Accept in principle

The Government will continue to monitor human rights issues in these countries and to make representations as appropriate. Since the period covered by the Committee's report, the Government has made specific representations on the rights of minorities, to the governments of Greece and Albania. While inter ethnic tensions between the various communities remain of concern, there are some positive signs that the respective governments are making efforts to address these issues. The Australian Government will continue to encourage them further in this regard.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee urges the Australian Government, through agencies such as the International Committee of the Red Cross and the Red Crescent or the Commonwealth Human Rights Unit in London, to encourage the Turkish Government to trace the missing Greek Cypriots and provide information to their relatives on their fate.

SPEECH.PARA: Accept
The Government has drawn the attention of the ICRC, the Commonwealth HRU and the relevant UN agency to the Committee's recommendation, and to the plight of all missing persons in Cyprus.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee believes the situation in Kosovo requires urgent attention from the international community, both in identifying human rights abuses and in seeking negotiations between the government of Serbia and the representatives of the majority of the people of Kosovo. The Australian Government should urge the European Union and the United Nations towards these processes.

SPEECH.PARA: Accept

The human rights situation in Kosovo is a specific and long-standing area of concern. It pre-dates the conflict in former Yugoslavia and is expected to continue to be a major concern in the foreseeable future, notwithstanding recent progress towards a negotiated settlement to the armed conflict.

The JSCFADT will hold a hearing in late October on the Australian response to the situation in the former Yugoslavia, including ethnic cleansing. This will provide a forum for consideration of broader human rights concerns in all the territories of the former Yugoslavia.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee, while noting with real concern the claims of terrorism and human rights abuse, urges the Australian Government to monitor the circumstances of the Kurdish people closely, in particular to monitor the trials of the Kurdish representatives who have been expelled from the Turkish Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Accept

The Australian Embassy in Ankara has been closely monitoring the situation of the Kurdish minority in Turkey, as well as the cases of the expelled Kurdish parliamentarians, and will continue to do so.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee asks the Australian Government to make representations to the Government of Sudan concerning the treatment of the people of southern Sudan and to urge the United Nations to provide monitors in the Sudan, to maintain an effective ceasefire and to encourage either the resumption of negotiations on a peaceful settlement to the civil war or to encourage the United Nations to held a referendum on the status of the south and in the interim to place an arms embargo on the Sudan.

SPEECH.PARA: Accept

The response to Recommendation 52 is relevant. The Government continues to make representations to the Government of Sudan through both bilateral channels and multilateral forums regarding the continuing human rights abuses in Sudan. Our Ambassador in Cairo, who is accredited to Khartoum, maintains a dialogue on this important issue with the Sudanese Government on his regular visits to Sudan.

In November 1994, the Australian Government delivered a statement to the Third Committee of the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA 49) in New York calling on the Government of Sudan to abide by its international human rights obligations and to negotiate a solution to the civil conflict.

Australia also co-sponsored the resolution on the human rights situation in Sudan at UNGA in 1994. This resolution urged all parties to the conflict to agree to an immediate cease fire and called on the Government of Sudan to cease immediately all aerial attacks on civilian targets in Southern Sudan.

At present the Government of Sudan does not allow entry into the country of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights Special Rapporteur on the Human Rights situation in Sudan, Mr Gaspar Biro. The resolution passed at UNGA 49 called on the Government of Sudan to extend its cooperation to the Special Rapporteur and recommended the continued monitoring of the human rights situation in Sudan.

Australia supported a similarly worded resolution at the 51st session of the UN Commission on Human Rights in March 1995. At a meeting in January 1995, the heads of government of the member countries of the Inter Governmental Authority on Drought and Development, which sponsors the current peace negotiations, agreed to the placement of a United Nations observer in Nairobi to monitor the peace initiative.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee believes that, in relation to East Timor, if there is to be any prospect of peace, there should be an enduring and just resolution of the Dili massacre—the release of political prisoners and those detained as a consequence of peaceful demonstration, devolution of appropriate powers to the province and the reduction of the combat military forces.

SPEECH.PARA: Agree

The Government agrees with the thrust of this recommendation. The Dili massacre is, of course, symptomatic of wider concerns in relation to Indonesia's approach to East Timor. The Government regards the Indonesian Government's response to the Dili massacre as credible, including in its setting up of a National Commission of Inquiry and a Military Honour Council which led to the gaoling of a number of military personnel involved in the Dili killings. The response, however, had some shortcomings. In particular, the Government has continued to make clear to the Indonesian Government its concern about the discrepancies which remain in accounting for those reported missing after the Dili Killings.

The Government continues to make frequent representations to the Indonesian Government expressing its concerns in respect of East Timorese detainees. The Government has urged the Indonesian Government to accord all detainees due legal process, and requested that they not be ill-treated and that the ICRC continue to be allowed regular access to all detainees. The Government takes a particular interest in cases where it appears that a person has been detained for exercising his or her right to peaceful protest.

The Prime Minister has raised the situation in East Timor with President Suharto on a number of occasions, most recently, in Bali on 17 September 1995. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, also has been long urging on the Indonesian authorities the desirability of their talking frankly and directly to people of different opinions within East Timor, including the armed resistance, about longer term reconciliation strategies for the province. The Government believes such strategies should include a major reduction in the military presence, greater involvement of the East Timorese in the province's economy, further recognition of the distinctive cultural identity of the East Timorese and some measure of political autonomy. Senator Evans reiterated these points publicly after his meeting with the Indonesian Foreign Minister at the ASEAN Post-Ministerial Conference in early August this year.

The Australian Government welcomed the holding in June this year of intra-East Timorese talks facilitated by the UN Secretary General and the continuation in July of the dialogue between Indonesia and Portugal on the issue of East Timor, also held under the UN Secretary-General's auspices.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee believes that, in relation to Bougainville, despite the failure of the peace conference, there should be no return to violence and both parties should maintain the ceasefire. The Committee hopes that the peace process can be resumed as soon as possible and in particular, that both parties will accept the movement of people within the island so that humanitarian assistance might be freely distributed to all Bougainvilleans. Finally, the Committee urges that the PNG Government and the PNG Defence Forces should continue to give assurances that, in any reconvening of the peace talks, free passage for the leaders of the Bougainville Revolutionary Army (BRA) be guaranteed and, possibly, that talks should be held on neutral ground.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes the generally positive nature of developments toward peace which have occurred since the staging of the Bougainville Peace Conference in October 1994, and the accompanying improvements in the human rights situation.

Under the `Charter of Mirigini for a New Bougainville', signed in November 1994, a broadly representative Bougainville Transitional Government was sworn into office in April 1995, and immediately commenced discussions with the PNG Government on the political, economic and administrative future of Bougainville. On 18 May the PNG Government and Bougainville Transitional Government announced a series of agreements under the `Waigani Communique', the most significant of which was the announcement of an amnesty for all crimes committed either "on Bougainville or in relation to the Bougainville crisis" during the period I October 1988 to 19 May 1995. The amnesty will apply to the security forces as well as the Bougainville Revolutionary Army (BRA) and resistance (civilian militias opposed to the BRA). The Waigani Communique also mandates the Transitional Government to develop its preferred model for the political, economic and administrative/restoration framework of the province for national government consideration. The Australian Government recently announced a further $10 million in humanitarian assistance to Bougainville to help facilitate the restoration process (bringing total allocated assistance to $23 million).

Since the Peace Conference and until recently the incidence of armed activity has been low, barring some notable and persistent attacks by hardline BRA groups. There was an increase in the reported armed activity on the island in August 1995. Such action risks undermining the reconciliation process. The BRA leadership has refused to participate in peace negotiations with the PNG and Transitional governments, refused to accept three seats held for it in the Transitional Government and rejected the amnesty offer. Should the BRA leadership declare its willingness to enter into the dialogue and negotiation process, assurances for safe passage would obviously need to be confirmed by the PNG Government with the BRA leaders concerned.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Burns, I present additional information received by the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee following the 1995-96 budget estimates hearings.
—I present the 19th report of 1995 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 18 1995, dated 29 November 1995.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Calvert, I present the following reports of the Joint Committee on Public Works: No. 27 of 1995, Construction of 20 apartments for Australian High Commission staff, Kuala Lumpur, and No. 28 of 1995, Construction of 10 apartments for Consulate-General staff, Shanghai. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to those reports.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the tabling speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President the two reports I have tabled involve accommodation projects proposed by the Overseas Property Group. The committee's 27th report for 1995 relates to the construction of accommodation for Australian High Commission staff in Kuala Lumpur Malaysia.
The estimated cost of the Kuala Lumpur proposal when referred to the committee was $11.345 million at May 1995 prices

Kuala Lumpur is fast becoming a city where most expatriates can no longer afford to live in free-standing houses as opposed to apartments/town houses. The sustained demand for properties in Kuala Lumpur has made the cost of leasing residential accommodation expensive.

A significant proportion of the Australian-owned residential estate in Kuala Lumpur is nearing the end of its economic life or has proved unsatisfactory for the post's property requirements. Commercial and residential rent escalation has reached 8% plus per annum and the Overseas Property Group expects that at least for the life of this project, rents will continue to escalate, particularly within the immediate areas surrounding the central business district and in proximity to the High Commission.

The economic and life cycle costing analysis of options provided to the committee by Overseas Property Group clearly indicated that constructing a mix of apartments and townhouses on owned sites, selling unsuitable owned accommodation and relinquishing undesirable leases, is the most advantageous and economic course of action in Kuala Lumpur.

The Kuala Lumpur proposal referred to the committee involved the construction of a three storey complex of 10 apartments at 9/11 Jalan Taman U Thant and construction of another 10 unit development on a site to be identified. A swimming pool, recreation room and multi-purpose room will be provided as part of each complex. At the public hearing the Overseas Property Group advised that a decision has been made to develop 4 Jalan Taman U Thant and investigations have shown that it is only possible to fit eight townhouses on the site. However, the Overseas Property Group has advised that this will still provide a viable project.

The committee notes an assurance from the Overseas Property Group that it will continue consultations with the Post Property committee during detailed design development. While there was general support for the Kuala Lumpur project from the staff at the High Commission, the Community Public Sector Union and Foreign Service Family Association, there was some concern expressed regarding the extent of the development at 4 Jalan Taman U Thant and also some details of the design of both buildings. As the site at 4 Jalan Taman U Thant was not confirmed until shortly before the public hearing, it is inevitable there is some confusion in relation to the details of the development on that site. The committee has recommended that the Overseas Property Group consult with the staff at the High Commission, the Community and Public Sector Union and the Family Service Foreign Association during the detailed design phase to resolve outstanding issues.
Mr President the committee's 28th report for 1995 relates to the construction in Shanghai, People's Republic of China of a five-storey building of 10 apartments.
The estimate cost of the Shanghai proposal when referred to the committee was $10.529 million at May 1995 prices.

The rapid growth of the Chinese economy in recent years has meant that the Shanghai property market has grown at a feverish pace. The financial pressures on the Shanghai economy are unlikely to abate within the next three to five years. Rents are expected to continue to increase at an estimated rate of 10% p.a. Residential accommodation of a suitable standard and size will continue to be scarce and command premium prices in sought after areas.

Rents are currently in the order of $A19,000 per month and have a fixed escalation clause of 10% p.a for the two year leases. There are currently 10 Australia-based staff in Shanghai with staff numbers likely to increase in the longer term.

On the basis of short supply and rapidly rising costs, the Overseas Property Group in late 1993 examined its property strategy in Shanghai including options of ownership. Early evaluations indicated a simple pay back period for a development option in the designated consular district was less than six years. The Canadian Government has indicated an interest in either renting or meeting the capital cost of two of the apartments. The Overseas Property Group advised that negotiations on this matter are continuing.

The 10 apartments in Shanghai will be constructed as a single building of five storeys incorporating two apartments per floor. An indoor swimming pool and a combined recreational room will be provided in a separate recreation facility. Basement car parking and storage areas will be provided under an all weather tennis court which is elevated one metre above natural ground level.

Apartments have been designed in accordance with the design brief, taking account of local building regulations, climatic conditions, the surrounding built environment and the need for privacy, amenity and security for the occupants. Account has also been taken of the recommendations and requirements of the Consulate-General, which has been consulted in the development of the proposal.

In agreeing to the project proceeding the committee has recommended that the Overseas Property Group continue consultations with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, staff of the Consulate-General and the Community and Public Sector Union regarding possible changes to the design of the project which will allow for better utilisation of the site.

The committee accepts that many Australians at overseas posts would prefer not to live in compounds. But there is a basic dilemma if we wish to continue adequate Australian representation in many areas where we cannot afford the ever increasing rental costs. So it's a case of building apartments such as outlined in my reports or drastically reducing Australian-based staff.
Mr President I commend the reports to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of the Senate, I provide three advices provided by the Clerk of the Senate on parliamentary privilege and the Western Australian royal commission into the use of executive power.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Schacht) proposed:
That intervening business be postponed until after government business order of the day relating to the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1995-96 and two associated bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to debate this motion because we were given a program this morning that we were going to work by. That program—
—Why just waste time?

—I am not wasting time. I am going to say what I want to say on this matter. We had agreed that we would do some of the appropriation bills to fill in between 12.45 to 2 o'clock if we had finished the four non-controversial bills. We were on taxation this morning and I had arranged with senators on this side to speak on that. The non-controversial bills took up all the time so we did not start on the appropriation bills.

PARA.TAB: We were under that impression until question time, at which time I received a note from Senator Short that had been sent from the PLO, requesting that we go on to the appropriation bills. We are happy and ready to do that but the point is this: for the sake of orderly operation in the Senate, we would like to know what we are doing. Our speakers were ready to finish the tax bill. Now we have had to turn around and change the order with very little notice.

Also, I do not like being told that we knew about this arrangement. I did not know about it until question time. We are ready to go but I make the point that this is not an orderly way to run the business of this Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard Senator Panizza's remarks and there are a couple of corrections I wish to make. The opposition did know about the arrangement. There was a discussion at the whips meeting. The appropriation bills were not in at that stage. I made a statement to the effect that on receipt of the appropriation bills we would make room to bring those bills on in the Senate.
—Not necessarily today though.

—You are making that judgment for me. That was the decision at the whips meeting. I checked with the Democrats to see if that was what was said and clearly it was. We intended to move to the appropriation bills at lunchtime but we were doing the non-controversial bills and ran out of time. We are proposing to go to the appropriation bills, as suggested at the whips meeting and as was agreed to by most people at that meeting.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will agree to the reordering of business. The business is a shambles. I think everyone will understand that. There has been little attempt at management on the part of the government. I thought it just extraordinary yesterday, with the Senate debating the government's social security bills, that, without any notice at all, the government brought along a whole lot of amendments to its own bill and expected them to be voted upon. Bills that have arisen out of the budget in May are now being presented for the first time—and the government expects the parliament to be fulfilling a function of scrutiny and review. It really has turned into a farcical situation. Nevertheless, it is your program. If you want it in this order, then we will accommodate your request.
—It was agreed to at the whips' meeting, I might add.
—That does not surprise me because we are very cooperative and accommodating in this regard.
—That is the most extraordinary statement.

—I would not have thought you would doubt that, Senator Schacht. In this session of parliament we have been bending over backwards to facilitate your program. If you were to have shown just a touch of management skill, you would have found yourselves a lot further advanced than you are to date. But ministers basically have been disinterested in the program. They do not turn up; they do not care; there is no effort to use the committee system of the parliament effectively. Then they get frustrated at the end of the session and ask, `Why haven't we got our legislation through?'

PARA.TAB: But in relation to these appropriation bills, there is a matter that arises that is the background, in effect, to changes that were made in the House of Representatives. We would like to have the position clarified, and Senator Schacht may well be able to do so. We understood that the government had made the decision to withdraw from its appropriation funding for the litigation that was designed to close down the commission—that is, the unsuccessful litigation that the government sought to support with taxpayers' money.

I think last night there was a sigh of relief from the Australian taxpayer that the government had finally realised that using the courts for party political purposes should be paid for by the party rather than by the taxpayer. Yet it seems that Senator Gareth Evans today—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is actually a speech about the appropriations.

—No, you have changed the appropriations between yesterday and today, and we would like to know what is going on. Senator Gareth Evans apparently, before lunch today, said that it was still the government's intention that the taxpayer should pick up the tab for this extra $ 1/4 million or so that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) decided that the taxpayer should pay to fund, through Carmen Lawrence, the attempt to close down the Western Australian royal commission. What we want to know is: is this just a technique to avoid, in this parliamentary session, the parliament addressing this—

—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The motion before us is to reorder the business. Senator Hill is now clearly raising issues about the content of the appropriation bill itself. I thought he would quite legitimately raise these and other questions on the appropriation bill in the debate that would take place upon this motion being carried. As the list of speakers is quite extensive and includes five from the coalition, I would have thought there would be plenty of opportunities for those questions to be put. And, of course, the minister responds at the end of the debate on questions raised. So, on the point of order, I think we should put the motion and get on with the debate. It will be then that those issues which have been raised by Senator Hill can be discussed.

—My impression is that Senator Hill is attempting to clarify exactly what is coming before the Senate under the reordering of the program. He has not fully developed that argument. But that is my understanding of what he is doing.

—The minister could simply tell me what Senator Gareth Evans said when he said in relation to the attempt to take the quarter of a million dollars out of this bill, `We will take it on again next year when parliament resumes.' Is the government really attempting to split the appropriation bills so that when we come back again we will find there is an appropriation bill No. 5 that deals with this quarter of a million dollars? If it is going to do that, we might as well have the debate on the extra quarter of a million in the course of this debate rather than next year. Or is the government planning an ex gratia payment in an attempt to avoid parliamentary objection to the payment of taxpayers' money in this area?

PARA.TAB: As we are about to address these bills, I think some clarification of what the government is planning is warranted because, as I said, there is no doubt that taxpayers are angered at the prospect of having to pay the bill for a party political objection that was instituted by the Prime Minister in an attempt to protect Minister Lawrence in the lead-up to the federal election, matters that have nothing whatsoever to do with her ministerial office as federal Minister for Health but rather to protect her reputation in the lead-up to the election.

Of course it is history that the royal commissioner found that she had lied; it is history that she refused to resign as she should have; it is history that the Prime Minister demonstrated a lack of national leadership in not standing her down. But what is still current is the question of who is going to pick up the tab. Does this government still expect the Australian taxpayer to pay for this party political exercise, this exercise in which you sought to close down the royal commission and, as a matter of interest, in which an order for costs was made against Minister Lawrence and the other parties?

We are talking about not only another quarter of a million dollars but likely double that. If there is another half a million to come, when is it going to come and why is it not going to be included within this bill? Why did Minister Beazley last night in effect mislead the Australian people by suggesting that no longer were they expected to pick up the ALP's bill? Why can't these matters be clarified before we start this debate? It seems to me a most appropriate time to do it at this time of reordering the program to facilitate your appropriations. Senator Schacht seems to have passed the baton to Senator Faulkner. He presumably has the answers to these questions and we wish to be enlightened in that regard.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a rather poor, but I must say rather typical, performance from Senator Hill, the same senator that earlier in the week asked the government whether he could seek leave—which the government indicated it would agree to—to make a statement in this chamber about the Senate sitting on Friday. The opposition had an ideological objection to the Senate sitting on Friday.

PARA.TAB: You have to understand that Senator Hill is under a great deal of pressure at the moment and he missed the boat. Senator Hill failed to come in and make the rousing leadership speech to shore up his flagging numbers in the Liberal Party Senate room. So we have it today on a procedural motion in relation to bringing the appropriation bills before the Senate, I might say on a matter that had been discussed between the whips and on which notice had been given to all parties, including minor parties and independent senators in this chamber.What we have at the moment is a brilliantly managed Senate, and you know it. I think it is for possibly the first time in the living memory of this Senate, and I have to say this is a pretty doddery old joint and living memory is a pretty long time around here.

For this the final sitting week of a session, possibly even the final sitting week of the parliament, we made it very clear to everyone in this chamber what the routine of business would be. Over the miserable objections of the opposition we sat at 12.30 pm, the same as the House of Representatives, on Monday and Tuesday.

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't object to that at all.

—You did. Over the miserable objections of the opposition we decided to adjourn later than usual on Monday and Thursday nights. We are not dealing with government business on Thursday. We are adjourning the sitting of the Senate on Thursday, continuing on Friday and adjourning the Senate for this session at 3.45 pm Friday.

PARA.TAB: Normally at this time of the session, as Senator Hill knows full well, there is a great deal of manoeuvring and carrying on with the opposition trying to understand what is happening, trying to keep up with the government's legislative program, trying to keep up with the parliament, and we went out of his depth. But I have tried to make it easier for him. I have tried to make it easier for Senator Hill.

You have to go a long way to help Senator Hill, but we really have. We have laid it all out so that even Senator Hill can understand because Senator Hill is very busy at the moment. The old knives are sharpening over on the other side of the chamber with the power plays for a Liberal ministry. Senator Alston is out there. Senator Hill, you should not be in the chamber now talking about this, disrupting, wasting time, filibustering, doing what you normally do. You should be out on the telephone because that is what Senator Alston is doing, I can tell you. He is out on the telephone undermining you.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: we are always amused to see Senator Faulkner try to demonstrate his oratorical skills but, with the greatest respect, this is totally and utterly irrelevant to the motion on hand and I suggest you direct him to address the motion in question.
—I am sure the minister is about to conclude his remarks so he can get on with business.

—As a matter of fact I am. All senators in this chamber have an understanding of what the government wants to achieve in terms of its legislative program, when the Senate will sit this week in terms of hours and routine of business and when we will bring on the appropriation bills. That has been made clear to all and, with the miserable exception of yourself, Senator Hill, has been accepted by everyone in this chamber. It is not my intention, and it has never been my intention, Senator Hill, to breach faith with those that we come to these arrangements with, including yourself.

PARA.TAB: On this side of the chamber our word is our bond. If you give a commitment that you will bring on the appropriation bills, you do it; you bring the bills on. You honour the commitments you make. This is pretty unusual for this mob over there out sharpening the old knives, ready to plunge them right between your shoulder-blades, Senator Hill. That is why this motion has been moved, that is why the government is bringing the appropriation bills on, because we made a commitment to do so.

In the spirit of the way I try to manage the government business program in this place—always with you, Senator Hill, involving yourself in the usual negative, carping, disruptive manner that you do—if the opposition had put to me, the whip or the deputy whip in the chamber that it would like to see the tax package concluded, we could have spoken with other senators and then brought on the appropriation bills. That could have been organised without this effort at disruption, filibustering and wasting the time of the Senate which is, and has been, your stock in trade ever since you have been the leader. No wonder Senator Alston wants to pull the plug on you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I am normally restrained, I cannot resist a response to that speech. I am almost tempted to pay the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) a few dollars for it. It was the best comedy performance I have heard for quite awhile.
—Any donations, gratefully received, will go straight to the marginal seats campaign.

—And probably into the save Carmen campaign. Senator Faulkner said that his handling of the business of the Senate had been brilliant. I will tell you what you have been brilliant on: you have been the most brilliant disaster as a manager of government business in the 10 years that I have been a senator. I have had the misfortune to see a few pretty crook managers of government business, but you take the cake.

PARA.TAB: I want to add support to the very serious point Senator Hill—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the only support he has got.

—He has overwhelming and unanimous support on this side of the chamber. I am not sure about you lot. Senator Hill raised a very serious point. We have not been given an explanation why the order of business is being changed. Senator Hill was looking for a reasonable explanation why the change had been made.
—It was interesting that Senator Faulkner didn't refer to it at all.

—He did not refer to it at all. He did not have an answer. Senator Jones, the government whip, a very reasonable senator and a man of integrity, is here. He might be able to explain why the change has occurred. It is an extremely odd way of doing business.

PARA.TAB: I am not sure that we have the bills. I have not seen the bills that went through the House of Representatives last night. They may have been circulated. I am not aware of it. We are asked to bring forward into today's business bills which have not formally been distributed. If they have, you might correct me.

We are told that they contain the amendment that was sought in the House of Representatives by the coalition, namely, to reduce the appropriation in Appropriation Bill (No. 4) by approximately $250,000, to take account of the expenses for Carmen Lawrence in her challenge to the existence and validity of the royal commission in Western Australia.
