I have not seen that.

Like Senator Hill, I was very concerned to read the transcript of Senator Evans's doorstop interview today in which he said that the government would continue to pursue that matter; so the taxpayers of Australia would still be required, if the government had its way, to foot the bill for those expenses which were expenses of a purely party political nature. The government knows full well that was the reason for their inclusion in the appropriations.

There are several questions to be asked about that quarter of a million dollars, including whether the remaining funds contain coverage of the payment to Dr Lawrence of the costs awarded against her in her challenge to the Western Australian royal commission. There are a lot of questions to be asked. You are asking us to debate these bills and pass them not only without having had an explanation but also, what is worse, without having seen the bills. They are reasonable reasons why we question that and seek a clear explanation for this change in the procedure and the order of business.

It is not that you are bringing the appropriation bills forward; as of this morning, they were not on the Notice Paper. We had started debate on the very important tax bills. To meet the government's suggested timetable, we were prepared to debate those bills. Now that debate is pulled off. Without any explanation, we were asked to start debating the appropriation bills during the period from one o'clock to two o'clock today. I could not get an explanation for that, until after the event. It is a shambles the way the Senate is being run under Senator Faulkner and the government at this stage.

They are the reasons why we are concerned. We are looking for a clear and simple explanation for the change. We are prepared to debate them now, but the Carmen Lawrence payment factor is a significant factor, particularly when you take account of the very worrying remarks of Senator Evans today that the government will try this on again when parliament resumes next year.

I fully support Senator Hill. He asked some very appropriate questions. Regrettably, no-one on the government side at this stage seems able to give a rational answer. That is typical of this government. It is a matter of concern if we are seriously being asked to handle very important parliamentary business in a responsible and managed way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly want to raise a further concern about the government's change in program. It is always a concern when the Labor Party changes the order of business as listed. In the past we always left debate on the appropriation bills until answers to questions raised at estimates committee hearings had been received. We do that because a lot of the questions asked at estimate committees are very penetrating questions. When ministers have political difficulties in answering questions they get out of it by saying, `We don't have the officer here. We don't have the information here. We will take it on notice.' That is code for saying, `That is a politically difficult question for us. We cannot answer off the cuff. We want to go away and give the most politically neutral answer we can.'

PARA.TAB: There is every expectation that we will not come back after Friday. The Labor Party, in typical fashion, is avoiding answering some of the very penetrating questions and politically damaging questions to this government that were asked in estimates over the last couple of weeks. We will now be in a position where those questions, which exposed this government's weaknesses, will not be answered by the government. They will not be answered by the deadlines set by some of the committees, and parliament will not be in a position to demand answers because parliament will not sit again. It means that yet again the Labor Party will have weaseled out of providing the information that the public needs to fully assess the Labor Party's mismanagement of this country and its economy.

I have that concern that these arrangements are being put at risk and that will mean that the parliament will not get the answers it deserves from the executive government. If the parliament sits again next year, which the government is pretending might happen, one wonders why this legislation could not be dealt with then. It would give the parliament some opportunity of ensuring answers were given.

I share the concern mentioned by my colleague about what Mr Beazley and Senator Evans meant when they talked about revisiting Carmen Lawrence's fees. Everybody knows that Dr Lawrence has been a big embarrassment and has caused a great deal of concern to the government because of the extent of her fees that she was trying to get the taxpayers to pay to her, not for the inquiry but to try to shut the inquiry down so that the truth could not be found. Dr Lawrence chose that course of action, expecting the taxpayers would pay for it, in typical Labor Party fashion.

Because of the stance taken by the Liberal and National parties, that did not happen. The government backed off. It is this vacillating on whether it would go ahead that has sent some alarm bells ringing. Perhaps the Labor Party is again up to its old tricks of saying one thing to take the heat off and then after the event doing the exact opposite. The taxpayers of Australia, whom we want to protect, do not want that.

Finally, I just want to make a comment about the management of the program. Senator Faulkner, the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, would have to be the worst manager of any type—whether of government business or of the Labor Party headquarters at Sussex Street or of anything else—that I think we have seen for a long time in Australia.

The program has been continuously out of order. In the last period since Senator Faulkner has been in charge, there has not been any order or rhyme or reason about it whatsoever. Senator Faulkner manages this government business in this chamber in the same way as he manages his portfolio: everything is done on the run. It is done without sufficient thought; it is done without sufficient planning; it has no management principles in it whatsoever. I give the Labor Party a piece of advice: when you get where you will be after the next election, please get a new manager of opposition business in the Senate, which is what the Labor Party will need to manage whatever business they might have when they are in opposition. The way the country has been run is the way this chamber has been run.

I understand that Senator Faulkner and the frontbench of the Labor Party are continually distracted—distracted by infighting within their own party, infighting over people like Mr Graeme Campbell: `Will we sack him; won't we? How much support has Mr Campbell got? What do the members want to happen? What does Mr Snow want to happen? What does Mr Fitzgibbon want to happen?' There are threats of large-scale votes against the decisions of an arrogant Prime Minister, even within the Labor Party.

For the last 12 months at least, the Labor Party has been distracted on this infighting. You have problems with the Carmen Lawrence legal fees on whether or not they should be paid. I know, as you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, that a great number of decent Labor Party parliamentarians did not want a bar of paying taxpayers' money for those fees for Mrs Lawrence. It has taken an enormous number of caucus meetings, cabinet meetings, little huddles in the corner and little factions forming amongst the factions of the Labor Party as they try to desperately manage the problems within their own party.

As I say, Keating accuses state Labor people of setting out to get Mrs Lawrence over what has happened in Western Australia. This is not Liberal people; this is just state Labor Party people themselves, whom I think Mr Keating called the `friends of Burke'. You have all this internal Labor Party fighting time and time again. It is a continuous thing. It takes up an enormous amount of time of the caucus, of the cabinet, and on it goes. That is why the program is in the sort of mess that it is in.

The Labor Party have not been able to solve their internal differences, have not been able to work out who should have been Deputy Prime Minister, whether it was Mr Beazley or Senator Gareth Evans—it could not be Senator Evans, of course, because his colleagues in the Senate stabbed him in the back at the time when he was overseas. They called the deputy leadership meeting when Senator Evans was overseas. He did not even get a chance to throw his name into the ring. Everybody knew that Senator Evans's reason for going to the lower house was so that he could be Deputy Prime Minister. When Mr Keating leaves after his defeat at the election, Senator Evans wanted to be the Leader of the Opposition, but he was not given the chance. Senator Schacht, Senator Ray and all of Senator Evans's friends here brought the meeting on while Senator Evans was overseas. It is that bitterness and rivalry that is continuously there that is the cause for the mismanagement of business in this chamber.

I regret that the chamber has been delayed again by the way this motion has gone. Senator Faulkner says that he is interested in getting the program going and then he comes in here and makes the most specious speech, which not even he understood—certainly he did not believe it. In all of the bluff and bluster and theatrics he went on with, he was laughing all the time. There was no seriousness in it whatsoever, and it was just meant to waste a few more hours. And he talks about managing the business properly. So they are the concerns that I have.

We will continue to keep the Carmen Lawrence fees under scrutiny to make sure that the Labor Party does not weasel out on the commitment it has given. As well, we will use every opportunity at our disposal to ensure that the questions which remain unanswered following the estimates committee process are answered before the election comes on, so that the people of Australia can make informed decisions on just how bad this government has been for the management of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President—
—I hope this is better than your last contribution.

—We have been sitting here waiting for you to give a responsible answer. You do not have a clue about how you manage your government business in this place, and you show the normal contempt and disregard for the Senate that has become the hallmark of you and your colleagues over there.

PARA.TAB: Appropriation bills Nos 3 and 4 plus the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1995-96—the three appropriation bills which are called the additional appropriation bills—were introduced into the parliament on 26 October. Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1995-96 authorises the Minister for Finance to issue $836 million from the consolidated revenue fund in addition to funds appropriated by the Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1995-96 for the annual services of government; whereas Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1995-96 authorises the release of additional funds for proposed capital works and services and payments to the states and territories—most of which were first allocated funds under the Appropriation Act (No. 2) 1995-96.

In debating these bills, and presumably passing them today or tomorrow, the coalition has—despite the ramblings of the government members opposite—in fact worked overtime to try to cooperate with the government in putting some semblance of order into its legislative program. The equivalent bills last year were, in fact, not passed until the end of March 1995 so, in cooperating with the government in this exercise, we are bringing forward the passage of the bills by something like four months compared with the situation last year.

That poses some difficult problems for us. What it means is that there are still a large number of outstanding answers to questions that were posed by coalition senators during the Senate estimates hearings over the last few weeks. So it is regrettable that the additional appropriations are being passed without answers to those questions having been received.I do urge the government to respond to the cooperative approach that we have adopted on this side to the passage of these bills by providing answers to those questions which are still outstanding. The bills add another, in gross terms, $1.4 billion to the government's expenditure this financial year. In net terms, when it is offset by savings in some other areas, the increase is going to be of the order of $1 billion.

Therefore, it is almost certain that the so-called budget surplus that the government trumpeted so loudly in May of this year in the budget statement—and that was a figure of $718 million alleged surplus—is not going to be fulfilled and indeed what we are going to see is yet another budget deficit which could, depending on the outcome of the assets sales program, be as high as $3 billion or more this financial year. The government is talking about the sale of the remaining 50 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank. That I would have thought is an extremely unlikely call to be achievable this financial year—in the course of the next six or seven months.
Senator O'Chee interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator O'Chee points out, it is just a few short days or weeks ago that the government was saying that nothing would happen until after the election. Indeed in the budget itself of May of last year it was said quite clearly that the remaining 50 per cent would be sold in two tranches—one this year and the second tranche in 1997-98. So here again—and we are talking about huge sums of money involving the Commonwealth and Australian taxpayers and the sale of some major assets—we have every indication of a government in continuing disarray in terms of attempting to manage its program, be it assets sales, be it the handling of legislation here in the Senate, be it virtually anything that the government tackles.

PARA.TAB: Because of its tiredness, because of its divisiveness, because of its sheer incompetence, it is unable to give a clear sense of direction to the Australian public and the investing community on any grounds at all. (Quorum formed) There is additional spending by the government of a net $1 billion contained in these bills. There is a likely shortfall in assets sales proceeds and there is talk that the government has been putting around in the last few days about proposing to sell the whole of the remaining 50 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank between now and 30 June next year. That is contrary to everything the government has been saying before, and therefore makes you doubt that in the extreme. So you have to discount that.

Then there is the shortfall in the Qantas sale and the government's inability to sell ANL. There has been a complete reversal in terms of its approach to the sale of the AIDC. Only seven months ago it was going to sell the remaining 80 per cent of the shares in the AIDC that are publicly owned. Now it is going to turn around and buy back the 20 per cent that was out in private hands. That is a turnaround in the budget figures of something like $180 million to $200 million. When you look at all of those things you see that the so-called surplus, which we always knew was a spurious surplus, of something like $700 million, published in the May budget, is going to turn out to be a very significant deficit, which could be as high as $3 billion or more.

That is going to put inevitably increased pressure on interest rates. That is one of the reasons, no doubt, why the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Fraser, said yesterday that there was unlikely to be scope for any interest rate reduction in the foreseeable future. That is why the further national dissavings by the Commonwealth government is making it harder and harder for the private sector for investment purposes. At a time when the government bleats about the need for increased national savings, it is putting its hand in the cookie jar of national savings and drawing on those national savings because it is unable to manage its own economic performance and its own finances.

So we have another budget out-turn this year which is going to be absolutely contrary to the needs of the Australian community, and that is seen very widely. It has been commented on just in the last few days by such leading figures as the chief executive of the ANZ bank, Don Mercer, and by many others, including most of the leading business organisations and associations in Australia.

The economic consequences of these additional appropriation bills, coming on top of the other economic policy failures of the government, are simply going to compound the problems that have befallen and beset this nation as a result of the government's failure, as I say, to manage its own finances and its failure to take the tough decisions, particularly in the area of industrial relations, that are necessary if we are going to move the Australian economy off of the plateau that it is now on.

The economy has been on this plateau for many years under this government, whereby you get a burst of growth and, because of the failure of the government to undertake the necessary structural changes in the Australian economy, we have to put on the brakes again to prevent inflation going through the roof, to prevent the balance of payments blowing out to even greater proportions than the crisis proportions we already have and whereby policies, as I say, run down rather than increase the level of national savings.

We have had a lot of debate in this place in the last few days, and we are going to have a lot more debate in the period ahead, about just what this government has done to taxation since the last election. Prior to the last election, the Prime Minister, in that infamous statement during his interview on the Lateline program with Kerry O'Brien, promised that the government would not increase the level of taxation in this country. He said that the level of taxation as a proportion of GDP—he subsequently interpreted it this way—would not be increased. That was gilding the lily compared with what he actually said on the Lateline program.

Even if you accept that subsequent reinterpretation and rewriting of what the Prime Minister actually said, he has still failed lamentably in this respect because at the time that he made that statement the level of taxes to GDP in Australia—that is, in 1992-93—was 22.2 per cent. This financial year, on the government's own figures, the level of taxation as a proportion of GDP will be 24.2 per cent. That is two percentage points of GDP higher than the government promised it would be. That is $10 billion higher. In other words, simply because of that percentage increase, let alone all the other tax rip-offs that have occurred, the government has taken an additional $10 billion out of taxpayers' pockets over and above what it had promised to do.

Worse still, the figures will deteriorate, on the government's own forward estimates, and will get worse over the next few years. That 22.4 per cent in 1995-96 will go out to 24.6 per cent in 1996-97 and it will stay around about that level until the end of the century. In other words, what the government is saying to us in those forward estimates—that is on existing programs, let alone anything else they might seek to do—that the tax burden will go up in this country. We have always known that that would happen because one of the fundamental differences between Labor governments and governments of Liberal-National Party persuasion is that Labor governments in comparison are big spenders and therefore have to be big taxers. So long as you have a Labor government in power you will have higher government spending than would otherwise be the case. Therefore, you must have higher taxation and all the other consequences that flow from that. You will have higher interest rates, lower levels of employment growth and higher levels of unemployment. The performance of the Australian economy over the last period of this Labor government has shown that par excellence.

Labor talks about big increases in employment in the last few years. That is an absolute nonsense. It is true that employment has grown in the last few years from the depths that it reached during the recession, but the fact is that there are no more people employed full time in Australia today than there were five years ago, despite the fact that the available work force over that period has increased by something like one million people.

The employment record of this government has been absolutely appalling. The unemployment record as a consequence has been equally appalling. We now have the terrifying situation where, in a period of what the government claims is good solid economic growth, we are seeing unemployment rise. We have had three successive monthly rises in unemployment. The rate is now 8.7 per cent. It is absolutely inevitable that under a continuation of the government's present policies that figure will, tragically, grow heavily in the new year. That applies to the long-term unemployed and the short-term unemployed—the whole lot of the unemployment pool. Long-term unemployment today is virtually unchanged on what it was a year ago.

There are some other aspects of the appropriation bills that I want to comment on specifically. Before this debate started we had that procedural debate on why we are debating the bills at this time. Both Senator Hill and me raised the concern about the alarm bells that seem to have been ringing as a result of Senator Evans's statement today during his doorstop interview. He commented on the payments by taxpayers of Carmen Lawrence's expenses in association with the Western Australian royal commission.

Last night in the House of Representatives the government bowed to the coalition's amendment to delete approximately $250,000 from the $800,000 that was contained in Appropriation Bill (No. 4) for the purposes of meeting her expenses. I am pleased to say that we have managed to force the government to reduce that $800,000 by $250,000, being the amount of taxpayers' money that was proposed to be spent on reimbursing Carmen Lawrence for her costs in mounting the challenges to the very validity of the royal commission. That was a party political stunt if ever there was one by the Labor Party. They were never prepared to accept the existence of the royal commission and its validity and they went hell-bent for purely political purposes to prevent the royal commission ever taking place.

There was no way that the coalition was ever going to be prepared to accept the reimbursement to Carmen Lawrence of those parts of her legal costs as a legitimate use of taxpayers' money. As a result, the amendment was made last night to the appropriation bill in the House of Representatives, which has now come into the Senate and which we are now debating—that is, Appropriation Bill (No. 4). Today in his doorstop Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: The government still remains firmly committed in principle to ensuring that she is paid out of public funds. We have made that clear, we haven't resiled from it. The trouble is we have a problem in the Senate. . . the time constraints that we are up against, we have decided simply to defer further consideration of the bit that the opposition won't agree with until next year.
He goes on to say:
We will take it on again next year when parliament resumes.

It is quite clear that the government has deleted this amount from the appropriation bills for purely opportunistic reasons associated with the mismanagement of its program. We will fight this government tooth and nail whenever it proposes to again attempt to seek taxpayers' money to fund that aspect of Carmen Lawrence's legal costs.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that there are two ministers' legal costs that are being met in these legal bills. One is Carmen Lawrence's. The other is the payment of $544,000 for the legal costs of Mr Alan Griffiths in connection with the notorious sandwich shop affair. There was an inquiry by Mr Michael Codd involving Mr Griffiths in that respect. Although the costs are included in the appropriation bills, they have never been identified as such. It was only simply by asking questions of the Attorney-General's Department that we have confirmed the sum and the purposes following press reports to that effect.

The other interesting aspect is that Mr Griffiths's legal cost payments are contained in Appropriation Bill (No. 3), whereas Carmen Lawrence's legal costs are contained in Appropriation Bill (No. 4). There has been no adequate explanation of the difference in treatment between the two. From my point of view, I cannot see the validity of the distinction between the two, given that it does have implications for the way in which the Senate can handle those matters.

Appropriation Bill (No. 4) also contains a payment of $32 million to New South Wales for the redevelopment of the Sydney showground site to facilitate the establishment of the Fox film studio and the development of a new showground at Homebush. Although the coalition is not opposing that measure, it is certainly not at all clear to me what this has to do with the federal government.

I conclude on the real point at issue here, that is, we have a government whose finances are out of control, which has had to go for major increases in additional expenditure, on top of the original budget appropriations which showed huge increases in their own right. As a result, this has necessitated huge additional tax rip-offs of the Australian people, which will lead to inevitable further hardship for Australians, who have suffered great damage under this government over the last dozen years. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like Senator Short, want to deal, if only briefly at this stage, with one of the phoney elements of this budget, that is, the extent to which the surplus has been massively padded and will not be achieved. Senator Short dealt with big ticket items. I point to the way this government has tried to milk its government business enterprises such as Telstra to pay huge dividends which they cannot afford and which are leading to financial problems within the organisations.

PARA.TAB: A multi-million dollar dividend was required by the government from Telstra. This was a record, by the way, and far higher than the percentage of profit normally paid by government business enterprises. The consequences are that it is paid out of profits that telephone users have to pay. The more profit and more dividend that the government squeezes out of Telstra, the more Telstra has to get from somewhere. And that somewhere is the Australian consumer—the ordinary Australian user of the phone services.

What is particularly dreadful about the way the government screwed extra multi-millions of dollars in dividends which should not have been paid out of Telstra was that Telstra knew at the time, and the government knew at the time, that Telstra would have a negative cash flow of half a billion dollars in the current financial year, according to its budget. In fact, we found out when the famous Blount memo was leaked to me a couple of weeks ago that this was going to blow out further, by another $1 billion—a $1,000 million negative cash flow in addition to the half a billion dollars negative cash flow that was in the budget. In other words, overall, Telstra was going to be $1,500 million short of cash, which might explain why some Telstra employees were complaining they were getting a pretty frosty reception from some hotels when they wanted to book in on business, because Telstra was not too prompt about paying their bills.

The reason we know about it is not because of any leaked document; it emerges from a speech that Mr Blount gave to senior Telstra employees which was televised around Australia on the very day that I was revealing the leaked document. This is what he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I must tell this year our budget is to be negative four hundred and eighty million dollars in cash flow. So this year we are going to have to borrow just to have . . . to make our payments. In other words, our cash coming in is going to not be—
this is his language, not mine—
up to enough money to pay our obligations going out by four-eighty in the budget.
In other words, $480 million. He went on:

Now, some of the senior management team members here know that of late we've been looking at forward looking estimates of that budget of cash and it is very troublesome because it looks like it's blowing out for an additional one billion dollars.
One billion, I didn't say one million.

That would make us be negative cash flow by one point five billion for the year. Obviously, we're not going to let that happen, so you're going to see a lot of effort to drive that cash back to something four-eighty to five hundred million, negative, which was our budget when we started this year and is our commitment.

I detail that because I want to underline the fact that the leaked memo from Mr Blount which I tabled in the Senate a couple of weeks ago was totally correct and is reinforced by what he told his senior staff.

PARA.TAB: The point in relation to this debate is that Telstra and the government knew it would not have the cash, that it would be behind by half a billion dollars in its cash flow. Despite that, the government demanded it pay its highest ever dividend and its highest ever proportion of profits in dividend to the government to help it out of a budget problem. In other words, this government will cheat, dodge and sneak around to, if you like, fudge the figures so that its budget looks better than it really is. Of course, as Senator Short said, its asset sales program is absolutely hopeless, so we cannot expect anything like this phoney budget surplus to be achieved.

I wanted to mention that in passing because there is another matter that I want to deal with at some length—the industrial relations situation. Next to financial mismanagement, the greatest area of disaster for this government has been its failure to make the reforms that are needed in industrial relations to make Australia competitive, so that we do not keep losing businesses overseas and we do not keep having Australian costs absurdly higher than costs in competitive countries. You may have noticed that whenever we raise the question of the Weipa dispute, the greater intellects of the government like Senator Cook continually say—

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you are joking.

—I am joking; I take your point, Senator Short, but he represents the level of thinking in this government, because he says, `This shows you what would happen under a Liberal government; that's what the Liberal industrial relations policy is all about.' The response, as everyone knows, is: how can that be? We are not in government. There are two Labor governments involved—the Queensland Labor government and the Keating Labor government. It has nothing to do with the Liberal Party or its policies.

PARA.TAB: What is clearly happening is that the Labor Party has made a mess of it. While the ACTU does not see it that way, and claims that CRA is to blame for the Weipa dispute—the Labor Party says it is the Liberals' fault; the ACTU says it is CRA's fault—according to the union movement, the real culprit is the Queensland branch of the AWU and, in particular, the Federal President of the AWU who is also the secretary of the Queensland branch, Mr Bill Ludwig. I am assured by my leak from the AWU that he is known affectionately by his comrades as `boof' or more formally as `comrade boofhead'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is this?
—This is Mr Bill Ludwig. I have here a letter that has been leaked to me which comes from Mr Bob Smith.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to Senator Baume's reference to a person not in this place as being known as `boof' or `comrade boofhead'. The point of order I raise is that if that is to be acceptable from Senator Baume and his grinning opposition colleagues, I hope they will practise the same tolerance whenever something is said by those on this side. Otherwise, would you rule that out of order?

—On the point of order: Senator Crowley well knows that those provisions in the standing orders only apply to members of this house, members of the other place, members of state houses of parliament and judicial officers. From his conduct, Mr Ludwig is certainly not a judicial officer. He may give orders to the cabinet, but he is not a member of parliament—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator O'Chee!

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

—I think you are now approaching compounding what I consider to be an error that your colleague Senator Baume may have made. However, it is not a point of order. I do not think you should use the provisions of the standing orders in order to compound what I consider to be an error made by your colleague. I am ruling that there is no point of order.
—Sorry, I did not quite understand what the ruling is. Should I withdraw it?
—No. There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am certain that Mr Ludwig has the opportunities through the structures to respond if he feels offended. I am simply quoting his colleagues; I am not attributing that name to him. But the letter from Mr Bob Smith, the Victorian Branch Secretary of the Australian Workers Union, to Mr Ludwig on 23 November says:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sir,
YOUR RESIGNATION AS A.W.U. NATIONAL PRESIDENT

Your gross incompetence as National President (and Queensland Branch Secretary) has resulted in the disastrous situation at Weipa, W.A., and elsewhere. The AWU has become a laughing stock under your "leadership".
The responsible course of action for you would be to announce your immediate resignation as National President, and give notice now of your retirement as Queensland Branch Secretary in 1997.

It is impossible for those of us who didn't know you in the 1970s or 1980s to judge whether or not you were a good union official. It's clear enough now, you are a broken-down joke. Preserve some pride from whatever your past achievements, and end our embarrassment, by resigning now!!!

The mess which is "Bill Ludwig's AWU" began with your gutless failure to take effective action in Western Australia and Victoria against your incompetent friends there and here. The industrial fiascos at Mount Isa and now Weipa highlight your inability to represent AWU members. No wonder you prefer to spend time in Washington while members here are out on the grass!!!
Well, Bill. You know that a majority of AWU officials (ex-FIMEE and ex-AWU) aren't prepared to put up with your domineering—
and I will censor myself—
bull——anymore. I am happy to table a motion for the next National Executive:

TAB.EMPHASIS: "That the AWU National Executive express no-confidence in the industrial and administrative ability of its National President, and calls on him to tender his immediate resignation."

SPEECH.PARA: Now we know who is to blame, according to the union movement, for the Weipa fiasco, for the Mount Isa fiasco and for all the industrial relations fiascos that the government is saying, `That is the Liberal Party's fault.' It is just unbelievable what the government's defence for the chaotic situation has become. Remember that this is the government which says, `We know all about industrial relations and we will continue to buy our way out of any kind of trouble.' It has not bought its way out of this one.

PARA.TAB: I believe that this parliament and the people of Australia are entitled to an unequivocal assurance from this government that it will not give in to ACTU demands that incompetently run unions like this one must be the vehicle, according to the ACTU, through which workers' arrangements with CRA and other employers should be forced to be channelled. Quite frankly, if you were a worker in an area that was under the `control' of the AWU, would you want these people—people described as incompetent, hopeless and embarrassing who made a laughing stock of the union—looking after your best interests?

The AWU, for example, covered the poor workers in Paul Keating's piggery. The workers in Mr Paul Keating's piggery were AWU protected. That is why they got sacked when they complained about having been given under-award wages for two years. They are still before the Industrial Relations Commission trying to get justice something like a year and a half after their disgraceful sacking. While Mr Keating was half-owner of this piggery, they were paid less than award wages. Would you want the AWU to look after you if you were working in that situation?

Naturally, the great bulk of people at Weipa want to come to their own arrangements, which are a better deal than what the AWU could get for them anyway. Australians are entitled to ask: why can't workers choose to make their own arrangements unfettered by the incompetent hands of this kind of self-serving union hierarchy?

The `broken down joke', according to the union itself, that is running this union is obviously not someone who contributes to the wellbeing of his union members. The point is made in the letter by Mr Bob Smith, the Victorian Branch Secretary, that Mr Ludwig's efforts at representing his members at Weipa have been managed—of course, they describe Brisbane as `far away' when they are in Weipa—from even further away: in Washington, USA. It is a pretty inadequate attempt at interaction with one union's membership to try to do something from Washington.

I should acknowledge that Mr Smith may be considered to have a bit of a grudge against Mr Ludwig because Mr Smith is still trying to clean up the Victorian branch of the AWU after its virtual destruction by Mr Ludwig's famous running mate in AWU ballots, Mr Bruce Wilson. I am also told by my friends in the AWU who are his comrades that Bruce Wilson is know as Bruce the Goose or Comrade Goose.

Anyway, he is now helping police with their inquiries in relation to the use of certain property, including a union car and a couple of flats, which apparently the AWU did not realise it owned. There is also the small matter, which I dealt with earlier in this chamber, of the $150,000 which had been socked away in a slush fund, unbeknown to the union's state and federal officers, and quite a lot of which had to be repaid to the Brisbane office of a national solicitors firm called Phillips Fox, which, I understand, refunded it to a major oil company which had planned, apparently, to resolve its union problems by contributing to some travel funds.

Mr Smith's views on Mr Ludwig are shared, apparently, by people like the ACTU President, Jennie George, who has been strongly critical of the AWU and its failure to maintain numbers, particularly in Queensland. The Australian and the Brisbane Courier-Mail recently noted that Ms George blames the lack of union presence in Weipa and the consequent rise in the power of CRA, with these direct negotiations, on the failure of Bill Ludwig adequately to represent his Queensland members over the proceeding two years.

It seems that Mr Ludwig has failed to retain his 350 AWU members in Weipa, despite the best efforts of the Industrial Relations Commission and the Queensland commission to ensure that the AWU is the preferred union on that site. Heaven knows why in so many places in Queensland the AWU has been determined to be the preferred union on site, unless it is, of course, that the Premier of Queensland has a lot of political debts to pay to Mr Ludwig.

Mr Ludwig senior has said that maybe it is about 28 members who are left in Weipa, instead of 350. But his son Mr Joseph Ludwig, who was hired by his father under the authority of a Queensland AWU branch executive motion—that motion said they had authority to appoint an Aboriginal trainee, although I do not think he fits that category—admits that the union has only four members left in Weipa.

Unkind officials of the AWU and the ACTU say that these four members have retained their membership of the unions only so that they could have the privilege of running against Mr Ludwig senior at the next official ballot, to be held in June 1997. Clearly, senior officials of the AWU and the ACTU are worried that the AWU membership in Queensland has collapsed under the leadership of Mr Ludwig senior and Mr Ludwig junior—the latter being appointed by Mr Ludwig senior to run the Weipa campaign leading up to and including his Washington sojourn for worker solidarity. I am sure, to be fair to Messrs Ludwig, that these people simply fail to understand the broad international obligations of the modern trade union official. They are much more important than looking after your members, particularly those who work in, say, Weipa or Mr Keating's piggery!

How many members Mr Ludwig really has is a serious question. It is somewhere between 71,000 and 80,000. It is 71,000 according to the Queensland Labor Minister for Industrial Relations, but a few weeks later it suddenly grew to 80,000, according to Mr Ludwig. If he has that recruitment record, I suppose he will get re-elected. But the fact is—and this is a serious point, despite all that jocularity—that here is a major union part of a major dispute involving what is the right process for industrial relations in Australia and it is, on the admission of its own members, disastrously run. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4), and I will speak to them in the reverse order. In one of the appropriation bills before us and under consideration today is the Lawrence legal costs. The stance of the Greens (WA) on this has been clear from the outset: there was no appropriateness in the executive assuring, through a cabinet decision, Dr Lawrence a blank cheque from the taxpayer. In this regard, I hold the cabinet responsible rather than Dr Lawrence, who did not ask for that.

PARA.TAB: A valuable lesson that we should take on board is that Dr Lawrence has been left in an invidious position because the cabinet assured her, as I said, a blank cheque. They also seemed to have facilitated that she got the most expensive legal costs in the country, not only for her defence but for a challenge.

In that way the cabinet left Dr Lawrence exposed to a most invidious situation. They did it without the parliamentary right to do it. In fact, that whole position, as argued in the chamber in August by the opposition, the Greens and I believe the Australian Democrats, has been vindicated by the fact that it actually appears as an item in the appropriations. It proves the statement that was made in August in this chamber that the government had no right, the executive had no right, to determine the allocation of taxpayers' funds without the approval of parliament. It did so without having that consent. In that respect, it has been solely responsible for the exposure that Dr Lawrence has been given in relation to her defence costs and also the costs of the challenge.

The Greens made a statement on 24 August that the government had shown no good reason for Dr Lawrence being provided with legal funding. In fact, the precedent cited by the government did not fit the situation. The guidelines providing ministers with legal aid did not fit. There is a very questionable constitutional basis for what has been requested, even in this appropriation bill before us now, and I believe it is a question that has not been properly determined even by the committee that was set up to look into this matter.

Finally, the legal argument whereby the government refers to a particular section of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act 1990 is highly questionable and its interpretation begs credibility. What it has used to support the legitimacy of the funding is subsection 4(4), which says:

SPEECH.PARA: Benefits under this Act do not limit:
(b) benefits afforded by the government to a Minister for the purpose of carrying out functions as a Minister.
In this case, it would be as the Minister for Human Services and Health. It is not to ensure that she is able to keep carrying out her functions as a minister as a matter of her political survival.

PARA.TAB: I believe the government has one thing right in that it has accused the whole royal commission of being a political exercise. I see that as a perfectly reasonable and arguable statement. But the government has also fallen into an equivalent error of using as a political matter defence costs, a challenge to the commission and federal funding thereof for a federal minister in relation to her previous role. That would therefore be appropriately addressed by her political party rather than by the parliament and by the taxpayer. As I said, we did not believe that it was a legitimate use of funding. At that time there was support from the opposition and also the Democrats in that regard.

I feel personally quite offended that the Greens' standing on that principle of the illegitimacy of the government's application for taxpayers' money to be used was used to suggest that somehow I, as a woman and a fellow member of parliament from Western Australia, was quite heartless in regard to Dr Lawrence and I felt she should pay even if she went bankrupt. That was a particular spin that the media chose to take on the remarks we made—which were that she had been left in an invidious position, a position many people in this country are in, but, because of her role as a minister, she was in a somewhat more fortunate position than other people. First, she had a cabinet that was willing to put themselves out on such a limb as to be highly questionable. Secondly, she is a minister, she has a salary and she has not resigned. Thirdly, this is being used in a preferential way.

I believe the Democrats have made a response in that regard. They have responded to her difficulties by saying that, basically, the amount that is being requested leaves her in a preferential arrangement. They have suggested that it is more appropriate that she be given the level of legal aid.

The opposition has had a remarkable change of heart and mellowed quite considerably. I am not entirely sure of the reasons for that. Perhaps they feel that when they are in government they would like to accept the same precedent that has been established. However, they have agreed to the defence costs being covered. All I want to say about that is that I think we should be able to rejoice in a diversity of views in this chamber. It is extraordinary that the opposition has changed its mind because the principles underlying the inappropriateness of this segment of Appropriation Bill (No.4) remain and have not been sufficiently addressed.

Nonetheless, that has been dealt with in the House of Representatives by pre-empting any decision that this chamber may want to bring to it or any delay discussion may bring. So the government has taken advantage of the opposition's mellowing in relation to this. It has taken advantage of it in a pragmatic way rather than a principled way. It has even had the audacity to state that. That is something we should be quite concerned about, because I think this is a case study where a cabinet makes a decision and then, by dint of persuasion, challenge in the media, sympathy, allegations of victimisation, et cetera, actually turns the parliament around to at least fund in part something which it did not have the executive power to order in the first place. So the Greens remain on the record as being against the principle that has been involved.

We have been discussing, in this time and in my consideration of these bills, Appropriation Bill (No. 4). It is quite appropriate to move an amendment to that appropriation bill. In fact, the Greens foreshadowed that we would move a motion that the bills be split so that this item could be removed and considered as a bill on its own merits in order not to jeopardise the rest of the measures within the legislation by giving it the consideration that we wish or delaying those other measures. We are not proposing to do that.

It is quite obvious that the whole issue has been pre-empted in the House of Representatives. But it does provide a salutary note as to what happens, if there is a decision made in the House of Representatives that suits our political monoculture, when the two parties vote together and come to some kind of agreement. It actually reduces the capacity of this chamber to make a democratic decision and have a discussion of the issues.

It is quite acceptable to move amendments of that kind. I have already said that I am not planning to do that, but I want to put our position on the record. However, it is not ever accepted that Appropriation Bill (No. 3) be challenged in that same way, because Appropriation Bill (No. 3), being a supply bill, falls into the convention that the Senate should use its powers to block supply only in very extreme circumstances, that it has total justification for taking the elected government back to the people because it has done something that is worthy of this happening.

I want to discuss in the remainder of my speech the issue of the Senate's powers to block supply. This has been particularly relevant because in recent weeks we have had the nostalgia surrounding the anniversary of the dismissal in 1975. It is also particularly relevant because there are some proposals regarding whether the Senate should relinquish the power to block supply. In fact, the Australian Democrats have promoted that view by saying that their membership, on coming into the Senate, would immediately sign an undertaking that they will never block supply no matter who is in government.

My main concern about this is to point out that, while this might sound eminently reasonable and as though it is assisting stable government, it is actually undercutting democracy in a way that is quite serious. In fact, it amazes me that the Australian Democrats, with their motto of keeping the Senate strong, are actually tying their hands behind their backs in relation to their own strength of powers within the Senate. Far from their previous motto of `keeping the bastards honest', they are actually changing it in this way by saying, `Keeping the bastards in government, no matter who they are nor what they do.'

While I want to comment on that, I just want to contrast where the Greens (WA) view the position. We view it very differently. We view the capacity to block supply as a capacity of the Senate which should be used only in a very thorough, ethical and rigorous way in extreme circumstances. However, we feel very strongly that we should never surrender that power. We believe—and I think we have grounds to believe—that it is the basis of federation. The importance of the Senate is made quite clear in section 67 of the Annotated Constitution of the Australian Commonwealth by Quick and Garran. In danger of getting carried away, it reads:

The Senate is one of the most conspicuous, and unquestionably the most important, of all the federal features of the Constitution, using the word federal in the sense of linking together and uniting a number of co-equal political communities, under a common system of government. The Senate is not merely a branch of a bicameral Parliament; it is not merely a second chamber of revision and review representing the sober second thought of the nation, such as the House of Lords is supposed to be; it is that, but something more than that.

SPEECH.PARA: In our view it is the basis of federation. We have been misrepresented in some cases. We say that it is not using the power to block supply that is important but having it. We have been accused of using that in a deterrent way. Anybody who knows me knows that I have very severe concerns about the use of deterrence as an argument to legitimise anything. Deterrence is not usually anything to do with justice; it is to do with manipulation and coercion.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, the reason why it is very important that we retain that power, even if we do not use it, is that it is that power which gives the two chambers their equality. They are like two poles of a ladder, and democracy needs both of them. If we lose one of them, which we would if we lost the power to block supply, which is the equivalent of the Prime Minister's power to dissolve both houses of parliament and call a double dissolution election, we would become a pole rather than a ladder and we would have all the associated discomfort of a pole. Remember: what we are aiming for is to aspire to democracy.

I want to go on to talk about the Greens' view of the importance of retaining that power, regardless of whether we use it or not. While it may be legitimately argued and perfectly understandable for a group like the Democrats to say that they want to voluntarily relinquish that power—and there could be electoral reasons for it or conviction reasons for it, and I do not deny the right of the Democrats to do that—it is quite another matter to propose that those powers be stripped from everybody else in the Senate. I want to raise that as a very serious matter of concern—when people propose a referendum that is going to undermine the basis of federation and this constitution.

The trap is that it falls into what has been a very unhidden part of the Keating Labor agenda: abolishing the Senate. If people think I am being paranoid, I refer to comments made over past years—comments like `unrepresentative swill', the threat to change the voting of the Senate to single member electorates to rid it of its cumbersome minor parties and the genuine disrespect on every announcement that the Senate has actually sought to amend something that is not to the liking of the cabinet and the executive. I do believe there is an agenda to abolish the Senate, and I think we should be very aware of that. We should be very aware of that when any referendum to remove the power to block supply is mooted. I think it would be an unmitigated disaster for Australia and for democracy.

It has been quite wrong to think of the House of Representatives in some way as having greater legitimacy or greater representativeness than the Senate. In fact, it is quite a myth to call the House of Representatives the `people's house'. Because government is formed by majority support in the House of Representatives and preferential voting means that it is nearly impossible to elect any members to that House who are not members of either the ALP or the coalition, party bloc voting means that members of the House invariably support cabinet and any bill put up will pass unless party members cross the floor. So the House of Representatives becomes a rubber stamp for cabinet. That is the reality.

The Senate, with proportional representation, has the power to review cabinet outcomes and is often the only point of review. It is the only place where significant minority interests get direct representation. So the Senate is actually the house worthy of the title `people's house'. In fact, what we have is the House of Representatives as the house of majority and the Senate chamber as the house of democracy. To support that I would like to again read from some favourite quotes of mine. One is in Odgers, and there are two others that are quite delightful. The first one is in relation to the houses, and is by John Stuart Mill. The second quote is at the beginning, in relation to the separation of powers. The John Stuart Mill quote relates to the reason he offered for supporting a parliament with two houses. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The consideration which tells most, in my judgment, in favour of two Chambers (and this I do regard as of some moment) is the evil effect produced upon the mind of any holder of power, whether an individual or an assembly, by the consciousness of having only themselves to consult. It is important that no set of persons should, in great affairs, be able, even temporarily, to make their sic volo prevail without asking any one else for his consent. A majority in a single assembly, when it has assumed a permanent character—when composed of the same persons habitually acting together, and always assured of victory in their own House—easily becomes despotic and overweening, if released from the necessity of considering whether its acts will be concurred in by another constituted authority.
It is a delightful quote and I commend it to my colleagues. It is rather long so I will not continue with it.

PARA.TAB: The importance of the link to the separation of powers is that if the House of Representatives consists of a three-yearly elected dictatorship of the executive, it is at liberty to do what it has gained support in this chamber to do because of the two major parties voting together. That is to overrule and pre-empt decisions of the High Court by bringing in legislation that severely crosses the separation of powers. I now quote Andrew Inglis Clark at the beginning of Odgers:

SPEECH.PARA: You must have an independent legislature, an independent executive, and an independent judiciary, and you can have only a mutilated government if you deprive it of any one of these branches.

We have some great aspirations in the Senate. We have some lessons to learn from what we are doing with appropriation bill No. 4 and some lessons to learn from the useful opportunity to consider appropriation bill No. 3.

PARA.TAB: I conclude with some notes on what we aspire to. The government has always sought to represent Australia as a pure Westminster system of democracy. That has never been true. We are a hybrid, which our founding fathers established by drawing from both the Westminster and American systems. Our system of government, as with the vast majority of real democracies in the world, can be more appropriately described as a consensus model of democracy rather than the majority Westminster model. The consensus model is characterised by the sharing of executive power, separation of executive and legislative power, balanced bicameralism and minority representation—that is, a multi-party system.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1995-96 and related bills, I wish to canvass a number of matters. The first, which Senator Chamarette also dealt with, is the payment of the legal costs of Dr Carmen Lawrence.
—What about Robin Gray? Who paid his legal fees?
—Mr Acting Deputy President, would you advise Senator Sherry not to interject when he is out of his seat. He is being highly disorderly.
—But what about Robin Gray? We would love to hear about his legal fees.

—Since Senator Sherry has invited me to respond, I will engage him. As you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, being a Tasmanian senator, when certain payments were made to Mr Gray, the Australian Labor Party in our home state, aided and abetted by their federal colleagues—people such as the then justice minister, Michael Tate, and the present Minister for Justice, Duncan Kerr—held rallies in Tasmania saying what an outrage it was.
—As they should, Robin Gray was corrupt.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask that that comment be withdrawn. There was no finding of corruption.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—Order! Senator Sherry, please withdraw that reference to corruption.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will certainly withdraw the word `corruption'. I think Robin Gray's record was established by the royal commission.
—Order! I also ask you not to be disorderly.

—People like former Senator Michael Tate and the present Minister for Justice beat their breasts and said to the people of Tasmania, `Imagine what these few tens of thousands of dollars could do for the legal aid system in Tasmania?' Today, with these appropriation bills, with Mr Griffiths and Dr Carmen Lawrence we are dealing with in excess of $1 million. Where is the Labor Party's righteous indignation today? We on this side have taken the view, quite properly—
—Because, prima facie, she had done nothing wrong legally, whereas Robin Gray was a crook.

—Point of order: I think Senator Sherry should be asked to withdraw that unparliamentary remark. We have been listening to speakers this afternoon in silence, as we should, and Senator Sherry should be asked to do the same.
—Senator Sherry, I ask you to withdraw that unparliamentary remark. I remind you that this is the second occasion. I will not tolerate a third one.
—I think the words used by the royal commission were that Robin Gray was deceitful, not a crook. But I will withdraw.
—Unconditionally?
—Unconditionally.

—This is typical of the way Labor tries to waste time because they hurt each time you draw to their attention their double standards in relation to this matter. The Labor Party—Senator Sherry and others—did not call for any rallies about the payment of Dr Lawrence's legal costs. Where was their righteous indignation? Where were the rallies? The Australian Democrats circulated a petition about the payment of legal costs in Tasmania, but where are they now? The Democrats voted against the motion that Dr Lawrence be sacked by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

PARA.TAB: We on this side have taken the view, on balance, that possibly Dr Lawrence should have some of her costs paid. It is a pretty long bow to draw and I still have some concern about the decision but I understand that it was an appropriate decision in all the circumstances.

But let me remind the Senate what brought all this on: the then Premier of Western Australia, Dr Lawrence, struggling in the polls, staring defeat in the face, was given an opportunity with the Easton petition to play some very dirty politics. There is no doubt, given all the evidence and the findings of Mr Marks QC, that Dr Lawrence was in the thick of things. So often `smart' `clever' political ploys come back to haunt those who perpetrate them. That is what happened in Dr Lawrence's case; that scenario has visited itself upon her.

While I am on this matter, I want to state publicly that I am horrified at the way the Australian Labor Party vilify and belittle decent, honest Australians who go about their work the best way they know how. When Sir John Kerr sacked the Whitlam government, the Labor Party waged a campaign of vilification against him—against a man who, undoubtedly, made a gut-wrenching decision, given his former Labor Party candidature and connections. Rightly or wrongly, he acted in what he thought were the best interests of the nation he was serving. The fact that the Labor Party were absolutely routed at the next election and again in 1977 is completely dismissed from their minds. Indeed, if there were any legitimacy to Sir John Kerr's actions, it was given by the people of Australia through their votes in 1975 and 1977.

Exactly the same sort of attack of vilification has now been brought to bear on Mr Marks QC who, in his retirement, made himself available to serve the nation by engaging in and conducting certain inquiries. Indeed, one of this government's own instrumentalities, Telstra, engaged Mr Marks because it was convinced that Mr Marks could go about his duties in an honourable, objective way. Of course, Mr Marks provided a report; the findings were accepted and implemented. But as soon as Mr Marks had made a finding which was not within the political agenda of the Australian Labor Party, they turned on him and attacked him with a viciousness which I think is to be deplored.

There is no evidence that Mr Marks was biased. There is no evidence that he was incapable and no evidence that he was dishonourable. In fact, exactly the opposite is the case. I think he was impeccably fair. He was sharp, he was capable and he was honourable. He came down with a considered judgment on the evidence of Dr Lawrence's former staff members and former ministers.

It is within that context that Dr Lawrence, in absolute desperation, sought to scuttle the royal commission. Of course, we now know that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, was warned well in advance, by Mr McGinty from the Western Australian Labor Party, that Dr Lawrence's `views' would not be supported by her state colleagues.

Why would the Reverend Wilson, a former minister in Dr Lawrence's government, want to lie on oath to somehow protect Brian Burke, who is now convicted of criminal offences in relation to his stewardship when he was the Premier of Western Australia? It just does not dovetail at all. Why would a minister of religion seek to perjure himself to try to assist a convicted criminal, or to assist the convicted criminal in getting back at Carmen Lawrence? It just does not make sense. Yet the Australian Labor Party, through its leadership, engages in these most despicable activities.

I was surprised to read that the Labor Party was willing to acknowledge and cut out of the bill the sum of $243,000, because that action raises a lot of questions to which, I think, we and the Australian people deserve an answer. The question ultimately is: who will pay the $243,000?

We do know that the Western Australian Labor Party have, in the past, paid off the gambling debts of their politicians to avoid problems, such as with their former Attorney-General or spokesman on law and justice—and I think that amount was $40,000. That was done under the stewardship of Chris Evans, the then secretary of the Labor Party, now a senator in this place. One wonders whether the Labor Party might have some sort of slush fund to assist Dr Lawrence in this situation.

But it ought be remembered that we are not only dealing with $243,000; there is the very real possibility also that a similar bill will be visited upon Dr Lawrence in relation to her failed challenges to the royal commission—at first instance, in the Western Australian Supreme Court, then in the Western Australian Court of Appeal and finally in the High Court. That may represent three unsuccessful challenges on which the Western Australian government quite rightly could seek orders for costs and have them visited upon Dr Lawrence.

If Dr Lawrence's bill for those three actions amounted to $243,000, it would stand to reason that in rough terms the Western Australian government's costs would be of a similar nature. So you can double the $243,000 and ask yourself: how will Dr Lawrence be able to afford the payment of $486,000? Will the Labor Party pay for those actions?

The hard working men and women of Australia, including those who might be listening to this broadcast, who pay their trade union fees on a compulsory basis so that they can keep their jobs, will be horrified to think that the Australian Labor Party would put their hard earned trade union levies to assist and fund somebody like Dr Lawrence. So will all those hard working Labor Party branch members around this country, who have the barbecues, the fund raising ventures and things of that nature, when they find that that money is used to pay for Dr Lawrence's legal costs, rather than the promotion of the Labor Party.

Of course, the delay in the payment of such a large sum to the legal firm that was employed must surely be accruing interest. One wonders what will happen with the accrual of interest. Perhaps this legal firm has done a deal and said, `Look, we won't bother charging for this,' on the promise that they will undoubtedly get other jobs from this Labor government. Let us not forget what legal firm we are talking about: it is the one that Stephen Loosley, a former senator of this place, went to. That one job he got involving Carmen Lawrence has given that legal firm, in rough terms, about $853,000 in costs. It is not a bad little earner, is it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you should go back to the law.

—You are quite right, Senator Panizza. I sometimes wonder what I am doing in this place rather than back at the bar. The simple situation is that the people of Australia have a right to know the answer to some of these questions. This is the government that talks about looking after the little people. It looks after the Dr Lawrences, the big people, but it does not look after the little people. What about the little people who go to university? Labor promised no fees; it introduced the HECS scheme. Labor promised no up-front fees; it introduced fees for graduate courses. Labor promised no up-front undergraduate fees; it is now bringing in up-front fees for certain courses.

PARA.TAB: Labor told us at the last election that the GST, or indirect taxation, is a thoroughly regressive tax. But what do we find when we have a look at all of Labor's consumption taxes? Petrol excise import duties and wholesale sales tax now total $30,700 million per annum. What was John Hewson's GST going to bring in? The sum of $23,000 million. The people of Australia, having believed that by voting for Labor they would be saved from indirect taxation, have had reaped out of their pockets an extra $7,700 million in indirect taxes—without getting all the benefits that John Hewson was promising at the last election.

Of course, to try to match those promises, what did the Labor Party say to the Australian worker and the Australian community? `There will be $14 billion in tax cuts.' Remember? It was l-a-w, law. It was to be introduced from 1 January 1996. January 1996 will undoubtedly be the beginning of the election year. But 1 January 1996 will go down in history as the day on which Labor breached one of its fundamental promises to the Australian people.

Whilst we are talking about all these broken promises, what was one of Dr Lawrence's first comments when she became health minister? She said that there would be no increase in the Medicare levy. Chances are she forgot about that promise, or something else happened along the way; I do not know. But we do know that the Medicare levy has increased.

The government promised that they would not sell their half of the Commonwealth Bank. In absolute desperation they are now selling it to try to keep up the flow of money. They promised that unemployment would fall to five per cent by the year 2000. They have as much as abandoned that. They promised no new taxes. They tried the building tax. In my own home state of Tasmania, as you would be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, they are trying to introduce a cider tax. The apple industry has been given no warning, no nothing, and, as a result, jobs will be lost.

The Labor Party's history in relation to the financial management of this country has been absolutely and utterly appalling. We know the way the Labor Party goes about its campaign techniques because we now have this document of only 14 days ago addressed to all union secretaries from the South Australian United Trades and Labour Council. It says on page 3 that they would run a campaign of fear and loathing. What a great way to run this country. What an honourable way to try to win the votes of the Australian people.

But their tactics have been exposed, undoubtedly by one trade unionist who does have some moral fibre and who is concerned about the way the trade union movement and the Labor Party are going to embark upon the next campaign. Every Australian can now know that, whatever Labor says about the coalition policies, it will be based on their campaign of fear and loathing with no regard for the truth whatsoever.

Indeed, if we want to know the sort of campaign that the Australian Labor Party will engage in, we do not have to look any further, although it is some distance away, than the magazine called Research, the market research society for the United Kingdom. There is a heading in the November issue of that bulletin `Labour Frugging', frugging being fundraising under the guise of polling. Remember all the nonsense against the Liberal Party as to what allegedly happened at the Canberra by-election? Mr Tony Blair, freshly back from Australia, having learnt all the campaign tricks from Mr Keating—and he told us that he had learnt a lot—went back to the United Kingdom and immediately engaged in this frugging.That is of course akin to what they did in Queensland. You know, the corporate sponsorship of Labor cabinet meetings, all that sort of behaviour.
The people of Australia have a clear choice. It has to be John Howard and the coalition government if there is going to be some moral fibre put back into the government of this great nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take part in this debate on Appropriation bills Nos 2, 3 and 4 much earlier than I or my colleagues had expected, for reasons that we have already debated this afternoon. These additional Appropriation bills provide for additional estimates for 1995-96 of a total of $1.4 billion. Of course some of that $1.4 billion will be offset by some savings. There is that $1.4 billion of extra spending which is ever rising spending by this government. The offset is a saving of some $944 million, leaving a new net spending of $433 million for 1995-96, and of course we are not even halfway through 1995-96.

PARA.TAB: Do you remember budget night, Mr Acting Deputy President, that big announcement of a surplus of some $750 million? There was the gloss of the announcement that it was a budget to end all budgets and it was to be a budget to take this government to the next election—which was originally going to be in September—if it had shown up in the bright lights that it was supposed to when it came down in May. That was $750 million in surplus.

There were those other fiascos of selling off the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas. Qantas was the big sell-off, if I remember rightly. It is not that long ago, but this government's good news dissipates very quickly. Even if those fiascos had not occurred, if that supposed $750 million surplus had not been wiped out then, it would have been wiped out by these additional estimates in no time at all. So this government has never been able to manage a budget. It cannot manage the simple running of the Senate from day to day so how can you rely on it to run a budget? That supposed surplus would have been wiped out by these additional estimates today.

This government assured us on that day leading up to the election—or they thought leading up to an early election—that it was a tight budget, that it was an efficient budget run by an efficient government. Do you remember those words on that night, Senator Sandy Macdonald? I remember them plainly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear. They are true.

—Obviously Senator Sherry remembers them also. If Senator Sherry is the parliamentary secretary winding up this debate he will have the chance to explain what happened to all those great words that were only great words to give you that inner warm feeling. He can explain to Australia later on tonight what happened to that supposedly responsible budget. In just six months they have not only spent the savings on increased running costs but also increased it, if you work out the figures, by an extra $272 million. Let us take the areas of expenditure where it has blown out.
—Have you added to the expenditure?
—No, we have not added to the expenditure.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—Senator Panizza, address your comments to the chair, please.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. I apologise for that, but surely I do not have to stand here and stare you in the face all the time.
—You do.

—With the natural movements of my body, I like to move around, otherwise I get very stiff and expressionless standing here. Also, I have to use the natural expressions that I was born with, Mr Acting Deputy President. But I am not slighting you whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: Those areas of expenditure include $46 million for defence facilities. All of a sudden the government found that it needed to spend another $46 million there. All of these figures are since the budget was brought down in May. They were not part of the budget. It needs $25 million for computer equipment in the Department of Social Security. Surely it should have known it needed that equipment when the budget was being drawn up.

There is $69 million for a loan to Papua New Guinea. I do not know how this government works the budget out, but this budget is only six months old and they have to find bits and pieces which add up to this extra spending. If a household budget were run on that basis, I am sure the meagre salary we get in this place would soon blow out. This $69 million loan to Papua New Guinea has not been very well explained, either.

There is the provision of $25 million for the development of the Homebush site in Sydney. Surely they should have known there was a need for that in March-April when they were drawing up the budget. Government spending always seems to me to be going upwards.
The Treasurer (Mr Willis) gave us some famous quotes on that night in May. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: A higher level of national savings will allow higher levels of development . . .
If development can occur in Australia, with the restrictions that have been foisted on us by Mabo and the evergrowing Green movement, I would be surprised. He continued:
and economic growth without the costs and constraints associated with undue reliance on foreign savings.

What has happened to foreign borrowing since May? I do not know. I have not read any good news in the papers. It has not gone down, except for a little change in the exchange rate. There definitely has not been a net reduction. To quote Mr Willis again:
This budget provides a two-part plan to improve Australia's savings performance, immediately and over the long term.

They were very good words. Has that happened? Has the budget caused that? Have there been savings immediately? If there had been savings immediately they would have been knocked around by the CRA dispute of late that the government has been powerless to do anything about. He went on:
Firstly, it increases public savings.
The Budget delivers a surplus . . . of $718 million.

I have already addressed that. I have already told you what happened. It does not deliver anything like that. The surplus disappeared within 24 hours. Six months down the track and we are into the old government mode of ever increased spending and not being able to contain themselves.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the position on the waterfront. I can remember Senator Bob Collins, who sits opposite, saying he would resign on 27 May 1992, I thought it was—if I am wrong someone can correct me—if he did not clean up the waterfront. What has happened on the waterfront since then?

Even for 1995-96, when the government was making a big noise about tightening up the budget, spending on the waterfront grew by 1.7 per cent in real terms. This government does not know anything else. The waterfront has gone backwards since that reform. Remember that $140 million was spent on that restructuring, through early retirements, retraining and other matters. Most of those who were retrenched or took the package are back on the second register. The situation is the same old situation that it was before. With over $140 million having been spent on that package, Australia has gone backwards.

Charges on the waterfront are higher than they are anywhere else in the world. It is cheaper to move materials through New Zealand.
