We used to treat New Zealand as a joke, not only with the underarm bowling fiasco but for their trade and production. Now they are a mile ahead of us. It is far cheaper to send materials through Singapore. Fifteen years ago Singapore was regarded as a third world country. The position is the same in Great Britain. I am very surprised that they are ahead of us, with the problems they have had in years gone by. It is not even a close race. They are a mile ahead of us.

The government keeps telling us how well they are doing on this reform of the waterfront. The handling rate of containers improved for a while after Senator Collins's so-called restructuring. Now it has gone backwards. They are slower than they were and more costly.

I move now to Australian National. One of the measures in these new appropriation bills provides $35 million for Australian National, which stems from the establishment of the National Rail Corporation. There were a number of reforms of the National Rail Corporation. I am one of the biggest proponents of the restructuring of National Rail because I believe that on long distance hauls of big volume, bulk items—whether it is in the medium range of between 300 and 500 kilometres or whether it is across the country, between 3,000 and 5,000 kilometres—goods have to be transported by rail. There has to be a swing back to that form of land transport. Is our spending having an effect? At present I do not think it is.

The coal industry is one of our biggest and most important exporters. It is not quite as important as the iron ore industry in Western Australia. Efficiency has not been shown there. For the carriage of coal from the coalfields to the ports, the reliability factor is only 61 per cent. In the road industry, a competitor, the reliability factor is about 96 per cent. In other words, the reliability of delivery on time for trains is 61 per cent, compared to about 96 per cent for road transport. Rail has a long way to go.

The Bureau of Industry Economics reports that Australia has a much lower productivity rate than the United States. AN was outperformed by Burlington Northern in the US by a factor of 3.6. I studied the private and national rail systems in the United States about four years ago. I thought then Australia had a long way to go. I thought Australia had caught up a lot further than it has. We are still outperformed by a factor of 3.6, which is not good enough.

Rail transport and road transport have a big bearing on the efficiency, productivity and the profit factor of the primary industry in which I am involved. I have spoken of the inefficient rail systems. The road transport operators are generally efficient, but they are being charged more and more for fuel.I will leave rail now and move to road funding.

Last year the federal government collected about $10 billion from fuel excise. The actual figure is between $9.4 billion and $9.7 billion. It will soon be $10 billion, with the indexation that occurs every six months. Last year they collected $10 billion. In 1982-83, at the end of the Fraser government, $1.4 billion was collected, and 62.4 per cent was spent on roads. You can see that the road system in Australia is being run down because the states have been starved and robbed of funding. This means that the expenditure on our roads is decreasing.

The government brought in a very worthwhile program in the black spots program. Mr Robert Brown was the Minister for Land Transport at the time. I criticised this program in the beginning as an election ploy and said that they were spending money in 1993 only on marginal seats. It was a good program at the time. It is a pity that it was not kept going.

In Western Australia the black spots that have not been repaired have been replaced by something of a different colour—white crosses. As I drive along the Great Eastern Highway at Southern Cross, which is 370 kilometres from Perth and which is where I live, I can see—and I have been driving both private cars and commercial vehicles over the years—the bad spots. As I go past these spots I can see month after month the number of white crosses is increasing. The government should—and we will do it in government—increase road funding for this purpose.

For every half a million dollars that was spent on a black spot, a life was saved. Each fatality costs Australia $631,000. It is estimated that the black spot program has saved 540 lives since inception and $340,740,000 in the on-costs that come out of road trauma. During the period of this program the costs were only $270 million, so it just shows you what can be done. Of course, there is the employment angle. For every $1 million spent on roads, 61 person-years of employment were created, together with 25 jobs directly related to roads and 36 jobs in related industries. So it does a lot for employment as well.

My time is running out, but I would just like to address, as Senator Abetz did, Carmen Lawrence's legal bills. The amount in the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1995-96 was reduced in the House of Representatives yesterday, I believe, by $243,537 for Dr Lawrence's legal bills for the challenge to the WA royal commission in the Supreme Court and the High Court. Now they seek funds, instead of the original figure, of $556,463 for legal bills. However, the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has said that the estimated cost for Dr Lawrence is to be only $456,603. That is about a $100,000 difference. I would just ask the question: why is there a $100,000 gap? Is that because more bills are coming? Is an interest bill coming in or something like that? I would like to know exactly where the rest is going.

In Appropriation Bill (No. 3), this government is proposing to appropriate $550,000 for the legal fees of a former minister—that is a different minister—who could not run a sandwich shop. So between those two ministers it adds up to nearly $1 million in legal fees for ministers who either could not run a sandwich shop or seemed to have a great lack of memory, which is a disaster. Even though this minister in the other house who was a former Premier of WA has been found by a royal commission to have not acted correctly, Mr Keating refuses to tell her to go, whereas he should have long before now and cut the bills and cut the costs where they are at this stage and not have to worry about it any more in the future.

In an interjection across the way when that royal commission made its finding, one of the government members over there said, `You didn't mention a couple of ministers in the Fraser government that did something wrong.' I think that was up in Queensland, and I am battling to remember who they were, but the point is that they were guilty of a misdemeanour. They admitted it, and Fraser sacked them that day. They were gone. No excuses. Bang, they were gone. I think there might have been another one as well somewhere along the line. That is what Mr Keating should have done at the time and saved Australia $1 million in legal fees in total—that is, if it is in total and there is not more to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to address the two items in these appropriation bills which deal with the funding for the legal fees for Mr Alan Griffiths MP and the legal fees for Dr Carmen Lawrence. The total amount that I have here for Mr Alan Griffiths MP comes to $468,945. With the amendment brought by the coalition in the other place, I understand the total figure appropriated for Dr Lawrence's fees will be $556,463. So, in total, we have a figure in excess of $1 million worth of legal fees for two people.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that at the outset one sees that, in Dr Lawrence's case, fees were paid at the hourly rate of $500 for a Queen's Counsel; $250 for counsel assisting; and a range from $125 to $330 for instructing solicitor. That is per hour, of course. In relation to Mr Griffiths's fees, they were set at the hourly rate of $350 for a principal; $200 for a solicitor; and $100 for a clerk. Although Mr Griffiths's fees related to a period which ran from January 1994, I think, through to February 1995 and Dr Lawrence's fees related to some months earlier this year, I cannot see that the disparity in time could equal the disparity in the hourly rate.

So the first issue I would raise is: why can't the Commonwealth settle a set rate by which it will provide assistance to people? It does it with legal aid in the community. That is a set rate. There is no question about that, but it seems that what we have here is that the rate is set on an ad hoc basis. This is entirely unsatisfactory when you are looking at in excess of $1 million worth of legal fees.

Another aspect I would raise in relation to Dr Lawrence's fees is that the government has decided to adopt the decision of the majority of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee in relation to payment of a minister's legal costs. In that report which looked at this decision, the committee recommended by a majority that, if the government wished to proceed with the payment of Dr Lawrence's legal costs, it should do so by introducing a single-line appropriation into the parliament in order to allow the matter to be decided upon directly by the parliament.

Quite frankly, I am pleased to see that the government has taken the advice of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee, because when the government was pressed it was not exactly clear how the cabinet came to this decision. In fact, there was mention of payment being made under the Advance to the Minister for Finance, supported by the Parliamentary Entitlements Act 1990, and also by way of an appropriation bill. The evidence that was put to the Senate was scant indeed as to how cabinet intended to go about this.

That is relevant to the point I am making, which is that this decision was made on the run. It was made with bits and pieces of legal advice, to use Senator Gareth Evans's phrase, and it was done entirely in an ad hoc fashion. When you are dealing with this sort of amount of money, I think you really are letting down the taxpayers of Australia when you make these decisions on the run. What has happened, of course, is that through not thinking this through, the government initially set aside $800,000 but has now left Dr Lawrence in the lurch because only $556,000 has been approved. There was not any clarity of how this money was to be spent and whether it was to be spent challenging the royal commission in question.

There is another aspect which I am still waiting for an answer on. I asked Senator Ray last week whether the Attorney-General's Department had contemplated who would pay for the costs awarded against Dr Lawrence in the Supreme Court and the High Court. No answer has yet been forthcoming, although Senator Ray undertook to take that up with the Attorney-General's Department. It would seem that those amounts of costs awarded against Dr Lawrence would be substantial, because her figure for challenging the royal commission was in the sum of $247,000. Of course, if the other party's fees are the same, she could well be facing a bill in that amount in addition to the amount that it has cost her to challenge the royal commission.

So, because of the government's lack of attention to detail and because of its shoddiness in the way it has approached this matter, I believe it has left Dr Lawrence in the lurch; it has left Dr Lawrence's solicitors in the lurch. But, above all, I think it has treated the whole process with contempt. The executive in this case has behaved in an arrogant fashion and with total disregard to the taxpayers of Australia.

The decision by the coalition was made on balance, as Senator Abetz said, in relation to the payment of these fees. Certainly, if there is a royal commission and someone is involved in the royal commission by way of their official duty in the past, then the government that is calling that royal commission normally pays fees for that person. There is precedent for that. The Western Australian government agreed to pay Dr Lawrence's fees for her appearances before the royal commission.

But quite rightly the Western Australian government refused to meet her costs to challenge the validity of the royal commission. I might add that her three applications were all defeated—her application to a single judge in the Supreme Court of Western Australia, the Full Court of Western Australia and the High Court. When you look at those decisions, you can see the lack of merit in her applications in that regard.

The situation is that the government has seen fit to put the Senate in a spot whereby we are faced with a situation which is a fait accompli—money has been expended over and above the Western Australian allocation for Dr Lawrence's representation. I would say Dr Lawrence has been looked after in a most generous way. Certainly I think the provision of two counsel with an instructing solicitor is as generous as it can get, especially when you consider the disbursements in relation to accommodating those counsel who had to travel from the eastern states. I look at one aspect which was $18,000 alone for photocopying. I think accommodation was in excess of $40,000 and travelling was in excess of $40,000. Nonetheless the coalition has decided that it will not be churlish and it will, on balance, support the payment of those fees which relate to the representation of Dr Lawrence before the royal commission.

With respect to the challenge that was mounted against the royal commission, I would submit there was lack of merit and certainly that went above and beyond any possible call that a minister could make on a government. I believe the problem we have here is that there are not sufficient guidelines in relation to how a minister's costs are met in these particular instances. I might add that the guidelines that the Commonwealth does have in place did not accommodate Dr Lawrence's situation. The guidelines that are in place do not provide for an action to be commenced by the person concerned, as was done by Dr Lawrence in relation to the challenge against the royal commission, but relate to the defending of actions brought against the person involved.

In relation to Mr Griffiths's fees, I see that the fees relate to the initiating of the Codd inquiry, the trial against Lynette Harrison, Mr Griffith's former business associate, and also answers and interviews which related to the preparation of drafts, collation of material and interviews with Mr Griffiths in relation to newspaper and media materials and activities. This was subsequent to an interview by the inquiry on 10 December 1994.

In relation to the sums, we see that quite substantial sums are allocated to the three discrete aspects of the funding involved. This funding totalled $468,000 in round figures. I note that in January 1994 Mr Griffiths was conducting his own case against Lynette Harrison, his former business associate. I can say that from the two-page letter that has been provided in relation to break down it does not specifically exclude any work done in that case, although it does not mention it. I just wonder what assurance there is that those fees did not relate to that private action which was brought by Mr Griffiths as well.

I am not saying that there are not going to be situations where a minister, acting in the course of his or her duty, might be funded by the government of the day, but there should be strict guidelines laid down as to how any decision in relation to the funding thereto is made. There has to be absolute transparency and decisions have to be made on a carefully considered basis and not on the run or on an ad hoc basis without sufficient legal advice.

Furthermore, all care must be taken that there should be consistency of funding—that is, the applicable rate be uniform—and furthermore there should be due inquiry as to where the money was spent and there should be a full itemisation of the accounts in question. I look at the costs in relation to Mr Griffiths and we have here totals which deal with solicitors' costs and partners and principles, but they are in round figures.

We have the itemisation of disbursements—photocopying, $9,600; facsimile, $7.800. I would be interested to know at what rate per page photocopying was done and what cost per facsimile. If you prepared a legal aid bill, you would be asked those questions. If you billed a private client, you would be asked those questions. You would have to itemise each letter, each telephone call and the folios you had drafted in relation to the legal costs concerned. But we do not have that here. I think that is totally unsatisfactory, particularly when you are spending in excess of $1 million of taxpayers' money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —These appropriation bills include Appropriation Bill (No. 3). Appropriation Bill (No. 3) implements an increase in running costs for all portfolios of 3 1/2 per cent. Included in that is the portfolio of the Attorney-General and included in that are the running expenses of the Australian Securities Commission.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators would know that the conduct of the Australian Securities Commission has been a matter of some concern to me for a great deal of time. In particular, I have been concerned about the conduct of the Australian Securities Commission in relation to a failed investment scheme called Aust-Home Investments.

That matter would be known to Senator Jones because I know Senator Jones has been approached by people in relation to Aust-Home Investments. Senator Jones might be interested to know that I now have to hand information which suggests that the investigator employed by the ASC who ran the investigations into the Aust-Home matters appears to have misled the court and the Attorney-General in relation to an interim report which he claims was done pursuant to the ASC law.

This matter is of grave concern because it has had serious implications for investors in the scheme who were caught in court applications that were made by the Australian Securities Commission to freeze their assets. Honourable senators would know that I have raised the case of Margo and Max Bunt before because they were two innocent investors whose assets were frozen on an application of the Australian Securities Commission to which they were forced to consent for the simple reason that Mrs Bunt, in particular, was told that if she did not consent to applications freezing her assets the ASC would go ahead and also freeze her salary at Qantas as well. That is the information that has been provided to me.

Under duress, poor Mr and Mrs Bunt said, `We give in; we will agree to the orders for the time being.' The consequence of their agreeing to those orders in 1992 was some 18 months of litigation to get the orders rescinded and an ongoing fight in relation to their court costs to defend their family home from the Australian Securities Commission, which was supposedly going in there to defend their interests as investors in a failed scheme.

This is a wonderful situation when the Australian Securities Commission alleges that a scheme is defrauding investors—I believe the scheme was fraudulent—and then proceeds to say, `We are going to freeze all of these assets which we believe are caught up in this scheme to protect the innocent investors.' Whose assets do they freeze? They froze the assets of the innocent investors. Those investors suffered massive losses of income and massive legal expenses as a consequence.

I want to point out one thing. Early on in the piece, Mr Brendan Behan—he was not a playwright, unfortunately; he was one of the ASC investigators—claimed in court documents that he had conducted an interim investigation into 50 named respondents and companies pursuant to provisions of section 13 of the ASC law. That material is contained in an affidavit that was sworn by Mr Behan and filed with the court on 16 March 1992. It is interesting that Mr Behan claims to have been investigating these companies for three months, the point at which he filed the affidavit. So sloppy was the investigatory work undertaken by Mr Behan that he was not even aware of the relationship between some of the respondent companies and some of the respondent investors and the fraudulent company, Aust-Home Investments Pty Ltd.

That in itself is fairly disturbing, but what is very disturbing was that it appears that the interim report was not filed until some time after the affidavit was sworn. It was not until the following year after the affidavit was filed that the interim report was prepared. The interim report, under section 16 of the ASC law, was prepared and dated 23 January 1993, not March 1992. In fact, the extracts of the minutes of meeting 246 of the Australian Securities Commission, prepared and dated 1 February 1993, state:

SPEECH.PARA: Resolved that the Commission adopt the Interim Report pursuant to Section 16(2) of the ASC Law and that it be forwarded to the Attorney-General pursuant to Section 18(1) of the ASC law, for the purposes of winding up under 461(h) of the Corporations Law.

That in itself gives lie to the claim by Mr Behan that he prepared an interim report in 1992. It was not even considered by the ASC until 1993, by which time the ASC, in its oppressive court actions against the innocent investors, had already ensured the consent of Mr and Mrs Bunt and other innocent investors to having their assets frozen, in part because Mr Behan asserted that he had conducted an interim report when he quite obviously had not.

PARA.TAB: Worse still, this report that was supposed to be forwarded to the Attorney-General was not available to the then Attorney-General at the time. My understanding is that that report has only just been received by the Attorney-General. I might be incorrect on that; I hope I am incorrect. If that is the case, I would like something from the Australian Securities Commission to show that they did provide that interim report to the Attorney-General promptly after that meeting on 1 February 1993.

From correspondence which Mrs Bunt has received from the Attorney-General, it sure seems that if the ASC provided the report to the Attorney-General in accordance with the resolution of the meeting of 1 February, he never saw it because it was never referred to in his correspondence with her. In fact, in one of the letters I was shown he said he was still awaiting it.

What is going on at the Australian Securities Commission? What is going on with these so-called guardians of the investing public? We now have a situation where it appears that officers of the Australian Securities Commission have wilfully misled the Attorney-General and the Supreme Court of Queensland. That is just thoroughly unacceptable. In fact, the various justices who have heard the applications related to this matter have expressed concern at the accuracy of some of the material that was presented to them. They have expressed concern that the Australian Securities Commission proceeded in the way in which it did. Page 18 of a judgment handed down by Mr Justice Hill on 23 August 1993 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Next, it is not insignificant that the initial appointment of a receiver was continued by consent. This does not mean, as was submitted by counsel for the Commission, that Mr and Mrs Bunt accepted the strength of the Commission's case. There are many reasons why parties consent to interlocutory orders being continued, not the least of which is the potential difficulty of raising finance to meet the costs of a court case . . . No doubt it suited the Commission not to continue the litigation to final hearing as it was pursuing its investigations in the Aust-Home Group. It must, I think, be said that the Commission appears not to have understood the underlying nature of the appointment of a receiver under s.1323(3). In particular it is clear, as is emphasised by Cooper J in His Honour's judgment of 19 March 1993, that the interim appointment of a receiver should only remain in force for a limited period. In fact, for whatever reason, the orders remained in force for in excess of 12 months.

That is a decision from the bench. It is quite clear that the actions which have been embarked upon by the Australian Securities Commission have at the very least been misguided. At the very worst, one could characterise these actions as vindictive, oppressive, malicious and spiteful.

PARA.TAB: The Bunts have sought to sue the Australian Securities Commission for the loss which they have suffered as a result of the actions of the ASC. There is no doubt that they have probably lost hundreds of thousands of dollars as a result of the precipitous action of the ASC. Of course, there is a provision in the legislation which says that the ASC cannot be sued, nor can its officers be sued when they act in good faith. I believe that what I have outlined to the Senate shows that certain officers of the ASC have failed in that solemn duty to act in good faith. They have failed in that solemn duty because they have misled the Attorney-General. No wonder the Attorney-General had so much difficulty dealing with the correspondence from Mrs Bunt because he was believing that what he was told by the Australian Securities Commission was correct. It was incorrect. I pity Mr Duffy and I pity Mr Lavarch, who have quite clearly been mislead.

The fact that the ASC would mislead the Attorney-General is indicative of the fact that they have probably not acted in good faith in this matter. Even if they did act in good faith in seeking the applications that they originally sought, they certainly did not act in good faith in continuing to maintain that they were entitled to the benefit of those orders, nor did they act in good faith in trying to cover up their own mistakes.

I believe that the Bunts have a very good case against the Australian Securities Commission because the Australian Securities Commission did not act in good faith. There was never an interim report done prior to the initiation of application QG3004 of 1992. The ASC did not conduct a proper investigation. That is quite clear. They did not provide information to the Director of Public Prosecutions. That is also clear. They have misled the minister. It is thoroughly unacceptable for the Australian people to be told to put their faith in the ASC because it will be their watchdog when, in fact, the ASC has failed to protect the rights and interests of the innocent.

There is always a danger in these matters that in pursuing what the ASC may believe to be a wrong, precipitous action may harm the innocent. That is what has happened. The provisions of the legislation say that if that has happened in good faith, the innocent cannot receive damages from the ASC. I can see good policy reasons for saying that. But when excessive pursuit of an ASC cause leads to a trampling of the rights of the innocent, the ASC then misleads the court and misleads the Attorney-General about the investigations which they have conducted, fails to provide material to the Attorney-General and fails to provide material to the Director of Public Prosecutions, it is difficult to have confidence that the ASC will take care of the interests of innocent investors.

I would hope that honourable senators on the other side of the chamber would be as concerned as I am about this matter—that the taxpayer is forking out for the ASC to do basically what it wants, when all these legal actions initiated by the ASC, for example, applications for receivers to be appointed over the assets of 50 named respondents, were paid for with taxpayers' money.

At the end of this sorry saga, not one investor has received one cent back. Many investors who lost all the money they put into the scheme were compelled to pay additional amounts in respect of tax. Many of the investors were innocent coal miners in Blackwater, for heaven's sake! On top of that, we find the ASC spending additional taxpayers' money to freeze the assets of innocent investors and then fighting any application those investors made to have their assets returned or to have their court costs paid by the ASC.

I believe we should have watchdogs, but occasionally it is necessary for somebody to watch the watchdogs. That is the role of this parliament. I hope the matters I have outlined here will receive the immediate and urgent attention of the Attorney-General. I hope the government will recognise the justice in the case which the Bunts presented and recognise that they do have, and should have, a proper claim for compensation for the wilful and malicious conduct of the ASC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking tonight on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1995-96 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1995-96. The Senate would have noted with interest the discussion that Senator Chamarette began in relation to appropriations and, in particular, the debate that is beginning to emerge in relation to the role of the Senate. What is important here is that an informed debate take place.

PARA.TAB: It is important that if there are to be changes in the way Australia is governed, if there is to be a new way of organising government, the nature of that debate, in my opinion, is not defined arbitrarily by executive government. It is really not good enough, in my opinion, that either government or opposition put forward a proposal for what will be the issues in any future debate about things such as the constitution, the head of state or the role of government. It is extremely important that the nature of the issues be canvassed first, before they are ever put to the people. We have a unique opportunity now to look at the nature of the debate.

Some of the issues which have arisen include a move by members of the community to talk about a bill of rights. Other people feel it is important that we have a full debate about things such as the treaties power within the constitution. The government, and some people within the government, think a major issue to deal with is the role of the Senate. Other people would see that the other side of that coin is the role of executive government and whether election should mean a three-year dictatorship.

A growing number of people see that there are important issues to be dealt with. We can see what are sometimes very destructive tussles going on in relation to the role of states to regional government, local government and federal government—the lines of communication, what is actually happening there, how the democratic process is working, where it is not working and where there are moves to remove the democratic process that we have seen between states and local government. Many people see that as an issue which must be eventually dealt with.

There has been a great deal of debate over the years in relation to environmental powers—so much so that in order to get the pretence of any kind of agreement between the states and the federal government, the federal government acts as if there is no power within the federal sphere to act on the environment. If local government, state governments and federal government are either unwilling to protect the environment or feel they are unable to, in the end, if the community feels that ecological sustainability is a very important issue, at some stage we have to work out whether or not that becomes a right of citizenship.

In line with my mention of the bill of rights, we include things such as a move towards democratisation of workers, if that is what is at issue, the rights of indigenous people, minorities and so on. We probably need to look at the Australian constitution in relation to the role of the international market, because in many ways many of the decision making aspects of the Australian federal government seem to have been donated to a non-elected international body of people who have no connection with each other except their desire to speculate. So there are many changes which we are seeing in a very real way.

As the Hilmer reforms continue, there are many very fast changes occurring in our society. If we do not take the opportunity of looking at the implications of the decisions we are making now, the implications for the future and the way people want to see Australia in the future, we may lose a very valuable opportunity.

I put all of this in the context of the issues that are at hand in relation to the appropriation bills. If we have executive government who feel they are not accountable to the electors between elections, if they do not feel they are accountable to the parliamentary process, a very dangerous situation may arise. It is important that that level of scrutiny and proper process continues.

In Appropriations Bill (No. 4) there will obviously be, there has been and will continue to be, a process by which this House will look at things such as the funding for Fox television and an appropriation for Papua New Guinea, which appears to have no democratic basis, no real indication of what the outcomes will be and no actual rationale that seems to make any sense. In the committee stage there will be a discussion on those issues, and that is right. That is what the Senate is here to do. It could be very dangerous if those kinds of issues could not be dealt with in this way in this place.

I hope that as time goes on both major parties will see the benefits of doing what the commission on government has been attempting to do in Western Australia, which is finding a very popular response—the importance of going to the people first and talking to them about what their issues are in order to make the best decisions.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! It being 6.50 p.m., the Senate will turn to consideration of government documents.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The report on the Australian delegation to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty conference tabled before the Senate reveals an interesting expose of Australia's position on the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, the NPT. Paragraph 28 on page 12 of the report states:

PARA.TAB: The indefinite extension of the NPT has been a longstanding and critical Australian security and non-proliferation objective.

SPEECH.PARA: This statement in itself is a sad reflection on the Australian government's lack of ability to think for itself or to have any capability of strategic analysis of this issue. It is merely mouthing the words of the nuclear weapon states.

PARA.TAB: By taking this line, the government is perpetuating the false bargain that is the underlying premise of the NPT. The heart of the false premise is the bargain between the non-nuclear weapon states and the nuclear weapon states. The non-nuclear weapon states have agreed not to develop nuclear weapons, in return for which the nuclear weapon states have agreed to disarm. Unfortunately, the nuclear weapon states have patently failed to hold up their end of the bargain.

Since 1970, when the NPT came into force, more than 75,000 new nuclear weapons have been deployed by the nuclear weapon states. In fact, of all the nuclear weapons currently in the superpowers' arsenals, the vast majority were deployed after the NPT was signed. Even now, with the end of the Cold War, the nuclear weapon states continue to maintain their arsenals and pour millions of dollars into weapons development.

The nuclear tests by China just days after signing the NPT and the resumption of testing by France in the Pacific are testimony of the contempt that the nuclear weapon states hold for the NPT. It is further signified by the fact that the United Kingdom has refused to condemn the French for their testing and by the announcement that the United States might undertake low yield testing in the near future. That just about wraps them all up.

If nothing else, the NPT conference will go down in history as a breathtaking example of diplomatic cheek. Having spent 25 years ignoring their part of the NPT bargain, the nuclear weapon states and Australia then had the gall to ask the extension conference to make the deal permanent, in doing so forever legitimising the division of the world into nuclear haves and have-nots. In return, the rest of the world will have to make do with a weak commitment to disarmament that has always been ignored for a quarter of a century.

Some enlightened non-nuclear weapon states, which Senator Gareth Evans referred to in the Senate as twilight zone countries, argued that the NPT could have been extended for fixed periods linked to disarmament goals. But while these so-called twilight zone countries were looking for a meaningful solution to nuclear proliferation, the Australian government was locked in the palaeolithic era still believing that `might' is right.

Paragraph 29 of this report provides an interesting insight into Australia's position. It reveals that Australia's position on the NPT is related to its participation in nuclear trade; that is, the NPT is supposed to give an assurance that the sale of our uranium will not be used in nuclear weapons. Only last week was this premise shown to be blatantly false. The Australian Safeguards Office in its submission to the Senate inquiry into the nuclear non-proliferation treaty could not give an assurance that Australian uranium sold to France was not being used in their nuclear weapons tests in the Pacific.

It is a simple fact that, once uranium is mixed with uranium from other sources and then transformed into a gas as part of the enrichment process, there is absolutely no way of identifying atoms as being made in Australia. This fact highlights the weak and carefully metered response that Australia has given to the French nuclear tests.

Finally, paragraph 31 comments that Australia was concerned about getting the widest possible support for the indefinite extension of the NPT, especially in our own region. This is despite the twilight zone comments made by Senator Evans. Despite special visits by Senator Evans, many non-nuclear weapon states, including Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia, were opposed to an indefinite extension of the NPT.

With the resumption of testing by China and France, we found Australia's position on the NPT to be shallow and naive. We certainly hope that the government will have a more enlightened position in discussion on the comprehensive test ban treaty.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council is a statutory consultative body established to contribute a national perspective on the operation of the rural adjustment schemes as administered by the states. The schemes objectives are, among other things: to achieve the promotion of better financial, technical and management performance by the Australian farm sector; to provide support to farmers who have prospects of sustainable long-term profitability with a view to improving the productivity of their farm units; to provide support in a way that ensures that farmers become financially independent of support within a reasonable period; and to provide support for farmers during periods of adverse and exceptional economic circumstances for which they could not be expected to have planned.

PARA.TAB: It is on the exceptional circumstances that I would like to make a few comments tonight. I am not game to say that the drought has broken, but it has certainly eased in the last few months. The drought we faced in New South Wales and Queensland was certainly exceptional. It drove efficient producers to the brink and, in many instances, beyond the point of no return.

I applaud the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council for the work that it has done in assisting farm families during the past 12 months. However, that support is not completely unqualified. I believe there are many deficiencies in the way that the eligibility for assistance has been based not necessarily on need but on where a farmer lives.

It is an indictment of the government that lines drawn arbitrarily on maps determined whether deserving farm families survived or not. I recall a ridiculous case in the Hunter Valley where one farmer was deemed to be eligible for exceptional circumstances while his equally suffering neighbour missed out. I am sure all honourable senators would be aware of a number of examples where areas of greater need missed out to others that were less deserving.

I am also concerned by the secrecy surrounding RASAC's advice to the government. I believe the information upon which the minister bases his submissions to cabinet must be made public to allow the more intense scrutiny that is essential. We have been told that, in formulating advice, RASAC considers meteorological, agronomic, economic and environmental conditions, water supply and the scale of events. My concern lies in the interpretation of this advice by the government. After all, they are the government. They are there to provide help. Help must be provided by them.

Minister Collins has claimed a lot about the assistance that the government has provided. It has provided some assistance. But for the coalition's pressure, thousands of farm families both in New South Wales and in Queensland would not have had the assistance that the government has provided, nor would they have been eligible for the drought family payment.

Senator Collins has always argued from a position of strength because he is in government. He has said that we lack the sorts of policies that would provide help and assistance. But you, Senator Collins, are in government. You are in a position to change your mind, and I can tell you, you frequently have.

There is no escaping the fact that the federal government response has been miserly in terms of the historical commitment that the coalition made when it was in government in 1983. There is no getting away from those figures. The future of hundreds of New South Wales farmers was jeopardised—in fact, their future was destroyed—by the glib promises the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made and despite the fact that he said nobody would be left behind.

The Prime Minister also said drought is a natural occurrence. He is probably right but, under 12 years of Labor, the ability of farmers to prepare for drought has been virtually destroyed. Farmers were not in a position to meet the problems of the last four years of drought. The reasons for that are obvious: the government has run a high interest economy, a high inflation economy and a high indirect tax economy and has taken away what was the prudent farmer's friend—the ability to plan for drought by the use of income equalisation deposits. Much of the anguish caused by the government's hotchpotch response to drought could have been avoided if it had not gutted the sector so, and had had a decent national drought policy.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I want to make just one or two points. One is this: in terms of a group of people who would like to see themselves as the next government, if Senator Sandy Macdonald thinks that providing drought assistance to farmers at the rate of $2 million per week, which is what we are doing right now, as I speak, and have been for some time and will continue to do for a full six months guaranteed by statute after the drought declarations have been revoked, is miserly, it is an interesting little glimpse at what kind of fiscal management will be run by the coalition.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Macdonald seriously suggests that that level of assistance is a miserly contribution, it is not. I know that from direct feedback I have had from the farmers of Australia. As late as last night I got a phone call in my office—because I was the only person there at the time, I took the call—from a person ringing to say `thanks', which I appreciated, to be honest, because you do not get too much of that in this business. What the government has provided has been significant assistance.

In terms of the opposition taking any credit at all for the drought policy, I, as the person who actually put the submission together, know that is a nonsense. But I do want to say this to Senator Macdonald—I am usually fairly forthright in what I say: I do have to give credit, and I have done it before, to the people who really did have an influence on that policy.

The National Farmers Federation certainly had. We only have to look at the written submissions they made to the government to see how much of that was reflected in the document that was finally produced. The Australian Grain Growers Association, particularly its President, Ian McFarlane, had a great deal to do with it.

But, as I have said before, the people who particularly contributed to it were primary producers, in particular—I have also said this before—rural women. That is why we provided cash instead of fodder subsidies. Even though Senator Macdonald might disagree with a great many things that I say, and I am sure he does, I think he would accept my statement that I did seriously consider all of the options that were available. I rejected fodder subsidies for a number of reasons, one of which is that they do not do a damn thing for people who do not get their income from stock.

But, apart from that, what I was told by rural woman after rural woman when I visited the bush was that the most desperate assistance they needed was not subsidies for something that they had to actually pay money out on in the first instance but cash. I can tell the Senate that I received those representations in that first drought trip I made to Queensland in the most, I have to say, desperate circumstances, in which farm families had not had a positive income—that is, money of their own—through no fault of their own, for something like four years. You have to experience it before you can appreciate the utter soul-destroying impact that simply not having an income has on normally independent people.

There are two things that farmers are short of during droughts. One is rain; the other is money. That is why at the end of the day we determined that a system of direct cash payments—which farmers could spend on fodder if they wished or anything else they wanted—was the appropriate way to go.

I am the first to concede that these things need to be continually improved. That is why I initiated the review into the drought policy—it is going on right now—through ARMCANZ to continually refine it. The last refinement, allowing for the altitude effects of effective rain, was, I have to tell you again—and I think Senator Macdonald knows this—as a direct result of representations that were made to me by delegations of farmers from that region that I thought were fair. That is why they were granted.
Having said all that, I conclude this little contribution by saying from the heart—and I say this with a great deal of feeling—I thank God for the rain, and may it continue.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1995 annual report entitled Access and equity of the Keating government really shows that the Labor government's actions on access and equity are falling well short of its rhetoric. Access and equity is said by the government to be—and I agree with this—a fundamental element of multicultural policy in Australia. It is supposed to ensure that all Australians have access to all publicly provided services without discrimination.

PARA.TAB: The 1994 annual report levelled many damning criticisms in relation to access and equity performance. Most of these criticisms emanated from the community and were directed particularly at service delivery departments. The criticisms were levelled primarily at, as I say, government agencies, including particular departments involved in service delivery. This year's report, the 1995 report, which we are now considering, asserts that these criticisms have been addressed by various government programs. There are statements as to what has been done to address the previous year's criticisms, but scant quantitative evidence is provided on the effectiveness of any of these initiatives.

Quite frankly, it seems to me that the Labor government is running out of steam on access and equity. I am not certain that it has ever really had it as a high priority so far as performance is concerned. It has talked a great deal about access and equity but, when we look at many of its own actions, it seems that access and equity is often being observed more in the breach than in the actuality.
The government's current poor performance is highlighted by the general focus of this year's annual report, which general focus is called `Participation'. Participation was defined in the report as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the opportunity for representatives from A&E target groups—
including people from non-English backgrounds—
to take part in decision-making and formal advice to government, including through membership of government advisory and review bodies.

It is quite remarkable that the report focuses on non-English background participation at this level yet it remains totally silent on the level of non-English speaking background participation in the Public Service as distinct from, as I say, the government advisory and review bodies.

PARA.TAB: The silence on this matter is only to be expected because, when you look at it, the performance so far as the Public Service is concerned is appalling. As a recent ACTU study found, there has been an actual fall in the number of NESB personnel in no less than 28 government departments and agencies. The ACTU study also found that less than two per cent of all officers in the Senior Executive Service of the Australian Public Service are overseas born NESB Australians. Worse: only nine per cent of new appointments to the Australian Public Service were from a non-English speaking background and NESB people were more likely to be made redundant in the restructuring of federal departments. So that is quite an appalling indictment of the government's real approach to access and equity.

The regrettable decline in participation of overseas born Australians in the Public Service sector is occurring at a time when we are observing the remarkable success of such people in a range of other areas outside the control of the federal government. The Business Review Weekly reported recently that some 30 per cent of the 200 richest Australians were born overseas. NESB Australians are over-represented amongst owners and operators of small business and the children of migrants are achieving better results in higher education than children of Australian born parents. It is remarkable and unfortunate that the Office of Multicultural Affairs has found this glaring inconsistency between the public and private sector performance of such little importance that it did not warrant any significant analysis. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an intriguing report, if a short one. The Corporations and Securities Panel is made up of some of the top business and legal brains in Australia, it costs $135,867 a year to run and in the latest year not one reference was made to this body. This body is there to help the Australian Securities Commission, particularly in areas of significant matters. Its purpose, according to the Hon. Michael Lavarch, the Attorney-General, is to set some of the ethical and business standards for the Australian business community.

PARA.TAB: One would presumably wonder, as one looks at the pages of court actions involving some entrepreneurs, whether in fact there was not some significant need for this organisation to be very active indeed; but it depends on references from the Australian Securities Commission, and the commission has made none. In fact, since this panel was created in 1991 there has been only one reference to it. In order to give the panel something to do, the Securities Commissioner has determined that the panel should conduct a hypothetical case study to give the ASC and itself experience in handling these procedures.

It seems to me extraordinary that such a wealth of talent should be obliged to spend its time on a hypothetical when there is clearly so much that a panel of this substance should be doing. Let me read from the report just to demonstrate that I am not making any of this up. Under the heading `The work of the panel in 1994-95', it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Panel received no referrals from the ASC in 1994-95.
Then it went on:

The work of the Panel is primarily determined by the complexity and number of matters referred to it by the ASC. There is a small amount of informational and policy development work required but this is minor compared to that required by even a single application.
It then went on:
The Chairman of the ASC, Mr Alan Cameron . . . said that he considers that its experience in its single referral to date—
since its creation in 1991—
has been an important development and learning process for all concerned.

The president of the panel is an outstanding businessman; he is Mr John Pascoe, the Chief Executive Officer of George Weston Foods Ltd, a former director of Qantas and a trustee of the Sydney Opera House Trust. You would think that a panel led by him would be given plenty of work. He has said:
. . . that he is looking forward to the Panel developing its role and taking a robust and positive attitude to its work.
He is the newly appointed chairman. I hope he does not get as frustrated as previous chairmen were. He said:

. . . the Panel is keen to ensure that its mode of operation is not perceived as having an adversarial and quasi-legal manner but an informal, practical manner with Panel members acting as persons with business and market expertise rather than as inquisitors or judges.

All I can hope is that Mr Pascoe and his team in fact get something to do; otherwise I wonder why on earth $135,867 a year is being directed to this venture. I will not go through the list of the top quality people who are there; the Senate will be able to read it for itself. It seems to me that if you are going to have a panel like this, for heaven's sake use it. Looking at the area of business activity, one would have thought that the ASC would have needed as much assistance as it could get in this area.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of foreign currency loans has assumed considerable importance in the Australian community, especially among the rural community and farmers. In relation to this issue, a number of clients of banks have taken action against their banks for negligence in relation to the provision of foreign currency loans and, in some instances, those actions have achieved a measure of success in the courts.
