TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to sculpture tonight, particularly to the work of Lawrence Beck, a well-known sculptor in Sydney whom I have assisted in organising a number of international sculpture seminars over a period of years—two in the Gosford area, at Wondabyne and Mount Penang, and, more recently, a symposium at Broken Hill. I want to talk about the development of sculpture because, with the approaching Olympics, Sydney needs to take stock of its sculpture assets. Although what I say will apply to other cities and towns, I want to concentrate on Sydney.

PARA.TAB: To a certain extent, there is a crisis in sculpture. I am informed that the English erected 37 sculptures of prominent citizens in Sydney up to the time of federation. Since then, the Australian government has erected only two—one depicting Lloyd Rees and the other, Henry Lawson. The Sydney sculpture map of 1975 listed 35 public sculptures in Sydney, and the city council map of 1990 listed 16. Although somebody might challenge those figures, they indicate a problem. I do not know whether that low level of sculpture reflects some Anglo-Celtic inertia about using sculpture to adorn and enhance our cities. I think Melbourne might be slightly ahead of Sydney. Nevertheless, there is a problem.

Many Australians were born in or come from countries where sculpture was part of their lives. It is mixed with the culture, the myths and histories of those countries. It is part of the education, part of the folklore of those countries. It seems that, as a reflection of the population, there is a need for us to look at this situation. If we are to achieve a truly multi-cultural society, we must correct this dearth of emphasis on sculpture. With our Anglo tradition, we need to overcome a sculpture deficit.

Another parameter is the link between sculpture and architecture, which is another way of making sure that we enhance the quality of our buildings and the environment in which our city buildings are erected. I hope that a discussion can be generated that will cause more money and resources to go into that area.

I would like to refer to my experience of the very successful seminars in Gosford where we arranged for the provision of a block of Gosford sandstone, which has a particularly good quality for sculpture. At various times we had Asian, Japanese, East and West Europeans and Papua New Guinean sculptors. They all created their own traditions from that block of sandstone, leaving a lasting monument. I have a vivid recollection of two men, both over 70, from the Sepik district of Papua New Guinea. They had only ever worked in wood, yet they left their sculptures in that sandstone.

All those sculptors lived together for six to eight weeks while they completed their works. I went to their camps and found that, although they did not have a common language, they were able to work together. The symbolism of that is a reminder of what I am talking about: the need to make sure that our society reflects all the different cultures represented by our people at the moment. Those sculptors have left their mark in those areas. Their gift is their creativity. I know that Lawrence Beck has done all of it on the smell of an oil rag.

My purpose tonight in raising this issue, particularly as it applies to Sydney, is to point out that with the Olympics and the turn of the century coming up, there is a need for us to consider what sort of cities we want.

TALK.START.PARA: —Republican cities, Senator.

—I have a vision that we will have sculptures—of republicans or whomever else—reflecting our history, whatever it might be. I believe it is possible to integrate that into the Olympic building program.

PARA.TAB: That is why I want to emphasise that sculpture is fundamentally a large-scale art. Like opera, it needs site and space to be effective. That is exactly what we need when considering a major event like the Olympics.

But it is more than that. For example, Lawrence Beck has suggested to me that we could have a competition by way of international symposia. People could come from all parts of the world to work on a sporting sculpture theme. With the turn of the century coming up, we should also be celebrating our cultural history. Our Aboriginal sculptors could make a contribution to the longer history of Australia.

All those things are possible, not only in time for the Olympics and the turn of the century, but there is also an argument for having yearly competitions. Imagine an international symposium with all the people involved converting their blocks of stone into sculpture along a driveway. Their works could be judged by experts or by ordinary people to find the most popular contributions.

However, people will argue; there will be controversy. There is controversy at the moment over two pieces of sculpture in the Sydney area. One in the North Sydney area is a sculpture resembling a phallus, which is causing no end of discussion; and the other in another part of Sydney is a sculpture of a prostitute, which also is causing a lot of discussion.

But I think that is the very point of art; it is to make people consider their city. In my own case, I served an apprenticeship as an etcher using paintbrush and acids in the photo engraving trade. I subsequently became a union organiser where my duties brought me into daily contact with a range of artists and skilled tradesmen in the graphic arts area. I will always remember an artist saying to me that it is important to look at the world through an artist's eyes—to see the light, the colour and the form of objects.'

In those controversial things I have referred to, the point is that you have to have controversy. People do not always see what the artist has attempted to achieve. But we are all enriched if democratic discussion of artistic matters becomes part of our everyday life. It is then that everybody has the opportunity of having a say but, more particularly, we are developing Australia and the concept of what Australia is. Any form of art, particularly sculpture, has the ability to enhance our tradition, our culture and our folklore.

For those reasons, I would hope that attention is given to this issue—and this is not an election issue, I should point out—and that sculpture be given a little more help and far more consideration than it has had previously from the Australia Council, the Visual Arts Board and other people. I hope that this plea might be something that people finally will pick up. I think the concepts I have mentioned are things that could be considered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue I discuss tonight is privacy. I seek leave now to incorporate our proposals to amend the Privacy Act 1988.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The proposals read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Proposals to Amend the Privacy Act 1988
Overview of Proposed Changes
Outline of the proposed major changes to the Privacy Act 1988

PARA.TAB: expansion and strengthening of the Information Privacy Principles (IPPs) contained in the Privacy Act. Two new principles will cover acts and practices for collecting or retaining personal information, as well as the assignment and use of `unique identifiers'
extension of the application of the Act to the private sector

introduction of the concept of codes of practice which can be adopted by industry sectors. When issued by the Privacy Commissioner, the Code replaces the Act's new IPPs. Codes are disallowable instruments
exemptions from the Codes for specific activities rather than for agencies or organisations

providing that `intrusion' or other acts which adversely affects an individual's privacy can be a grounds for complaint to the Commissioner and allowing the Commissioner to develop guidelines on what constitutes intrusion or other adverse effects on privacy

SPEECH.PARA: Coverage:
The Act will provide comprehensive private sector coverage (including individuals, corporations and unincorporated associations and bodies) as well as Commonwealth agency coverage in the amended Act
The amended Act can be a model for state legislation, although it will still not cover acts or practices of state departments or agencies.
Basis for the new Information Principles

The Information Privacy Principles in this proposal reflect both international and Australian privacy reforms. The basis for the principles are the Information Privacy Principles contained in the Privacy Act 1988. Other concepts are drawn from the European Union's Directive on the Protection of Individuals with Regard to the Processing of Personal Data and On The Free Movement of Such Data, the OECD Guidelines Governing the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data, the Privacy Act 1993 (New Zealand), the `Model Code for the Protection of Personal Information' (issued by the Canadian Standards Association), and The Australian Privacy Charter.
Proposals to amend the Privacy Act 1988
Part I—Preliminary
Section 2 must be amended to indicate when the new Information Privacy Principles (IPPs) will apply to agencies and organisations.

The application of IPPs will vary between Principles. Some principles may never apply retrospectively. There is a need to determine whether and to what extent information collected by persons prior to the commencement of the amending Act must comply with the IPPs, and within what time frame.
Part 11—Interpretation
New definitions will include:
Code—means a Code of Practice issued by the Privacy Commissioner under section 27A
Organisation—includes natural persons, all corporations and unincorporated associations not covered by the definition of `agency'
Unique identifier—means an identifier

PARA.TAB: (a) that is assigned to an individual by an agency or organisation for the purposes of the operations of the agency or person; and
(b) that uniquely identifies that individual in relation to that organisation or agency; but does not include an individual's name used to identify that individual.

SPEECH.PARA: In section 7(2)—omit all the words after Freedom of Information Act 1982.
Amend Sections 7 to 13 such that

PARA.TAB: acts and practices of employees or unincorporated associations are regarded as acts of that corporation or unincorporated association;
persons who collect personal information are regarded as collectors and are responsible for all personal information under their control
persons in possession or control of records of personal information are regarded as record keepers for the purposes of the Act
a new subsection should require that agencies and organisations must designate an individual or individuals who are accountable for the organisation's compliance with the IPPs and the Act.
Acts or practices which interfere with an individual's privacy include acts and practices of organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: Part III—Information Privacy Principles
Amend the current IPPs in Section 14 where necessary to incorporate the following principles:
Principle A: Justifiable Purpose

Systems or practices for collection or retention of personal information should not be used or introduced if the dangers to privacy substantially outweigh the public interest in introducing or continuing the systems or practices.
Principle B: Collection

Collection of personal information must be for a lawful and precise purpose or purposes specified no later than the time of collection. Personal information must be collected by lawful and fair means, and not be surreptitious. The collection of personal information must be limited to that which is necessary for the purposes identified by the agency or organisation. Full notification of all purposes for collection and rights must be given to the person at the time of collection. Collection must be from the person concerned, if practicable.
Principle C: Openness
Individuals must be given details of personal data systems on request, whether or not the system contains a file concerning them.
Principle D: Security

Agencies and organisations must protect personal information by safeguards, the security of which are commensurate with the information's sensitivity and are adequate to ensure against loss, unauthorised access, unauthorised use, modification or disclosure and against other misuse.
Principle E: Information quality

Personal information must be relevant to each purpose for which it is used or disclosed and the agency or organisation must ensure it is accurate, complete and up to date when it is collected and when it is used or disclosed.
Principle F: Use and disclosure limits
Personal information must only be used or disclosed for the purpose or purposes specified at the time of collection, unless:

PARA.TAB: the person concerned has given free and informed consent to any additional use of the information
use or disclosure of the information is expressly authorised or required by law
use or disclosure of the information is reasonably necessary to prevent serious and imminent harm to life or health
use or disclosure is authorised by a Code which has been issued by the Commissioner

SPEECH.PARA: Principle G: Retention limitation
Personal information must be kept no longer than is necessary for its lawful uses, and must then be destroyed or made anonymous.
Principle H: No disadvantage

People must not have to pay in order to exercise their rights of privacy nor be denied goods or services or offered them on a less preferential basis. The provision of reasonable facilities for the exercise of these Information Privacy Principles should be a normal operating cost absorbed by the agency or organisation. An agency or organisation must not, as a condition of the supply of goods or services, require an individual to consent to the collection, use or disclosure of information beyond that required to fulfil the agency's or organisation's specific and lawful purposes.
Principle I: Anonymity

People must have the option of not identifying themselves when entering into transactions unless the nature of the transaction makes identification necessary. Agency and organisations' systems should be designed to facilitate this choice.
Principle J: Access and Correction

People must have a right to access personal information about themselves, and to obtain corrections or deletions of personal information about themselves or have their comments recorded to ensure information quality.
Principle K: Unique Identifiers

A agency or organisation must not assign a unique identifier to an individual unless that identifier is necessary to enable the agency or organisation to carry out its functions. A agency or organisation must not require an individual to disclose any unique identifier assigned to that individual unless the disclosure is for one of the purposes for which the identifier was originally assigned. An agency or organisation shall not use a unique identifier already assigned for one purpose, for another purpose, unless expressly authorised by law to do so.
Compliance
Section 16 is to be amended to include all organisations as well as agencies.
A new subsection should state that compliance must either be with the Act's IPPs in Section 14 or with a Code issued by the Commissioner under Section 27A.
A new Section 16A should define Codes' operation, as follows

PARA.TAB: A Code may modify or replace or exempt some or all of the IPPs. If the Code modifies, replaces or exempts only some of the IPPs, all other IPPs not modified, replaced or exempted by the Code are automatically included in the Code
Codes may modify the application of one or more of the IPPs by prescribing standards that are more stringent than or less stringent than the standards prescribed by the IPPs
Codes may exempt actions from the IPPs
Codes may prescribe how any or all of the IPPs are to be applied or are to be complied with.
Codes may apply in relation to
any specified agency or organisation or class of agencies or organisations
any specified industry, profession or calling
any specific act or practice
Codes are disallowable instruments under the Acts Interpretation Act.

SPEECH.PARA: A new subsection should state that activities which are exempt from the operation of the Act include personal, family or household affairs and journalistic, literary or artistic activities.
Part IV
Amend Section 20 so that appointment of the Commissioner is for a fixed, non-renewable term of seven years.
Division 2—Functions
Amendments to Section 27:
throughout the listed functions in this section, substitute the words `agency or `organisation' for `agency', or `agencies or organisations' for `agencies'.
Amend 27(l)(a) such that, after the words `Information Privacy Principle' add the words `or otherwise adversely affects an individual's privacy'
Add new functions in section 27 to include:

PARA.TAB: right of the Commissioner to make public statements on any privacy issue
development of advisory guidelines on what constitutes intrusion or other adverse effects on privacy, as grounds for complaint to the Commissioner
issuing guidelines on exemptions from the operation of the Act

SPEECH.PARA: New Section 27A on Functions of Commissioner in relation to Codes
functions should include:

PARA.TAB: issuing of Codes. Before issuing Codes which either allow lesser standards for privacy than provided by the IPPs, or exempt actions from the IPPs the Commissioner must follow the processes in Part VI for making public interest determinations.

The Commissioner may issue Codes on his/her own motion. . . Any agency or organisation can also request the Commissioner to issue a Code. If the Commissioner refuses to issue a proposed Code, he/she must advise the organisation within 60 days. The Attorney-General may also direct the Commissioner to issue a Code
monitoring compliance with Codes
investigating systems and practices in relation to Codes

SPEECH.PARA: New Subsection 27B on Functions of Commissioner in relation to Systems and Practices under Principle A
functions should include

PARA.TAB: may nominate systems or practices which require prior notification (28 days) to the Commissioner
may nominate systems or practices which require notification upon implementation
may assist agencies or organisations in designing or modifying systems or practices so they comply with Principle A
may make a Special Report to Ministers and Parliament under Section 32 in relation to systems or practices which relate to Principle A

SPEECH.PARA: Division 3: Reports by Commissioner
Amend section 32 to include provision for a Special Report to Ministers and Parliament about a system or practice the Commissioner has investigated in relation to Principle A.
Division 4: Miscellaneous
s. 35—Becomes Division 5
Create a new Division 5 which gives effect to IPP J—which is both about access to personal information and the right to have corrections either made or amended.

The current Law Reform Commission Review of FOI may make recommendations affecting the access and correction regime under FOI which have implications for privacy legislation. The Privacy Commissioner's right to handle complaints/investigate an agency's/organisation's refusal to give access/make corrections/amend records should be retained. If the FOI regime is changed, it may be appropriate to strengthen the Commissioner's powers to oversee an individual's right to access/amending records of personal information.
Part V—Investigations
This Part needs to be changed to reflect that complaints can be made against organisations as well as agencies.

Add to Section 36(l) the ability of the Commissioner to investigate complaints about intrusion and other acts or practices which have adverse effects on an individual's privacy. Also amend section 40 to allow the Commissioner to investigate acts of intrusion or other acts or practices which have adverse effects on an individual's privacy.
Amend section 36(6) to say that the respondent, for purposes of handling the complaint, is also either a corporation, principle executive of an unincorporated agency or individual person.
Enforcement of determination against persons.
New section 59A—to allow enforcement against organisations—including enforcement against corporations, unincorporated associations and individuals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Privacy is an increasingly important international issue. Article 17 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights specifically requires that individuals must not be subject to arbitrary or unlawful interference with their privacy. The European Union direction on privacy requires member states to enact privacy principles. The OECD has issued a detailed set of guidelines on the protection of transborder flows of personal information.

PARA.TAB: Closer to home, only two years ago, New Zealand extended its privacy protection rules to both public and private sectors with the passage of its Privacy Act 1993. More recently, APEC's Seoul declaration adopted in May last year has, as one of its 10 core principles, the obligation to ensure the protection of intellectual property rights, privacy and data security.

Australia does not have full privacy protection. It does, of course, have the Privacy Act 1988, and amendments have extended the act's coverage to tax file numbers and credit providers. However, its basic coverage—apart from those amendments—is only over federal government agencies. The private sector is beyond our act's reach. The public has no legislative remedy for things like data matching by private corporations, the development and abuse of mailing lists, the use of some smart cards, or intrusive telemarketing.

Australians are concerned. Recent polls commissioned by the Privacy Commissioner show that almost three-quarters of the Australian public see privacy as an important social issue. Eighty per cent of those polled not only believe that the government should legislate to protect privacy but also believe that the protection should cover both public and private sectors.

There have been many calls to expand Australia's privacy protection. The Australian Privacy Charter Council, chaired by Mr Justice Michael Kirby, adopted a Privacy Charter of basic privacy principles outlining the privacy protection that Australians should expect. The government's own broadband services expert group said that, as we move towards the world of an information superhighway, we should have better privacy protection with rules which cover both the public and the private sectors.

Papers developed for the government's National Information Services Council made a very strong point that `the new information and communication services will lead to the much more active collection and interchange of personal information'. This strong recommendation is for comprehensive privacy laws which extend the operation of the current Privacy Act to meet the challenges of the new information age. The latest annual report of the Privacy Commissioner, which was just tabled a few moments ago in this place, repeats the growing calls for comprehensive national privacy legislation.

As yet, there has been no response from either the government or the opposition to strengthen what is an inadequate level of privacy protection for Australians. The Australian Democrats strongly believe that the current level of privacy protection is simply not good enough for the Australian public as we move into the information age. Australians have a right to expect there to be controls on all information collected about them. They have a right to expect that the personal information they provide to governments and private enterprises will only be used for reasons clearly stated at the time. Also, they have a right to expect that rules about privacy protection will be monitored and enforced.

Our proposals to amend the Privacy Act 1988 will be the basis for the Privacy Amendment Bill 1996, which the Democrats will table in the next session of parliament. One of the first major changes we are proposing is the extension of privacy protection rules to the private sector. Information privacy principles will apply not only to federal government departments and agencies but also to individuals, corporations and associations in the private sector. The proposals also, however, allow industries to develop their own codes of practice which, when approved and issued by the Privacy Commissioner, can replace the act's information privacy principles. Because the codes will be disallowable instruments, all codes will come under parliamentary scrutiny.

The other major change that we propose is that there be two additional privacy principles. The first concerns the development and implementation of systems and practices for the collection or retention of information which threaten the individual's privacy. This principle will cover practices such as data matching or the development of other information gathering practices. If the Privacy Commissioner finds that there has been a breach of this principle, he or she can make a special report to the minister or the parliament. The other new principle provides protection against development of unique identifiers—or the Australia Card, by any other name.

We are tabling this proposal at least two months before our tabling of the proposed bill to allow time for public consultation and debate. We welcome any and all input and, in particular, we welcome support from all parties to ensure that Australians are guaranteed the level of privacy protection they have a right to expect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I arise to continue the third of a series of speeches to place on the public record the government's failure to deliver jobs to the long-term unemployed. The Employment, Education and Training References Committee inquiry into long-term unemployment has relied on witnesses from all over Australia. The evidence of those witnesses adds up to an indictment of the so-called Working Nation program. The clear message is that the Keating labour market intervention programs are not working; they are not delivering outcomes to the unemployed.

PARA.TAB: So far I have used evidence from the long-term unemployment report to set out real people's impressions of Working Nation. The consumer's view of this product is less than flattering. Last night I spoke about the voice of despair, the stark landscape for the long-term unemployed for 1995, and the failure of Working Nation in general. Tonight I want to underline the shortcomings of the centrepiece of Working Nation: the case management system.

The Employment Services Act 1994 established the case management system. It established the Employment Services Regulatory Authority, ESRA, as an independent statutory authority responsible for regulating the case management system.

Under this system, the CES is required to send out two notices to people who are under case management. The first letter notifies the person that they have been registered in the case management system. However, the person may have to wait for months before they actually meet up with their case manager. Sometimes later they receive another notice where they are actually referred to a specific case manager. With this system, the government can immediately inflate the number of people in case management by totalling the number of letters initially sent out—even though a large number of these people have never met a case manager—with those who are actually consulting with case managers.

One of the biggest constraints this system faces when people finally get to have a case manager is that there are more people in case management than there are adequate managers to handle them. The coalition has long been concerned that the number of clients per case manager is sometimes ridiculously high. There have been reported incidences of case managers servicing up to 200 clients each. Clients cannot expect an adequate level of attention or advice when they are competing with so many other people for their case manager's attention.

The Senate inquiry into long-term unemployment heard repeatedly from witnesses that since the introduction of case management resources are inadequate. The perception was advanced that DEET has set case loads between 125 and 250 people per case manager. These figures were given several times in evidence to the inquiry. This is indicative of the confusion and lack of realism in setting up this case management system.

This was highlighted in particular by the Auditor-General's Report No. 3 into CES case management, which revealed very serious weaknesses in the functioning of the CES. The report said this must be `very quickly' remedied `as they reduce its capacity to assist the long term unemployed'. It was evident from this report that many unemployed people have very tenuous links with their case managers and are not receiving effective service at all. The survey results were critical in their assessment of the CES case management system.

It was found that 39 per cent did not recognise that they were supposed to have a return to work plan, and yet such a plan is supposed to be a key element of the case management system. Surely if this government is failing to get across information about a key element of the Working Nation program to a large proportion of participants, there is something drastically wrong with the operation of the scheme.

The survey also found that 29 per cent of the clients had not been asked for feedback about the usefulness of elements of their return to work plan in finding employment. Also, only 57 per cent of clients in employment or study at the time of the survey indicated they did not receive post-placement support. This support is supposed to aid clients in their transition to employment or study.

Given that people who are receiving case management are the long-term unemployed, this is a group that should receive at least 100 per cent support in transition. Coming back into the work force after a two-year or longer gap, possibly after retraining, would necessarily entail a large amount of readjustment for most people.

One of the most damning findings in this report was a suggestion that, while most clients were satisfied with the length and type of contact, 30 per cent of the clients who had visited or personally contacted CES officers believed their contact was useful. Presumably, 70 per cent did not think it was useful. For such a large minority to be unhappy with the scheme indicates there are some serious problems with the CES case management system. This negative perception by clients raises questions about the skill level of some of the CES staff operating the program. A witness from our long-term unemployment inquiry said at page 96:

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the people in the CES who actually deal with clients are not skilled . . . they do not have the skills to create a rapport with a LTU person and an employer.
This harks to another issue raised in our inquiry Australia wide which was encapsulated in recommendation No. 1 of the report:
The committee recommends that mature age workers (35 and over) who become unemployed be eligible to access labour market programs within three months of becoming unemployed.

Many mature age workers feel that this early intervention is essential. Mature age and being long-term unemployed are two great barriers we have found in the inquiry to re-entry into the work force. As one witness told the committee:

We need to get to people before they become demotivated and totally debilitated. That is essential. It is no good waiting until someone has been unemployed for two years before you come along and offer some assistance.
There is clearly a need to make the whole system a lot more flexible. To quote again from the report:

. . . the system does not sit well with staff faced with a range of clients who often show contempt for the process of dividing the unemployed into groups who are eligible for immediate assistance and those who are not.

The operation of case management is an example of a sound idea being totally mishandled by this Labor government. The coalition supports proper case management but we are highly critical of the way it has been developed and managed.

PARA.TAB: The Employment Services Regulatory Authority, ESRA, has the so-called private contract arm of case management also under scrutiny. It has operated now for a year under Joan Kirner's guiding hand. Evidence to the Senate committee suggests that ESRA is creaming off the cases that can be more easily managed to secure an early employment outcome. Our support does not run to endorsing these sorts of rorts or the shambles that I have described in this speech. Case management can be improved by a coalition government. The consumers in the system, the long-term unemployed of Australia, deserve better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen J.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday it was raised by Senator Abetz that such luminaries as myself, at the time representing the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees' Association, made a contribution to the Lyons Forum inquiry into families and the economy, and it is on that subject that I want to comment tonight. It has been implied that in my appearing before the inquiry it gained credibility, and I take that compliment. But let me comment on the Lyons Forum report and its findings.

PARA.TAB: I separate the two, the report and its findings, because Senator Abetz claims that the document produced by the inquiry, Empowering Australian Families, set out in summary form a whole host of submissions put to the inquiry. I would suggest that the report does not accurately summarise the submissions made to the inquiry and the findings do not follow from much of what was submitted.

Let us start by looking at the SDA's submission. This is a submission that I spoke to in the public hearings. I must say that after contributing to those hearings I was disappointed when, rather than actually receiving a copy of the report, I chased up a copy of it and I reviewed what I felt were fairly limited contents. The SDA made a fairly extensive submission to the inquiry and there are a few points from it to which I would like to refer.In relation to its submissions on support for families, the SDA submitted that there should be reform of Australia's income, taxation, social welfare and community support systems so as to bring about a fully integrated and coherent social system that gives social justice to all Australian families.

In discussing this subject, I should also mention that the submission was presented nearly two years ago, so some things have changed in the time since. The SDA felt that the basis of such a system should involve, firstly, the recognition of the family as a basic fundamental social unit of society on which many people can agree; and, secondly, the creation of a national family policy which provides a comprehensive and integrated set of policies directed to the wellbeing of a family and its members.

The SDA said there is the need for the government to provide financial support for families by, firstly, increasing family payments to at least their 1976 real value and maintaining indexation of such payments; secondly, increasing what was at the time the spouse rebate, cashing it out and restructuring the taxation procedure so that taxation falls equally upon one income and dual income families; and, thirdly, the introduction and payment of the home makers allowance.
With respect to what was at the time the spouse rebate, the SDA said:

SPEECH.PARA: The spouse rebate is worth $27 per week prior to any changes which occurred in the 1993-94 budget. Current dual income families receive the benefit of two tax free thresholds. An increase in the value of the spouse rebate to $40 per week would remove such a bias in the tax system towards two-income families.
With respect to the work done by full-time home makers, the SDA submitted:

It is both socially and economically valuable. Apart from the care of persons young or old, home makers contribute in innumerable worthwhile activities which benefit the whole community. Because of accounting conventions the value of full-time home making does not enter calculation of GDP.
Once again, this is two years ago. I continue:

Research by Dr Duncan Ironmonger of Melbourne University shows that the real value of this work would add 30 per cent to GDP if it had to be paid for. The SDA's view was that it was time the government recognised the value of home makers work with respect to three steps that should be introduced. To have the ABS calculate the value of domestic work, to recognise the value of such work in GDP calculations and to introduce the payment of a home makers allowance.

I would ask: how do the report and its findings pertain to this submission and some of the other submissions? The SDA submission does not support income splitting, one of the major findings in the report. When I made my verbal submission I was asked, on the subject of income splitting, what the association's view would be. I raised the association's concerns with the regressive nature of income splitting. This, as with much of the content of the SDA's submission, was not summarised in the report; rather, only limited reference was made to comments on the role and value of the family which the SDA made in its submission—issues on which we can all agree.

PARA.TAB: The only other reference to the SDA submission is as a secondary source regarding Dr Ironmonger's research into the value of unpaid work. Given that the findings in the report highlighted that more work should be done on recognising the value of unpaid work, I was somewhat surprised that the inquiry did not go back to the original source of such data. The SDA got more attention paid to its views in an article on the Lyons Forum in the Age.

What does the report do? Rather than focusing on supporting and nurturing stable and secure families, in typical opposition style, it hurls blame and insult. It attacks individualism. It attacks what it terms political correctness. It attacks feminism. Ironically, the thread throughout the report is an ideology based on individual choice.
On at least this issue I agree with Bob Santamaria. Let me quote his comments on the Lyons Forum report. This was in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Santamaria pointed out the contradictions between economic rationalism, with its stress on the individual maximising his interests and pro-family rhetoric. `I resent it when people talk about giving the family priority and then pursue economic policies that cut the family's throat'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read it again.
—According to the article, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I resent it when people talk about giving the family priority and then pursue economic policies that cut the family's throat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put it in context.

—I will put it in context, as Senator Abetz requested. I will look at the macro-economic changes that the inquiry thinks are required. It refers to a tax system which recognises family commitments; for example, income splitting or family unit taxation. Secondly, it refers to tax rebates for necessary family expenditure such as child care and mortgages. This government introduced a child-care cash rebate. That is one area that has been acted upon. In relation to mortgages, it is interesting that the opposition feels that mortgages are a necessary family expenditure. What about all the families that do not have mortgages because they are in the rental market?

PARA.TAB: The next recommendation was: a tightening of the social welfare system to remove disincentive to family life and a recognition of home makers' contributions to the family. Rather than tightening the social welfare system, this government has improved the social welfare system, to recognise home makers' contributions to the family.

Another recommendation, which I have already mentioned, was the recognition of the economic value of unpaid work done in the home in the GDP figures. Let us look at what the government has done in that area. This government has made a clear commitment to include the value of unpaid work in the national accounts through the development of satellite accounts. Australia is one of only seven nations world wide to undertake a valuation of unpaid work. Further estimates will be produced following the 1997 time-use survey which the government put in place.

The government recognises the valuable contribution of parents, mostly women, who choose to remain at home to undertake unpaid caring responsibilities. Spouses of low income workers at home caring for children can receive up to $136 per week under the new parenting allowance. The basic component of the parenting allowance, which was previously the home child care allowance, is available to all spouses at home, with children, and was introduced by this government and increased by this government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too want to address the document Empowering Australian families and the wonderful work of the Lyons Forum. Whilst I can understand Senator Jacinta Collins's concern that her submission was referred to only twice in the report, it should be understood that the report is a 36-page document that had to summarise 60 submissions. I reckon the SDA got a fairly good run by being mentioned twice in a 36-page document which summarised 60 detailed submissions.

PARA.TAB: The Lyons Forum was set up in memory of the Lyons family—Prime Minister Joseph Lyons and Dame Enid Lyons, great Tasmanians. Joe Lyons was a former Premier of our home state, Mr Acting Deputy President, and a former Prime Minister. His wife, Dame Enid Lyons, became the first woman minister in a federal cabinet. In her first speech to the parliament, on 29 September 1943, she made this comment, quoting King George V:

SPEECH.PARA: The foundation of a nation's greatness is in the homes of its people.
Somebody else said words to a very similar effect in their maiden speech:
Family life is the very basis of our nationhood.
Guess who said that?

TALK.START.PARA: —P.J. Keating.
—Prime Minister Keating. On the basic fundamentals, there is no difference between the view taken by the late Dame Enid Lyons and the current Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: The Lyons Forum was established by people who believed that, by helping to strengthen family life by building strong, functional families, we will strengthen our nation from the foundation up. That is the purpose of this organisation.

Senator Collins has followed the strategy of Minister Crowley by reading through this document and saying that certain matters have been recommended by the Lyons Forum. We need to look at the executive summary. The submissions and presentations raised many concerns. A number of prominent concerns are listed.

What astounds me is that the Labor Party cannot welcome the Lyons Forum as a genuine attempt to raise with the government the plight of families. Sure, they can disagree on different strategies on how to protect the family. Sure, they can disagree with all of us who are in the Lyons Forum or in the coalition. They could say, `We agree,' or, `we disagree.' It is the manic feminist ideology of Senator Crowley and some of her colleagues that blinds them to the aspirations of the vast majority of women in this country.

Some of the assertions that have been made are simply not correct. The Lyons Forum heard 60 submissions, dealt with them in detail and, as a result, made some recommendations and some suggestions as to how these matters could be addressed. The actual report is concerned about family life. Sure, we can argue about the best tax system and the best social policy system, but why not acknowledge the basic fundamentals—that here is a group of people genuinely concerned about the family unit and wanting to achieve something for that family unit and for our society?

Only 14 days ago we on this side, and indeed the Australian people, had highlighted to us the sort of campaign that Labor was going to embark upon for the 1996 election. We have that courtesy of the South Australian trade union movement, who said that they were going to embark upon a campaign of fear and loathing.

Mr Acting Deputy President, as I am sure you would recognise as well, if you have a deliberate policy of embarking upon fear and loathing, then rational argument, honest argument, sincere argument and genuine concern for the Australian people just go straight out the window because all you want to achieve is the fear and loathing of your opponent by the Australian people. So the engaging of your opponent in honest debate to see if you can tease out issues where there might, in fact, be agreement is just thrown out the window and discarded because all the Labor Party want to do is embark upon this campaign of fear and loathing.

So, when we talk about tax and when we talk about industrial relations—and now we even have it in relation to family policy—they will pursue a campaign of fear and loathing. That is their tactic, that is their raison d'etre, in this coming election campaign, because they have nothing to offer from the other side but to target the coalition with a campaign of fear and loathing and hope that people will be scared.

The Labor Party did that very effectively in the last election with their campaign against the GST. But, of course, when you analyse the figures, you find that the people of Australia are now paying $7,700 million in indirect taxes under the Keating government more than they would have under Hewson, without all the benefits that the Hewson policy would have provided to them. So I believe that the people of Australia are now a wake-up that a simple campaign of fear and loathing is not going to work again, because they got tricked once. They got tricked and tricked very badly. They were promised less indirect tax and they got even more than this loathsome GST that Mr Keating campaigned against so very heavily.

I am proud to be associated with the Lyons Forum, as are very many other members of the Liberal and National parties. I believe the fact that Ms Jacinta Collins, as she was in those days—now Senator Collins—made a contribution to the Lyons Forum inquiry was an indication of the seriousness with which the hearing was treated by her and her trade union. They made a submission. It was factored in. It got recognised. Just because all of their policies and suggestions were not adopted does not detract from the very basis of the inquiry, which was to look after the best interests of the family unit.

I would have thought that people on the other side would have welcomed a social policy outlook that encouraged the Australian population to get the focus off the self-centred aspect and on to a more social awareness concept of society through the family. I would have thought Senator Jacinta Collins and the Labor Party would be the first ones to embrace that and say, `As part of our socialist objectives, we have never believed in the me-centred approach to life.' But here we are witnessing Senator Collins criticising the Lyons Forum because we are encouraging people to go away from the me-centred approach to social policy to a more family and society oriented approach to social policy. I do not resile from that. Our society has been too selfish in the past. I recommend the report. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish tonight to speak again on matters which I have certainly spoken on before in this chamber. I wish to do this because there are so many issues related to the whole issue of whistleblowers and the Senate inquiry that I was recently a part of. It was clear from the enormous number of submissions that the committee received from the outset of its inquiry that there are many people in Australia who believe that they are not being listened to. The Senate and its committees try to perform that role, but it is not always possible.

PARA.TAB: As I said in a speech last night, the Senate Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases was unable to examine many of the submissions we received. I did read many of them and met with some people so that I could hear their cases in more detail. One of the first things that struck me when the first whistleblowing committee, the Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing, began its inquiry—indeed, I found it quite astonishing—was the extent and depth of animosity expressed towards the CJC by so many Queensland people who saw themselves as whistleblowers.

The story which these people told had a common theme: strong disillusionment with the treatment that they had received from the CJC. This did not simply relate to the fact that the complaints they brought to the CJC about the actions of various government instrumentalities were not investigated or acted upon, or were not upheld. Their concerns were as much to do with the treatment they received from the CJC—how they were made to feel as though they were the wrongdoers, or that their concerns were not worth proper examination, or that they were just crazy people who should do everyone a favour and disappear.

This is the treatment which whistleblowers or aggrieved people usually get from the department they feel has wronged them; it should not be the treatment they receive from the body that is supposed to investigate complaints. I am not suggesting that the CJC should unreservedly agree with the grievances of all people. Some grievances are clearly frivolous. I am talking as much about the process followed as I am about particular complaints.

This impression was strongly reinforced by the extremely antagonistic approach that the CJC took to the Senate committee itself from the very outset of the inquiry. My usual response to this sort of behaviour is to ask myself: what have they got to hide? This was also a common response of many people who made submissions to the inquiry.

One case which the unresolved whistleblower committee was not able to examine and which I will mention tonight is that of Mr James Egan, a dairy farmer from the Beaudesert area south of Brisbane. Mr Egan presented the CJC with evidence of serious misconduct in the dairy industry, stretching through the 1980s up until 1990. The allegations which Mr Egan raised were the same as those raised in this chamber some 10 years ago by former Labor senator John Black and in the lower house on a number of occasions around the same time by the member for Rankin, Mr Beddall, and the former member for Hinkler, Mr Courtice.

Whilst the Queensland Labor Party was happy at the time to point to these dubious activities as evidence of cronyism in the state National Party government, when it gained office itself the new Labor government ignored its own policy commitment to fully investigate these allegations, choosing instead to let sleeping dogs lie. The allegations were also given widespread media coverage back in the 1980s. Indeed, I understand the well-known and widely respected journalist Paul Bongiorno won a Walkley award for his coverage of this scandal.

Whilst the relevant legislation has now been changed to prevent the continuation of these dubious practices, the legality of the practices and the actions of the people involved in them have never been properly investigated. Some of the people who profited from the allegedly illegal practices still hold important positions in the dairy industry in Queensland.

The CJC's response when Mr Egan presented it with the allegations and supporting evidence was to inform him that the allegations related to things that happened too long ago and it would cost too much of its limited resources to investigate it, with little likelihood of any successful prosecution at the end of it. Dissatisfied with this, Mr Egan went to the Parliamentary Criminal Justice Committee, the PCJC, which monitors the activities of the CJC.

The PCJC informed the CJC that the allegations `are of a serious nature and deserve a full and proper investigation'. It requested the CJC to reconsider the matter and conduct a proper investigation. The CJC refused this request and to reinforce this spent some money on hiring a QC to provide a legal opinion saying that the PCJC could not tell it what to do. So much for its limited resources!

I agree with the PCJC that these allegations are serious enough to warrant proper investigation and I call on the CJC to reconsider once again its action on this issue. As the allegations are somewhat lengthy and have been canvassed previously in this chamber, although some time ago, I will not detail them further tonight. Instead at a later time I will seek leave of the Senate to table related documentation.

I agree with the subsequent recommendation of the PCJC, flowing from this case, that the relevant legislation in Queensland should be amended to enable the PCJC to direct the CJC to investigate a particular issue. Such a direction could be required to be a unanimous one to prevent partisan political inquiries occurring. The CJC argues that this would compromise its independence from parliament. I cannot see how this would be the case.

It would certainly be inappropriate for the parliament to direct the CJC not to investigate particular allegations, but I cannot see why it is inappropriate for a parliamentary committee to make a unanimous direction for an allegation to be examined. I see this as a suitable check to enable some sort of reciprocal accountability from the CJC. Whilst the CJC is crucial in ensuring state government bodies are accountable in Queensland, it also needs to be publicly accountable. The PCJC, or its equivalent, is the obvious body to perform this role.

The Queensland government's unreasonable tightening of freedom of information laws has also demonstrated that government's lack of commitment to openness and accountability—one of the reasons it received such a caning at the recent state election. Indeed, Mr Egan has now spent a number of years unsuccessfully trying to access documents relating to how his original complaint was dealt with.

The Labor Party's ascension to power in Queensland in 1989 was predominantly achieved on a wave of public support for reform. The people of Queensland were sickened by the entrenched corruption which was partly exposed by the Fitzgerald Inquiry. The voters turned to Labor with the hope that real changes would result that would transform the system that had become so discredited. I was one of a great many Queenslanders who believed that change was essential to ensure that real reform could be achieved.

One of the reforms to come out of the Fitzgerald inquiry was the establishment of the Criminal Justice Commission. I strongly supported its establishment as an independent body that would have the ability to deal with misconduct and maladministration. It was seen as somewhere that people could turn to—a place where their concerns would be given a fair hearing. However, for the CJC to be effective it must have the confidence and support of the vast majority of the public. The concern I have is that this support is now not as strong as it should be. The CJC must acknowledge this and look to itself for at least some of the reasons. It must not become a mirror image of the unresponsive, antagonistic and unaccountable bureaucracies which it is meant to police.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the importance of Australia's traditional cultural heritage and its place on the international stage. In April and May this year, a company of 30 tribal dancers, songpersons, musicians and painters from the Northern Territory travelled to the United States for a three-week tour. Called Dancers of the Dreaming, they performed in California, Arizona and Texas, receiving rave reviews and a letter from Texas governor, George Bush, urging them to `come back soon'.

PARA.TAB: So why is this group so well-known abroad and not at home? The blame rests squarely with the federal Labor government. Despite recognition and acclaim from the US to Europe, the company does not fit existing federal funding guidelines and therefore must rely on the generosity of its overseas sponsors. That is an embarrassing situation for all Australians.

I will go into detail later on, but first I want to pay tribute to the organisers—the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation—who remained committed to the tour despite seemingly impossible odds. The Darwin-based Aboriginal Cultural Foundation was set up in the early 1970s to support Aboriginal cultures under the control of traditional owners and managers. Governed by an all tribal executive committee drawn from across northern Australia and the desert regions, the foundation has strong support at the grassroots level.

Its aims include promoting and protecting the rights of Aboriginal groups and clans to control their own ceremonies, to help provide instruction, and to organise presentations to the wider community. In fact, the foundation started planning the Dancers of the Dreaming tour five years ago in collaboration with universities in California, Arizona and Texas and the San Antonio Festival. Eight United States representatives flew to Darwin to meet with the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation in 1990. They then travelled to the Tanami Desert and to north-east Arnhem Land to see dancing and singing in a ceremonial context and to discuss the possibility of a tour.

Finally, in 1995, the foundation assembled three distinct cultural groups for the tour which, together, would convey the richness and scope of indigenous heritage in northern Australia. The 1995 Dancers of Dreaming tour included people from communities along the east coast of Arnhem Land, from Gapuwiyak, also known as Lake Evella, in the north to Ngukurr, also known as the Roper River, in the south; the interior of the territory, through the Warlpiri people from Lajamanu, also known as Hooker Creek, in the Tanami Desert; and Tiwi dancers and singers from Bathurst Island.
As the executive officer of the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation, Lance Bennett, wrote to me recently:

SPEECH.PARA: The aim was to present audiences with something as near as possible to the experience of being in northern Australia at the exact time that these dances and songs happened to be being performed as an actual ceremonial episode, in the daily life of the people.

To provide that experience was the aim of the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation, and the clan leaders were very sympathetic to this goal. First, extended discussions of this project took place out in the remote communities, among the clan leaders and the senior dancers and songpersons. The membership of the dance company, and the broad parameters of the program content, were decided out there in the field.

Then, the dancers came together in Darwin for a full week prior to the tour and rehearsed intensively. The dance and song content was finalised during this week and the commentary was agreed upon. On the technical side, the lighting plot for the production was also fine tuned.

The subsequent tour—which included Tucson and Phoenix in Arizona, San Antonio and Austin in Texas, and Los Angeles—drew enthusiastic comments, reviews and even a standing ovation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a review that appeared in the Los Angeles Times on 5 May this year.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Los Angeles Times
Friday, May 5, 1995/F15
Aboriginal Culture Endures in `Dreaming'
Dance Review

PARA.TAB: Covered in white and ocher face and body paint over a thick paste that makes them look like ancient mud figures come to life, dancers of the Northern Australian Territory re-enact a mythic odyssey ("The Wallaby Dreaming") a world away from the Tanami Desert that is their home.

Accompanied by deep-toned singing and the rhythmic clack of wooden boomerangs, they walk heavily, wearily, with long boomerangs held across their shoulders, re-creating a journey of a thousand miles in only a few minutes.

Representing the oldest continuous living cultures on Earth, they joined two other, unrelated but equally venerable Australian Aboriginal groups in "Dancers of the Dreaming" at the Wadsworth Theater on Wednesday. (The performance was originally scheduled to take place outdoors but was relocated due to the cold weather.)

The program was organized to make Americans aware of the great diversity and depth of Aboriginal expression—encompassing everything from vibrant animal dances and meditative ceremonies that may date back 50,000 years to ritualizations of comparatively recent events.

For example, the Tiwi Islands contingent from the North West Northern Territory presents "The Bombing of Darwin, 1942," recalling their role in warning against a Japanese attack plus helping in defense and rescue efforts. Typically, they compress and distil the subject in key sounds and images, combining what we might call a child-like purity of concept with a powerful, adult physicality. This is dance deeply rooted in history and in the landscape, dance central to a society's sense of itself.

When the dancers of Eastern Arnhem Land, Northern Territory, bound forward to the edge of the sand-covered stage, their stamping feet dig deep, and, in one sequence of restless twisting, crouching, clawing motions from "The Garnbulabula Spirit Beings," they confront the audience with images of violent death and a sky soaked in blood—not exactly affirming our sentimental notions of indigenous cultures' "oneness with nature."

Laced with humor—including the Tiwi group's parody of bad dancers—the program approaches the audience with the authority and patience of a master teacher, one who recognises both the importance of the subject and how much a beginning student can be expected to absorb and appreciate. As a model for world dance touring presentations, "Dancers of the Dreaming" is in many, many ways a dream come true.

SPEECH.PARA: -LEWIS SEGAL

TALK.START.PARA: —By contrast, I turn to the plight of traditional cultural heritage in this country and the funding battles that beset the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation in Darwin. Take this latest tour, for example. The foundation had to struggle for five years to come up with a paltry $7,000 from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Arts Board of the Australia Council. ATSIC provided nothing. Eventually the cultural counsellor at the Australian embassy in Washington contributed $10,000. I am sorry to say that that was the extent of the Australian contribution. The remainder of the $US200,000 was raised in the United States.

PARA.TAB: At the University of Texas, for example, the College of Fine Arts and the Performing Arts Centre were joined by UT Athletics in an unprecedented joint push to raise funds for our performers. In other words, they raised money for Australians to represent the heritage of Australia because we could not afford to do it.

The federal Labor government—in particular, ATSIC and the Australia Council—must take responsibility for this sorry state of affairs. They effectively turned their back on our heritage and these Australian performers. They effectively made a mockery of their own arts and culture policies, notably Creative Nation. This situation is a stark example of Labor's preoccupation with Melbourne and Sydney at the expense of the rest of the country.

Now that the Dancers of the Dreaming are back in Australia and continuing to receive messages from the United States, the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation is again battling for financial survival. For some reason the Aboriginal Arts Board declines to fund the foundation, since the Australia Council only funds `new art'. In other words, this country's traditional cultural heritage does not fit into their neat funding guidelines and falls by the wayside.

For its part, the Australia Council insists that ATSIC should provide funding support for traditional culture. But ATSIC wants to focus on new technology such as broadcasting, not heritage. The tragedy is that no-one in the federal government or, for that matter, ATSIC, gives priority to our traditional cultural heritage. Australia is allowing a cultural resource to slip into obscurity. Well may Texas governor George Bush write to the Dancers of the Dreaming wishing them `continued success in the future and come back soon'. I seek leave to table that letter, along with a proclamation by the Mayor of Austin, Texas, and a letter of appreciation from a Los Angeles inner city arts project.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reality is that the federal government has starved this company of funding and they may never return to the United States. I trust that it is not too late for the federal government to reassess its national and international priorities and act in the best interests of Australia's artistic and cultural future.

—I wanted to table a report before the Senate this evening but, quite understandably, I was not given leave to do so because the report is quite a heavy document. So instead I will just speak about it.
—I will give you leave.

—That is very kind of you, Senator Crichton-Browne, but I think I might need a few others to give me leave. This is a rather long report, so what I am proposing to do is just talk about the report today and, when I have been given leave to table it, I will do that at another time.
—Would you like me to read it for you?

—I know you have good experience in that, and I may well do that myself. But I will put that action off for the moment and give my colleagues a chance to consider it while I get advice about tabling it in the future. The report details the operations of the Rimbanan Hijau Company and other businesses controlled by the Malaysian Tiong family.

PARA.TAB: The Tiong family companies have come to dominate the timber industry in Malaysia and Papua New Guinea. Their companies are now expanding rapidly throughout the Asia-Pacific region. Rimbanan Hijau means `green lushness' in Bahasa Malay, and its publicity material claims that the name reflects the group's `green' conviction and care for the natural environment and the ecosystem. My colleagues will be well aware of why I am interested in this matter and the activities of the company.

Sadly, the company's name is a gross misnomer. The report that I was hoping to table tonight analyses the environmental and human rights abuses of a wide and very complex web of companies established and controlled by the same family. Many of these companies are formally linked with Rimbanan Hijau.

The report notes the conflict between the indigenous people and logging interests in Sarawak, Malaysia. It further reports on the massive overcutting in the forests of Sarawak. In 1990, for example, when logging was at its peak, some 494,700 hectares of forest were logged out. In many cases, the indigenous people only found out that their lands had been licensed to a timber company when the bulldozers arrived to put in a logging road. The report lists a variety of human rights violations by the Rimbanan Hijau Company in its operations in Sarawak.

The report goes on to detail the operations of Rimbanan Hijau in the forests of Papua New Guinea. In just 10 years, Rimbanan Hijau and its related companies have taken control of 50 per cent of Papua New Guinea's timber industry. The crisis that has beset the logging industry in this country is detailed in the report.

There is special mention in the report of the use of transfer pricing in the logging industry of Papua New Guinea. Here, the logging companies operate a cooperative arrangement with their overseas buyers. The logging companies officially `sell' the logs for a price which is below market value to an intermediary, who then sells the log on to a final customer at the true price. The difference between the two prices is held in trust in a tax haven—usually Hong Kong—and divided between the logging company and its company and its customer. Transfer pricing allows companies to declare a loss in Papua New Guinea yet make massive profits offshore. The report suggests that Rimbanan Hijau is heavily implicated in this type of practice in Papua New Guinea.

Plentiful evidence is provided in the report to show that this company has repeatedly and wilfully broken its permit conditions and national laws in Papua New Guinea. Environmental problems include such activities as river pollution, felling in buffer zones, coral reef destruction, pollution of drinking water, felling of undersized logs and logging of protected species. The list goes on. The report also cites a number of legal misdemeanours, including falsifying legal documents, bribing shareholders and breaking a court injunction, to name but a few. It also notes that some logging operations have destroyed graves and sacred sites.

Finally, the report lists some of the investments of the Tiong family in New Zealand, the Solomon Islands and, last but not least, Australia. I believe that this is a matter in the public interest. It is one of grave environmental concern at not just a local but a global level. I hope that it will be possible for me to put the report on the public record so that it can become a catalyst for a closer scrutiny of the operations that these companies partake in. I hope that it also serves as an example and a trigger to curtail the operations of logging companies which conduct unscrupulous activities and violate the environment in the Asia-Pacific region.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak about two issues that are very important to the community, to the extent that they have expended a lot of energy in collecting signatures on petitions for tabling in the Senate today and tomorrow. The first is on landmines. With the assistance of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, Australian Catholic Relief and the Christian Centre for Social Action, they have collected 14,579 signatures. They request the government to push for a total ban on landmines and implement a domestic ban also.

PARA.TAB: This is a big issue in the community. It is an issue that cuts across all political parties, although it has not yet broken the party line. The addition of 14,579 signatures brings the total collection in the last three months to 239,275 signatures—almost a quarter of a million people. There are few petitions that have been delivered to this parliament which have had the level of public support that has been demonstrated by this.

People are very concerned about this issue on the basis of human rights, defective military strategy and damage to the environment. One thousand people are killed or maimed every month by landmines. It is a human rights issue. People are also concerned at the example that landmines have become of a trend in conventional warfare to target civilians instead of the military. The rules of war have changed and so have the players. Maimed people are seen as a strategy to burden a country with bigger compensation and health payments and a reduced economic output.

Landmines damage the environment and create a staggering refugee problem for people who cannot retain their self-sufficient agrarian lifestyles. The amount of arable land abandoned due to the destruction imposed by landmines is enormous. In Angola, eight to nine million people cannot be repatriated on their lost agricultural land and many people have starved. In Afghanistan, for example, where 350,000 people have died from landmine blasts, this has created 3.5 million Afghan refugees. At the present rate of clearing, it is estimated it will take a further 4,300 years to clear the remaining mines so that people can resume normal lives. The situation creates a refugee problem that many other countries have to deal with. However, in many cases, they are an active part of the source of the problem in the first place by producing, selling and using landmines.

There is no doubting how cruel and indiscriminate landmines are. Many of them cost between $US1 and $US3 to make. Mines may be cheap and nasty to manufacture but each mine costs about $1,000 to remove in a dangerous and painstaking process. Many are non-detectable because they are made solely of plastic and disguise themselves as a child's toys, as balls, plates, apples and saucepans. There is no recording or marking of mines and they are scattered widely and indiscriminately. They are also not self-neutralising and may last decades after a war is over.

World wide, there are 85 million to 100 million landmines in 62 countries. There are 95 manufacturers in 43 countries manufacturing landmines. Countries involved include the United States, the UK, Japan, Singapore, Korea, Germany, Italy, France, Sweden and Switzerland.

So how should the government best respond to community concern to achieve a total ban on landmines at home and abroad? The government's current strategy has failed. They have taken a compromise position in pushing for a partial ban that is expensive, a technological fix, unworkable for developing countries and more difficult to implement than a total ban would be. At the last meeting of the Vienna Review Conference on the Inhumane Weapons Convention, countries could not agree by consensus on such an approach.

Our government needs to give up on this strategy and strive for the only strategy that is achievable—that is, a total ban. If the government proceeds with a partial ban it will be toadying to powerful, rich states like the United States which are against the banning of all landmines because of the excuse of `national security'.

We cannot ignore the fact that a partial ban on landmines would do nothing to reduce civilian casualties during war and post-conflict, before demining operations begin. A partial ban would merely aid demining operations after conflict. I have already mentioned how many years that takes to make any impact. Demining is also a selective service given out by first world nations to third world victims of conflict.

The Australian government, to meet community concerns, has recently moved towards the position of a total ban. They now concede that a total ban is an ultimate goal. The government needs to go further, as evidenced by the popular support given to this issue by the community. They need to be committed to working for a total ban in their strategies and tactics for the next review conference in April 1996.

I now turn to another set of petitions that will be tabled tomorrow, Thursday. There are 1,491 signatures from the Imagine Australia campaign calling for an end to Australian involvement in the US bases, Pine Gap and Nurrungar. They call on political representatives to serve to the United States in 1995 a formal notice to quit on the peppercorn leases of Nurrungar and Pine Gap. They do not want the leases renewed with the US in any circumstances and want total withdrawal of support and personnel from the bases. Their suggestion is to redirect the $100 million spent on the bases annually into environmental rehabilitation and job creation.

These signatures have been collected by one woman who has worked tirelessly since 1993 to obtain these approximately 1,500 signatures. These petitions are very timely as we near the national notice to quit protest campaign in Canberra from 1 December to 3 December. This protest will be calling for a notice to quit the bases, notice to quit our part of the nuclear cycle and French nuclear testing and notice to quit Australia's military involvement in the proxy wars of East Timor and Bougainville in particular. The community will be arriving in Canberra for the weekend of actions and honourable senators should lend their active support to this gathering in any way they can.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)
