I would like to put that on the record, not that I expect leave not to be given in perpetuity. Indeed, leave may well be granted after there has been time to consider Senator Chamarette's document.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—It might be worthwhile, Minister, your mentioning the matter formally to the Deputy President, who chairs the Procedure Committee, so that she might be able to take it to that committee for investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition also had some problems with the presentation of all those documents tonight. The whip has told me that we will be taking our time to look at these documents and will make a decision tomorrow, if she wants to do something about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I am prompted to rise tonight because, in the other place last night, the member for Moore, Mr Filing, attacked the party to which I was very attracted for a quarter of a century. I am not aware of anybody rising within the Liberal Party to respond. I notice that Mr Filing said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Western Australian Liberal Party has allowed its affairs in its north metropolitan organisation to be dominated by people who had contributed towards what is an organised criminal operation.
It is amazing how things must have deteriorated since my time.

PARA.TAB: As an ex-policeman, Mr Filing would know something about organised crime, although when he resigned from the police force in an abortive attempt to enter parliament, the police department would not have him back. Perhaps he should have applied for New South Wales, where he would have fitted in very well.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator Crichton-Browne is quite able to come in here and make comments, but I think that was a reflection upon a person in the other place. I think he should be asked to withdraw. When he said that he should have been in the New South Wales police force, it really was a reflection on a person in the other place, I thought.
—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—I would be pleased if you would speak to the point of order, because I mustn't have heard it properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that Mr Filing would fit very well in the New South Wales police force. The Deputy Whip of the opposition has problems with that. People join that New South Wales police force every day. I don't think you can say that is a reflection on a member of parliament, any more than you can say it is a reflection on the New South Wales police force. It is a very reasonable observation to make.
—I will ask you to continue, but I will try to keep both ears towards you at this stage.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I find it offensive that Mr Filing would make those allegations about a party whose endorsement he desperately sought very recently. They contrast rather quaintly with the fact that recently he scrutineered the results of one of his own branches in that electorate, the Joondalup branch in the northern suburbs. He was provided with the results by the returning officer and asked to pass them on to the divisional secretary. But in the process, he had them typed up in his own office and changed the result to one which materially benefited him and benefited his prospects of preselection.

PARA.TAB: It is not without consequence to observe that, when Mr Filing first sought endorsement for the seat of Moore, he was contested by Mr Ian Viner QC. Mr Ian Viner QC, interestingly, got one vote. He seemed to be the only person who did not know he was not going to win. Mr Viner QC then appealed against Mr Filing on the basis that Mr Filing had corruptly sought to induce one of the delegates to cast a vote in his—Mr Filing's—favour on the basis that he would provide him with employment in the event he was successful.

I must say that, while Mr Viner presented a statutory declaration to the appeal committee, he was unsuccessful. My difficulty is that I do not know who I believe—Mr Filing or Mr Viner—except to say that, as a result of Mr Viner recently stealing information from a court file and then passing it around to members of parliament, including Mr Eoin Cameron, I do not know who I would trust. But I find it offensive for Mr Filing to be attacking the Liberal Party in the way he has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to come in here tonight to make some very short comments with regard to the speech Mr Paul Filing made yesterday in the House of Representatives. I want to place on the record my disappointment and disgust at the gutless accusations that he has made under parliamentary privilege. I challenge him to go out into the public arena and say the things he said about such people as Cheryl Edwardes, our Attorney-General, and others in the Western Australian government at this particular time. It is a gutless act. I suspect that most of it is totally dishonest. At the time when Paul Filing stood for preselection for Moore back in, I think, 1989, I also stood for that preselection.
—For Moore?

—For Moore, and I lost. I then went out and worked for Paul Filing with my uncle, Bert Crane, who had been a member of the Western Australian Parliament for the seat of Moore for some 15, 16, 17 years and who often said that he was the only member of the Western Australian parliament who beat everybody. He was in the Country Party to begin with, then after what occurred there he became a Liberal. That is a factual statement. In 1993 I also worked in that electorate for him and assisted him on a number of functions and with a lot of doorknocking.

PARA.TAB: This speech I call a very gutless speech, attacking Richard Court in the context in which he has done. Shortly before Court became Premier of Western Australia, when Carmen Lawrence was Premier, unemployment was 2.1 per cent above the national average. It is now nearly 2 1/2 per cent below the national average. Western Australia has by far the lowest unemployment rate of any state. Under his government's stewardship Western Australia now has a trading surplus of almost $10 billion. Compare that with the current account deficit of this nation of some $27 billion and consider the turnaround there has been. I believe this of every Western Australian—I do not care whether they are Liberal or Labor or Independent: to attack in such a cowardly way, the way this man, Paul Filing, has attacked, the Western Australian Liberal Party and for him to say—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you reckon he will win the seat?
—You just sit down and listen for a while. It will do you good. You don't do much listening in this place. You do wonderfully well at interjecting and are thick between the ears:

PARA.TAB: As someone who has observed and participated in the milieu of these events, I can only marvel at how easy this state of affairs has come to pass, how the Western Australian Liberal Party has allowed its affairs in its north metropolitan organisation to be dominated by people who had contributed towards what is an organised criminal operation.

SPEECH.PARA: This man should be gaoled for having made that comment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise two matters: firstly, to expand a little on some remarks I made earlier about the Queensland AWU secretary and national AWU president, Mr Bill Ludwig, who, as I mentioned earlier, appointed his son to a job in the union. I have no objection to that but I am told by dissident elements in the union who are very unhappy with Mr Ludwig's leadership that when the union's minute secretary, Lyn Hewlett, pointed out that this appointment had not been approved and was therefore in breach of union rules, Mr Ludwig pointed to the motion empowering his predecessor to hire an Aboriginal trainee and indicated that that was close enough for him.

PARA.TAB: The fact that his son was not an Aboriginal person and that this action denied access to the job to someone who was an Aboriginal person and whose wages would be subsidised by the federal government did not seem to worry the AWU. It is sort of harking back to the roots of the old AWU, which was an historic bedrock of the ALP White Australia policy, which found its embodiment in its 1890 racist anti-Chinese and anti-Kanaka history. I suppose it is ironic that at the same time the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is protesting about Mr Graeme Campbell and his alleged racism.

I am not going to go into the details of the internal battles going back over many years involving Mr Ludwig, although there are clear examples of what appear to be most unfortunate standover tactics, particularly in relation to some senior women employees. I should just mention one of those because it does raise matters of concern. An employee, Janine Walker, had this to say in a letter, part of which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: On Tuesday, August 30th, you spoke to me in your office and indicated to me that you wanted me to appoint Deidre Swan as one of my proxies to the Administrative Committee of the A.L.P. I told you at that time that I had appointed only one of the two proxies allowed me under Party Rules and that I was happy to appoint Deidre as my other proxy. You would note that I complied with your direction within a matter of an hour or two. I asked you during that meeting if you had any other directions you wished to indicate to me or if, indeed, you had any problems with me or my work—
she was a secretary there—

I understood you to respond in the negative to those questions and we had a full and frank discussion on a number of matters, including your wish to see Deidre `rehabilitated' within the Union, as you put it. You stated to me that it was your view that I had `taken' Deidre's position on the Administrative Committee.

My response was that I understood that the ticket supported by the Union at the last Conference was one drawn up by the then Branch Secretary of the Union and that my name was placed on the ticket by the Branch Secretary. Rather than `taking' someone's position, I had followed the direction of the Branch Secretary. You indicated that you concurred with that view of events and retracted the accusation that I had `taken' the position to which I was elected.
Our discussion ended on an amicable note and I assured you of my continued loyalty to the Union and to you, the Branch Secretary.

Last Monday, September 12th, you spoke to me in my office and indicated that Deidre would attend that evening's regular meting of the Administrative Committee. I pointed out to you that I was free and planned to attend myself and would not require a proxy. You put it to me very bluntly that I was not to attend this meeting or any other meetings of the Committee at any time. You repeated the view that the position I hold `belongs' to Deidre.
She then said:
Both of our conversations on that day were difficult and unpleasant—your attempts to `stand over' me were crude and I found them personally distressing.

Bill, I am resigning because I do not believe that I can continue in the employment of the Union and remain subject to the bullying and threats to which I was subjected last Monday. If this is the way in which you propose to deal with your staff as Branch Secretary and to conduct the administration of the Union then I do not wish to continue in your employ.
There is one further paragraph I should mention:

I further believe that your direction to me not to attend meetings of the Administrative Committee is a most unfair one. As an elected member of that Committee, I am not subject, under the Rules of the Party, to any outside direction in relation to my attendance i.e. I am not a `delegate' appointed by a Party Unit such as the Union. The Party Rules provide that a member of the Administrative Committee who fails to attend meetings persistently without a satisfactory explanation is subject to being reported for such non-attendance to the State Council. Your assurance that that Rule `will be all right' gives me no reassurance at all. Compliance with your direction would leave me open to denigration, ridicule and disciplinary measures in the forums of the Party.

I raise that just to mention the sort of union rule that exists in the AWU, which is a central union in, of all things, the Weipa matter, the Mount Isa disaster or whatever industrial chaos you want to look at at the moment. No wonder workers do not want to be part of that union and have that union allegedly look after their interests. No wonder so many people who were working under CRA preferred to make their own arrangements and their own direct negotiations with the company—which involved getting them more money than the union would have been able to get for them anyway.

PARA.TAB: This leads me to the central piece of what I was concerned about in relation to Mr Ludwig: the people in his union are voting with their feet and, no matter what sorts of props the state Labor government in Queensland or the federal Labor government in Canberra try to put under this decaying element of the union movement, the workers of Australia will not have a bar of this kind of standover tactic and self-interested union leadership.

These old-fashioned union bosses have no role in Australia's future. I speak as one of the very few people on this side of the chamber who have been on the state executive of their union. I do not object to unions. I think unions have an excellent and important role to play, but the people who have been running Australian unions have, in some instances like this one, damaged the status and integrity of the unions.

Since my comments about Mr Ludwig earlier today and the alarming drop in his union's membership in Queensland, I have been sent the most realistic guide to the number of members held by the Queensland AWU in the form of the election returns from the electoral office ballot held last August. These official figures show that Mr Ludwig's claims last week of having 80,000 union members appear to be absolute nonsense. Only something like 53,323 names and addresses of voters were actually submitted to the Electoral Commission. Something like 8,280 were apparently sent to a previous address and a further 3,736 had no address at all. I have not shown this to the minister at the table, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht). I will not seek to have it incorporated, but I will seek to have it tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is it?

—They are Australian Workers Union election statistics as at 17 August 1995. Unfortunately, it does not have the name of the Commonwealth Electoral Commission on the document. I will not proceed to even seek leave in that event. I note that it shows Mr Ludwig now has only 41,307 genuine members left in Queensland, not the 80,000 he has been speaking about. This might be why so many people within the union are moving against Mr Ludwig, as I outlined earlier, when I revealed the letter from the Victorian secretary who is moving to require him to resign at the next meeting of the national executive.

PARA.TAB: What is interesting to note is that Queensland has only 41,307 members as against New South Wales, which has 43,387. Queensland used to be the heart and soul of that union, which now has only 141,173 members spread throughout Australia. I simply want to say this about Mr Ludwig and his union: if there were to be an efficient, well-run AWU that recognised the merit of allowing workers to come to the best possible deal with their employers which would be in the workers' best interests, that would be fine. But it is not good enough to have a union run by a union boss who prefers to stand over people.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What development cooperation commitments has the Australian Government entered into with other countries for each budgetary year from the 1996-97 financial year up to and including the 2000-2001 financial year.
(2) Can the forward commitments be provided by country, value, project and the nature of the agreement through which the assistance was pledged.

(3) What contractual arrangements has the Australian Government entered into under the Development Import Finance Facility for each year of the budgetary years from 1996-97 financial year until the 2000-2001 financial year.

(4) Can the total amount contracted for each budgetary year, including a breakdown of the annual contracts by reference to contracting party, project under consideration and value of the project, be provided.
(5) What percentage of projected overall development cooperation funds has been committed already for each of the budgetary years from the 1996-97 financial year until the 2000-2001 financial year.

(6) What percentage of projected overall expenditure on the Development Import Finance Facility has already been committed by contractual agreements for each of the budgetary years from the 1996-97 financial year through to the 2000-2001 financial year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

PARA.TAB: (1) The aggregated total forward development cooperation commitments, determined as at 30 September 1995, for each of the financial years 1996/97 to 2000/01 are listed in Attachment I. These are recorded against AusAID's appropriation structure; country programs, global programs and corporate services.

It is important to note that Australia's commitment to food aid is a special case. A liability has been incurred through our commitment to the Food Aid Convention of 300,000 tonnes of wheat or wheat equivalent per annum for the period 1995/96 to 1997/98. There is no specific allocation for food aid as such. Rather, our Food Aid Commitment is met through country appropriations, emergency and refugee appropriations, as well as the World Food Program.

The commitments have been recorded in accordance with the accounting definitions specified by the Department of Finance in its guidelines to Commonwealth agencies for the preparation of annual Financial Statements tabled in Parliament. Obligations are recorded as liabilities, commitments and agreements equally proportionately unperformed (AEPUs). These definitions are explained at Attachment II.

Using these definitions, the levels of forward commitment as at 30 September 1995 are as follows: 1996/97—$1,055 million; 1997/98—$908 million; 1998/99—$678 million; 1999/2000—$595 million; 2000/01—$481 million.

There are other programs/activities that are not covered by these definitions and therefore not recorded for the purpose of the Financial Statements, but which also place a high degree of obligation on Australia for moral or other reasons. While there are strong expectations that such funding will continue, these activities have not been included as development cooperation commitments for these Questions on Notice.

These other obligations include core contributions to United Nations development organisations (eg. UNICEF, United Nations Development Program, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees). The contributions are voluntary and not covered by legislation as in the case of multilateral development banks, nor are they covered by the `assessed' formulae used for other UN bodies. There is, however, a strong expectation internationally and domestically that Australia's contributions to these organisations will continue, reflecting Australia's role as a good international citizen and the principle of burden-sharing with other donors.

The category also covers: allocations to meet commitments where the Government has pledged support for specific programs (eg. Prime Ministerial multiyear pledges for development cooperation programs in Vietnam and Cambodia); provision for refugee and emergency relief; funding for Development Import Finance Facility projects where activities have been agreed between Australia and recipient governments; funding for the AusAID/Non-government Organisations Cooperation Program; funding for volunteer programs; and support for regional organisations such as the South Pacific Forum Secretariat. There is also an expectation of maintenance of support for bilateral country programs in key regions such as the South Pacific.
For 1996/97, the total value of these `strong expectations' is estimated to be $363 million.

(2) A detailed supplementary paper of some 127 pages, which outlines all forward commitments, disaggregated by country program, global program and corporate services; and further, by activity, value and nature of commitment has been provided to the honourable senator. Each commitment type is reported on separate schedules.

(3) Under the Development Import Finance Facility a contractual commitment occurs when the implementing contractor receives a formal offer to undertake the project. At 30 September 1995 no contractual arrangements were in place under the Development Import Finance Facility for project funding in 1996/97 and beyond.

There is, however, a high degree of obligation on the Australian Government because (i) a pipeline of projects has been agreed bilaterally at officials level with China, Indonesia, Nepal, India, the Philippines and Vietnam; and (ii) on this basis commercial contract negotiations between contractors and recipient governments are under way. Details of individual contractors, prior to the award of contracts, are commercial-in-confidence.
(4) There were no contractual arrangements in place under the Development Import Finance

ANSWER.PARA: Facility for the period 1996/97 to 2000/01 as at 30 September 1995.

PARA.TAB: There are, however, expectations based on requests on hand to a total value of $267.9 million, of which it is anticipated that some $60 million will be funded during the remainder of the 1995/96 financial year and the balance funded in out years. Funding is provided as contracts are signed in any year up to the total annual allocation for the Development Import Finance Facility program. There are expectations of funding from the countries concerned and Australian contractors for these projects and, on that basis, contract negotiations have commenced. It should be noted that not all the identified projects will necessarily proceed to formal offer by AusAID. The latter is contingent upon satisfactory appraisal by AusAID on developmental grounds, including an assessment against OECD criteria for mixed credits and the satisfactory conclusion to negotiations between the Australian supplier and the buyer in the recipient country. Attachment III provides the list of Development Import Finance Facility projects agreed with recipient governments.

(5) The percentage of projected overall development cooperation funds that are committed, in accordance with categories defined for the financial statements, during financial years 1996/97 to 2000/01 are listed against the overall program totals in Attachment I. The total commitment as at 30 September 1995, in percentage terms, assuming 1995/96 aid levels are maintained in real terms, are: 1996/97—65 per cent; 1997/98—54 per cent; 1998/99—39 per cent; 1999/2000—33 per cent; 2000/01—26 per cent.

PARA.TAB: (1) Introduction

The definitions covering financial commitments are those applicable to reporting requirements for the annual Financial Statements to Parliament. The listed categories; Commitments, Agreements Equally Proportionately Unperformed (AEPUs) and liabilities are mutually exclusive and are recorded separately.

These categories of commitments are reported separately in a Supplementary Paper, of 127 pages in length, which has been provided to the Office of the Honourable Senator. These provide a detailed outline of all forward commitments, disaggregated by country programs, global programs and corporate services as per AusAID's program structure; and further, by activity, value and nature of commitment.
(2) Commitments
There are two types of commitment recorded.
In Schedule A of the Supplementary Paper commitments are recorded where:

there is a firm intention to incur a future liability for goods or services which are yet to be provided. The commitment actually arises when a definite decision is made to incur the liability (eg. when FR 44A approval is given to a spending proposal); or

action has been taken to determine the actual amount of the commitment or a reliable estimate, and where the conditions to be satisfied under the obligation are clearly defined in a written agreement (eg written record of a High Level Consultation that specifies agreed individual activities including a firm estimate of cost). If the above requirements are not satisfied, then the intention to incur a future liability is considered too vague for there to be a commitment.
Schedule B records commitments covered by Memorandum of Understanding (MOU), which are firm agreements evidenced by a signed document that commits a firm dollar amount.
Where there are contracts arising from an MOU, these are recorded as an AEPU in Schedule C (see Section 3 below).
(3) Agreements Equally Proportionately Unperformed (AEPUs)

Once a signed contract exists, and before any work has been performed or payments have been made, a commitment becomes contracted expenditure unperformed. In accounting terms, contracted expenditure unperformed is known as an "agreement equally proportionately unperformed" or an "AEPU".

An AEPU arises at any point in an agreement and applies where contracted work remains to be performed and no payments have been made for the work yet to be done. (For example, where 60 per cent of a contracted activity has been completed and paid for, the remaining 40 per cent of work still constitutes an AEPU.) The same applies where goods are involved rather than services.

These agreements usually involve a legal commitment by AusAID. For example, where AusAID has legally committed the Commonwealth to provide from future budgets from an existing contract. (Note: AEPUs are not restricted to contracted expenditure/receipts. However, most amounts included here are those that form part of an existing contract.)
AEPUs are recorded in Schedule C and show amounts which will be payable in each financial year until 2000/01.
(4) Liabilities
A liability arises where an intention to incur a future obligation becomes a present obligation.

There are few items that are reported as liabilities. These are the non-reciprocal treaty for budget support to Papua New Guinea, Nauru Settlement, payments under the Food Aid Convention, payments made to multilateral development banks from Special Appropriations and a range of AusAID employee entitlement provisions.
Liabilities are recorded on Page 1 of the Supplementary Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, upon notice, on 25 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Australian Urban and Regional Development Review Workplan for 1994-95, `Land Use and Urban Design' objective:

(1) What progress has been made in discussions between the department, the Department of Administrative Services and other institutions on the development of Commonwealth land in a joint venture arrangement with the private sector.
(2) What areas of surplus Commonwealth land pertinent to the current negotiations for the joint venture have been identified.
(3) Were tenders called for a joint partner in the venture.
(4) Who is the successful tenderer.
(5) When is the joint venture due to commence.
(6) Does the joint venture provide for large-scale land development and housing projects; if so, can details be provided.
(7) Is it proposed the joint venture will receive funding under the Better Cities Mark II Program; if so, what is the amount of funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Departmental officials have held preliminary discussions with officials from the Department of Administrative Services, Australian Estate Management, Department of Defence and the Department of Veterans' Affairs about options for development of surplus Commonwealth sites.
No joint venture arrangements have yet been entered into with the private sector as a consequence of these discussions.
The department is a member of the Coordinating Council for the Release of Commonwealth Land which is developing a database of all Commonwealth properties planning for sale during the next five years.
(2) There are no current negotiations for joint ventures.
(3) to (7) Not applicable.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 18 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the amount currently charged by the Australian Commerce and Industry Office (ACIO) in local currency for the processing of a short term visitor visa for a Taiwanese citizen planning to visit Australia.
(2) When was the visa fee last reviewed.
(3) Was the Department consulted in the review process.
(4) Does the Department exercise any control over the level of the fee.
(5) Is the fee designed to cover the direct costs incurred by ACIO in issuing the visa.
(6) What proportion of the fee represents those direct costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Commerce and Industry Office (ACIO) imposes a fee of $NT1,000 (approx $A50) to facilitate an application by an individual Taiwanese citizen for a short term visitor visa.
For group tours of 15 persons the facilitation fee is $NT900 (approx $A45) per person.
For group tours of 16 or more persons the facilitation fee is $NT850 (approx $A42.50) per person.
(2) August 1992.
(3) Yes.
(4) Yes.
(5) The fee was set at a level sufficient to meet direct and indirect costs, and to repay set up costs for the visa facilitation service.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: State Ward of New South Wales: Pension Eligibility

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 30 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to House of Representatives question on notice number 2533 (House of Representatives Hansard, 21 September 1995, page 1540) relating to a certain former State ward in New South Wales who in 1973 was classified inappropriately as mentally retarded for the purposes of eligibility for the then invalid pension:
(1) Did a medically or psychologically qualified officer of the Department of Health certify that the individual was mentally retarded for the purposes of pension eligibility.
(2) Was a medical history taken of that individual, indicating any drugs which may previously have been prescribed for the individual prior to the examination.

(3) Given that a recommendation was made that the individual was in fact mentally retarded, are there any written reports of the psychological examination or other records which indicated that a full examination did in fact take place.
(4) In October 1995, did an officer of the department admit to a legal representative of the individual that no such examination did take place.

(5) Given the official apology recently given to the individual because it was admitted that the individual was incorrectly assessed as mentally retarded, will the Minister: (a) instigate a full internal inquiry into the facts of this case; and (b) present the report of such an inquiry to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) A medically qualified general practitioner acting as an agent of the (then) Department of Health examined the individual for medical eligibility for an Invalid Pension in 1973. "Mental retardation" is recorded under the diagnosis section of the Medical Report form.
(2) The form includes a medical history section, and some limited details were recorded. There is no reference to the use of any prescription drugs by the individual.
(4) I am advised that the answer is no.

(5) A full review has been conducted in relation to this case, and my Department has written three times to the individual concerned. The 1973 examination, a 1981 review, and a 1995 examination have all recommended that, on medical grounds, the person was eligible for pension benefits. Given the obvious difficulty in assessing events that occurred over twenty years ago, and the fact that at no point has this person been denied pension benefits, I can see no gain to be made in further reviewing this case.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 9 November 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to press reports that the families of children who visited Norfolk Island as part of a choir were required to repay a fortnight's family payments to the Department of Social Security.

(2) Is the report correct and, if so: (a) did the repayments refer to family payments or additional family payments or both; (b) what are the relevant sections of the Social Security Act which prevented the payment of family payments or additional family payments for the time the children were on Norfolk Island; and (c) will the provisions of the Social Security Act be amended to prevent such penny-pinching from occurring in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am aware of the press reports regarding the Rosny Children's Choir visit to Norfolk Island and the effect on a fortnight's payment of Family Payment for some families.

(2) In October 1995, a number of families in Tasmania were informed they had lost their entitlement to Additional Family Payment (AFP) for the family payday when their children were visiting Norfolk Island as part of a tour by the Rosny Children's Choir. Of the families affected, 18 potential overpayment cases were discovered through data matching with immigration records. All the overpayments raised have been waived.
(a) The overpayments referred to AFP and not the Basic Family Payment. AFP is not paid for children who are outside Australia. Norfolk Island

ANSWER.PARA: is not treated as part of Australia for the purposes of the Social Security Act (and many other pieces of Commonwealth legislation) and has its own social security arrangements.

PARA.TAB: (b) The relevant sections of the Social Security Act which prevent the payment of AFP while the children were on Norfolk Island are:

ANSWER.PARA: Section 23 which excludes Norfolk Island from the definition of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Section 1069-D2, which requires the child to be present in Australia for AFP to be paid:
1069-D2. Subject to points 1069-D2A,1069-D2B, 1069-D5, 1069-D7, 1069-D9 and 1069-D11, a person is qualified for additional family payment for a dependent child of the person (an "AFP child") if:
(a) the person is present in Australia or point 1069-D5 applies to the person; and
(b) the person is receiving family payment in respect of the child; and
(ba) the child is present in Australia; and
(c) the value of the person's assets does not exceed $376,750
(c) The Government is considering options for changes to the legislative provisions that affect payment of Family Payment when children are overseas.
